The direct sequel to 2009’s Final Fantasy XIII, Final Fantasy XIII-2 brings a slate of improvements to the flawed formula of its predecessor, from improved exploration to the non existence of a 20 hour tutorial, to the way you encounter enemies, while perhaps taking a hit in other aspects but overall it should be said that XIII-2 does surpass XIII and it also unveils the actual mythos behind the Fabula Nova Crystallis.While very similar to XIII it does bring some quality of life improvements, finally being able to change party leaders during enemy encounters which leads to not losing battles when your party leader is downed despite the two other members being alive, which was in my opinion a flaw of XIII and a departure from classic Final Fantasy. The level design, while still somewhat linear, does lead to more exploration and choices while walking around, it clearly is a step up from XIII, but it continues the linearity the franchise has had since Final Fantasy X. In a myriad of ways XIII-2 does mirror X-2, it has a similar level “selector”, the Historia Crux mirrors the Celsius, such as being able to visit every biome that existed in the previous games in a non linear form, while both predecessors you walked the world in a linear progression following the party’s journey to their destiny.Speaking more in depth about the changes to combat, the paradigm pack is a nice addiction with a somewhat Pokemon style system, that is to say, during the game you may catch crystals that contain the monsters that you defeated and they may help you in battle, and each monster has a given role attributed to them that is immutable, you level their crystarium with components that you either randomly gain during battles or chests during the game or buy them through the shop system in XIII-2, there are various tiers of components for each type of beast, be they robot or l’cie or biological and as Pokemon have EV’s (read: Effort Value) which are mutable characteristics. There’s also an infusion system in the game, that I did not delve much into, but to summarise it, you infuse a given beast with the crystal of another’s so that they may gain said beast’s passive ability.The last thing about gameplay should be the Crystarium, while in this game we still use a Crystarium it has changed to be less linear, you do not have 6 paths for each character, you only follow 1 path that has 22 stages, and that are not gate kept by your progress in the main journey unlike XIII’s, in this iteration of the Crystarium each role is attributed a level that goes up to level 99, each role favours a stat, be it strength, magic or HP, and when you level a role you get a bonus for the stat that said role favours, usually Serah is the Magic User while Noel is the Attack User, you may only focus on Commando for example and leave every role at level 1, there is absolutely no restrictions, and if you do end up levelling a role to 99 in early Crystarium Stages, it costs little, because the CP costs are tied to the Crystarium’s stages not the the level of the role you are levelling.Final Fantasy XIII was the first one to be released under the umbrella of the Fabula Nova Crystallis, but while XIII deals with theme of defying destiny and focuses on Crystals such as early entries in the franchise, it doesn’t delve much into the mythos of the Goddess Etro that the cancelled Versus XIII was supposed to deal with right from the get go.As with the gameplay the initial setup for this game also mirrors X-2’s setup, in the fact that each of their predecessors doesn’t foreshadow a sequel or has an emerging intrigue starting in their ending, neither does either one need a sequel, both games reach conclusive endings on their own without the need for a follow up, which leaves the setup for both feeling maybe forced and unnecessary, nonetheless both games bring interesting gameplay and are worth the play.The game starts 3 year after XIII’s events, which is dubbed 003 AF (After the Fall [of Cocoon]), Serah is living in what is called New Bodhum in Gran Pulse which is populated by the familiar faces that lived in the original one, but we soon learn that shortly after XIII’s ending, Lightning disappears mysteriously, and suddenly monsters appear in the town and with them comes a strange fellow called Noel that says he arrived there from Valhalla where he found Lightning protecting the Goddess Etro’s throne, and he informs Serah that to reach Valhalla and save her sister they must journey through time fixing paradoxes.The game introduces us to Valhalla to the Goddess Etro and to broader themes of the Fabula, but does it so in a way that sometimes can feel disconnected from the original game, the characters may suffer less characterization given the more non linear progression of the story, that was one of the upsides to XIII’s linearity and some of the supposed emotional scenes may come out as cheap same with some of the plot twists but overall XIII-2 tells a decent enough humanist story with the overall theme of the Fabula, that is defying destiny or dying trying.Similarly to its predecessor the OST of this game is decent enough, there are some songs that are quite well, one that strikes me the first time that I heard it was the one in the seaside in one of the more advance levels, but for the seasoned Final Fantasy fan it doesn’t come close to the legendary OST of past entries made by the legendary Nobuo Uematsu.The original endgame of this game rubbed me in a way more positive light versus the endgame of XIII, it was way less grindy and the fragment list was actually fulfilling to complete unlike the trapezohedron grind of the previous game, although the hardest bosses either played exactly like the previous one or very similarly, but that point ends up being fixed with one of the DLCs.There are a few DLCs, I’ve read that Square Enix’s DLC practice for this game (and others for that matter) was quite consumer unfriendly but for the Steam version everything comes with this purchase.Some of these DLCs are spoiler heavy and so will be my review about them.Sazh’s Story: Heads or Tails? The objective and gameplay is quite dull, the synopsis for this story is that Sazh’s son has disappeared and for him to recover his son he must play poker at the universal casino, when translating this concept to execution it really ends up being a really boring DLC, and its plot implications are simply to explain how Sazh appears at the end of the game to help out Serah and the crew.Snow’s Story: Perpetual Battlefield This DLC is the one that can really satiate the more hardcore players with it’s fights, you find yourself in an universal omnitemporal colosseum where you fight various enemies from XIII’s universe or related to common Final Fantasy mythos, and a SPECIAL appearance from Ultros ( a Final Fantasy VI classic).Lightning’s Story: Requiem of the GoddessThis DLC and the secret ending that you acquire after getting 160/160 fragments is the one that connects XIII-2 to Lightning Returns, something that should have been done to connect XIII to XIII-2. The gameplay for this is somewhat fun, it requires you to fight Caius and lose enough times until you become strong enough to beat him and witness the ending of the DLC.Overall this game is a step up from its prequel, and while XIII is overly criticised in Final Fantasy circles this game helps clear this trilogy’s reputation for those that dare to play it.Also this port requires you to fix it cause Square Enix, for that follow this useful guide:

New characters, a cool story, and a heartbreaking ending. You play from a different point of view in this game as well, which makes it even better. 8/10 would recommend.

So playing this game right after Final Fantasy XIII, gives a quite clear idea what Square Enix wanted from this game. They initially tried something new in Final Fantasy XIII, in which some things were appreciated but some were heavily criticised. They took all those good things of initial game and evolved it and tried to address the issues gameplay design wise in this sequel.First I'm going to talk about the port itself. Overall pc port is mediocre at its best in vanilla form. A lot of people in past have complained about crashes and FPS drops. To resolve or at least to minimise those issue I would suggest going to , this has safe links to fan made patches and mods that tries to restore the game. For me after these patches, my gameplay experience was quite enjoyable with only one crash in whole run. Overall FPS was good as well.Instead of being linear like previous instalment, the sequel gives you multiple areas to explore and travel back and forth as much as you like. This game introduces random encounters again with a slight modified form which I personally liked a lot. Battle system is more responsive and with paradigm shifts animations taking a lot less time to change now. One party leader dying the game does not over but instead the control of the game shifts to the other surviving character. This game only has two playable characters. We can also add third party member as well but that will one of the monsters which we catch while during random encounters. Yes, it also has monster capture elements. The crystarium has also been upgraded. Instead of predefined upgrade nodes we can select the type of stat upgrade we want on the node. To sum up, the gameplay experience has definitely been refined in this game.Story of this game is about time travel and it can get a little confusing. The story overall takes places in multiple areas in multiple time eras, with time era having its own minor lore. I found protagonist Serah exactly opposite of Lightning, where Lightning was brooding with emotional layer hidden deep within, Sarah is a little bubbly and polite with slight emotional layer on the top. The villain in this game actually feels like a powerful and destructive being which I liked a lot. Overall characters are well defined in this game.The soundtrack is awesome. Simple enough.This is a good sequel and I would recommend to play this if you finished and liked Final Fantasy XIII. Even if you didn't liked part 1 enough still give this game a try. It may surprise you.

The good:A great JRPG. It's much better than XIII and has much more -gameplay- elements than it did. It's non linear, has puzzles, lots of minigames, and tons of side quests. There are tons of monsters to recruit into your party, and it can get a bit addictive. Some are infusion fodder, and some are great on their own. The trick is knowing which is which.The story is much more interesting than XIII as well. The main characters have much more depth and I find myself caring way more about Caius and Noel's stories than anything that was in XIII. Caius is the best kind of villain - one who thinks what he's doing is right.Now for the bad:The only problem I had with the game is that it's too easy to gimp your characters if you don't know what you're doing. The game doesn't tell you anything about the leveling mechanic. Doing it right makes a huge difference, but basically you want Noel to have all of his strength bonuses on the big nodes and all of Serah's magic bonuses on her big nodes.The port is decent. The only real problem I had was framerate dips, which can be annoying but isn't really a big deal.

This is a review for those who are interested in the Final Fantasy XIII series (ON PC) :Final Fantasy XIII-2 is considered one of my favorite games of all-time (ON PS3), and it still reminds me even after finishing the series as a whole. From the music, to the characters, to the progression as a whole, to the semi-linear structure of the whole event, this experience has stuck with me for maybe years (ON PS3). To explain, I played FF XIII-2 FIRST without even knowing it's name due to how young I was stupidly enough. I ALMOST beat the game before my PS3 was stolen and sold for a addiction a family member had, and I never managed to beat it till I became a young adult. After putting the time and money together, I bought the entire series of FF XIII to play (ON PS3). And traveled through it's world. FF XIII was a beautiful and musical masterpiece <AS A MOVIE> but as a game, it is super slow and tiring. Plus due to my experience of playing the second game first, a lot of events that happen just got me angry or confused (Example with Lighting Punching a specific character and just thinking Lighting was just a bad character from XIII due to my thoughts from XIII-2, which is shocking to see what she is later.) (P.S. I HATE FANG PERIOD but Vanille gets a pass due to who is overall is despite common thoughts. ) Overall, XIII was a great movie to watch but a terrible game to play. FF XIII-2 doesn't need much explaining of my opinions and with the context of the first game even having a shorten verison in the game really shows what is in store for you. However, with the addition of FF XIII-3, the ending kinda causes a weird "Paradox" to happen due to future events.FF XIII-3 was... INTERESTING. From a story standpoint, it wraps this up and entire pulls the sheet off the table and causes everything on it to fall and break. The game even pulls the "And the world was turned into Earth and maybe the friends along the way may still be alive" bullcrap the game says. I did enjoy the story bits that expanded what left. The Gameplay however is so different and strange that it was slapping someone in the face. And the system would evolve to help develop future games down the line, but here it just feels werid. Plus the game is also built around an always online system with a lot of mechanics surrounding it and made my experience feel off (ON PS3). Overall, it is interesting to say the least.Overall, the FF XIII series was amazing for what it brought and what it gave (ON PS3). However, the PC ports of the three games seem to be REALLY BAD. While it seems FF XIII works fine, FF XIII-2 REQUIRES Heavy outside support to even RUN. Plus even with the use of the Patches, it could even not run at all. However, if you can experience this series first-hand and for the first time, I HIGHLY RECOMMEND watching a Movie-based gameplay video on youtube of FF XIII due to it's problems but then playing XIII-2 & 3 to experience the wonder of this game.FF XIII-2 will forever remain in my heart as one of the most important games in my life and my most favorite game of all time.

=Story 7.5/10=One of the weaker points of the game was the story. Everyone can agree on this and I'm no exception to that. The whole “let's save Lightning” angle felt forced from the start. I would have taken a game where we play as Lightning the whole way thr- Oh, right, that's what Lightning Returns is about. Anyway, a lot of plot points and major story elements felt forced or like they didn't belong. This didn't hold it back all the time, but it could have done far better.=Art 9/10=On the PC, this game is absolutely stunning. When you throw all the settings up to max and optimise your graphics settings, you end up with a game that is so beautiful you sometimes forget you're playing a game. Admittedly a lot of people have complained about FPS issues, but I felt that the way it was solved in FFXIII (Editing general graphics settings through my Nvidia Control Panel) solved the issue for me before it even became one. The game played in 60 fps steadily throughout the entire playthrough. If you're having problems, Google around and try to fix it before complaining. It's worth it.=Sound 10/10=Music and Final Fantasy are synonymous terms for me. Whenever I play any of the FF games, the soundtrack is the first thing I listen out for. What sort of instruments are we leaning towards? What sort of feel does this game want to give me? Every boss fight is unique, every average fight is energetic and every area has a theme that suits it perfectly. I've listened to the FFXIII-2 soundtrack more than enough times as I do other things to know how much I love it.=Characters 7/10=Admittedly the weakest point of this entire game is its character lineup. Why Serah? Why Noel? Why do I care about them? A lot of the twists towards the end felt both forced and pointless. The Goddess Etro wasn't even introduced in FFXIII and now I'm supposed to believe she's a big thing that's a big part of everyone's lives? No one else seems to know who she is, so it feels a little stupid. Whatever, it's no big deal. I would have rather focused on Hope and thrown a boomerang around, to be completely honest.=Gameplay 9/10=I don't like the way prior FF games handled combat. Sue me. FFVII was absolutely trash with the Materia system. FFVIII's Draw system was only marginally better. FFXIII's system made it so that some characters were only viable because they had skills others didn't. FFXIII-2's Crystarium does the same thing as FFXIII, but makes good on a few faults from its predecessor. Haste and Slow aren't casual abilities to throw around now, which were absolutely broken prior. Your bonuses from stacking multiple Roles into a Paradigm is better, meaning that swapping to 3 SEN's is now a really smart move whenever you see a charge up attack. This game involves more thinking than most people care to admit. For that, I salute you, FFXIII-2. For the record, playing with Keyboard and Mouse is so easy that it's criminal.=Overall 8.5/10=FFXIII-2 is worth the $20. By far. I got 50 hours out of this and I played the hell out of it originally, so I was already on top of where everything was and what I needed to do. A newcomer could easily spend an extra 30 hours and not feel like it's forcing you to grind or do anything you don't really want to. Even if you played the game prior, it offers a new experience to what you might be used to. Definite recommendation from me.

Square released a patch today which actually  some DLC from the game. The performance remains unchanged.Buyer beware.The resolution selection does nothing but change the window size while the game is still rendered in 1280x720, making everything blurry unless you have a monitor running natively at 720p (which few modern computer users do). The framerate jumps wildly from 60 to well under 15 almost arbitrarily.The problem lies in the fact that both FFXIII and FFXIII-2 for PC are  multi-threaded applications when virtually 99% of software written today is. This is an artifact from when Square ported these two games over from the Playstation 3, which had an extremely complicated and poorly designed CPU architecture. To minimize writing code (perhaps due to time constraints or inexperience, or both), Square decided to throw the entire game on a single thread.Regardless,  in this case. You could try running this game on a 486 or Cray Supercomputer and you would probably achieve the same results. Kidding aside, this port is  poorly optimized.

Still one of my favourite Final Fantasies ever, top 5 for me for sure.It's got some of my most beloved characters, one of the best villains, an absolutely phenomenal OST, a REALLY good story (if you're into one filled with Time Travel, Paradoxes etc, lots of stuff like that), tons of open zone areas to explore that are surprisingly pretty big considering the platforms this originally released on and to top it off one of the best combat systems in FF history, the combat is a wildly improved version of the Paradigm system from FF13 that just feels super satisfying to play with in all aspects.Then throwing in the 150+ monsters you can get to add to your party definitely makes the updated combat feel even greater too. You can mix and match any 3 Monsters at once with the same or different roles/jobs to spice up your builds, but that isn't the best part... the best thing about the Monsters in this game is the borderline infinite customisation they provide, you can upgrade Monsters basically any way you want with a wide range of materials and as they level they'll unlock specific skills and abilities which you can infuse into any other Monster to create the perfect being.Now unfortunately by default the PC port for this game like FF13 is not great at all, without the correct fixes you'll be stuck ranging from 30-45FPS and that for most people won't feel good to play. However there are a mountain of guides that fix this (I've been running the game at a perfect 60FPS no problem even in the more graphically intense areas of the game) so if you're on edge about buying it because of all the tech issues don't worry, they ALL can be fixed and extremely easily. That of course doesn't take away from the fact that normally it is a bad port though, I don't know why Square keeps doing this but hey at least it's fixable and not just DOA.I'd also recommend going for all the mods and enhancements you find in the guide presented below, like the HD mod, button prompt fix, 4gb Patch and so on, they will definitely be worth your time.Link to the guide I used that fixed my game - As a final thought I hope more people decide to give this and the rest of the games in the FF13 trilogy a try despite the bad rep they got on release, they're all so good and get so much blind hate now that it's sad. Plus of course this is a sequel to 13 anyway so playing this one before that doesn't really make too much sense and jumping in without any knowledge of the first game will leave you confused for most of the playthrough, lot's of context to specific things comes from playing the first game. BUT there is neat feature on the main menu that explains parts of each of FF13's chapters to fill you in, it's not as good as actually playing through the game but having a lore tab for the first game in case you're new to the series is really nice.So yeah there's so much more about the game that I love that I didn't mention above mainly because spoilers (if people even care about that now) and also because it would take WAY too long to share my love for this game haha. With everything considered though this game is a solid 9/10 for me, not many Final Fantasy's make me feel the way this game does... it's just so perfect and packed full of content.

I played most of the final fantasy games since when I was young, before FFX10 and FFVIII came to steam. I used to play them in a very old Windows XP and a Windows 7 computer. Back then those games was always refreshing and broke the usual norms held by video games. I always wanted to play FFXIII series- it was a dream to me. Regardless of course I jumped to FFXIII-2 without playing the prequel for various reasons. I did saw a lot of videos related to FFXIII and I could say it’s more epic than this. But, I think it was a bit too much when people say that FFXIII-2 is bad compared to most Final Fantasy games. In terms of bugs, FFXIII-2 is indeed bad and frustrating. But you have to understand this is a badly ported game and I never let that bothered me really. There are many workarounds for the bugs and some worked for me. With that said, I managed to get all of the achievements (most were ridiculous), completed the DLC and the main story and my judgment is the story is epic. Since the bugs were bad I’d first start the review with that.The bugs for me did not happen overnight, it happened when I was a little bit into the game (up to Bresha ruins for the first time) and crashed when I was riding the chocobo. There were glitches in saving sometimes and that sucked. When taking screenshots the game would crash a lot. I felt like the steam overlay is insanely slow when I was in the game too. The fix what worked for me is mostly running the game using the Nvidia processor (rather than the onboard which is since it’s a laptop pc users won’t have probs) and making the game play in the windowed mode. Also taking breaks from time to time helped too- memory tweaking such as increasing the UserVA could be done to allocate more memory to the game if you want (this was the fix that works 200% of the time). But no matter what- it was really hard to enjoy the game when there is an immense FPS drop. There were many ways to tweak this in the forums but ofc I did not follow the methods because of the fear that the game would break… more.. The story is totally related to the first final fantasy game, and it continues from there. Lighting is fighting in a place called Valhalla, Noel comes from the future, and Lighting asks him to get help from her Sister. And Serah takes the job. However, you are supposed to travel timelines to different periods and eras to go through the full story. The story also involves the farseers of padra, who are like the messengers of goddess Etro and the guardians who protect them. The game is a mental relief for people who were obsessed with FFXIII since the characters from that version appears here. This story has several endings depending on the fragments you collect. Collect all 160 fragments and you can get a secret ending, the version I bought had the DLC also and that includes the real ending in a side story after the main final battle is done. I never really liked Serah’s character much, but you have to admit that she has a noble personality Lightning was fascinating putting a strong upfront always. This is Noel’s game for me since he seems more powerful, more headfast, straightforward and strong. Most of my friends know that I was literally obsessed with Noel and it was not strange because it was his personality that helped me through the dark times. The villain himself could not be characterized as a villain since if you take his point of view you can justify him. The most loved characters for some players, such as Hope Esthiem seems really cool and interesting. The chemistry between the characters are great, especially Noel and Serah. I don’t care what anyone says, but Serah is more fitting for Noel than anyone else. Snow seems too uh big for Serah idk. Compared to the old FF games the battle actions have initially changed a lot I noticed. But I found that more realistic and challenging so it was great. I missed using the guardian forces though- but taming monsters and fusing them seems so creative. Battle paradigms were a total new thing to me, but I really liked it! There were some unfair battles here and there but the usage of the fragment skills made everything easier. To keep it short and sweet I will name some of the unique features*You can play casino and get nice prizes*Chocobo races in casino requires you to have a high level chocobo to win*Fragment skills get unlocked when you collect fragments of each time portal and it has stuff like earning more CP, monster crystals*Choices are important in the game dialogues. Replaying each level with a specific fragment skill would trigger hard boss fights and may unlock a different ending (paradox endings)*Hard monsters which have very rare dropout rates for precious items- getting the ultima weapon is quite hard. *Very nice side quests that requires some work. *Time travelling- each location might have multiple time portals so finding fragments for one location can depend on another.*Closing time portals and replaying levels to get different endings*When the commando and ravager roles are maxed you get two powers each for Noel and Serah (they are cool)*Staggering and chain making seems interesting and creative.*The dialogues the bystanders say are so funny LOL*Chocobocolina is here to sell you some awesome goods. Also I’m not sure if it was the part of DLC but Sazh’s side story is pursued later in the game in the casino place.Technically, I also loved the battle moves and I never depend much on items except wound potions. But I really missed skills such as casting Aura by myself because such features are attributed to the monsters in this game. Leveling up seems kind of nice since it’s separated for each role. Also just because you have leveled up doesn’t mean that you get the max strength you need good weapons and accessories. I didn’t like the limited capacity for the accessories but oh well. I like changing the outfits but I hoped there were more outfits for both Serah and Noel, Mog of course had many. The DLC content have a side story for Lightning which includes the real secret ending- the battle itself is very hard unless you max out lightning. You should get a five star rating battle result to get into the second half of the fight which is harder and slower than the first one. The fights in the colossiuem could be unlocked if you have the DLC which is kinda interesting. You can unlock the opponents you fight and level them up in the crystarium. It was pleasures to beat Omega and Lightning in the colossieum.I expect the weapons available in the shops higher than the ultima weapons are from the DLC as well. As usual FF games never fail to disappoint me in creating stunning visuals which are breathtaking. Every battle I fight is so satisfying just because of that. Every main character looks like some kind of a god like deity lol. The landscapes are stunning especially academia. The music is good but I prefer the music in FFXIII better. Also the designing of clothes and weapons seems so fascinating and intricate. The names of the weapons are also very unique- it’s close to my culture and I can understand the meaning of the names. Some achievements here seem a lot tougher to get and frustrating. Clockstopper requires you to get 100 preemptive strikes without break. The lucky coin fragment which you can get from the casino by playing slots is also mighty hard to take. Players have to tape the *tab* button on the keyboard and wait for hours to get it- but I don’t think that works. I had to go into super victory mode and then take the game by myself and I randomly got it- it actually requires luck that gameplay. Saddlesore and getting all the monsters for the fragments is time consuming.It's a nice RPG overall, but the bugs can kill you so be aware of it. Epic story and gameplay though.

PLAYED ON STEAM DECK13-2 is a better "game" than its predecessor. All the gameplay related qualms one might have with the first game are sufficiently squashed in this game. Party leader can faint, combat opens up earlier, there are more places to explore, there's some nice post-game stuffs, etc... The paradigm/stagger system is still the most underrated combat system in the series that's infinitely hindered by the words "auto-battle." It's the most kinetic and engaging version of rock paper scissors in gaming, and that can be fun too. The story doesn't really pick up so naturally from the last game, nor does it follow its own rules of time travel. But I'd be hard pressed to say that the story is a mess or hard to follow (common critiques). It's actually very easy to follow and contains a pretty good cast of characters. Whether the original 13 party should have been shafted in favor of the new characters we focus on is a discussion unrelated to the quality of the game itself. The music? Outstanding... except for that one rap song wtf was that.It's a hard recommend but an overall thumbs up because an the greatest hurdle into this game is finishing 13 itself. But, if you liked 13 (as I did) then you'll feel pretty alright getting to paradigm shift on some fools for a few more hours.7.3/10 Snow still sucks.

Updated review for 2021.From a story and gameplay perspective, this is one of my favorite Final Fantasy games, and my top pick in the FFXIII trilogy.  You can re-explore various areas at different points of time, recruit monsters as allies, and there's a ton of DLC and side-story content to explore outside the main game.  On the subject of allies, the system gets really complex, allowing you to not only level up monsters, but also combine them to absorb certain abilities into certain other monsters.  It's surprisingly complex and something I really like about this game.There are two key negatives that led to a negative overall review: DLC and technical.On the DLC side, some of the original DLC is completely absent, notably a few costumes and most of the weapons.  Additionally, the story DLC has been moved from Chapter 2 to Post-game.  I don't necessarilly dislike this change, but it does take away content that was previously available.From a technical view, the game crashes a lot.  Turns out the game only allocates itself 2GB of RAM, but sometimes needs more.  Whenever this happens, the game crashes.  This can be fixed with community patches, but hasn't received any formal patch to address it.  Similarly, you can’t select your display monitor on a multi-monitor display, and you’re limited to 720p and 1080p (no 1440p or 4k support) when in Windowed mode.Ultimately the console experience for this game is just a better one, and this port fell short.

If you like playing games where you can explore a beautifully crafted world with a proper story behind it, then you will enjoy FF XIII-2. You feel like you are really getting to know Serah and Noel throughout the game's main story. There's plenty of supplementary action, chatacter-building and lore to learn in the side quests as well.Whilst you couldn't really class it as a sandbox environment, there's still a bit of room for exploration and as mentioned, lots to do aside from the main story. While it may be a sequel to FF XIII, it is not necessary to have played that game first as FF XIII-2 stands fine on its own. You are suitably filled in on the events in the previous game.The music is very wide ranging in its style but there are some truly spellbinding moments where you can clearly tell a lot of thought has gone into the creative process and the team behind the game have worked together to create instances where you are seemingly locked into a moment in time; a fitting counterpoint to all the travelling through the Historia Crux that you do during the game.The gameplay itself isn't particularly exciting in my opinion. It can get quite repetitive but there's lots of room for variety in your approach to battles with the various paradigm packs and monsters, but I get the impression that for the creators of FF XIII-2, the gameplay itself is arguably one of the lesser important elements.After spending 50+ hours on the game, I have come to the conclusion that FF XIII-2, at its core, isn't about grinding monsters and attaining level 99 in everything. You can by all means grind away, and many players will end up doing this if they are struggling with a particular boss battle so that they can advance in the game and find out the next chapter of the story and enrich their view of the world(s) that FF XIII-2 takes place in. Because that's what this game is about. Telling a story and building world full of rich detail and history for this story to take place in.Caveat: the port is a bit buggy such that you will almost definitely have to actively take action to change some settings on your PC to ensure you can reliably run the game without any major issues.

Writing this review after 6 hours into re-playing on the PC version.Storyline and gameplay-wise it is a great improvement compared to the first one.They somewhat fixed the "linearity" which was a problem in FFXIII. The game is a bit more open-world but still pretty straight forward in terms of traveling, etc. It is definitely, however, not a straight lined map with no town/NPC interactions. They also did a really good job (in my opinion) with the storyline that is still a bit confusing but not as bad as the first one. Keep in mind that the store page is somewhat misleading as they only show you screenshots of Lightning but the main character in this game is Serah and the new character Noel.Graphics and performance-wise it is a bit disappointing but I don't believe it is detrimental to the gameplay. I have an i7-2600k GTX 770 OC and 8 GB of RAM and I frequently have frame drops to below 30. I believe people with a much higher-end PC experience the same problem if not worse. The game still requires patching and optimization so if you are looking for a drastic change in performance compared to the first one I don't recommend you buy it just yet. They allow you to change the game resolution and shadow resolution. I don't really have much knowledge whether the in-game resolution is set to native 1080p but to me it just looks like a stretched out 720p when I set it to 1080p (I could be wrong). Overall I still think it's a good change compared to the console version but can definitely be improved some more.tl;dr If you don't care too much about performance issue (it's not great but not detrimental to the gameplay) and are looking forward to improved gameplay (open-world, more NPC interactions,etc) and a good storyline I definitely recommend buying it. However if sudden frame drops and stretched out resolution bothers you I recommend you wait for the devs to fix it before buying this game.

In many ways, Final Fantasy XIII-2 is a great sequel. Intending to fix many of the issues that fans had with the original game. Combat is refined, with more reward for experimentation. The non-linear approach also fits the narrative of a time travelling adventure well. Creating a larger sense of player freedom. It isn't as impressive or grandeur as XIII but ends up being a more enjoyable game overall.The art-style still looks beautiful to this day, and the score is utterly magnificent. If there is one thing the XIII series can't be faulted for it's the ability to evoke an emotion or atmosphere so readily with its soundtrack. However, the narrative is told awfully. Almost all the dialogue is expository and honestly, does a bad job at explaining what is happening regardless. While the linear design of the original game allowed for such a rich world to be built, and I'm sure the intermittent nature of this sequel meant story would have less focus. There is no excuse for how blatantly poor the game is at conveying its own plot.If it was left just up to this; Final Fantasy XIII-2 would be an easy recommendation for fans of XIII and the franchise. Unfortunately, this port is awful. While the first game definitely had its issues, they are magnified in this release. Stuttering, freezing, bad optimisation and severe instances of crashing in a game that already had a particularly bad auto-save are frustrations that make this by far the worst platform to play on. Sadly, these issues are quite common in many of Square's releases to PC, and the main reason why review scores of this game on steam are so low. Until such problems are fixed (). I can't recommend this. These issues go far beyond what is acceptable and ruin what is otherwise, a very good RPG.

I will not comment on the port and issues that arise from them, because firstly - you can fix it by applying patches, and secondly - i did not face many problems here besides tiny frame-hangs every once in a while. I'm here to tell you why this game is great enough to not warrant a "mixed" rating.This is, as everyone says, a definite improvement over FFXIII, in every way, except the story. The combat got more strategic, and it does not hold your hand more. It does, however, present you with the opportunity to become overpowered if you choose to put time into it. Opportunity. Something that FFXIII surely missed on, being a linear adventure. FFXIII-2 gives you so much freedom that its' story suffers for it. This game allows you to visit many locations in different time periods, and even to restart them whenever you feel like it. In fact, there is so much freedom that it compelled me to almost 100% it, not counting a few achievements, while I wanted to be done with XIII as soon as possible. There's also a Pokemon-esque/SMT aspect to it, giving you another huge layer of freedom when building up your third member of the party.Story-wise, it's a little disjointed and chaotic. You have to really think about it in order to truly understand the storyline, as you have to jump through time a lot. Due to the time-travelling nature of the game, you WILL understand the main plot, but will probably miss out on a lot of background detail and worldbuilding due to the way it's presented to you.The characters are an improvement over XIII. While I liked XIII's characters, generally there are some issues there with some, especially Vanille and Snow (though, as another side-note, I believe Snow is fine, solely due to the fact that he is a TANK. And a TANK should be crazy, reckless and willing to jump into a pit of demons just to protect his party). Serah is a reserved and logical person, while Noel is the slightly more rash of the two. However, they both make no dumb decisions and are very relatable. Noel in particular is a really likable character. The main villain is a tragic character, if you can look past his over the top design, he has an interesting, unique underlying motivation and his theme is absolutely dope.Speaking of the villain's theme - the music here is amazing. I don't know what type of a earless, billie eilish listening imbecile you have to be to not enjoy the magnificent soundtracks in Final Fantasy games. This one is no exception. It does, along with the rest of the games in the Lightning saga, feature a more electronic take, and FFXIII-2 in particular even uses a lot of vocal tracks, which give it a unique feel and perfectly builds up the apocalyptic/techno-fantasy landscapes. I especially enjoy the Oerba/Dying World themes.I could gush over this thing even more, but I doubt anyone read this far anyway. The point stands - this is an excellent game, and a very wrongfully judged one. It has flaws, rarely anything doesn't, but it manages to take the theme of FFXIII, and rebuild it into a thoroughly open, enjoyable experience with an unforgettable techno-fantasy adventure.TL;DR: open, beautiful, atmospheric and an overall epic adventure full of very interesting takes on time-travel. This is the Terminator 2 to the FFXIII's Terminator.

Game ran fine for me on a i7-6700K and GTX 970. The built-in frame limiter/balancer sucks. But if I have to choose "meh" performance on PC or a previous gen console; I'll choose PC. Because if this thing breaks, I can still play my game.Aside from that performance/system gripe, the game is fine. It drags in spots and the story's speed is a bit of a yo-yo. The biggest issue I've had this time isn't the linearity of the game, but the PC port. I consider my computer as very good, yet I've had few problems. The most annoying one would be the lack of 7.1 surround sound support, and I didn't find a way to at least make it work with my Razer headset. Video stutter in cutscenes is still there and there are few locations where I've had lower FPS than I'm ok with.The story yet again feels as an interactive anime world, truly well written and astoundingly presented. It felt a bit shattered at first, but that's the part of "don't lead the way for the players too much". Plus, if you are fan of time travelling and consequences of changing things in the past/future, you may love this one.Character progress is more "free" aswell. And I don't think you can actually develop your characters so badly you won't be able to finish the game. If you don't grind a lot, it will be hard, though. I've spent a lot of time in final battles that were also close to death, it wasn't just about not enough damage.The battle system was slightly improved. Ok, it's nearly the same, BUT. There is one big BUT for me - the pre-emptive strike finally does not start an hour-long animation of hitting every little enemy, instead, it's like one quick Blitz attack and that's it!I was missing characters, though. From the start to the end, you'll be forced to play with Noel and Serah (yeah, and the Mog) + some monster Serah is able to capture. And also cinematics. There really is only the opening and ending, everything else are just regular cutscenes, I think.But well, I don't think this game was as good as the first one (story-wise), because it didn't have that much touching moments, but it's still Final Fantasy. And a very good game.I definitely recommend this, Kupo!

This game was a perfect sequel to Final Fantasy XIII. It's like Square took notes on everything people didn't like and went "Okay, let's fix this." You want streamlined item-crafting? CheckYou want quick time events in cut-scenes? CheckYou want streamlined Chrystarium and Role Development? CheckIt really feels like they bumped up the drop rates for the "rare" items, and there are lots of accessories that increase your drop rates as well (if you like to farm items).Your third character/party-member is a monster. You can capture monsters as you fight them and add them to your party once captured. It's a really fun mechanic.Despite not having much screen-time, they really played up Lightning as a character, into such a badass that she gets mistaken for the Goddess herself. I hear that you can add her to your party, but after 150+ hours with this game, I personally think it might just be a rumour.All in all, I can't recommend this game enough for people who played XIII and still want to spend more time on Gran Pulse. This is the sequel XIII deserved, and even with some of it's flaws, the game stands out in different ways than it's predecessor while still holding on to what was GOOD about FFXIII.TLDR; if you liked XIII enough to consider the sequel, do yourself a favour and pick this game up. It's such an improvement while staying true to the original.

I'll start out by say, DISABLE steam cloud saving for this game if you don't want random crashes while saving.With that out of the way, I can recommend FFXIII-2 if you don't mind a bit of back-tracking and exploring in your JRPGs.The battle system is more or less the same as it was with FFXIII, but you only have 2 main characters + 1 extra monsters in your party (they can be customized). This game is very polarizing for me. I gave it a thumbs up, but it's borderline. Where do I start? I guess the first place to start is with your main characters. Rather than following the heroes from the first game, you're stuck with the wallflower Serah and a new face, Noel. That's it. No additions to your party members, no changes to your roster. You're stuck with these two for the entire ordeal. This wouldn't be a problem if they had some personality, but they're sadly about as bland as cheap rice crackers.The combat system is recycled from the first game. The first problem some of you might've noticed is that this really doesn't work well with only two members in your team, so who gets to fill the third slot? Serah, lacking any kind of prior combat experience, inexplicably gains the power to recruit monsters to the team and becomes an instant warrioress the instant she's given a bow. To match her new combat prowess her outfit is magically transformed overnight as well. Because, why not?Okay, so the characters are a boring and the combat has become Pokemon lite-edition but surely the storyline keeps things ticking right? Wrong. The storyline is a mess. Instead of a continuation of the original, we get time travel. This basically gave SE free rein to destroy established canon whenever they wanted since rewriting history is basically the entire plot of the game.During some parts of the game you can choose dialogue options to get some exposition and ask questions. These don't really do much, although you're rewarded with items based on your responses. I personally hate Noel, so lamented the fact that none of the choices allowed me to treat him with the contempt he deserved. Noel acting almost like a love rival for Snow doesn't help to make him very likeable either, and you're stuck with him for the whole game.Okay, so it sounds like a rather scathing review all said and told, so why the thumbs up? Simply because when you set aside the plot and the characters, you get to the gameplay and it actually does this well. The monster system, while ridiculous, is actually well fleshed out and meaningful. Each one can be levelled individually and you can even customize their appearance thanks to 'adornments'. The areas are lively and interesting and as dumb as throwing a moogle sounds, it adds a mechanic which allows you to collect distant items which enables Square-Enix to hide secrets around the maps.The gameplay is actually really GOOD, and that's why it deserves a thumbs up even if the overall plot and characters are less than stellar. Also, throwing a moogle into Noel's face at full force is surprisingly theraputic sometimes.

TL;DR - If you want to play Lightning Returns and want to know about the story beforehand, I recommend skipping this broken game and reading a summary instead.I have three big qualms about this game. One involving the PC port, the other two involving the gameplay and its story.Firstly about the PC port: It is HORRIBLY BAD optimized. And I'm saying this after they had plenty of time patching the game but it seems this is as good as they're gonna make it. The game runs on a very, very weird dynamic fps capping system that generally limits your framerate very low so it doesn't spike, sometimes far lower than what you consider okay to look at. The community has found a way to remove this framerate limiter, greatly increasing the potential fps you will have. However, this will cause audio and animation during cutscenes to go out of sync if the framerate drops below 60, making most of them ridiculously stupid if they happen in a performance intense area.Secondly, the gameplay. I've never been fond of XIII's Active Time Battle system, which frankly hasn't changed very much in this game, making this already a minus. What's more is that most of the time it feels like you're fighting unnecessary encounters partly unrelated to the situation. The whole time-travelling system is also very confusing and annoying to do, gating you from progressing by having to go back and finding wild artifacts or other keys in order to progress through the main story. I suppose this was an attempt to go away from XIII's linear world but it's not better at all, making it more annoying if anything.And lastly, the story. If you enjoyed the story of FFXIII then you probably won't feel at home here. Apart from starting off somewhere near the ending of XIII and sharing its characters, it's like a fan-made alternative universe. While I understand that time travelling is playing a major role in this, it feels very disconnected from XIII. The character relations aren't reflective of XIII either, seperating it even more from being a sequel to XIII.On top of all that, Lightning Returns almost nullifies everything that happened in XIII-2 and just starts off from an almost completely unrelated universe. The only thing the 3 XIII games have in common are characters and modifications of its ATB system.

Final Fantasy XIII-2 is a nice sequence to Final Fantasy XIII. I personally remember when this Game first came out on Xbox 360 & PS3 and after playing the first FFXIII I bought this one as the Crystal Edition. Now almost 3 years later it finally came to PC.First of all let me say that this Game does have horrible fps drops and sometimes in some areas you will experience 30fps instead of 60fps.Performance wise the first FFXIII Game was alot better on PC then this one. But let me tell you that the Third and Final Part of this series runs even smoother then the first part!In this Game unlike the first Game you can only play 2 Characters which are Serah Farron and new Character that hasn't been in the previous Game.The Fightning System has also changed a little, not just in layout but also as to how it works. Once again you have Paradigmas but this time you will be able to tame Monsters / Enemies and let them fight by your side! Each of the Monsters come with their own Role that you can level up with Monster Material.The Leveling for the Characters is such the Same as before. Once again you have the Crystarium and the CP (Crystarium Points), with the only difference that the Crystarium looks a bit different and it seems to take longer with more points then before to level up your characters.Unlike the First Game you can now explore a bit more Freely and can get up to 8 alternative Endings. With 1 of course being the main ending. Once you've unlocked all 8 differend Endings you will get a Secret Ending as well.What makes this Game on PC better then on Console? The Fact that we got almost all DLC for free (besides 2 Costumes or so but you can mod them if you really want to)The Free DlC's include some Story DLC's and also some Costumes. So once you finished the Main Game there is actually alot more to do to catch the full Story!Although this Game has its Problems, once you get passed them it is a beautiful sequence to the First Game in the Series and up to this day one of my favourite ones. Since it took me 58 Hours to complete the Main Story (without any DLC done) I do recommend this Game to anybody that loves a good jrpg and a Story Rich game for its full Price.I also do recommend this Game to any Final Fantasy Fan! Especially the ones that enjoyed Final Fantasy VII as it is in the Same Universe as such.

Does this game improve and innovate on the mechanics of the first game? Yes.Is it at times one of the most simultaneously epic yet solemn final fantasy games ever? Also yes.Is it a better game than the original ff13? Perhaps.(Possible spoilers for ff13 and ff13-2 ahead)First off, this game exponentially adds to the lore and mythos of the twin worlds of cocoon and pulse but in doing so, dampens the sacrifice that took place at the end of ff13. When the game starts we are introduced to the driving force of the first game’s narrative and lighting’s sister, Serah Farron, who has been living on pulse in the town of new bodum. Shortly after awakening from a dream about her now long missing sister lightning fighting someone at the end of time, a time paradox opens (yes it’s one of THOSE stories) and the town is attacked by futuristic monsters and Serah meets up with 2 new characters, noel and mog. The story of the game then centres around Serah and Noel fighting and closing time paradoxes in an attempt to prevent the now crystalline cocoon from crashing down and ushering in the end of the world. Overall the story is intriguing and well written in regard to tackling the main themes of despair, loneliness and sacrificing the many in order to save the ones you love, if not a bit short. On the topic of gameplay, the paradigm system from ff13 has been greatly overhauled. Now, opposed to 3 party members that change based on the story, there are only 2 permanent party members (Serah and Noel) and the other party slot is occupied by any of 3 creatures you’ve captured in battle (think less pokemon and more persona as it is 100% luck based) who occupies a single paradigm. This was a novel inclusion as it makes party compositions feel more unique as you have access to almost every basic enemy to add to your party, train and customise with humorous attire but despite this, does not make up for not having a third CHARACTER in the party as all the dialogue tends to be between Serah, Noel and mog (who is practically useless gameplay wise other than for completionist purposes). Overall the lack of a wider party really sells Serah’s excitement for reuniting with Snow (who also went missing) and Noels sense of loneliness being the last person alive in the end of time. Combat wasn’t the only thing that was changed as the chrystarium was also completely overhauled. This time, rather than progress being tied to story events, a new chrystarium would unlock as soon as the old one was completed. This made progression feel a lot more fast paced and less like it was intrinsically tied to the plot. Paradigms also received some updates as now the SEN paradigm negates more damage than in ff13 and this feature is made apparent from the very start. This leads to combat being more fast paced but also more challenging in places. One final change to the gameplay formula is that random encounters are back but work on a system more akin to persona 3 than to a traditional final fantasy game, where an enemy randomly spawns, you have the chance to attack first to gain an advantage or flee and if you get hit by the enemy, you start with a disadvantage. Honestly I prefer this system as it means preemptive strikes are far easier to get as you aren’t sat in the gapra whitewood waiting for that bastard behemoth to turn around just for the chance of a preemptive strike! Not to mention that now you can change the party leader mid fight so now the annoying death of a party leader, leading to the loss of a fight in ff13 is replaced by the death of a party member, nothing more, nothing less.For the most part, the changes to the gameplay are welcome additions in my eyes and help to make the combat more enjoyable and engaging. The level design has also been altered for this sequel. This time around, Square really took the criticism of ff13’s corridor levels to heart and as a consequence, the levels and the way they are connected feel way too open. This seems like a good idea but now rather than being stuck at the end of a corridor, you actually took 27 wrong turns and have gone through 3 different time zones only to find out through a decade old youtube guide that you went through the wrong time portal and went several millennia in the wrong direction. As for the area design, that is a completely different story. Final Fantasy XII-2 continues to hold the bar set by its predecessor and in some instances surpasses it, conveying not only the state of the world to the player but also the emotions of the characters, using the contrast of the same area being perfectly fine in one timeline and utterly demolished in another to sell the urgency of saving cocoon and its inhabitants.As a result of your time tampering, not only do you save the many lives of cocoon, but you also get a glimpse into the more personal effects of your actions with the character of Alyssa Zaielle, who you witness grappling with the knowledge that they themselves are a time paradox and should have died, if not for the player altering time. Now for the real reason anyone would play a final fantasy game. The villain. Caius Ballad is the eternal sworn protector of yuel the seeress who is continually fated to die at approximately 15 years old. Understandably, this leaves Caius distraught as the one person he loves dearest is ripped from him prematurely, leaving countless iterations of him alone. Caius acts as a foil to Noel as they are both people confronted with immense loss but the way they handle it is completely different, as where Noel sees hope and is seen as a light in the dark, Caius seeks only chaos and destruction. On the topic of chaos, I would like to discuss this game’s implications on the wider story of the ff13 universe. With the end if ff13, you see the entire party, save fang I believe, transform into ceith, then to shortly later revert back into people. Ff13-2 tries to explain this by introducing the unseen character of Etro, the goddess of death, who it turns out took pity upon the party and used her powers to revert the party. This caused a time paradox which was resolved by lightning being sacrificed and imprisoned by the chaos until the end of time in valhalla, which in turn led to the death of Etro, whose heart (the heart of chaos) is stored inside Caius. This is an interesting addition to the lore as it shows that there are beings above the likes of the fal cie who possess the power to rewrite history. As none of this was referenced in the first game, this makes it feels less planned and more like a slapdash effort, especially with bunevelze’s introduction in lighting returns.After numerous fights with Caius and saving the population of cocoon, the game’s climax takes place as a battle against Caius in valhalla at the end of time. This leads to either Noel killing Caius or his suicide based on the player’s choice. This then leads to the heart of chaos being shattered, setting the events of lightning returns into motion.Like it’s predecessor, this game has excellent music with a large selection of high energy tracks as well as loads of more typical final fantasy music, with each area having an alternate version of the song for when an enemy appears and tries to attack you, which helps sell the sense of upcoming action with the next fight. Like with the area design, the ost also contains some more sombre tracks which succeed with selling the emotion of the comparatively darker story.Overall while this review was fairly positive in its tone, I would like to add that there are flaws with the game. The actual story is relatively simple and more of a vessel for the interesting themes and during the latter half the game becomes extremely TEDIOUS as in without a guide this game would be over 75 hours long levels of tedious. It also ends on a cliffhanger that only serves as a way to sell lighting returns which I won’t get into. but if you liked ff13, you should like tis game.

Despite the best efforts of Lightning and her crew, the world is once again in danger. Now it's up to Serah, mysterious traveler Noel, and moogling Mog to make things right. Despite putting 50+ hours into FFXIII-2, I'm about as equipped to discuss the plot as somebody who has never even heard of the game....or Final Fantasy. I guess this title could be compared to previous Square games like Chrono Trigger & Chrono Cross. The player must pass through various times and dimensions, alleviating paradoxes, fighting monsters, and getting pushed around by some jerk named Caius. There are dark moments (like Chrono), but it sticks to 3-4 characters, instead of attempting to juggle 300 (like Cross). I guess that's part of what got me through this game. When the story doesn't make a lot of sense, at least you can watch the friendship between Noel & Serah grow, and realize that they're getting by despite the heaps of BS being tossed their way.The battle-system is straight outta FFXIII, but with numerous changes. The most obvious is that the third party member is always a monster. Pocket Monster fans are going to find dozens of creatures to recruit throughout their journey. Monsters are strengthened via materials, and can be infused with others to gain additional skills. Admittedly, I was a little disappointed that monsters adhere to the FFXIII system. For example, I recruited a Giant Cactaur, but he's not going around using 100,000 needles on everything. He's a synergist so he sticks entirely to buffs.  I know I know, the paradigms are essential to winning in FFXIII, but I just...oh well. On the bright side, monsters tend to have unique skills that make them more effective in a given situation than Serah & Noel. On the whole, FFXIII-2 is a fair bit easier than its predecessor. This is mostly due to the fact that you're actually not limited in how much you can grind. Since this game is non-linear, you could go to various optional areas and amass a ton of levels, making the story-battles trivial. Aside from a handful of post-game & DLC fights, you'll have to limit yourself if you want a challenge.Speaking of levels, the Crystarium got a convoluted revamp. You cash in points for stat bonuses: +3 to magic, +20 to HP, etc. Over time you unlock and level all six roles, but your level 99 stats can vary. There's a "perfect" guide floating around to help you figure this mess out. While I ended up using guides to have a chance at 100%ing this game, I merely stuck to leveling what I thought would make sense. For Serah, I leveled Ravager on the large nodes to boost her magic, and with Noel, commando. I probably goofed somewhere and cost myself a good 30+ points in an essential stat, but I've done most everything in the game, so it isn't that much of an issue.In order to get all 160 fragments, you're going to be doing a lot of exploring, grinding, puzzles, and stupid pet tricks. Mog is capable of finding hidden items, and can also be thrown to reach faraway objects (which you might need a guide to find). The puzzles are almost entirely mini-games. As anyone who has played FFXIII-2 will tell you, the clock puzzles SUCK. Most of them aren't that difficult and can be brute-forced. But there are a few that all but require a website for calculating solutions. Either take advantage of the tools the internet has made available to you, or watch in horror as the pacing dies a painful death, your choice. The grind isn't quite as bad as FFXIII, but expect to spend a lot of time in the Archylte Steppe fighting the same monsters for potent orbs, essences, & crystals. After completing the game, all of the major DLC is unlocked. In the Coliseum, players will engage in battle with numerous fan-favorites, and a few characters from FFXIII. I find it amusing that one of the opponents should have been in a boss-fight in FFXIII, but it never happened because reasons. I won't spoil it, but if you played FFXIII, then you already know who I'm talking about. You'll want to fight these battles not just because they're quite good, but also because you can recruit everyone you defeat. The next DLC adventure is a solo battle between Lightning and Caius. Lightning has a specific set of roles, and is expected to switch between them constantly. For example, she can use the knight role to become impervious to damage, and it's necessary to avoid getting one-shotted by a handful of Caius's attacks. Since this DLC doesn't require Serah & Noel, you can do it immediately after completing the game to gain a powerful ally. Sazh's DLC adventure takes place in a Casino. He's trapped in limbo, and his son is nowhere to be found, only by gambling can they hope to be re-united. While the concept sounds sufficiently dark, this isn't exactly Gambling Apocalypse Sazh. The goal is to acquire 30 fortune medals, which can be done in less than 30 minutes by playing Texas Hold'em. The casino is also available in the main-game, though all N&S can do is play slots and race their chocobos. Once I got the items I required, I never went back. I'll admit, I enjoyed my time with this game more than FFXIII. Noel, Serah, and Caius are some of the better JRPG heroes and villains I've seen. Trying to make sense of everything is headache-inducing, but the revamped crystarium and monster-raising provided excellent distractions. The combat itself also recieved some slight improvements, like paradigm  shifting being noticeably faster. The various areas/times/dimensions being more than a narrow corridor definitely helped, though the quests tend to be of the fetching variety. The port still could have been a lot better though. I'm not nearly as frustrated about it now as was when I started the PC version, but Square-enix isn't getting a passing grade for this one. FFXIII and its sequel deserve better ports, but I expect Lightning Returns to be at about the same quality as the previous two PC entries; superior to the console versions, and not much else.

I'm a huge fan of Final Fantasy series, maybe not hardcore fan but this is one of my favorite game series. And Final Fantasy XIII-2 in my opinion is one of the worst games in the whole series. But that doesn't mean it's bad. Final Fantasy XIII lacked a lot of things which made the game a FF game. But I really loved combat in that game. While this game retains very similar combat system it simply lacks characters. You can't build a team since it has very limited playable characters. You play as Serah (oh how I wanted to play as her, it's like dream come true, cutie) and Noel. You can have third party member as a captured monster. They also can evolve and you have quite a bit of choice which monster you want to use. Other than that the combat is very similar to FF XIII – it's fast but it allows some tactical gameplay and isn't as boring as turn based combat. Yes I get it turn based combat has a lot more tactical possibilities but most of the time you're fighting regular monsters which are easy to beat and you run into them a lot, so waiting each time while clicking one button becomes boring after your 100th fight.This time Serah and Noel embark on a journey to find Lightning. They travel through time to various locations some being new and some you've visited in previous game. Although those locations are quite different when you travel there because of the time period you travel to.There are a lot of locations to explore. From vast open areas to some weird sci-fi-like mazes and cities. What I loved about the setting was that the game feels pretty dark, the worlds you travel to are desolate and the whole atmosphere is like that. It's still pretty but feels very eerie, grim, dismal (can't find a word for it).So the whole gameplay is exploring those areas in different time periods and fighting enemies alongside doing some side quests. But there's one gameplay mechanic I hated, I hated it to the degree it almost ruined the whole game for me. It's clock puzzles. When you get there you'll know why. Don't believe me? Google it, someone even made clock puzzle solver. I have no idea why they put this crap into a game.Of course there a chocobos and moogles so it has at least a bit of Final Fantasy soul. But nearly everything else which made Final Fantasy great is gone just like in XIII.Graphically it looks surprisingly good considering the age of this game. The game looks really pretty, character models are very high quality (except AI characters) and since the PS3 release the hair modelling still looks great today.Areas are ranging from ok to good in my opinion. Some could use more work and some look really good.Since this is an old game, PS3 port, it should run pretty good but don't expect performance to be great. It's straight up PS3 port after all. Porting from PS3 was difficult, besides seeing the game's price it's clear SE did not put a lot of effort into porting this.Sound design is great as always in the series. Music is very good and in some areas it creates that kind of hopeless, the end of the world mood. Voice acting is good too, I have no complaints.It's a decent Final Fantasy game. If you enjoyed XII you will enjoy this too. But somehow it feels even smaller than XIII, lacks characters and the whole time traveling is a bit tiring and confusing. But it retained the combat system which makes fighting fun. Get this on sale if you enjoy FF or jrpg's in general.

This game is more playable after applying the 4GB patch EXE which allows it to have better framerates.  Now onto the game itself compared to the first:  + Better Music  + More streamlined combat  + Fixed issue with high resolutions (you can read the notes on each enemy now)  + Environments are more detailed and look better  + Voice acting is far better than the first game  + Ending is decent  + Most side quests build the world a bit.   - Quick time events....  - They have the idea of time travel but it's lazily implemented.  The most you get is a tint and maybe some thunder or snow when going a hundred years in the future?  Lame.  Although Academia was well done.  - It feels like this game story was written then they hacked it up so it fit with the first game.  You'll also get tired of hearing the words "timeline" and "paradox" by the end of this game.  - Only 3 main characters and they barely get developed.  Story is mostly boring until late in the game.    - Long load times.  Exacerbated by the fact that in order to get fragments you have to repeatedly search timelines.  Expect to do a lot of waiting.  - Pacing of the story is worse due.  XIII had a more enjoyable story. Overall, all of the positives don't outweigh the negatives. As a spinoff, it's not everyone's Final Fantasy. But it does attempt to rectify some of the problems that XIII had.First, the story, which is a weakness. I do not believe XIII-2 or Lightning Returns should have been attached to XIII. Each of them convolute the story so much, adding and changing the mythos in unnecessary ways. Personal beef aside, XIII-2 takes place... uh, anytime and everytime after XIII. That's right, you'll be traveling through time. It continues after XIII and retcons the happy ending. Series heroine Lightning has disappeared, and as her younger sister Serah, the only one who seems to remember her, you need to team up with Noel, the last survivor of humanity in the far-off future, to find the source of a timeline disturbance and fix it.The combat is similar to XIII, which is a more dynamic version of the ATB system from many other FF games. The difference here is that you always play as the same two characters, plus your choice of captured monster. In this game, you can recruit enemy monsters, each with a specific combat role (medic, physical attacker, magic attacker, etc.), as opposed to Serah and Noel who can change roles. You can change combat roles for your party on the fly during battle to react to the situation.Exploration is limited, each area is self-contained and you travel between each area/time via a menu. Some locations are used more than once, and you can explore them in different times to reach new areas and quests. Also unlike FFXIII, you can get sidequests from the beginning of the game. Completings quests will get you fragments, the chief indicator of progress. There are 160 fragments to collect. On the surface, I like the concept of fragments, reminiscent of Sonic Adventure's emblems. Most are single challenges. You'll have about half of them or maybe less if you're just gunning for the end (if memory serves). There is a meaty postgame, but it does get slow and annoying at times (but not as slow as FFXIII) and the fragment that has you logging battles with every single monster will be annoying, but perfectly passable with a guide. The Paradox Ending concept is also annoying too. Oh, and the quizzes in Academia. You would probably not know how to get all of them without a guide. Also unlike FFXIII, levels are not just single tunnels, but Academia (all time periods, really) is an unneccessary overcompensation. It's huge and confusing.Ah, almost forgot! The port. Both XIII and Lightning Returns are better that XIII-2. Nearly everyone has encountered slowdown with this game. It is simply not optimized well. That said, it never became unplayable for me, and I mean ACTUALLY unplayable instead of 'OMG it's 59 FPS instead of 60 FPS' like some people who use that term. This does dip below 30 FPS at points where I could run XIII at a pretty smooth 60 throughout. I can deal with that, but some people can't. It does not excuse Square Enix from doing that to us. The game's $20, though, so yeah.In summary, the game is worth the price. You'll have to deal with lag and a story that simply didn't need to happen, but you have a fun battle system and more exploration than FFXIII in return.

A beautiful RPG that marks the second chapter of the Final Fantasy XIII trilogy!In a departure from the first game, FFXIII-2 is very non-linear; you can explore all manner of side areas and progress the story at your own speed, but going straight through the story is also perfectly possible and not prohibitively difficult for a player that didn't grind. NOTE: This game does *not* run well without modification, as Square Enix did a very sloppy job porting it. Thankfully this is fixed by unofficial fixes and mods - you can find information on those here:  .Pros:   - Excellent soundtrack and characters   - Story is great   - Beautiful graphics   - Battle system is a lot of funCons:   - One of the Temporal Rift puzzles (the clock solvers) are an absolute nightmare and easily the worst design decision in the whole Final Fantasy XIII series. Easy for a computer for a solve, practically impossible for any normal human; google for Robert Woodward's FFXIII-2 clock solver to save yourself endless frustration.   - The game could have done a better job of hinting to the player where to find good early monsters - the ones given initially are awful, and getting decent monsters is very much key to the battle system in FFXIII-2. It's not a big deal, but something that could've been better.   - Much like FFXIII, this game was given an extremely sloppy port by Square Enix. Not only does it run badly out of the box but will frequently crash - thankfully you can fix all this with unofficial mods and game fixes, which are all fantastic and require little effort to install. For those who have had their games crashing, and DO NOT have intergrated graphics as well as a GPU installed. I beleive I have solved the problem.1. Right click on the game in your steam library, go to "properties" >"updates", turn off steam cloud to this game.    I have seen posts where people are turning off cloud in steam settings as a whole. THIS WILL EFFECT ALL STEAM     GAMES!        do it this way and it only affects Final Fantasy XIII-2.2. Go to "program files (x86)" > "Steam" > "userdata" > your ID (9 digit number) > "292140" > "remote". Now copy your      newest save file.3. Go back 4 times, go to "steamapps" > "common" > "FINAL FANTASY XIII-2". Paste your save data to this folder.    By doing this step you use the saves that were stored locally on your machine, so you do not have to restart your game     over, and you can keep playing without the cloud crashing your game.4. Enjoy!I hope this helps everyone!

Pretty good overall experience. If you didnt enjoy ff13's gameplay then i cant blame you. There havent been many changes to the basic mechanics (you still mainly just spam auto battle and let the game decide for you outside of specific cases), but the major overhaul of the party building (you recruit monsters you kill, allowing you to customize your party with thousands of combinations), and many QoL improvements (you dont lose when party leader dies, faster paradigm shifts etc.) make the game worth giving a shot. Story is actually comprehensible without reading tons of pages of encyclopedia (you still need to know what happened in 13 to grasp the story though), characters are better and fleshed out, tons of side quests (way over half the gameplay time is optional side quests), lot of exploration, good music and decent graphics. Be warned though, this is an atrocious PC port, you need to use fanmade patches to make the game run decently, and even then you will probably not achieve a stable framerate. Neverthless, its a good game worth getting on sale. I'd recommend
