I absolutely hate this game. I think in the 38 hours I spent with it I enjoyed about 3-5 hours at most. The biggest highlight is the incredible music and the voice acting of one of the main characters (Caius). Liam O brien is a fantastic voice actor and he fit the role perfectly for the only interesting character in the entire game.Lets go into a deep dive into why I hate this game and why I honestly think pretty much anyone should be avoiding this disaster.To begin lets talk about the games concept, its very rare for the final fantasy series mainline games to get sequels. FF 10 is pretty much the main example and that sequel had a lot of problems as well. FF 13 2 pretty much has some of the most horrific writing I have seen, Serah and a new character called Noel take center stage into a time traveling trip through the locations of FF 13. This is an excellent chance to explore the wide cast of characters and locations in the first game that didn't get explored including Serah which was such an incredibly important character to the story.Now tell me how in a 40 hour game with all these new characters you somehow developed none of them? Even the most interesting character basically gets left on a bunch of question marks once you finish the game. Every other character is downright horrible, especially the main characters. Serah has 0 personality and somehow shows less development here compared to FF 13 where she barely said anything for the entire game. Noel is just supposed to be a hero for heroes sake, he isn't interesting or built up, he is forced in for the sake of having a new character. And MOG, there is a moogle for no reason that follows you around, the game only barely gives a reason as to why he even is in the game. This moogle is the most ear grating thing ever and represents everything western fans hate about JRPG voice acting. MOG is a mascot character through and through and his KUPO will haunt me in my nightmares. All these characters have no proper role in this entire story, they exist for the sake of existing. The gameplay got touched on but has the same essence as the first game. Note I said touched on and not improved. The combat did become more fluid with less useless animations but the structure of battles has become much less strategic and much more reactionary. The main strategy comes from building a 3rd party member. Most enemies in the game can be captured and then turned into a 3rd party member, this can completely break the game depending on how you tackle this system. If you end up not understanding the system because of how confusing it can be then you end up slogging through the fights. If you even understand it a little bit you will end up stomping 95 % of the game until the final fights of the game, which for some reason are a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ nightmare. I could do every fight in the game nearly blindfolded with the same strategy, but for some reason the final area required me to have practically extremely decked out characters even with me spending a bit of extra time on side content and grinding. Either way I was already starting to get bored with FF 13's battle system towards the end of the first game, by the end of this game I grew extremely tired of it.Also did time travel, monster party member and new main character sound overly convoluted and confusing? Yes? Well you haven't heard the start of it. This game doesn't have a proper vision of what it wants to be, it just wants to be everything ff 13 failed to be. It tries to be extremely open ended but has to repeat a ton of content and messes up the games balance as a result. It constantly throws random plot points and game mechanics at you to try and keep you interested. There are puzzle sections that just feels forced. The last area has a platforming section with timed jumps that are slow as hell. It has a ton of side content which you can completely avoid if you want. Some of these are things that FF 13 was lacking but overall the execution is horrible. So many annoying things were cleaned up from ff 13 that it feels mind boggling that so many other aspects were introduced and made so slow and boring. There are a lot of ideas here but clearly not enough time/budget to actually realize the complete vision for this game. Which is sad, so much of this would have been really appreciated in FF 13, especially some of the side content like a coliseum or the 'Golden saucer' style area. That extra content is also one of the few positives I see in this game and it is what allows the ending to somewhat make sense somehow, those who are fanatic about FF 13 might be able to find something there in that bonus content.Maybe I could enjoy this stuff a lot better if the games port also wasn't one of the worst I have ever experienced. I had to mess 2 hours before even playing the game with mods to try and fix this mess and it still is so bad that its more common for it to be lagging and stuttering then for it to just run normally. If you have any particle effect like rain or sand on screen you can say goodbye to your frames. Some people even reported corrupted saves which I thankfully didn't get. Overall this port is a joke and a spit in the face of the fans of the series. Every time you move between area you have to look at a loading screen for like 1 minute, this ♥♥♥♥ is unacceptable when you have to move between areas constantly especially if you want to do side quests. Even something as simple as achievements feel half backed and forced in with descriptions barely describing what you are supposed to do. I hate this game but I think those who enjoy this game should be able to play it on PC without these horrible issues. Even if I enjoyed the game I think I would still not recommend this game purely due to how bad the port is.And somehow maybe the worst thing for me is the story. It turned the relatively straightforward story of FF 13 into a mess. All the themes and character build up of the first game feels like it was spit out in favor of the new cast of characters. And what do these new characters and story line offer? 'Future' 'Heart' 'Kupo' 'Friends' 'Paradox' 'CHAOS'. I miss the personal interactions between characters facing a difficult problem, ff 13 wasn't perfect but it did a lot right in creating some emotionally gripping scenes. Those scenes also exist here but they are extremely rare. Its sad to see because I actually can see a lot of potential in the story, it is exciting to see where the world of FF 13 was going after its ending, but everything here just feels like a bad fan fiction more then anything else.I downright hate this game with every fiber of my body. It isn't only bad but it actively makes FF 13 worse and I actually kind of liked that game to some extend. This game wastes your time, it runs like crap, it is boring as hell. For a game that tries to teach you so much about the value of time it is ridiculous that it has this much filler content that just straight up wastes your time. I can't ever recommend this game, even if you want to play all mainline FF games like me I would just recommend seeing a youtube summary or something and avoiding this. I entered with not a lot of hope and left with a disgusting after taste somehow. The only people I would ever recommend this to are those who 100 % completed FF 13 and still somehow wanted more, even to those I would give a warning to make sure you understand what you are committing your time and money into.

This game was quite a disappointment for me. It took me two attempts to finish it: one on PS3 but I got bored and stopped playing, and the other on PC, the latter of which I was successful in completing after a fair amount of forcing myself to keep going. Despite really liking FFXIII while still recognizing it has weaknesses (for me, it was plot holes and post-game stuff), I could not enjoy FFXIII during the great majority of my time playing it.Where to begin? This is a port, so let's talk about that first. It runs -terribly- compared to FFXIII. FFXIII ran like butter for me, while FFXIII-2 was choppy and near-unplayable on the same PC until I installed a user-made 30 FPS capping app from the Steam discussion page. After that, it was a little choppy still, with character lip synching off by a few seconds, but it was definitely playable. The controls and everything else about the port were just dandy for me.Do not play this if you haven't completed FFXIII or at least watched all the cutscenes from FFXIII, as it would be very confusing otherwise. Speaking of confusing, villain's plan isn't described well enough to make total sense, nor is much of the storyline, with plot threads such as Mog's origin and why people from a survival-focused era when less than 10 humans are left on the planet would wear stylish, ornate, colorful clothing in a barren wasteland, fighting for their lives, wanting to survive. It would be like if Rick and friends on The Walking Dead were decked out in bling, bright blue parachute pants, etc., while being pursued by zombies. The female lead in the game magically gets new clothing and there is no explanation as to why. The female lead should've just had a new outfit naturally, since she's living in a full-on civilization, and the male lead could get the magical clothing to replace his rags, but instead the writers chose to lack all logic with this decision. Now, many humans can suddenly use magic, whereas before, it was only l'Cie that could do it. I actually liked that plot point in FFXIII, so I would have preferred that only l'Cie and ex-l'Cie can use it, because only one human in the entire game would need a writing modification to explain why that character can use magic. Only ONE. Changing the rules of the lore is just weird and unnecessary. One major character from FFXIII becomes a l'Cie in FFXIII-2, but you never see it happen, it doesn't seem to have any importance in the storyline, and you never hear any resolution to it or see that character in the ending despite that character being one of the most important characters in the universe for one of the heroes.Also, the ending of the game can be pretty aggravating/upsetting/disappointing. I didn't upset me anywhere near as badly as Mass Effect 3's ending, but it's gotta be in my top 10 most disappointing endings if I bothered to make such a list. I didn't believe another reviewer who claimed that the ending would piss me off, and I regret it. That reviewer was absolutely right. I honestly recommend that you just watch all the cinematics and cutscenes, which you can watch spliced together on Youtube. It would've saved me 50-something hours, at least.This game has a battle system which is almost completely identical to FFXIII's. The only biggest differences are that battles are random with the player being able to slash the opponent to start with haste and part of the enemy's stagger bar filled. Oh, and you use the male and female lead, and a monster as your third party member. You can use almost any monster in the game, but each can only do one role in the paradigm system, and you have to feed items to the monsters to level them up, which ends up being a time-suck if you want to make a really good monster. Much of the time, my human characters were lords of war when I was in a fight, while my monsters were just sucking badly. This game was also much, much easier than FFXIII for me as well, and I'm pretty awful at this kind of game. The final boss was annoying, but other than that, I didn't even have to try on most of the bosses, and I just set my team to all Commandos for every non-boss fight, winning within 20 seconds or less after about 55% or so completing of the game's story. This game might just have the worst experience scaling of any FF game I've ever played, because half-way through, fights were giving me 400-440 XP and those encounters were nearly twice as frequent to pop up as the rest of the game's random battles, which gave more like 225 XP per fight.The music was very similar to that of FFXIII, with a few reused songs here and there, and a few songs that I really disliked which probably would be classified as metal, which isn't really my thing. I liked the voice acting as well, except for the villain, who came off a bit too melodramatic for my taste.There is a casino, which sounded cool, but the interesting-sounding activities are locked off as DLC (it's including but you can't use the DLC until you finish the game's entire main storyline), and everything else either requires a lot of time (Chocobo Racing which most players say is garbage compared to FFVII's), or is all about randomness, which is the slot machines. To get items I wanted from the casino slots without wasting my life away, I had to clamp down Tab on my keyboard for hours and walk away while it autoplayed, reloading my game if I didn't make money. The casino in this game just wasn't fun for me.Last but not least, this game does have a post-game. That's not really my bag, but I did try to collect all of the Fragments (hidden objects in the game), and got 122 of 160 of them. I called it quits when I got about 85% through the story and a quest-giver basically tells your "Lulz. The writers could've written this in somehow within your first hour of playing so you could prepare and not have such a daunting task, but screw you! I need you to fight every type of monster in the entire game including weird fights that you do for choosing incorrect dialog options during the storyline, etc., and you will likely have to consult an online guide and spent countless hours to get my Fragment," but I'm paraphrasing his lines from memory. Seriously, what a jackass move. And is it worth it? Getting all of the Fragments? At least half of my time at my computer with this game was spent getting Fragments, and all they do is give you some data files you could just look up online, help you get the secret ending (just watch it on Youtube after you finish the game) which makes a lot less sense than the original and still has the bad things happen that might anger you, and boosts the stats of the two lead characters. That stat boost, though? I had 122 Fragments, which gave me 40 higher attack attribute scores than I would have if I'd used the next best weapons which were on sale at the normal stores for CHEAP. My attack attribute was over 1100, so losing 40 points just wouldn't have mattered except when going for post-game optional bosses.In summary, the game has a pretty good soundtrack, a competent battle system with a third "party member" that disappoints unless you're willing to put in a lot of time, a so-so story with an anger-inducing ending, a crappy casino, hellish amounts of busy work to find all the Fragments, and a secret ending that's a complete let-down even though I didn't do all the work to get it. I cannot recommend this game, but I would say that the 7 hours it would take you to watch all the cutscenes and moviews from it in Youtube would be worth your time if you believe me and other reviewers that the ending really does deliver a low blow, and you were a big enough fan of FFXIII that you care to see what happens next (though Fal'Cie and l'Cie are rarely brought up and most FFXIII characters have very little screen time).

This is the second installment in the FFXIII Trilogy, and in terms of story I would say this game was an improvement. Below are my overall thoughts on the game.Pros:+Better Storyline/Pacing than the first game+IMO more fun gameplay, overworld map with selectable time periods+Soundtrack is beautiful as always+Graphics look really good with the HD mod+Lightning's Goddess outfit is HOT+Noel is a dope character+Time Traveling Shenanigans, perfect for a DC Flash FanCons:-The PC port is absolute garbage, it is so outdated and you will need to install some mods and the FF13 Fix for maximum enjoyment-Story has the same confusion and complexity as Kingdom Hearts, using time travel in story telling can demolish all of the momentum. I enjoyed it since I like time travel, but I think they could have eased on that factor.-Encounter rate can get pretty annoying after a whileOverall, it wasn't that bad... I enjoyed the scenery and the amazing beautiful soundtrack, and the setting was cool too, 7.8/10

You repeat the same action, expecting something different, something new, something fresh. And after repeated tries what you finally create or destroy is something entirely different but remarkably similar at the same time. A creation of something new, from ages past, a relic to be used once more. FFXIII-2 epitomizes such qualities in a manner that takes what their predecessor had previously done and made some in my eyes welcoming changes.It should also be noted, since the game is different from the first, some things remain the same. And since the game draws heavily from time-traveling expect lots of questions and eyebrow raising as well.No more will players be restricted to one path throughout the game like the previous. Areas are more fleshed out with quests! Involving a lot of back tracking in order to complete them in order to earn CP (Crystogen Points) which is used to upgrade your characters in the Crystarium. Players who played the previous installment will remember this as their go to way to leveling up their character. Usually by battling to accrue CP (or exp) or doing side quests to earn more CP and unlock Fragments. And oh boy, Fragments and artifacts; you will hear this in the story a lot being heard. Basically in it’s most basic form, their a plot device that you need to progress through the story. Using the items above one can traverse through time in different eras called AF(After the Fall), from 5-700, don’t be alarmed though the game doesn’t make it like after 5,6, 7, 8, etc. You will only visit relative and important eras spanning different areas to explore. An interesting twist with Time-travel is the addition of paradoxes and alternate timelines which the game heavily abuses to see different areas dramatically change in setting and thus irrevocably change. The power to reverse such paradoxes is up to you mainly. But, I found the different eras in different places pleasing and a welcome change. Exploration has been revamped coinciding with side quests so expect a lot of backtracking to either farm for CP, materials, and even a chance of taming a creature. Whereas before you can only go forward in the story for the first game, here you can keep going back and restart eras to replay the events prior to see it all again.Hell, there’s even a casino area and chocobo racing which i felt was rigged against me. Or I just suck badly...A new mechanic reminiscent of capturing Pokémon, or Digimon; upon battles you have a chance to tame the creature you are facing these creatures range from smallest to large creatures you primarily face in the FFXIII universe. Of course each creature you tame can also be infused and made stronger using another creature to boost their capabilities if their compatible enhancing their role, adding new abilities or even adding resistances. They can also be leveled up using items compatible for them different from CP using items like potent chip, potent slivers, etc. These items can be bought from shops or earned as drops from battles to enhance your creature quickly eliminating the need to grind them. Each item is different, and can be used to upgrade their hp only, their magic only, or both. Some creatures are unique and can be tamed enabling strong party members while others you can’t tame like bosses for instance or some creatures like C’eith.The battle system remains the same with paradigms and roles Commando, Ravager, Sentinel, Medic, Saboteur, and Synergist. However, with the new creature mechanic you can expect a lot of new experimentation to create your own team that suits you. Coupled with the creature taming it provides a diverse and fun way to hunt for new companions to suit your battles and become stronger. Fan of the old will immediately be familiar with the same battle mechanic with the same o’l ATB rate, but this time you can unlock your roles via Crystarium and unlock more ATB charges and boost your roles upon completing a round in the Crystarium. It pleasant needing no introduction to the battle system with several new additions to the system with taming.Story-wise with Time-travel usually gives me headaches to understand the convoluted sense of the story, but in this game they don’t make it overtly complicated raising the right questions that will sooner or later be understood in the progressing story. What really changes the story up are the dialogue options during events only four choices to depend on what you will say. And these events will pop up again and again to inform the player of important events. I’m guessing it all lodges back into paradox endings you can achieve. Quick time events are included with this sequel in order to gauge player choice. Usually within a cinematic event you are prompted with QTE to progress through the story. Completing them rewards items, while not completing them makes you restart the whole progress. And while it can be annoying to wait for the button prompts the events were short and not so much that it was intrusive and bothersome. Some QTE are unique in providing a choice of a certain different path to take than a usual previous route.You play as Serah, the sister to Lightning from the previous game in a race against time really to solve paradoxes, with the adorable Mog which you can torture by throwing to various places to pick up items, and reveal hidden items in the world. But, wait there’s more! A future guy also travelled back in time to help you because you need a partner. His name is Noel. And you in essence share the leader role with him. Meaning you can switch from running around the world as Noel or Serah or face battles as Noel or Serah! While it sucks I can’t change them to be just creature parties I found the cast to be likable and sympathetic to their cause to save time and reach Lightning in Valhalla. In true Final Fantasy fashion you can even customize your creatures and outfit Serah and Noel in different attire (Moogle too!) and guess what even your creatures can have certain adornments on them you find in the game or buy. Music and battle themes some may remember some old sound tracks which fit the times you are exploring providing a soothing comfort and others new provide the tension to keep your body tense reading to spring into action. To compare FFXIII-2 versus its predecessor is like comparing a baby to a child. The changes in the game make it very diverse from exploration and taming, battling and side-quests and dialogue options and more. It takes the criticisms of the first installment and in my opinion improves it to make it better for the player to enjoy. While it may seem drastic to add many new mechanics and along with a new protagonist represents a bold risk that ultimately paid off. While Final Fantasy XIII could be described as a piece of stringy meat that's though to chew but still occasionally tasty, Final Fantasy XIII-2 is the whole burger with some ingredients you may or may not like. This game is almost universally better than the first game in the trilogy. Combat is a bit faster and more streamlined, with an additional pokemon-like system that lets you use monsters during battle. Exploration is less linear, you can jump at any time, there's many different areas and everything is a bit more open. The soundtrack is fantastic as usual, and the story is about as much of a hit or miss as in XIII, though I personally love all of the characters and stories in this trilogy.The only fault of this game, as it were, is that it is part of a trilogy that debuted with a very mixed game. Final Fantasy XIII was linear, repetitive and restrictive until the 25 hour mark, but it had a setting, story and characters many people loved, as well as a rather unique battle system. Still, not many people wanted to play through the long initial linear gameplay loop and thus XIII got the reputation it, at least slightly, deserved.It pays off to have played it, though, as many events and characters are recurring in XIII-2. It also is nice to see the evolution the trilogy makes from first to second game, how every complaint is either solved or alleviated. Sure, it isn't perfect - the port in particular is very flawed when it comes to frame rate and performance, and the male main character is slightly irritating - but it is leaps and bounds better compared to XIII, which was a true flawed gem, though more flawed than gem. As someone who loves the trilogy, it's a great fun upgrade with returning characters, familiar and new locations, newfound freedom in environments and movement and an addicting gameplay loop of improving main characters Noel and Serah through the (now better) crystarium and collecting fragments as you jump through time and space to fix past and future. If you didn't like XIII, this might remedy the trilogy for you; but you should've at least played part of the first game first.Personal rating: 8/10.

First of all, before buying this game, I read some reviews mentioning it had many crashing/compatibility issues. Only one review mentioned that it seemed to work better on Windows 7 than on Windows 10.So far, I've been playing on Linux Mint using Proton 7 and it's been working flawlessly; save for the frame drop when there's a lot of particles/lighting on some specific occasions, such as cinematic or boss fights. Otherwise, the game runs perfectly fine.~~~~~~~~~~Gameplay wise, when you start playing it, you'll realise that it plays a lot like Final Fantasy XIII. The fighting system is the same, the controls are similar, the menu works the same way, the map works the same way, save for a few minor differences: - You actually have a button to physically jump. It's not really useful most of the time, save of when you have a blue jumping circle like in the first game. But if it allows you to jump a tiny cliff instead of going all around, it's nice. Combined with the Chocobo that allows you to run faster, it's almost like platforming.- Some fights (mostly boss fight) require you to perform actions during "cinematic fights". Basically, you will be asked to press on a few buttons or move the direction stick (if you play on controller) a few times within the given time.  Pro tip: you can pause the game by pressing start until you can recognise what you're supposed to do. That will make "cinematic fights" easier.When I started playing, I felt like it was going to be what FF X-2 was to FF X, albeit with a better start and an actual plot. But the game quickly took a bad turn, at least in my opinion. Everything I do feels frustrating, as if the very fact of playing the game was a chore; a bad one.In the first game, whenever I had to farm (experience, money, anything), I actually felt like I was progressing, getting somewhere. In this game, it feels like it's going to be a pain either way: farming takes forever, and if you don't farm, then the game is going to take forever too. There is a main plot, as weak as I find it. But it's not really what drives the story forward. You're just randomly advancing forward, hoping that you will eventually get somewhere in the story.The music, more often than not, is annoying. From time to time, you will get the music from the first game, which gives you a good moment of nostalgia. But the music of this game itself makes me want to wrap this up even faster than the game itself.Overall: it feels like it had potential to get somewhere, even if I initially didn't understand why they decided to retcon the ending of the 1st game. But the way it was done feels like they were just trying to milk money out of the 1st game, the same way as with FF X-2.The thing I liked the most was when I realised you actually win money whenever you finish a fight, along with Chocobo racing that makes you earn things you can resell for a lot of money. It makes it easier than in the first game.Some people probably enjoy it. Personally, it's definitely not what I expected from a Final Fantasy.

FFXIII - 2 is an alright game. It's certainly worse than XIII, but it is not bad.The game play is almost the exact same as XIII, but with a few good improvements. You can attack an enemy before an encounter to get a bonus, rather than having to sneak up behind them. Instead of having 6 people in your party, you only have two, and can switch monsters out in a third slot. The Crystarium leveling system is imo a downgrade from FFXIII because it is hard to tell what leveling up gets you, but one good thing about is that it lets you build the characters more than XIII did.The story of XIII-2 is not that grea. It's hard to write a good time travel story. They did OK with it, but a lot of the time you'll be like "oh come on." The best part of the story is the relationship between Noel, Caius, and Yuel, and also Lightning and Serah, but it feels like you have to peel off so many other layers of the story till you get to the good stuff.The port of XIII-2 is worse than XIII, but if you use RTSS to cap the FPS to 30, set the GFX settings as low as you can in the launcher, and install LAA (found here  then its a playable experience. Make sure you have a controller too, or you'll get bad stuttering.Overall, if you liked XIII, I would recommend you play this game. The game play is good, and the story is just ok, but there are some moments in this game, especially towards the end, that are incredibly powerful and moving.

I'll start this review with the obvious, that I am sure most reading will have seen time and time again. Yes. The graphical capabilities of this game on the PC are untrue. It runs slower than 60fps, sometimes dropping quite low in more intense battles / larger view battles. This is nota fault of anyone's PC, but how the game was programmed with the PS3 in mind, a poor architecture. It does not make use of the full capabilities of GPUs or Multi-core CPUs, therefore it will run similarly on older computers as it might on a state of the art. The software is the limit, not the hardware.That said, I do have an older PC. I played in a 720P window at that resolution using the smallest shadow-map, and 2x MPAA. It ran alright for the most part. As I said, it had it's slow moments, but was hardly unplayable as some might have suggested. I do play modern games at post 60fps, but do not find low FPS to be a kill all. I could probably have upped the shadow and AA and still been fine. No crashes, no critical flaws to the game in that regard. I could have been lucky, but that was my experience.Now then, on to the game review itself. Would I recommend this game? Yes.The story I find rather touching, if a little too sappy at times. I don't find it really killed the story of the first, but rather fleshes it out. The combat remains quite close to Final Fantasy 13, which is a plus, albiet there are times when I felt it was overly easy comparatively(explained later). The 'time-traveling' and 'gate-closing' mechanics give you chances to go back and redo areas to complete them differently where available. Unlike Final Fantasy 10-2, you do not need to replay the game through from the start multiple times to see everything. You will need to replay sections, but so far nothing I have seen too much repeating. The world is definitely more 'open' than it was in the first game. There is more to explore than narrow hallways. Still very closed in spaces comapred to /world maps/ in the older games, but better.Now for the things I did not care for. "Ease" of Battles:Battling in 13 seemed a bit more tactical than it is in 13-2. I attribute this to the libra spell which you could cast at will in the first game. In this game, there are librascopes you can find or buy for exorbitant prices about mid-game, but no actual simple libra-spell to get data on monsters initially. This means the game can't be too harsh for not paying complete attention to the monsters while you fight them. Without foreknowledge of the enemies, you just have to constantly hit them until information is revealed, often through multiple encounters. If you don't avoid fighting a long way through the game, most your 'random' battles until the very end will revolve around three commandos just nuking everything with blitz and ruinga. Auto-battle will be used overall, as very rarely do you need to worry about selecting proper skills.Not to say that there are no times it's better to manually control, especially if less than ideally leveled, but mostly that revolved around me applying proper debuffs to certain enemies. In that regard though, I felt a lot of the battles could just be brute-forced compared to 13, with only a few that it really mattered to focus on it all. Many times, if you didn't care about time too much, having a strong sentinal member(not too hard to get early on, and upgrade later) could really ease it.Speaking of character classes... The '3rd wheel' as it were of your 3rd party member. Rather than a single character with multiple classes, you capture and raise various monsters for the roles. Each monster only has a single role, and you can only have 'equipped' 3 monsters at a time to fill various roles. For the most part, this isn't a big deal... Raising them isn't too specifric unless you need uber monsters to help the uber enemies situation. Even then, I don't see the value in perfectly upgraded partners.And speaking up upgrades... The crysterium is very lack luster to me compared to the first game. I liked how you could choose which class to level in what order in the first game, but each character would ultimately max out at a certain stat level when all was finished. In the first game, you had a max level for a given area, which forced more strategy on the player as they could no brute force it as much. This game? Regular battles are basically infinite CP batteries. You will be maxed well before the end of the game, unless you really rush. How you level though, is is a single crysterium for all classes on each character. Depending which class you level though at different points in the crysterium(including even/odd levels on some classes) gives different bonus stats. In short, there is an ideal way of leveling each character, while others could leave you with somewhat less than great stats, depending which all you leveled. Nothing game-breaking, but if you are a perfectionist, prepare to study and research ideal leveling order.Lastly, a few of the 'fragments' in the game are a real time-sink and pain to get. Grinding certain enemies to get a lot of gil to just dump. At one point, taping a button on the controller down on the slot machines just to make sure I win a certain amount over a few hourts while I browsed the web. Battling every enemy at least once, including rare enemies and some that have a 50% chance of not spawning at all on a run through an area before you have to reset the area and try again. Making sure to explore every last detail of every map for 100% completion. Just... tedium work, really.That aside, I do not regret this purchase. It fixes some of the problems I had with FF13, but introduces different naggings. Despite my naggins though, I felt compelled to play it through and enjoyed the ride. A few points that were dull busy work, but overall a fun game. Just be prepared to look to the next game if you want any sort of conclusion, because this one literally pulls a Halo 2 with a "To Be Continued..."

In comparison to FF13, we are given a ton more free roam this time. The images on missions typically tell you where to go and for the story you just need to pay attention except about mid-game, you have to go through wild artefact portals till you find the right one which if you are unlucky, will be the very last one and make you go find more wild artefacts first. Another massive change is instead of having a large party, you play as either Serah or Noel and also have 1 animal companion which has its own rule, can be upgraded etc. Most encounters in the game can be turned into an assistant character for your 3rd slot.The story concept focuses on time travel and rifts so it can get very confusing but also a change to the typical Final Fantasy. The theme is what I would call despair, so it is more sad oriented rather than a happy fantasy and this concept is used throughout the whole story. You have the option to revert all progress in that map which is useful so you can never really mess up and only need to do a single play through + revert time to accomplish everything. The battle system is the same as FF13, just a more polished UI and for the most part, the game is easier and requires less grinding and there are less gaps in stats between you and the enemy. There are not many choices for equipment this time as the weapons you get are very linear and you just buy these from the store. The other equipabbles are accessories which each have a consumption value and you have a maximum value that you can fill up with accessories. There is no upgrading this time, so if any aspect of this game is linear, it would be the items you get.The music is what is truely amazing throughout the whole game and what really makes it enjoyable. There is an easy option so if you want to experience the soundtrack and just play the story, that would be a possibility.The puzzles... well the clock one can be really annoying and gets very tedious, there is a site on Google that you can put in the values and get the solution if these gets frustrating or tedious. The platform and connect the dots are more enjoyable.There are 2 technical issues encountered, one is the regular fps drops which is mostly during free-roam, so it doesn't ruin anything. Cutscenes and battles never were affected for me. The other issue is rather annoying and that is this strange super load static buzz when opening the game. A trip to google will give you the info on setting a certain file to admin which eliminated the noise.Overall it was fun for a playthrough, the music was the highlight of it all, the combat entertaining, story decent enough. Playing as Serah in her swimsuit was fun too. Noel can go away though, he reminds me of Sora from Kingdom Hearts with the voice of Tidus from FF10. Caius was cool.Personal experience score: 9/10Story: 8/10 - Can be confusing because it is based on time travelling between rifts, but it was something different and better than FF13. A lot more despair in this one though which is why it intrigues me.Sound: 10/10 - The soundtrack shines pretty quickly with some epic and intense music that rivals FF14 primal fights,Graphics: 8/10 - Great improvement from FF13 PS3 version. However it has quite a few fps drops while free roaming.Controls: 9/10 - Pretty much what you know from FF13, switching between roles for those large attacks can be annoying when you have to move fast and scroll through the list.Game Length: 10/10 - 40 hours of content about if you do a large portion of the adventuring and collecting. A bit more if you want to get max gear and do the super bosses in the colliseum.

I own this for my PS3 and decided to get it on PC. 100% trophies then, going to get 100% achievements now. Anyways, to review the fact that it is a port, it's not bad. It's crashed twice within a couple of hours (near the beginning of the second chapter), and has gotten slightly choppy in a few cutscenes (maybe 15-20fps). I have the game on full settings, which would be 1080p, 16xAA, and 8K shadowing. The main components of my system are...AMD FX 8370 Eight-Core 4.0GHzXFX Nvidia Geforce GTX 970 4GB16 GB 1600MHz RAMWindows 10 64-BitSo, seeing as how I can make almost ultra settings in the new Doom, it should've fully worked for a game several years old. It does, it's fully playable, it's just that the odd massive effect(s) can get in the performance's way. I'm setting compatibilty to Windows 7, so I'll update if it has a lack of crashing. I heard Windows 10 started it. EDIT: Still crashes. Not every few minutes or anything, but I think it may have something to do with autosaves.IMPORTANT EDIT: While inconvienent, there is a way to stop the game's crashing. Just disable it's cloud saving within it's properties in Steam. Never crashed again. How to fix the frames? Don't get cocky with your computer. I know, the game should be high-end friendly, but it isn't. Lower the shadow resolution (4K works decent for me). 8K can actually be a bit too crisp with shadows, so like PC Gamer mentioned, use 2K - 4K. As much as some complain about the graphics altogether, deal with it. Games are supposed to be fun, not just pretty. That's why I hate mentioning graphic quality when it's not necessary.The other problem with it's porting would be the interface/messages. Myself, and I'm sure many others, use the 360 controller. It works great. Feels just like the console. The problem is, the game doesn't care. It has a controller layout screen in the title's settings, but every in-game message will tell you commands for the keyboard. You'll have to realize that the in game controller showing setting will need to be changed, as well as the title (at least, that's the only way it worked for me). The keyboard controls look like crap too, so I fully recommend controller.Were I not to talk about it being a port, I'd give it a 9/10. Some days, I may change my mind and say 8/10, but it's still really good. It fixes the main-character-game-over problem from the first game, and adds a monster using ability. The random-enconter fashion it uses is cool to experience for people wanting somewhat old-game type random encounters (not exactly the same). The part about it I love the most is the reality/time travel. It's really neat to go to some of the same places in the future/past or after a different event happens that would change the future.Negatives? Well, you still have to understand a little bit about FFXIII. Like the Fal-Cie, the Cocoon, and so on. They're not too important, but it's just good to know some of these things in order to understand a few conversations. My reason for this being a negative is that I never came to understand everything in the first game, so recognizing it now, especially after a couple of years away from it, is hard. The other negative? Well, it has a sequel. A crappy one. I really want to explain my reason as to why I mention this, but that would involve telling a bit about the story, and I don't want to put out spoilers.Anyways, great game, recommend to any RPG player without a picky, Square-hating, closed-in mind. I know a few. They're terrible to talk to about FF games.Oh, and you have to press ESC to exit. No menu selection. Just thought I'd add that.

I enjoyed XIII, but XIII-2 falls short of the first one for me, badly.---------------Here's why;They exchanged linearity for total confusion, a big cast of enjoyable playable characters for two bad memes and a third party member for a totally unnecessary pokémon catching grind-fest.Environments are re-used several times, combat is still all "auto-battle" and the repeating soundtrack was actively annoying.Completionists out there have many hours of finding hidden objects ahead of them.I thought the story was kooky and full of plot holes, like some bad fan fiction, and the translation to english is yet again awful. by any means - it does have some emotional story moments (albeit existing in an ocean of WTF) - it's just so difficult to recommend to people, particularly if you have limited gaming time.I'd rather give this a thumbs sideways than a thumbs down.

Playing this game right after finishing a completionist run of FFXIII it's really apparent just how much they changed for the better compared to the original. The story pacing is much better and the plot isn't nearly as convoluted as the first game, your party is no longer a revolving door of people, side quests are varied and include more story rather than just being kill quests, and the endgame/postgame has a whole host of objectives rather than just farming turtles for hours on end for gil and cp.I wasn't sure how I would feel about monster capturing being introduced into the game but they're well incorporated into the gameplay. You can do as much or as little as you want to finish the story and even for the end/postgame objectives there's a bunch of monsters aimed at mid-endgame growth that require less resources to level but can easily help you conquer all end/postgame tasks for the achievements. And for those who really love monster capturing/raising there's a fairly in-depth system for raising and tweaking your monsters to build them out just the way you want.The devs also did a great job in adding fragment skills which are accessible as your collect more fragments and progress the game. These include: increasing or decreasing the encounter rate, increasing cp gain, and increasing monster capture chances among other perks. Having a system in the game to tweak playstyle preferences as a reward for completing side objectives in the game is a really great idea and something I think other JRPGs should implement more often.My one and only gripe with the game is the optimization. There is a great guide here on steam that provides solutions to fix or mitigate issues the game has but it's a shame that fan-made patches are required at all to make the game function as it should. A problem that cropped up somewhat frequently was reduced frame rate, it was never unbearable but it wasn't pleasant. Thankfully this only occurred in the most populated of areas even though I have a PC that's 4-5 years old at this point. During my roughly 50 hours of playtime I only had the game hard crash on me once after applying the fan-made patches, which I think is a pretty good shout out to the effectiveness of the fan-made solutions.All in all it's a shame that not many people played this game due to the reputation that the first game garnered from fans. But for anyone that enjoyed or didn't mind the shortcomings of the first game, or is even just interested in revisiting these games, XIII-2 was a very enjoyable journey from beginning to end and in my opinion worth checking out.

I want to preface this review by saying that I love the Lightning Trilogy so much. I know that Square Enix bit more than what they can chew in creating the then-hyped Fabula Nova Crystallis category of games, one of which became a game wholly separated from the series. I was one of the people who saw the games as it is: a series with an overarching, epic narrative that spanned three games with a polarizing yet actually sensible RPG battle system, and an iconic, very shoddy camerawork that I eventually learned to block out as I read the menus and the incoming enemy abilities.With that said: Man, this port really sucks. I love that all the DLCs were there, but man, it's not a very forward-compatible port. At least Square Enix did attempt to fix NieR:Automata but this game I feel like there's a snowball's chance in hell that this game's eventually getting fixed. It becomes playable despite the massive framedrops in several instances (such as Aerora spam during Ravager mode, exploring Academia, and some generally downscaled and framelocked cutscenes)--but only if you actually went your way to install fixes and mods to make the game seem as fluid as it can be. If there comes a time where Square Enix actually decides to release a Lightning Trilogy remaster, that's the only time I can actually forsee that they'll get these games--both the original and this game--fixed.

Certified banger, takes everything good about the first game and runs with it. No more going through 2 whole chapters before unlocking the game's primary mechanics, instead you'll find everything you need within the first hour and the rest of the game is spent trying to use and abuse those mechanics to get to the end. One new one that I loved is the monster pack system, which gives you a chance to recruit enemies to your party. They do a great job of making your party feel more personalized throughout, which is nice :) It also helps that the story feels a lot more immediate than the first game, with a more compelling villain than the one from the first game that gives the final boss gauntlet a lot more OOMPH. On top of that, the soundtrack is a banger, full of poppy, vocal tracks that make exploring feel all the more breezy. Oh yeah, this game has exploring too. I love 13, but going from its hallways to this game's open levels is going to make it hard to ever touch 13 again.My only qualms are that the visuals seem like they've taken a hit in some places and that the combat feels less responsive. If you queued up all your abilities in 13 Lightning would go as soon as her ATB filled. In 13-2 Serah and Noel feel like they sometimes delay their actions for up to a couple seconds after their ATB fills, which feels less punishing here because combat seems a bit slower, but it's still not good. It also makes the classic ATB refresh strategy way less effective, which sucks because that always felt good to do well in the first game. Oh, and the clock puzzles suck, if you're having trouble with them just search for a 13-2 clock puzzle solver, that's what I did.All-in-all it's a great game and has already cemented itself as one of my favorite in the franchise.

After the atrocious first entry in the "XIII series", I layed my hands upon XIII-2 and oh boy, I was surprised. Unlike its predecessor, this feels like a JRPG. You can travel freely and are not restricted to a one-way street anymore. You get cities with NPCs roaming around. The battle system is not much deeper but with the new monster system, they added a cool feature. Unfortunately next to one active monster you only get two characters, Serah and Noel. Serah is sweet and lovely just like in the first game but Noel is your standard cookie-cutter JRPG hero with some neat details here and there. But one of the most important additions to the XIII series: The battle doesn't end when your active characters die. This time around it swaps to your other character and only if that one dies as well it is game over. So you have some time to resurrect your fallen party member. Too bad there are some mega attacks again that insta-kills your whole squad when you're lower than 70%-80% hp. But as far as I can say this is only in the last boss battle. Also, the grinding is less noticeable here because you have to backtrack every now and then. The problem is that at one point in the story you have to have enough keys to open portals to (what I thought at first) optional areas. Looks like some of them contain very important objects. And since you never know to what area a new portal will lead you to have to get lucky or own all those precious keys. And they are well hidden at times. All around the world are translucent objects and containers you can reveal with your Moogle. And oh boy they are hard to spot sometimes. Unfortunately, most of the side quests rely on this mechanic so I hope you have good eyes. But at least it got neat side quests. (I look at you FFXIII Archylte Steppe). Once again all levels look great with different looks and feel. They get rehashed but it's okay considering the plot. And yes story. Although it is muuuch better than Final Fantasy XIII´s mess of Fal'Cie, L'Cie and more it is still a tad convoluted. But because the story is sprinkled nicely in between the chapters and different areas I pretty much enjoyed it. The whole game just feels more complete and well thought out. Somehow the battles feel more fun, although they are practically random encounters. And the music is also fantastic again. A tad too much singing though but most of the time it fits. XIII-2 is in fact a huge step up from the first game but not a perfect Final Fantasy game. If you want to catch up on the franchise I would recommend skipping FFXIII.

Compatibility:Worked well with no lag for my Windows 7 desktop with a Radeon HD6900. No problems with my Windows 7 laptop with a GeForce GTX860M. Steam cloud sync works perfectly and I am able to play the game on both rigs perfectly, except for that one time when my internet was down and the cloud sync did not work (duh). You can play it offline and it will sync once you have internet again.Having a playstation controller is highly recommended to enjoy the game!! Don't listen to keyboard players who complain about a game made for a PS controller.Battle System: This is the best part of the game! As someone who has played FF6 - 9, the battle system of FFXIII-2 was extremely refreshing and challenging. Throughout the battles, you will need to switch between modes in order to damage, mitigate damage, debuff and buff your party, failing which you will just die. And die again. And again. Fortunately, when you die you will be given the option to respawn at the same point prior to the battle or retry the battle, which saves alot of time. Also, if you think you're gonna lose the battle, simply press start and retry to have another shot at it.You get a chance to tame monsters after you have defeated them. Catch em, level them and infuse their abilities to other monsters to create your own unique monster!If you're looking for a game that you could simply press O and you could cruise through battles with ease, this is not for you. Go play dota 2 or something.Levelling System: You earn crystarium points after battles or side quests and can use it to level up your party's crystarium, gaining new abilities etc. Level up wisely in order to maximise your stat gains!Story: The storyline feels kind of lame and slow at the start, but believe me when I say the character story developers did a fantastic job of making me have dem feels for both the protagonist and the villain. BTW, there are multiple hidden endings for the game if you can defeat / unlock them, or you could just youtube it if you're lazy.Sidequests:CHOCOBO RACING AND A CASINO! You also get all the additional digital downloadable content Square Enix launched after you complete the game!Music / Soundtrack:After playing the game, I purchased the OST from ebay. The music made for this game is phenomenal. Lolz were had when I rode the red chocobo for the first time.Overall:Just play it, you will like it. Unless you dont like chocobos or behemoths fighting for you, then fine, you win.

Warning. This is a personal review. Everyone has their own opinions and Mine are just shown throughout this review.If you did not play the first game do not worry you are not missing out too much.HOWEVER This game is much more open compared to the significantly linear FF13. I believe that is one reason why people hated the first game.This game will use various tactics to keep you from progressing at a later point in the game which really will annoy anyone who plays this game. The puzzle challenges for example are by far the most annoying additions to this game.COULD BE LIKE ANY OTHER FF GAME WITH A BOSS BUT NO. PUZZLE CHALLENGES ARE ALL THE RAGE.Seriously, that crap made me stop playing. And sure I could go and watch someone do them, but I'd rather do it myself, especially seeing as my network connection isnt that great especially with video content.ANYWAY other than the annoyancesFor the good things so far-RESOLUTIONS: CAN CHANGE TO SOMETHING OTHER THAN 720p-A lot of elements from the first game reappear, giving you some idea just how the first game went.-A LOT of crap people hated in the first game is fixed (Like, if the leader dies, it used to be game over, yeah no, thats gone now)-If you have played Tales of Symphonia 2 THIS GAME FEELS SLIGHTLY LIKE ITWell in battle that is. You will only have two playable characters, and other characters like Snow joining in, but not in the party as they are not of the same timeline.-You will also be able to collect monsters to help in battle which is cool.Oh they also troll you a bit by making the game look like an older FF tittle, (like with an actual level system) But its not.-You get all DLC from the ps3 version included too!TL:DR the game is vastly more simplified than the original, My guess is the creators saw how annoying the first game was and aimed to change it up somewhat.The bad-THERE IS NO LINUX PORT. STEAM TROLLS YOU.-Character selection and world/timeline selection can be a pain to deal with at first and for some reason to me if feels like I'm playing kingdom hearts in a way due to Noels looks, however like all games you play for hours, you will get used to it.-The AI has a mind of its own, screwing up story lines, in more than one way.--Becareful how you talk to people, the camera may be in an odd position-Grinding does help lots here, ESPECIALLY WHEN THE GAME TROLLS YOU TO TAKE ON BOSSES WAY HIGHER LEVEL INSTEAD OF GOING THROUGH THE WHOLE MISSON TO MAKE IT EASIER.-Graphics options are available although limited. SE seemed to have borrowed the settings changer that was created for the first game, however I will say one thing.. >>There is no option to change the texture quality, so you WILL NEED A HIGH END PC FOR THIS GAME<<-Even though its a PS3 Port, the game has a significant performance hit even on low settings. So if you played the first game, thinking you can play the second one easily, think again.-The AUTOSAVE FEATURE WILL KILL YOU: By being stressed out, as for some reason steam needs to be not only online and active, but if steam gets disconnected, the game will LOCK UP DURING AUTOSAVE MOMENTS. Just keep that in mind if you have a faulty internet connection or you are playing during times where steam goes down for repairs.-----------------------------------------------------Over all I have nothing really bad to say about this port. This game  does however raise the question on if i shall buy the third installment of FF13 as even though the first game was mainly linear, I preferred it over this one currently. There is alot Square could do to make this game better and a lot of things that i hope do not transition to FF15 when it does arrive, assuming it comes out for PC. anywho gameplay wise It is much better to play over the original, and even though there could be a few more fixes here and there. I'm sure with the right system you would be able to play this game maxed out, however currently this game is as demanding as something like witcher 2 So keep that in mind when trying to play this game.Also for you tech heads out there, this game is multi(meaning 2) threaded.High clocked strong CPU cores are recommended. (so FX minumum, Intel core i7 or something above 4ghz)GPU Wise: RADEON HD 7870/7790 and above / NVidia GTX 750 TI and above (for 1080p gameplay)Ram isn't really an issue, so minimum being 3gb, lol.

This sequel offers improvements over everything from the past game.Gameplay-wise, there's much more side content, and less tedious and not grindy at all compared to XIII. There are NPCs to talk to (even though very few and without deep dialogue options). You're not locked to anything by progressing the story, thus you can revisit all the places you've already visited whenever you want.Combat is improved with Quality of Life changes and the introduction of a monster collection mechanic acting as your third party member: you can farm monsters and "spend" them on other monsters to give their auto-abilities, something that people who love micro-optimization in their characters will definitely love. Though, there are some monsters you can only get once, and the game does not warn you about this. I've noticed a difficulty spike only toward the final chapter of the game, hinting at collecting more Fragments, which essentially are what you get through side content - getting all 160 of them is required to 100% the game and learn the most about it. Not all DLCs from the console version are included, but they are good, and the modding community was able to restore those not included.On the narrative side of things, this game introduces the two most important characters of the trilogy, Caius and Yeul (together with Noel), who are very well characterised and likeable characters. The characterization of Serah, the main protagonist alongside Noel, is not too good or deep. The game also presents alternate endings as side content, though they're not too important, with the exception of the secret cutscene you get by unlocking and viewing all of them.As with the first game, the presentation of information is not well managed. lots of info is dumped into the in-game Archive. There are two novels of this game, "Final Fantasy XIII-2 Fragments Before", meant to be read after playing Final Fantasy XIII, before XIII-2, and "Final Fantasy XIII-2 Fragments After", meant to be read after completing XIII-2. I found the narrative relevance of this two novels high and great compared to the novel of XIII.Graphics are good but heavily damaged compared to the original console release, with several bugs, some of which the modding community managed to fix. Soundtrack is great and dub are great.The PC port of this game is the worst of the three. It comes with big, big graphics fidelity issues, and optimization feels non existant -- this game runs the worst of all three.I do still recommend this game on PC, if you have a powerful enough machine.  Mods improve the game a lot and the modding community is amazing. If you do not possess a good enough PC, the console version is still a good option. If you play the Xbox 360 version on Series X/S you also get 4K and 60 fps, even though I do not know if it's a consistent framerate or not.

Do you know how there are some games that are so, so bad, but you keep going on anyway, hating every second of it, just to see it through the end? This is one of those games. I’ve played every FF game up until XV, and this must be the one I hated the most.Here are my thoughts on this disaster of a game:It seems like they had absolutely no idea on how to progress the story after 13’s ending, so they made a filler game until they could come up with something. And it’s not an engaging and fun filler, mind you. They decided to include the overused time-travel trope in the story, out of nowhere, without any cool gimmicks. So, what happens is: you keep going back and forward between the same places on different time dimensions to complete quests and then advance the game. FF XIII’s story is not that great, I agree. However, even though the narrative could get quite confusing at times, it still made  sense. I knew more or less what I was doing and why. It still got me to the point of “ok, I’m intrigued, let’s play the following one to see what happens next”. But, on this game? Holy cow. Some random dude fell out of the sky and then told you that both of you must start travelling back in time to chase another random dude that also came out of nowhere but guess what, he’s actually responsible for the whole time-travel thing and probably for what happened to your sister as well, and you need to defeat him because…well, he’s saying all those cheesy bad guy lines, so he’s the villain, I guess. And let’s not forget a lot of retcon thrown into the mix. It really looks like bad fan-fiction.Oh, did you want to know what happened to the characters after XIII’s ending? We’ll get to that, poor thing! Forget about it for now and let’s switch the focus for 30h so we can play time-travel with Pokémon. Yeah, that’s right. It’s a mess. You only have two characters for the whole game, so there’s not a lot you can do for specializations, builds and stuff. You just have to keep levelling up and getting 200 skills from different roles, which you won’t use half of by the way, but you need them to get passive attribute increases. You don’t even have to think about it for the most part. Oh, and there are some quick-time events that you have to hit during some of the battles too! I had absolutely no fun in battles. The previous game offered much more of a challenge, while this one is just a watered-down version of it.And did I mention Pokémon? Yeah, they came up with a monster capturing system that lets you tame random monsters to be your third party member, and they have their own skills and levelling system. Sounds cool and complex, right? Yes, until you realise how poorly implemented the system is. At first, I was like “oh boy, maybe I can get some monster with some useful ability like a heal, I have to pay attention with their levelling so they develop well…”. But then I realised how bad their A.I. was to do anything besides attacking whatever enemy was in front of them. So, I just got the biggest monster I could find (a behemoth), spent their levelling points on whatever could increase attack power, and that was it for the whole game. At least the monster could have some usefulness as a dumb DPS for the group. I thought Vann was the most boring main character from the series. Up until now. The two protagonists from this game have not captivated me at all, in any sense; personality, values, goals, charisma, nothing. So, you can imagine how mind-numbing it was spending 40h with them and suffering through their cheesy dialogue. It felt like watching a really bad movie, the kind you keep watching to see if it could have some big plot-twist at the end, or if the characters would have some growth. But the big moment never came, and the characters stayed one-dimensional forever.I would not recommend this game to any FF fan. Not even to any JRPG fan in general. I would go as far as to say that, if you’ve played the previous game, skip this one entirely and go play the next one; it will make no difference other than like 2 paragraphs of actual continuation story you can read online so you don’t need to play 40h of filler for it. The third game has its own problems with its story going a different way, I’ll admit that, but it still makes more sense as a sequel than this one, while also being absolutely miles ahead in terms of fun gameplay. I couldn’t wait for this game to end so I could move on and never play it again.The pros? Well, the music is nice. They don’t usually mess that up.

Final Fantasy XIII - Part 2-kupo!This game picks up right after the first one, however this time you don't play as Lightning, but her younger sister Serah. After the events of the first game, Lightning is missing, and everyone except for Serah seems to have forgotten all about her. One day when a meteor falls from the sky, Serah encounters Noel, a man from the future who says he has brought a message to her from Lightning. Along with the cute creature Mog they set out on a mission to find Lightning, and stop whoever is messing up the timeline, travelling to the past, the future, and even alternate timelines in order to do so.The fighting is similar to the first game. Both characters can be assigned any one of six different roles which can be used to form various paradigms (formations), and you can freely jump from one paradigm to another as many times as you like during combat.Unlike the first game however this time you only have two controllable characters. The third party slot is filled by any wild monster that you managed to capture after defeating it. Each monster has one specific role, can be upgraded by using materials, and can even gain new abilities by absorbing other monsters. While I personally preferred just having three playable characters in the party, the new monster system is decent as well once you get the hang of it.Other than that the two games are fairly similar, however here are a couple of other differences:- In the first game when your party leader died, you would lose. Now, as long as one of the two main characters stay alive, the fight goes on.- Puzzles. There are plenty of puzzles throughout the second game. There are three puzzle types in total, each ranging from easy to hard difficulty. Some of the puzzles can be a bit challenging, but they never get  hard, and I thought they were a nice bonus. You also have a couple of mini-games mixed in, like Chocobo racing and slot machines.- Weapons and accessories are much more basic this time, and there is no need to run around farming materials in order to upgrade them. You  need materials to upgrade your monsters, but it's far from as grindy as the material gathering in the first game.Now, for my main complaint about this game: It is sooo poorly optimized. Saving to the Steam Cloud will usually crash the game (so you have to turn of the Steam Cloud and save locally). Taking screenshots might crash the game, which sucks since the game looks gorgeous. Minimizing the game might crash the game. Even just walking through a door crashed my game once. In addition to the crashing, the resolution settings are broken. In order to get the game to look good on my monitor (1440p) I had to set the resolution to 4k, preferably 5k. However by doing this the game would not let me take any screenshots, and minimizing the game would cause it to crash even more frequently.I could make some other complaints, like the inclusion of Wild Artefacts, which are keys used to open time gates. The problem with that is that they are located in the most random places across several different zones. And oh yes, they are also transparent. If I hadn't looked it up online I would never have been able to find them all...Still, since I enjoyed the game a lot, and my only (main) complaint is that it's a very poor port, I definitely recommend Final Fantasy XIII-2. Just remember to play the first one first. And know that you will probably have to play the third one to know how the story really ends. And (since some people might get fooled by the picture at the top of the page) you do not get to play as Lightning in this game (unless you play the DLC).If those terms are acceptable then no need to hesitate any longer. Just buy the game.

As you might recall, Final Fantasy XIII was pretty much reviled everywhere. As a response, Square-Enix released a sequel that promised to fix everything that was wrong with the previous game. Did it work?Yeah....sorta.The first thing that is immediately apparent with the game is that there is no longer any linearity. In fact, the game is the opposite of XIII, with both the story and game systems taking a free-form approach, allowing you to level your characters the way you want, and tackle the story chapters with quite a bit of degree of freedom, though this freedom also means there's some tedious back&forth in some sections.Speaking of story...it's still nonsensical, with a LOT of reading done through datalogs to get the gist of it,like XIII was.Liked it more than XIII, but that's mostly due to being a sucker for sci-fy plots (like time-travel), and for .Graphically, the game's a bit worse than XIII, but nothing serious that could distract you.Some places look just as great as XIII did (Academia looks pretty gorgeous). Graphical Settings are a exact carbon copy from XIII, with nothing to set both of 'em apart in that regard (patch for XIII released at the same time as this released). The performance did change though...for the worse. This game runs even worse than XIII did, on the exact same hardware.I usually don't mention audio, but Final Fantasy games in general are known to have good soundtracks, and XIII & XIII-2 are no exceptions. Special mention goes to that ridiculous chocobo metal song, it's just too silly to not like it!So, the tl,dnr: improved sequel marred yet again by performance issues. Buy it if you're a fan &/or is on sale.PS: Same regional restrictions that applied to XIII applies here. Asian version is restricted to the Asian region.Get the Western version if you want an unrestricted version.(Source:  )

TL;DR - The port is bad, the game is good.SPOILER FREE REVIEW****If you're wondering about my hours played, like FINAL FANTASY XIII, I have spent nearly 200 hours on the console version, so I can talk gameplay with a sense of where I'm coming from.If you read my last review on FINAL FANTASY XIII, I gave the game a pretty good review about it. Despite some performance issues that at least had the chance to be fixed, this PC port of FINAL FANTASY XIII-2 doesn't give you the same freedom. Let's talk about the port first - why is it bad? A lot of the game's visuals are a little subpar comapred to its console counterpart, but what really gets to me right now in my first 50 minutes in the game is the quality of the audio. The audio for everything except the soundtrack is all muffled and in poor quality, a complete downright shame which can really, really ruin the game for some. The soundtrack in FFXIII-2 is just fine though, no issues there. But I would suggest avoid playing with a headset, as hearing how muffled and poor some of the voices were done might just put you off.Now on to the game itself. When FFXIII was released, a major complaint was that it was mainly all hallways and corridors all the way up to Chapter 11, when you reached an open world area and where you would spend most of your time playing the game ultimately. In FFXIII-2, this issue is fixed, much to the delight of those giving the XIII series another chance. Straight away, in the starting area of the game, you'll get the chance to explore all the nooks and crannies of the town, really giving away the sense of exploration and detail in each individual map. The game, is always in the XIII series, looks gorgeous. From the sights of the Archlyte Steppe to Cocoon, each environment is captured with a sense of beauty and detail.Gameplay wise, the core aspect of Paradigms and Auto Battle is the same. But, if you read my review on FFXIII, you'll know what I'm going to say here. FFXIII-2's biggest flaw with gameplay can be fixed with a simple tick of a button in the options menu - the Default to Abilities. Many players went through FFXIII and FFXIII-2 using Auto Battle, complaining at how easy and boring the game was when what they were actually doing was playing the game at half it's potential. Set the option to Default to Abilties, and give yourself a challenge in this game. The Paradigm system is one of my favourite battle systems in the FINAL FANTASY franchise for a reason - give yourself the chance to play the game.Overall, the port of this game does the actual game no justice at all - FINAL FANTASY XIII-2 fixes many of the problems encountered in FINAL FANTASY XIII, and is always a worthy addition to the legendary roster of JRPGS. Unfortunately, much to my dislike, I'll have to vote aganst buying this game purely because of the poor port. Maybe in time, when Square releases a performance patch, this game will become recommended, but at the moment, it's another game ruined by poor ports.

Yes, the port itself is an abomination, and impossible to recommend to someone without knowing how comfortable they are patching it into a playable state. Almost 2000 other Steam reviews will tell you all about it, and how to circumvent it, but there's more going on here.The core game is a dramatic upgrade from 13-1 in every category, except maybe for music. The character dialogue, environments, set-pieces, and story are greatly improved overall. The combat, for the most part, is quite a bit easier than in the first game, but that's mostly owing to it actually working as intended here. The monster diversity and levelling system is decent enough. The weapon and accessory selection is a little myopic, but not worse than the pointless mess in 13-1.However, gating achievements, the hidden ending, and certain fragments behind massive amounts of backtracking, guide bait Wild Artefacts, exceptionally hostile casino RNG and 100% bestiary completion badly soured the overall experience by the end of it, and unfortunately nudge this game, which I might have otherwise recommended in spite of the unacceptable port, into negative territory.Unless you're on some crazy mission to complete every Final Fantasy game, you're probably safe giving 13-2, especially this version of it, a wide miss.
