Upon finishing and quite enjoying XIII (performance issues and slightly obtuse story aside), I decided to see what XIII-2 was about. Sadly, as soon as it launched I ran into a very annoying audio buzzing (fixed by disabling Windows Sonic for Headphones oddly). The issues didn't stop there. I don't have the highest end PC but it definitely falls within the recommended specs on the store page, yet the game's frame rate was truly appalling, even for enclosed areas. In the starting area of New Bodham the game would freeze entirely and just crash - I know there are some community fixes for common problems, but I just wanted to play the game, not diagnose various bugs and faults. Normally, I'm willing to accept some issues and rough edges, especially for a game that was released some time ago, but frankly it's just unplayable in its current state.

Constant freeze on loading screen (more than 15 minutes long). Dev doesn't give a damn about fixing this with a patch. If you have permanent solution, or happens to be the lucky ones, go ahead. But for safety measures, I don't recommend this broken game.UPDATE - MARCH 30TH 2020Before you try what I did to fix this below. If you're using only 1 Audio Playback AND using Realtek High Definition Audio, open your Audio Playback on Realtek Setting, try changing the Speaker Configuration to 5.1 Speaker, and changing your audio format on the Default Format tab to 24 Bits / 44100 Hz (Studio Quality). - P.S. You might need to restart your PC to apply the new changes.If my assumption is correct, the game may not be able to read the audio format differs from that.EDIT - JANUARY 5TH 2020:Funny thing is I found the solution in my case. It circles around the sound devices that were installed in my PC.I have:1. BENQ XL2411P Native speaker (not that big a deal in my problem so just ignore this)2. Speaker - Realtek High Definition Audio [RHDA] (default from PC - And I always use this)3. USB Audio device (for my microphone and additional speaker - I use this for stream / recording)Basically I just disabled everything I didn't use and still use the usual Speaker - Realtek High Definition Audio. It worked okay the first time.But, after PC restarted the next day, the freeze and crash comes back again.So, I found out that the active speakers is messing with FFXIII-2.I have USB Audio Device and Speaker - RHDA plugged in (but using the Speaker as default playback, not USB Audio Device)When the Intro started, I could hear the Music just fine through my speaker, but no character voice despite the subtitle showing on screen. But the plot twist is, the character voice was never gone, it strangely played on my USB Audio Device (I have my headphone plugged in the USB Audio Device). BUT my default device was configured only to my speaker on RHDA!Can you imagine the strange behavior?Music on Speaker, but Character Voice on my Headphone. But the default Audio Playback device is configured to the Speaker - RHDASo what I did was, I unplug my Speaker RHDA and plugged it in to my USB Audio Device, leaving my RHDA unplugged.And BAM! The game just worked flawlessly (playing the game 3 days straight with so many restart to test if this is actually work or not). Apparently the game now read the audio device is only on USB Audio Device.The reason why I plug it into my USB Audio Device is because I use it occasionally for my personal use. So I won't uninstall my USB Audio Device just to play this game.In my case, I do hope SE fix the broken Audio Programming on this game:1. Like in my case, the game became confuse because I have multiple Audio Playback Devices (like wtf?! why would it become confuse? is this some kind of a 20 Years old game when technology on programming was tricky back then?)2. The in-game music is so damn loud, I can't hear voice acting (had to use mod to either Half the Music Volume or turn it off altogether)Get your crap together SE. It's a good game, but not a good port.Even if I get to fix this game for me to play it. It still me and the great guys on modding doing the work and not the company I paid the game for.I still don't recommend this game till they fix the issue themselves. (which probably they will never do, they done milking this game, I guess)Cheers.

I am going to be straight to the point, I think the game isn't bad nor is it good it's definitely not a good sequel but there are ways to enjoy it depending on what you're looking for. I personally think the ending of FF XIII felt complete and mildly satisfying so while there were possible directions a sequel could've explored that could've been interesting this is simply not it. Generally speaking the gameplay is very similar with a few quality of life improvements however the story took a nosedive by introducing time travel and while I generally enjoy the idea when it's done right in this game it's not, I would even say it's a mess for the plot. To be able to enjoy the game it's better to turn off your brain and don't try to make sense of what the game pulls out of nowhere or simply ignore as much of the story as possible and have fun with the gameplay. I certainly couldn't because I play Final Fantasy games for a good story primarily these days and while the pacing issues from the first game are somewhat alleviated the writing took a significant hit in quality. It's also important to understand that by playing this sequel you will have to play Lightning Returns afterwards to get an actual ending since this one is a cliffhanger. The other notable issue is the quality of this port that practically requires you to patch it manually thanks to the community dedicated enough to fix the mess Square Enix left on Steam with bad performance and occasional crashes. Back to the gameplay, combat is pretty much the same but now you're stuck with only 2 characters and back to the monster party member of FF X-2 but less interesting (not like it was interesting to begin with) to fill up the empty space in the group. Character progression is not gated by story progression but it's even more streamlined than before and weapons/accessories can't be upgraded like in the previous game but there are some "crafting" in the shop that needs specific ingredients to purchase some occasional pieces of equipment. About the linearity, the areas are more varied and open and the time travel mechanic that give a level select basically a bunch of locations at different years so with multiple paths you get a bunch of endings which are mostly bad endings but fun I guess to see different outcomes even if the actual ending is obviously the same for everyone. The thing is how time travel is made in this game is kind of boring after a while, you get there you have to solve a time paradox distorting the world, spawning monsters and whatnot but even if the situations are slightly different from one place to another it gets repetitive eventually. The most notable positive change outside of linearity and some side content would be how they finally realised an animation for switching paradigm was a bad idea and now it's instant so you don't get randomly hit by the enemy sometimes. I am struggling to find good things to say because there are not many without repeating some of the goods of the previous game which is pointless in my opinion it boils down to same combat, dumbed down systems and linearity is improved with more exploration and side content to be had (it's not a lot of side content but still it exists).When it comes to the story it's sort hard to say anything positive since most of it is just really weak and disappointing I guess the best part is the villain has a decent motive but his solution is laughable so aside from his good battle theme and alright personality he's forgettable. I complimented the pacing being better but the beginning of the game is still a bit of a "what the hell is going on in this universe" moment in which everyone but Serah forgot the ending of the previous game now they think Lightning wasn't even there. Lightning is in this weird realm fighting big sword Caius with his purple hair and Snow believing Serah isn't insane went to look for her and the rest of the characters are just.. somewhere in the world. The 2 characters, Serah and Noel are kind of bland it's not like they are bad but they are sort of generic and most of their character progression is a bit uninteresting and sometimes okay. I'm generally good at tolerating mediocre writing but I'll admit this one was a chore to finish and my price was a cliffhanger which felt annoying before I was ready to stop there but I wanted to see an actual ending to this mess. Anyways, I would advise not touching this sequel unless you're fine with mediocre writing and more of the same gameplay otherwise you're not missing much. 6/10 for me maybe I would go to 7 if it wasn't for the port quality, I don't think it's acceptable also the music is good (didn't know where to put that lol)

If you liked the first one, you'll like this one better.Gameplay-wise, 13-2 has more meat to its bones than its predecessor (I know, that's not saying much, but still worth mentioning). Story-wise, you'll enjoy it if you're into string theory and quantum mechanics (with some artistic license, obviously, but they took a page or two from actual science). Also, it's refreshing to see a female-male protagonist team that is NOT a couple and a story with a female protagonist WITHOUT love triangles (Lightning in 13-1 didn't count, given how she was the resident grimdork*).* Final Fantasy is formulaic in its team ensemble, the team always has a grimdork, and every so often, this grimdork happens to be the protagonist. In 4 it was Black/White Knight, in 8 it was Squall, and in 13 it was Lightning. Deal with it.The soundtrack is less epic this time around and more on the pop side of things with more songs than melodies but it doesn't detract from the mood, and the world building now spanning over 700 years of history is still pretty solid.Warning 1: Some of the puzzles are unnerving unless you can actually do Linear Programming, so when the dreaded clock puzzles appear, use this link: Warning 2: If you plan to go all the way and get the Hidden Ending, the whole thing becomes a "Gamefaqs Game" (i.e the ONLY way to make heads from tails out of it is reading a guide).All in all, it's a worthy Final Fantasy within the confines of modern-day JPRGs so, if you already have the first one, you won't regret following up (just wait for a Steam sale). Finally, addressing the elephant in the room: is it linear? Well duh! all JRPGs are railroads, and Squeenix' ones doubly so, infuriatingly so, even, so if you're a fan of the publisher or the genre, then you should be long over that one.

Title: This isn't what "Final" means My 24th Final Fantasy, including FF 1-10, 12-13, 14 plus 2 expansions, 15, Legends 1-3, Adventures, Chocobo's Mysterious Dungeon 2, Chocobo Tales for DS, Chocobo Dungeon for Wii, Mystic Quest, Tactics, and Tactics A2, I am an RPG expert and FF expert. A classical 3D JRPG, Final Fantasy XIII is the worst port of any game, computer game or otherwise, I've ever seen.  The game is straight-up unplayable after the first 5-10 minutes without 3rd party patches (techpowerup's Large Address Aware patch, ntcore's 4GB RAM patch,) due to the fact that FInal Fantasy XIII's cutscenes continually wants Windows 10's portion of half a gig of RAM, even though my computer has 48GB of RAM to work with.  Krisan Thyme's patches on Patreon reportedly fixes all minor problems (I have not confirmed any of Krisan's work,) the problems being not excusable in their number, including no XBox 360 controller vibrations on PC, no Xbox button or PlayStation prompts for cutscene triggers, no surround sound, no anisotropic filtering, and the worst, "on-disc" alternate costumes have been disabled, however these are reportedly fixable.Multiple bosses exist to auto-kill you. It's a good thing when it happens once, like "Chrono Trigger" and its boss Lavos, however, I've never seen it multiple times in a single game except once, Suikoken II, and that game was awful.  Additionally, the game throws monsters at drastically different levels at you, with no fences between them, creating a harsh punishment system for refusing to go where the game tells you to go.  Seeing that the game repeatedly gives directions such as "somewhere on this map," these types of mixed signals give the hallmark of a really bad game. The beginning of the game starts with "we're continuing on from last time." which is not a very immersive way to begin a start a story. Players who haven't played FF 13 will miss a lot here, with the entire story going over their heads. The pros include an immense amount of voice acting, on par with Xenosaga Episode I, very addictive gameplay, an easy and calming difficulty level, a new combat system that gives a nod to Final Fantasy Legends I through III (hardcore FF players will know what I'm talking about,) dungeons which give the ability to walk sideways and backwards to end the dungeon, as opposed to running down a long beach or a straight highway to finish a dungeon, the main complaint of Final Fantasy XIII. The voice acting is the same as the previous game. This game is certainly for completionists only, and I wish I could give a thumbs-sideways for this game.  The game surfs the boundaries of kinetic novel, choose-your-own-adventure, and JRPG, this game deserves a negative, but, you know what? It's Final Fantasy.  2 1/2 stars.

The answer for this game is a very tentative maybe, but erring on the side of not recommended. We'll pass over poor porting outright, as a fair amount of that can be mitigated with community fixes. You can see the time I've played and I've done so without a crash. Having said that, be sure you follow the community guides to fix everything before attempting to play the game.As for the game itself-- interesting lore utterly buried behind loading screens, corridor areas, endless fetch quests and hidden easter egg hunts. I see the things they were trying to improve upon from its predecessor, but they failed in pretty much every respect. They could have allowed for an engaging exploration of the twin worlds of Pulse and Cocoon, an investigation into their genesis, symbiosis and ultimate destiny-- instead we got magic time gates with a complete disconnect of past, present and future. It's how you might have expect Chrono Trigger to work out if the person who wrote it was under the influence of crack cocaine: a myriad assortment of what-ifs and contradictions with essentially no relevance so far as the overall plot is concerned.The sheer amount of asset recycling is staggering-- the budget for this game was obviously quite low. Everybody looks the same. Perhaps forgivable in the 8 and 16 bit era, but certainly not beyond. Very little of the music fits what is being conveyed on screen in the slightest with a few notable exceptions. Many of the boss fights feel panicky and rushed. Most of them also require meta knowledge to be successful at. The controls are alright, but the jumping concept seems a bit tacked on-- in many places you can hop up a sheer cliff wall but if the story demands it, a piece of concrete that a child could hop over bars your further progress. One or two inconsistencies like this could be looked over, but this game does this over and over and over again. It becomes grating after a while. My biggest issue personally though is how disjointed the world seems. After all this time, I still have no idea what the geographical layout of either of these worlds looks like. It's just a magical hop from cave to cave without any real sense of where anything is located relative to anything else. This was a serious problem in the original game and was actually made worse in the sequel, hard as that may be to believe. If fetch quests and collecting are your thing, this game is for you. If you like hunting for lore in blobs of text, this game is for you. If you're somewhat of a masochist or otherwise exceptionally bored, this game is for you. Other than that, your money is almost certainly better spent elsewhere [read: taco bell]. If you had to pinpoint the exact spot of terminal decline for the Final Fantasy series, this trilogy is probably it.

The sequel to the controversial FFXIII. I'll say it right now, if you hated FFXIII, stay away from this one. While I feel it's a better game it will not win over people that hated 13-1. In fact this game is hated by a lot of people that liked FF13, so keep that in mind as well.Story: Following the events of FF13, things have begun to go very long, lightning has disappeared and the timeline is in shambles. You play as Serah, Lightning's sister, and a new character Noel. You traverse the timeline fixing anomalies known as paradoxes and attempt to repair the timeline and stop further damage from occurring. This story takes a wildly different direction than the previous game, and while it doesn't work perfect (as time travel rarely does) it's fairly passable.Gameplay:If you played FF13 you should know what to expect. Only some minor changes here and there, enemies spawning around your instead of being static in the world, making a mix of random encounters and FF13's static enemies. The game also features only 2 main playable characters, the third party slot reserved for tameable creatures. Most monsters in the game can be tamed and used in battle, each one having unique abilities, crystarium, and access to one paradigm. This system is actually pretty robust, allowing you to level many monsters and infuse them into other monsters to pass on their abilities.The game also now features a jump button which is new (Although not often that useful). While the core of the game is very similar to FF13, you will definitly find a lot of quality of life changes here and there. Although I will mention the loss of other human characters has crippled endgame choice in many aspects and the actual scope of progression is much smaller than FF13. It's a more compact game in a lot of ways, but I honestly appreciate that.Aesthetics:Top notch, amazing looking game. The game does dip in framerate under certain conditons, but these were pretty rare, for me anyway. Music is fantastic, tons of new and old tracks for the FF13 universe.tl;dr Slightly improved over FF13 in a lot of ways, but still a very similar game, stay away if you dislike FF13.

I took a dump on it because it was such a bad port. 6 years later, with the benefit of a significantly better PC and the contributions of the incredible PC modding community that care enough to help improve the shoddiness of the port Square Enix gave us, I feel I can give it a tentative recommend. I am playing this with the Nova Chystalia Launcher, with a number of mods that restore DLC content, improved textures, sound quality and, most importantly, fix performance. It isn't perfect but it is a lot, lot better than what I experienced the first time around.  4k resolution, an occasionally shaky 60fps frame rate and a cleaner audio presentation make this far more enjoyable than before. Given how underutilised my GPU is this remain a horribly CPU bound performance, even on what I feel should be a more than sufficient ryzen 5600. N.B. I found that the first entry in this trilogy, another shoddy port, has been much more comprehensively fixed by mods, particularly on the performance front as a reference point. As to the game? It has plenty of flaws but I enjoyed it in any case. I have a soft spot for the franchise so I cut it perhaps more slack than most. In summary, if you can go to the trouble of modding the hell out of this then it's worth giving a go. The fixes go a long way but your CPU might still not be powerful enough to overcome the performance issues that remain unless you have a top end part.

Amazing game, my favourite out of the 3 in the XIII trilogy (played all of them on PS3 before). There is alot of side stuff with 160 fragments to collect and the DLC includes two story scenarios and multiple coliseum battles that adds more for you to do in the game.The story is great, the whole time travelling idea can be rather confusing at first but it clears up towards the middle/end of the game. This game introduces a new version of the Crystarium system and you can choose the stats that you gain through levelling different roles as you go through the crystarium ranks. For an optimal build you can find them online, and on the guides here on steam that are uploaded by people, but I didn't follow any and went my own way.One thing I don't like too much is the casino games in Serendipity. You are required to earn a certain amount in the slot machines to receive one fragment and that can take such a long time, it's really hard to have a huge gain of coins, I've tried so much and haven't managed to get the right amount yet. Chocobo Racing is fun, and the Sazh DLC game Chronobind is a good way of earning coins if you understand it.I feel like the amount of stuff to do in the game is worth the price, and is very much a steal in a sale.10/10

Final Fantasy XIII-2 is sequel to Final Fantasy XIII (obviously) and is another underrated game in the franchise. Luckily for me, I didn’t have a single problem during the gameplay of this port so I could easily enjoy the game.Good side:Bad side:

is only the third (!) direct sequel in the long-running  franchise after  and . But considering how beloved  and  were and how  was, it’s also the only direct sequel in the franchise that really had to improve upon what came before. And despite a short development time of only  (!),  actually managed to (partially) fix what many disliked about its predecessor, miraculously.First of,  doesn’t fix what isn’t broken: The (great) ATB battle system from  makes a return, which means that stagger bars, paradigm shifts and the Crystarium are back again. There have been some adjustments however, as  drew criticism for only opening up its battle system late into the game. Now most jobs are available from the beginning and as core abilities are unlocked quickly, character development and stats can be influenced by the player from the start.Another change concerns the party system: As  only features two protagonists, there’s a third character slot that needs to be filled during battle. This can be done by taming certain enemies after fighting them in the wild. This might sound like  but in praxis it’s even more simple than that: A monster (only one per species) might join your party after battle, which is simply based on chance. And while monsters can be levelled by infusing them with certain items, their job as well as their (passive & active) abilities are predetermined. Only their stats as well as their looks can be (slightly) influenced by the player.But even if the monster system is somewhat simple, it allows for easy and quick party customization. Want your protagonists to focus on certain jobs in the beginning? Simply swap in a fitting monster for the jobs you might only want to level later. All monsters also got special “empathy” abilities which can be triggered after a certain time, which can range from attack with decent manage to very useful party-wide heals. The only downside to the monster system might be the additional time investments to gather the right materials in order to fully boost them to their max level.Another common complaint about  concerns linearity, as there were many straight corridors and very few open areas to explore. This has also been addressed by , which consists of many open areas, although most of them are on the smaller side. Think , though the similarities don’t end there: In both games, areas can only be accessed by selecting them from a map in a central hub, which means the world doesn’t feel as connected/coherent as the ones in  or  for example. also offers less interesting locations compared to  but is about the same visual quality otherwise – which is hardly surprising since many assets are reused. The soundtrack is quite varied this time around, which might fit the difference of the individual locations but doesn’t really seem coherent in the bigger picture. Additionally, there are a few moments where the music choice feels ill-fitting, which is extremely rare for a  title.As with , the PC port of  is of very poor quality again. This does include console-exclusive DLC this time around, visit  for fan-made fixes if you really want to play this game one day. The focus of the remaining review concerns the central theme of : time travelling. In terms of gameplay, it’s mainly used to restrict the available locations. Want to access a certain timeline for the next story segments? Find the right items (artifacts) to do so. Want to gather all available collectibles (fragments)? Manipulate the time of certain locations via artifacts. Though a time travel element during battles/exploration would’ve been interesting, time travel is only used to alter entire locations (e.g.: visit the same place 200 years in the future).The real problem of introducing time-travel and the main problem of  as a whole is the influence time-travelling has on the story. Time-travel stories are very hard to pull off and can quickly turn into a narrative mess, as the audience needs to be properly guided through a labyrinth of similar-but-different timelines. Since time travel could potentially change about every action, character or location in the story, it’s very important to make sure that the audience can follow what you’re trying to tell them.Needless to say that  doesn’t manage to do that.  already struggled with its  mythos and storytelling, adding time-travelling to the mix would certainly not help to clear things up. For one thing, while  does requires (lore) knowledge of its predecessor, it also feels strangely disconnected, as it’s focusing on entirely different aspects and foes of the world. While the cast of the original game returns in very limited capacity – expect for previous protagonist Lightning – the story mostly focuses on the sister of Lightning, Serah, as well as the last human of future earth, Noel. Thanks to elements that weren’t even hinted at during the previous game, Serah and Noel need to time-travel in order to achieve a certain “proper” timeline while going against a new – one-dimensional and uninteresting – villain.The resulting story is simply a mess, which is not very surprising but not exactly what I hoped for either. Serah and Noel are a step-up from the protagonists of , but they’re not going to leave a lasting impression either - and considering there are only very few characters present in the story, that's saying something. It’s also quite easy to get lost in what happens in which timeline and why, especially if you’re taking longer breaks between game sessions. The basic story might be downright predictable but it’s the poorly-explained surrounding elements, including the time-travelling itself, that can cause confusion. Some side stories with important information (once sold as DLC on console) are also only unlocked once the story has been completed.It also has to be mentioned that, once again, many important lore bits are hidden in datalog text entries. They’re even worse to unlock this time around, however, as you're required to find the corresponding fragments hidden in the game world if you want to read them (there are 160 (!) of them, all of which are required for the secret ending).Finally, it doesn’t help that the uneven story of  ends on an unsatisfying cliffhanger and a literal “to be continued screen”. Even as the middle part of a trilogy - this cliffhanger comes off so abruptly forced, it really makes you wonder why you even bothered playing through the story of  to begin with. It’s gameplay might be fine but the messy story turns  into a game that’s only for really devoted fans of  who still want more.

This was... interesting.  Strange choices were made for FFXIII-2...  and given how unpopular the opinions I heard of XIII were over here, I'm kinda surprised it got a sequel in the first place. I didn't like this one.  It was a close thing.  The gameplay was mostly fine.  It was just let down by the story elements.Arguably it is necessary for the trilogy as a whole... since things happen... but... well... I get a bit bothered when fiction starts playing around with vast spans of time a bit too casually without really exploring the necessary consequences of bouncing back and forth hundreds of years.  Not to go into too much detail... but the plot of FFXIII-2 is a complete mess.  There are holes EVERYWHERE that never get even close to patched.  The whole thing is a sequence of bad choices and... honestly... the entire game is a waste. I suppose this is a bit spoily to mention, but the main characters completely fail to achieve anything throughout the course of their journey.  It really was a complete waste of time... to the extent that it being such is actually lampshaded in the 3rd game. Things change, but they're all achieved by the antagonists.  And would be so without any need for any playable characters doing anything. You could spend the entire game just sitting around staring at trees and going nowhere and the outcome would ultimately be the same. Still...  you do actually need to know what happened between XIII and LR to make sense of the latter, so I suppose there is that. Oh, and some of the music in this game was neat.  They were very experimental with it.  Some of the music was awful and, as noted, some was neat.   I'm talking about the Crazy Chocobo, as I'm sure you guessed.

Before I started playing this game, I read all about the negative reviews, about how the battle system was terrible, that the storyline was not very well thought out, so on and so forth. This was my first ever Final Fantasy game, and I was thinking that it may have been a bad idea to buy this. Before I say anything else, I must say that this game is a love it or hate it kinda thing.So when I first started the game, I was rather confused by what the controls were, and how the game worked. Of course, it was my fault as I did not bother reading the instructions or tutorial that the game offered or provided. Nevertheless, after about an hour of playing (during which I was pretty much still in the first area that you start in), I got the hang of it. The battle mechanics and the various paradigms that you could switch to were more clear to me now.From that point on, it was smooth sailing, up until I first enccountered the main antagonist. I was hopelessly stuck at that portion, then I realised that this, being a RPG game, meant that grinding would be necessary. And grind I did. and FYI, it worked (eventually).A good point about this game is that even after you have defeated the final boss and completed the main storyline, which iin my case took about 40 hours, there are still things and people out there that will giive you a good thrashing. Even certain monsters that you may have defeated before countless times may take you down if you get a bit too complacent.Overall, I would rate the experience a 8.5/10, and greatly recommend it to others. Now, I'm just waiting for the next sequel to come out on Steam, at which point I'd likely pay the full price without waiting for a sale on Steam.

It's time!I can't say I expected much after the dissapointment that was Final Fantasy XIII.But I ended up enjoying this game a lot more than the original.If you want to read my review for the original XIII : Time for pros and cons:+The game is no longer a long corridor, the areas are open with things to be discovered and time travel gives a good excuse to see many diverse and interesting locations. There is a nice amount of different locations and some areas are the same location but in a different time period.+Good music overall and some tracks are superb. Like these:  +The narrative is very focused compared to the muddled mess in the original. This is mostly thanks to there only being a handful of main characters.+The villian is great, you completely understand why he is doing the things he does.+The combat is a lot better this time around while still feeling like the same system:     +When you changed your partys roles in the orignal game there was a animation that took you out of the battle for about 2         seconds, this might not seem like a big deal but removing this animation and just letting the battle flow like it was before does a lot to improve the pacing of fights in this game.     +If the character you are controlling dies you just take control of the other person in your party. This was lacking in the  original game and it is very nice to see them address this problem.      +You can also change what character you are controlling mid battle, a very welcome addition.+The leveling system is actually very open to customization compared to the linear mess in the original. If you want to you could go through the entire game without ever getting the ability to heal. Not that I would reccomend it but it's awesome that you can do that.+You have 2 characters that are stuck in your party and a third slot open for a monster that you have tamed. You can tame most of the monsters in the game and every monster has its own abilites and base stats. I say base stats because you could have 2 "Behemoth" monsters but level them up completely differently. You can also find a lot of cosmetic items for the monsters, including hats. Each monster also has a unique limit break ability.+There is loads of optional content. Through the story you will be collecting "Fragments" to unlock new locations and time periods. You get these items by doing side quests and just finding them in chests. When I finished the game I only had 36 out of 160. So if you want to, you could spend a lot of time with this game.+This time around they included some actual graphics options. Including resolution, MSAA up to 16x and shadow resolution.+The game CAN run at 60 fps but...+There is dual audio, I played it in english and everyone was fine except for Lightning. She has less peronality than Microsoft Sam. Good thing Lightning only has about 10 minutes of screentime in the entire game.+Weapon system is better than in the original. In the original you could upgrade your weapons meaning that if you just kept upgrading your original weapon you had no reason to ever buy a new one. And because of the effort and gil needed to upgrade a single weapon you literally had no reason to ever get a new weapon. In this one you get access to new weapons in the shop the further you progress in the game, some are just a straight up upgrade, stat wise anyway. But other weapons have special abilites stuck to them but these require some additional items aswell as gil to be bought. All in all it's a straightforward system but at least it works, unlike the original.+Game leads nicely into XIII-3.-Time travel elements are very "It's magic I ain't got to explain ♥♥♥♥", but then the characters waste a lot of time in cutscenes talking about how it works and it just ends up wasting time.-The combat is still very much a case of just switching your classes to match the situation and pressing the "Auto" button. There was only one time in the game where I actually selected commands and that was because I was against an enemy that had health regen but my character refused to cast poison with auto.-You can't control your characters in battles. This can be really annoying in a lot of different sittuations, like when you have somebody as a tank with the ability to divert enemy attention to themselves and the party just stands around really close to each other, as a result everyone gets hit regardless. This defeats the entire purpose of a system that works in a 3D space.-Story was okay at best but a lot of time was wasted on nonsensical time travel ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and in the end it just came down to "X thing is a paradox, we must kill/fix it!". X often being just a random boss enemy in the area. The story was more interesting when it focused on the stories of Ciaus, Yuel, Serah and Noel.-The game has very unstable framerate. I never dropped under 30 though, nonetheless it can be very annoying to watch as the framerate jumps all over the place.- The game crashed at least once every 2 hours. The biggest time lost as a result was 1 hour. Regardless, this was very annoying and by doing a short google search I can see that I am not the only one with this issue.-This time around there are minigames, something lacking from the original but all of them are luck based and some are even locked behind DLC.I must admit I wasn't excpecting much out of this game but all the non-linearity and freedom came as a big surprise.With loads of optional content, much improved combat system and non-linearity in almost every aspect, this game is actually worth playing unlike the original. As long as you are fine with a combat system that is very simplistic and a story that makes little to no sense.I will likely edit this review soon if I forgot to talk about something.

FFXIII-2 got the changes that people wanted from FFXIII.  -Less linear -you can actually spec your characters while leveling them up-change leaders in the middle of a fight which means you no longer lose the fight if the leader dies.-enemies randomly appear rather than already being there-premptive strikes are a lot easier and make more sense-introduced paradigm save slotsThe only major downside was the total nerf of the Synergist role and how you applied buffs.  -Haste is no longer a castable spell but rather a bonus for getting a premptive strike, some items also apply it.  They also added aoe buffs which I guess balances it out.-The two main characters do not have any offensive buffs you can only get them from your monsters or their feral links.-removed fortisols-accessories are restricted, each one has a numeral cost.-some of the accessories got absolutely dirt nerfed.Overal I like FFXIII-2 just as much as the first.  It feels more fast paced in both the story and the gameplay.  The only thing you might have some problems with are finding some good monsters to level up in your party, especially early game.=====7/28/2023After some time and playing through the game again for the third time there are some issues I noticed.The game is very stat orientated compared to the first. What I mean by this is that in the first game your stats were generally limited by the crystarium. In FF13-2 though there is no limiting. While this can be seen as a good thing in some ways for FF13-2 it creates a situation where if you grind too much the game play becomes VERY bland. The game play is what I loved in FF13, the fights and paradigm creating and executing. Alternatively, If you don't know what you're doing and rush the story everything will seem overpowered. And you'll be forced to do side quests and grind. Which isn't the worst thing but can be frustrating.This last play through I did I tried to be optimal in leveling, accessories and getting the monsters I wanted. And I quickly became overpowered without doing many side quests or grinding. The game play at that point was just sit in relentless assault until the enemy is dead. No paradigm changes needed. The only fights to look forward to were bosses and late game enemies which were way to strong for me at the time, but serve as late game content.A lot of people love the monster system but its one of the things I don't like the most about this game. As I mention in the original review you have to have a SYN monster because the two main characters don't have offensive buffs. If you want to be optimal and have max damage output you'll also need a COM monster to make the Cerebus paradigm. Following that, you would need a RAV monster to raise the stagger gauge as fast as possible with triple RAV. So realistically, your third character in this game only has three different roles and if you want to be optimal you really have no choice in the matter. COM, RAV and SYN. The two main characters can cover all roles outside those three just fine on their own. -SEN, its more a temporary damage reduction for everyone and you dont even need to level it. -SAB, both main characters can cover all abilities in the role and swapping between leaders means you can get what ever debuff you need when you need it.-MED, finding a monster that has all the MED abilities you need and has a large health pool and magic stat is such a huge investment that its not even worth it. Again, the two main characters can cover all the abilities in MED. A MED monster is really only useful at the start of the game when the two main characters dont have access to the MED role or dont have levels in the role.Another gripe I have with the monster system is your "third character" has variable health in fights. Since the third character is three different monsters when you switch a monster from half health the monster coming in will have half health as well. Having a monster with a low max health is too detrimental. If a monster with a low max health comes in after another monster switches out after taking a beating there's a good chance that low max health monster is gonna die real quick. And early game when you rely on a monster for the MED role can be really frustrating since most have really low max life.That being said the game is very short and confusing story wise. I feel this game was a knee jerk reaction to the initial public thoughts of FF13 and that hurt it a lot. Instead of sticking to its guns and doing its own thing  it tried to damage control. The game is so non-linear that it gets confusing and the story can be contradicting at times depending on what path you go down. The game can still be fun but it has some issues that FF13 never had.

Fainaru Fantajī Sātīn Tsū is a sequel to FF XIII , where you can play as Serah , Lightnings Sister and as Noel, a time traveler who wants to change the future that he lives in. I've played and finished nearly all Final Fantasy games, and I must say Noel is one of the best characters I've seen , although he quite looks like Sora from Kingdom Hearts and also acts like him. It's a shame that Noel takes place only in this game, he could've been such a good protagonist in my opinion but back to the topic. FF XIII-2 takes place 3 years after the FF XIII and we are looking for Lightning through time and space. Yeah, that means we are time travelling, restoring future and collecting artifacts and fragments. I think the story is quite fine and interesting that we can see the what happens from time to time and how the other characters change through time. I must say, leveling and the game is easier than XIII itself. Probably you guys have seen, how hard XIII turned into during last chapters and they were like hell. But XIII-2 is not that hard I must say.  Sometimes, during cutscenes or boss-fights you can encounter a cinematic action, similar to FF VIII's cutscene interacts, which I liked a lot in this game. While fighting a boss, a QTE occurs which is also visually fun and stunning mostly, and then you need to continue your boss fight from that point. Sounds awesome, and is awesome. Soundtracks are, kinda different but interesting. Sometimes fight theme is like dubstepish, some time it has some melodies and riffs of a metal song and sometimes it's typical FF soundtrack.If you played and like XIII , XIII-2 is a must buy game for it's story and gameplay.10/10 would time travel with Serah to find my waifu Lightning.

What an awful game. Who do we even blame for this? I should make clear at the start that I think this game's predecessor () is very good, so much of my disappointment comes down to this being a bad sequel in every possible way.To start with the obvious: this port is a technical achievement. It is utterly resilient to improvements in computer hardware in the last decade and assures the same crummy performance even if you have a PC built this year (or any year after this review is published). There exist mods which fix the most serious problems (i.e. crashes) but you'll still get frame rates bouncing all over the place, cut scenes constantly hanging at random, and lots of other sandpaper for the brain.To add to that, the game is just harder to play. The preceding game had excellent keyboard (and keyboard+mouse) controls and here they're just worse. Controlling the camera with the mouse is like molasses even at the highest sensitivity so that's basically not an option anymore. A dedicated jump button was added for reasons I will never understand and it cannot be remapped. Seriously, just visualize this: WASD for movement, numpad for camera controls and... Backspace for jump. Could they have chosen anything more awkward? And none of those can be remapped! But you can bet it'll let me remap the pause button because *shrug*. (I'm guessing a gamepad works fine but you'll need a mod to get the right prompts to show.)But let's say you can tolerate this total lack of software craftsmanship. The game you're getting is just a total capitulation. It's cowardice! A big reason I enjoy  is because of the number of bold changes it made to the JRPG formula. And  just walks those all back. Did you like the streamlined maps? Well now you're back to bloated, half-baked areas that waste your time as you wander around figuring out what you need to do. What about the carefully controlled level of difficulty? Completely gone, which means this game will be way too easy for most of you. And here's other miscellaneous trash that ended up in :I could go on but it's not worth it. If you hated  then don't play this (not that you were planning to anyway). If you liked  then don't play this. I think that covers everybody. Thumbs down.

First of all do yourself a big favor and turn off Cloud save syncing. The game will most likely crash often when you try to save unless it's off. The game is also locked at 30fps unless you download a fan made fix. There are definitely slowdowns during gameplay if you use this, and voices can come out of sync as a result since lip-sync is not directly tied to framerate - a horrible mistake imo.If you somehow can look past these pretty bad flaws, there's a game here that much better than FF XIII, with a soundtrack that's both great and laughingly bad. This time you're able to tame monsters which is actually great fun. There are way more side missions and optional paths this time around and you can even go choboco racing. As for the story, well it's pretty convoluted to say the least. Highly simplified one can say that: Serah, Lightning's sister in the first game got saved from her crystal stasis at the end of FF XIII. However, Lightning has somehow disappeared. Serah along with a time travelling dude named Noel Kreiss agrees to go looking for her. And they do that by travelling through time.In short, it's a mixed bag. It has interesting mechanics, a story and gameplay that's better that FF XIII, but a soundtrack that leaves some things to be desired. I'm looking at you, death metal chocobo song. However you can't look away from the horrible load times, semi-frequent crashes and bad framerate. Pick this up only if you can cope with the shortcomings - some downright unacceptable and puzzling for a pc port taken into account that FF XIII did not have any of these issues.Do I recommend FF XIII-2? Yes.Do I recommend this port? No.Rating: 4/10

You played FFXIII and want to know if this one is worth playing?  That depends on what you did and didn't like about XIIII'll compare the two games some to give you an idea of how the sequel changed up the formula.Linearity:XIII-2 is much more open than the first game.  Each area can be explored and has hidden objects to discover, there are also occasionally different enemy types for different parts the zones.  There are less unique locations than the first game, but I think the openness of the areas makes up for it.Party members:  There are 2.  The first game had 6 characters to choose from and while many parts forced you into specific configurations of party members, there were times that you had a choice of how to compose your party.  XIII-2 only has two human party members and the third slot is for monster party members that you capture and level up sort of like pokemon.  There is quite a bit of depth to this mechanic, but I still would have liked some extra speaking party members.Combat:  Largely unchanged.  Big improvements are the ability to continue fighting a battle when your party leader dies, and the ability to change leader mid-battle.  Some of the SAB and SYN abilities appear to be missing, making those roles a bit more simplified(Those skills may be present in monster party members that I haven't used yet)  Monsters are not sitting out of the world in this game, at least for the most part.  They act more like the random encounters of older JRPGs, with the exception that you can still occasionally avoid them after they have spawned by running away.  I feel like this is a better system because it mostly prevents you from farming a single enemy over and over like the optimal CP grind in the first game which ultimately led to me giving up on its endgame. Crafting:  I disliked the crafting system in the previous game, largely because it wouldn't tell you which items were required to improve weapons, and it had no indicator to show when a piece of equipment was at it's max level or could be upgrading another rank.  XIII-2 has solved these problems but also has a much simpler system which lost some of the depth that could have been.  A vendor sells you new weapons in exchange for crafting materials and occasionally an old weapon too.  Story:I found FFXIII's story to be enjoyable but also easily forgettable.  I didn't think any of the characters were well written or very likable(except for maybe Saszh) and only a few months later I barely remember any of the major plotpoints.  XIII-2 is much the same case, There are parts of the story that I liked, but the character dialogue was mostly bland and often grating.  In particular I found one of the main characters very unlikable, and with no option to remove him from my party I had to play the entire game with him.Endgame:  I find that I am enjoying XIII-2's end game much more than that of the previous game.  The path to max level is almost over and I have just been going around doing quests for fragments with barely any true grinding. There is a lot to do with the monster party members that I have not done yet; that appears like it could get grindy later on.  I haven't fought any of the hardest bosses in either game yet, but for XIII-2 I do think I will end up doing that, while I don't know if I can stand the grind in XIII long enough to get there.New Things:Puzzles:  There are some puzzles that are required to be completed in certain areas, and for the most part I found these ranged for boring and unenjoyable to frustrating and unenjoyable.  I think at this point that I've finished all of the puzzles in the game, and I didn't find one of them to be enjoyable at all, and I enjoy playing puzzle games occasionally.Hidden objects:  There are a lot of hidden objects to find in the game for 100% completion.  Fragments are mostly tied to quests but occasionally hidden throughout the game world.  There is an indicator to show you how many you are missing in a particular area, and I've been enjoying hunting these down.  I find them much more interesting than the less varied Ci'eth stone missions from the first game.Then there are the wild artefacts which I ended up hating.  These are hidden objects that must be found to access certain areas.  Most of them I found during regular play, but after beating the game I still had a few that I hadn't found, and with no indicator hinting at which zone they might be in, I had to mindlessly comb every area I had been to looking for the last few.  I finally did manage to find them all, but I found the task very frustrating.  It feels like the developers might have been assuming that players would just go online for a guide for these, but I prefer to avoid outside assistance when possible.Overall I enjoy it and if you enjoyed the first game you may very well enjoy this one as well.  It still has many of the flaws that drove away hardcore Final Fantasy fans, but some of those were fixed.

So, this game isn't awful, but I felt like I wasted my time by the end. It undoes FFXIII's ending and introduces an entity from a minor Datalog entry as the driving force of the game's plot. The story pales in comparison to pretty much any other RPG that shares its themes of fate, death, and time... including many within the Final Fantasy series.The questing and combat would be more fun if the game didn't perform so terribly. Even then, it's all busywork. The quests aren't very creative, usually. Buffs, debuffs, and tanking are all de-emphasized, and the majority of fights are super easy. I'd say this game's combat pales in comparison to FFXIII's unless you're planning to do postgame content.If you're a Final Fantasy devotee and you liked FFXIII, I can recommend this, but get it on sale, and don't set your hopes too high.

Final Fantasy XIII-2 is a Hidden Gem of the FF series.This game is woefully under-appreciated by both fans of the FF series and gamers at large. If you like Chrono Trigger, you will probably like this game.Pros:+Story is appropriately grand and enthralling+Music is amazing and memorable+Caius Ballad is a very "cool" villain. At first I saw him as a discount Sephiroth but over time he is fleshed out and made to be his own person.NeutralCombat system is passably good but nothing special. If you played FFXIII you won't really find anything new here. Some fights do require a bit of strategy (read: rapid paradigm shifting) but mostly you can get through using auto-abilities.Monster collecting shows some promise at first but I ended up using the same 4-5 monsters through the whole game. You will end up using the basket cat as your healer for the majority of the game.Serah and Noel don't do much to stand out as characters.Cons-Game pacing is all over the place. Sequences shift from blindingly rapid narrative advancement to coming to a near standstill. -Performance issues can become frustrating. This seems to be hit or miss depending on your specific hardware.-Like many FF games, this one takes a while to really get spun up in the beginning. The first few hours are a bit of a slog. Overall I highly recommend this game to any JRPG fan, especially those that played and enjoyed FFXIII and/or Chrono Trigger.

7.5/10I do not understand all the bad reviews about this game. While I do think that Final Fantasy XIII was better, this one is not a bad sequel. The story was interesting, and the game was in depth. I do think some things took it down in my eyes severly, however I did not run into many performance or graphical issues. All the negative reviews here based on performance made me hesitate to buy this game for years. After finishing the game I do not get the gripes.Pros:- Interesting story and continuation of the first FFXIII- Music was beautiful, though about half of it was taken from the original FFXIII.- Art was beautiful, though many of the monsters and their are also seemed taken straight from FFXIII- Monster taming was interesting, but to me that was a mixed bag.- Being able to visit other places and other times was also interesting.Cons:- Reusing some of the Music and Graphics seemed excessive. Most of the monsters were common in Final Fantasy XIII. This however did not apply to the world graphics for the most part.- There are MINOR performance issues I had the game crash once, but it was no big deal for me. At some points the game had minor stuttering.- There are a lot of puzzles in the game, some of them (the clock ones) are so hard you have to look up online for help literally. I am not against puzzles in games but those were rediculous.- The story seems in some ways to contrast with the original FFXIII and some things that happen are left unexplained (like how Dajh and Zhaz are alive 500 years after the first game's events.)- You only have 2 characters in the game and one monster at a time (three in a party but only one out at a time.) It is not as bad as it sounds but it makes the game feel more generic.- Most of the characters from the original are not in the game other than short cameos.- The game does have some minor graphical issues, the rain in the game looks a little funny.- The fragments you have to find are often very hard to find without assistance. Many fragments are not necessary to beat the game, but some of the hard to find ones are.- Synergy abilites feel like they have little worth, as they do not last long and the bosses are fairly easy to beat. I beat the game on the last bosses and they were rediculously easy. (I think I only had to start a boss battle over like 2 times, the puzzles and finding fragments were harder than the bosses.)With so many cons it may seem like I really hated the game but it was a decent game... Some of them are minor... I loved the Music even though some of it was remixes of the original. The original was one of my favorite Final Fantasy games. The one that I am sure will never be beat is Final Fantasy VII.

Not a single crash so far in the first hour. Seems to have more stable fps than XIII but there are still stuttering and wild swings in the fps just not as often as XIII. This is just my perception though so i could be wrong as there is no in-game benchmark. Right from the start you're not confined to linear corridor as as in XIII so it's better. Also the battle mechanics is more complex as soon as you start the tutorial because you have more or longer action points (can't remember what's the actual term) that stretches the whole width of the screen.Another difference is the cutscenes and actual gameplay are more integrated. Meaning they blend smoothly; it's hard to tell where one begins and the other ends. No longer is it just the standard mashing of auto-battle or spamming the same keys over & over again. At some stage you have to press keys according to on-screen prompts and it can be quite unpredictable. I found myself waiting for the prompts rather than watching the scene unfold. In addition the auto-battle is more useful now; it also select healing spells when you're hurt about 50% instead of you having to manually use a potion. Battle mechanics is more tactical now with the addition of Paradigm shift (again i can't remember exactly what terms are used). Essentially this is a selection of team tactics you can choose in mid fight. For example, concentrating team fire on a single target or attacking each target separately.There is also more interaction in narrative or dialog. Previously conversation is all automatic and so is jumping over obstacles. Here your decisions shape the story and you have to manually jump over things. Also you can save almost at any time. So there are a lot of improvements over XIII.I thought Milestone is lazy for making simple launchers year after year with the exact same basic graphical options. FFXIII & FFXIII-2 have the exact same launcher that is even more basic with only 3 options; screen resolution with option to choose full screen or windowed, Anti-Aliasing and shadow resolution. Windowed only has 2 res to choose from. There's not even an option to set V-Sync Off or On. I tried many combination of options in an attempt to get stable 60 fps, even overclocked RAM and CPU all to no avail; there's hardly any difference.Of course the one thing both FFXIII & FFXIII-2 have in common is the amazing cinematic cutscenes worthy of a place in movie theaters.  I can't comment on the actual game content or story as it's just been an hour as of this writing. Suffice to say there is a voice over text background story of what happened in FFXIII for those who jumped straight into FFXIII-2. The background story (prologue) made it easier to understand what was going on in FFXIII so it probably should have been in FFXIII. I didn't read all of it though as i was impatient to see if there are any performance improvements. Maybe there is something there down the line that explains the how Lightning ends up in Valhalla and why Valhalla was under attack.Ok so this game is, umm . Above average. Could be 8 or 9 if only performance is better and more consistent.

If you found the original Final Fantasy XIII to be lacking and are hopeful you'll enjoy the redesigned second entry into the FF13 trilogy, be prepared for indifference. While FF13-2's battle and encounter system have been greatly improved, the flaws from FF13 are still present and hamper enjoyment of the game. The time travel element is welcome if you're, like me, a fan of the SNES classic Chrono Trigger, but wears out its welcome when it comes to collecting specific key items required to advance gameplay. You'll quickly grow tired of time-hopping in order to run across a regional map to pick up one item only to do the same thing in several other timelines. The plot is also a mixed bag and only mildly improves on its predecessor's writing, leaving me dreading the last quarter of the game or so which I only completed as I felt obligated to at that point. If you're already an FF13 fan, this game might be worth checking out otherwise avoid this game.

Final fantasy XIII-2 is an adventure game with a lot of cutscenes. While the combat is the same as in the previous game, most of the fights will be much easier, to the point that most of the times I just had to press A a few times with Relentless attack being selected as the default paradigm. Even most of the boss fights were made fairly forgiving. That doesn’t mean there are not some hard battles, but they generally happen in the side content and not in the main gamepath.Just as in FFXIII you control only the party leader, the other two members will act autonomously according to their role. This time there is only a cast of 2 main characters, Serah and Noel. During most of the game you can set freely who is the party leader, so you can have either a female or a male character leading the party around. Instead of a supporting staff, there will be monsters fighting along these two. These monsters are captured randomly during fights, and can be leveled up with the right type of materials. Also they can be infused into each other, gaining the passive abilities and a level based number of class specific abilities. Eventually I just used the Early peaker types of monsters to get access to high health, and infusing the missing skills from other partially leveled monsters. The fighting styles are bundled into paradigms, where you can set up only up to six to switch between. The available paradigms are further limited by the fact that only 3 monster types can be used, out of 6 possible role types. The only really important monster roles are the sentinel for tanking and ravager for chain bonus building. Till the midgame a medic was handy, but eventually the main cast will level up as makeshift medics too. The only other monster that I used was a commando, meaning that I skipped on the saboteurs and synergists. I leveled up such monsters, but because only 3 monsters can be used in a setup, I stuck to RAV, SEN, MED, eventually replacing the MED with a COM.Leveling the main characters is extremely straightforward. You select a role, and linearly progress along it. The still unlockable skills are listed at the lower right, with the level when they unlock. By the end of the game, I had the main skill at the max level 99 (happened around the third of the game), and practically all the other roles had all of their available abilities unlocked. There is an easy mode in the game, but I didn’t feel the need to switch to it at any time. That meant that the final boss battle lasted well over half an hour, since I was defensive enough to survive/recover from partial wipes, but lacked the offensive power to do high damage in a short amount of time. It didn’t help that the supporting enemies were continuously resummoned, forcing me to kill them again and again. As far as I know, there is no hard mode.The progression through the story is extremely contorted. You have to unlock random things on different maps to progress on, however there is no guidance whatsoever as to where to go next. Nodes with still darked out gates, or with lot of fragments remaining are a good guess to explore further, but you might end at a gate that requires a random fragment that must be unlocked - at an unspecified place / side quest. Even when I knew what to search for on the internet, finding out the correct route was a matter of lucking out on the search results. Of all the games that I have played this had the most obtuse online guidance help. If you don’t follow a full walkthrough guide right from the start (and I didn’t do that at any point), expect a lot of hindrances to progression. Even the side quests are not highlighted in any way, you literally have to talk to everyone, hoping to start a side quest instead of getting a random bit of trivia. When you do get a side quest, there will be a hint image showing the completion location. If that image seems entirely unfamiliar, it means that it is in a place you haven’t traveled yet (and of course with no help whatsoever how to get there).Some maps can be accessed through a special key item - the wild artifact. As far as I can tell, all of those maps are optional, you can reach the ending without touching them. You get at least one of these artifacts for free on the map, I got one as a side-quest reward and as a last resort they can be bought for coins in the casino - and since money can be freely traded for coins, at worst you can buy such a wild artifact for 100.000 gil. Don’t expect to have the map fully unlocked just by playing through the main game path. Beside the wild artifact maps, there will be some paradox ending maps, which I assume can be accessed after finishing the main story line. As such having a lot of undiscovered nodes on the map is normal for a simple playthrough through the main storyline.Most of the times you will encounter enemies through them randomly spawning out of thin air on you in the map. I remember only one map with roaming enemies, but even there were enemies randomly spawning. There is an option of running away from random spawns, but that works only if there is enough space to distance yourself from them, and they don’t have fast units (generally there will be no such units). Also there is a bonus if you can engage an enemy by pressing A, instead of being attacked by it or running accidentally into it (which is very easy as they spawn out of thin air as you run, and in confined spaces its almost guaranteed that you run into them). Should you fail an encounter, after the game over screen you get a retry option, starting just before the encounter. I didn’t know for a long time, but the save button can be used to force a retry even before the actual defeat.There are a variety of logical puzzles to solve, but one kind of them is quite though. It is the clock puzzle, where the problem is exacerbated by the fact that you don’t even know the right starting point, and eventually with 9+ possible starting points there can be a lot of trials that are doomed from the start. I eventually used an online solver.You can buy better equipment at the various store points sprinkled througout the game. Some of them require special components to farm. I abstained from selling random junk, because I didn’t know what would be a useful upgrade component. In a hindsight, I could have sold everything, even the money only weapons should be sufficient. Just in case, you can buy such money only weapons before the final boss fights.The graphics of the game were gorgeous, but that was partially because I used a texture mod, which pushed the graphics to the limits of the engine - it already had to keep some texture in the original state to fit into the memory limit. The music was good, but a lot of it seemed familiar from FFXIII. The japanese voice acting was good too (as always when there is a choice for native japanese voice acting, I used that). This time there wasn’t text only NPCs like in earlier games, everything will be spoken out.There is manual save in the game, and out of combat / cut-scenes you can save freely. As far as I know there is no auto save, so always save manually before exiting the game. Also I used only a single save slot, though there might be more.The game can be played with keyboard + mouse or with a gamepad. I, naturally, used a gamepad, the native system intended for the game. Ironically, you can exit the game only with the keyboard (either Esc + Enter or Alt-F4), as there is no such menu option.The game starts with keyboard prompts, even if you use a controller. Be sure to change to controller prompts prior to New game, as during the intro part I couldn’t figure out how to change that, and got keyboard prompts for quick time events even playing with a controller. I installed the HD texture mod from Nexusmods, and FF13Fix, which I think is a must for 1440p mode. The game crashed only once, in Academia 4XXAF, which is the graphically most taxing level, with a lot of independent actors.

Decent game; I don't know why so many people whine about it. Even though it's a port and it's short compared to the previous title, I had no issues with it on my PC; it ran smoorthly and it only crashed once, and I enjoyed playing it. The game is pretty good; I honestly liked FF-13 more, but 13-2 wasn't bad. The story was alright, it was confusing at first but it all makes sense by the end. Although, I didn't really feel anything by the end, whereas at the end of FF-13, I felt a tiny bit emotional. It felt like they made a huge game and spilt it into two parts; the second being Lighting Returns. So, I was like "meh, that's it?" at the end.  Graphics are great, nothing really to say about it. The music was perfect as it usually is with a Square Enix game. Gameplay was good, but I still don't get why I have to grind, even for a tiny bit, in a single player game. I couldn't be bothered leveling my party past stage 14 and I didn't need to because I beat the final boss with ease. I still had a few side missions to do to get more fragments, but I couldn't be bothered since it has no effect on the story what so ever. Overall, it's a great final fantasy game, not the best, but pretty decent. I defintely recommend buying it, especially if it's on sale. It's worth your time if you're a FF fan. Ignore all those negative reviews; those people either play on ancient PC's or are obsessed with the past and are unwilling to accept change to the franchise.

What will you expect from Final Fantasy XIII-2? (Strongly recommend to play through the previous game, CONTAINS SPOILERS FROM XIII)(TL,DR: Read Pros&Cons and Overall at the bottom, I played on the console version)„Why does mankind defy its fate?”The game takes place three years after the events of Final Fantasy XIII, and depicts the story of Serah Farron's journey across time and space to prevent the end of the world while searching for her missing sister, Lightning.Pros: - Fantastic atmosphere - The battle system expanded (you can catch monsters and they fight with you as third party member)- Epic music (more vocals and remixed versions for pre-battle)- ’More openworld’ than the XIII had, side missions, puzzles, casino etc.- Returning characters and places (You can visit the areas in other timelines, these areas change in appearance)- You can replay the chapters/missions anytime you want, and you can continue your journey (this is the NewGame+)- Paradox (or alternate) endings- Epic final boss battle with one of the best FF antagonist- You will get all the DLCs (3 story, all Coliseum battles, outfits)- Still an amazing story, but...Cons:- ...again linear and complicated (time travelling)- Only two playable characters (the DLCs grant you to play with Sazh, and Lightning in their own story)- Too easy- Shorter than XIIIStory (AF timeline means After the Fall of Cocoon):After the events of XIII, Lightning gets caught by a paradoxon and taken to Valhalla, the realm of death. While everybody thinks Lightning is dead, Serah is confident that her sister is alive. Lightning will be a knight of goddess Etro, and her task to save the future from Caius Ballad, who wants to destroy the time, he is Yeul's immortal Guardian and seeks to end the suffering she sustains by being endlessly reincarnated by killing the goddess Etro. Noel Kreiss comes from the Dying World at 700 AF, where he is the last surviving human in a world that faced destruction 200 years after the Crystal Pillar’s fall and Lightning ask him to find Serah and help her reach Valhalla. In New Bodhum (on Gran Pulse) at 3 AF Noel coming to find Serah. The two encounters in an epic journey through time and space to solve the paradoxons and save the world and Lightning. What about with the original team? Fang and Vanille are still in the Crystal Pillar, Hope is now 24 years old and the leader of the Academy (the new capital city), Sazh and Dajh have mysteriously gone missing, Snow left to search for Lightning two years after her disappearance, and Serah stayed with the NORA at New Bodhum.Battle:The battle system returns from XIII, you are able to switch the party leader during battle, the third party member will be a monster that will fight along with you with their own role (One monster = One role) and you can upgrade them (new abilites, better stats). It’s okay because three monsters can be held at a time, and automatically switch to the role a player shifts to in the paradigm. The Crystarium system returns too, with levels not with tiers. A new form of damage, called Wound Damage, lowers a target's member's max HP during battle and can only be healed by items, giving further incentive to defeat enemies as quickly as possible. If the current party leader is KO'd, the party leader is automatically switched to the other human character. The defeat of the human characters in the party results in a game over.Playtime (My first walkhthrough): Story: 32 hours (ofc with cutscenes)100%, All achievements, all (160) fragments, best chocobo for racing: 63 hoursOverall:For me this game 10/10, if I need to compare to the other FF games then 8/10, the story not better than the XIII’s story, but the atmosphere is better and the battles are exciting, there will be people who like this game more than the previous.If you loved the first installment, you will love this one too, if you hated you will be disappointed again, don’t buy it then. That's a pity, because I think it promises adventure not to be missed, despite its flaws.If you liked the game, I can recommend the finale of the trilogy: Lightning Returns.Thanks for reading!

I highly recommend the game, but not this port.Without exaggeration, the game crashed more often than I voluntarily shut it down.  The save system crashes the game (and often takes Steam with it) and, even with cloud saves turned off as recommended in several threads/reviews, I experienced an average of one crash every hour while playing this game.  Three levels actually placed me in an infinite loading screen unless I switched cloud saves back on (a risky move since it usually caused a crash), and the story requires you to visit two of those levels on multiple occasions.  This does not appear to be a random glitch since the infinite loading screen happened in every instance of these three levels, regardless of era: .  To add insult to injury, the two required levels (of the three listed) glitched out and kept repeating the story events long after they were supposed to be completed.  There are two boss battles (one story and one optional) where I had to start the fight with cloud saves turned on but I had to switch to local saves immediately after the fight or else the game would crash.  If that were not enough, the weather machine located in a later level has a chance to crash the game every time it is used (story requires it to be used at least three times but side missions require it far more often) and I also experienced a small number of crashes for which I could find no cause.  The trial and error required to find out where I could go and when I could save the game resulted in over 6 hours of lost progress in the game and several more hours were wasted outside of the game rebooting everything.There are smaller concerns that can be raised about the lack of sound sliders and the very limited graphics options, but those problems don't hold a candle to the constant crashes.I will say that, while I experienced many softlocks that required reloading levels or rebooting the game, the game never glitched in such a way as to make it permanently impossible to complete the objective (and that includes all side content as well).  So, if you want to fight this game tooth and nail for every inch of progress (like I did) then I wish you the best of luck.

The game is 8/10 but this PC port is more like a 5/10. Out of the box on release day, this thing ran like a sloth on my ROG G750JM laptop (GTX 860M, i7-4700HQ, 16GB RAM). I had to open Nvidia control panel and manually adjust the performance settings (say INTEGRATED) before the game ran anywhere between 30-60FPS at 1080 (though it seems to be locked at 720 anyway), usually closer to 30. The graphics and even audio options are extremely limited (screen resolution, shadow resolution, aliasing, English/Japanese voice) so make sure you're at least close to the recommended specs. Once I had the settings down, the game was smooth sailing with no crashes so far but the overall experience could be more consistent. And for crying out loud, I would love to be able to adjust the background music level! That song at the beach was totally out of place when it kicked in!The game just feels natural with a controller so I plugged in my PS4's dual shock FTW. One thing that irks me is that there's a silly bug that resets QTE displays from controller buttons to keyboard keys. You'll have to change it each time you boot up the game if you plan to stick to controllers or it could get very confusing during the QTEs. Either way, you can use both control methods at the same time.As for the game itself, it's FFXIII made better in every way with a good dose of fanservicing. Oh and it's just Serah, Noel, your trusty Moogle, and a bunch of pets. If you heard bad things about this game's predecessor, well, XIII-2 more than makes up for them, at least in its systems. However, if you never played the first game, I strongly advise playing that before this because you'll sorely be lost in the story if you haven't.There are reports of the story DLCs missing but that does not take away from the main story. It should eventually get patched up since they advertised the inclusion but who knows when that'll happen? Thankfully, the bonus costume DLCs work.In spite of all that, I still recommend getting the game but with caution. In my own experience, the game is entirely playable and does not bog down. But there are some bugs and plenty of room for optimization. This release comes loaded with more things than the console versions came with and at a lower price to boot. Putting this game on your wishlist to wait for a patch isn't a bad idea though to get a fully fleshed out experience.
