I was fortunate and didn't have any issues or crashes, so for me it was a very nice experience.FFXIII-2 takes the general mechanics from FFXIII and removes a lot of the tedious aspects. These include:1) Switching between paradigms is pretty quick and allows for quick switching to a full SEN team to reduce damage and quickly switch back within a few seconds.2) Your party leader can now be reduced to 0 health and the game DOESN'T end. This was incredibly frustrating in FFXIII.3) Enemies have less health, no more 5 minute battles for trash. The reduced amount of time spent in each battle really picks the pace up.4) Staggering enemies is no longer mandatory. A lot of enemies can be burned down by 3 COM, but there are some that will probably need to be softened up with a stagger here and there.5) The main cast is interesting (except the furball that you "accidentally" throw off a cliff). The villain is actually one of the better ones in the entire franchise. I even felt bad for him towards the end.6) Collecting fragments isn't too bad once you learn that the picture alongside the text indicates where you generally need to go. Also, these are completely optional. No mandatory fetch quests.7) No grinding for tiny (but necessary) upgrades.The story is absolutely nonsense and full of things that don't make sense, but it was nice to see how your actions affected the future. It reminded me of Dark Cloud 2 (in a more limited capacity). Hidden objects being pointed out by a certain fluffball made hunting for things so much less frustrating that having to wander around checking every corner. Imagine if they made a game where you have to do that and put in a time limit. It would be frustrating and awful for a first time play.The only really tedious part was the final zone and waiting for the platforms to move. That got really old, really quick.I think this would have been better as a stand alone game with a little more time in production. FFXIII had a good ending, and this wasn't needed. Though I thoroughly enjoyed my time with it, and still find myself listening to the soundtrack on a very regular basis. It's an absolute banger.7/10

However, it has the added annoyance of you running around trying to actually hit enemies before a battle in tight spaces. This ends with you attacking the air for 15 seconds before battle as you try to hit your enemy.If you play it, you won't hate it, but I can't imagine many people finishing it unless they simply have nothing else to do.It's a real shame that we can't buy this game on PC, though. We have to make do with renting it from steam.

The game is definitely a lot of fun. No, it's not the most serious nor the best written story but it just feels so, so much better than FFXIII. Honestly I think if this had been released instead of FFXIII (with obvious little story changes that would entail) I would have been much more pleased with the brand instead of being constantly scared that whatever they put out will be "just like FFXIII."The world, although still slightly linear, feels much more freeing. There are no more literal corridors with a bunch of static monsters waiting for you to approach and battle them. Being able to replay some chapters was quite interesting as well. The combat feels smooth; nothing new, just like FFXIII. Not my favorite FF combat system but still good. I like small challenges in games such as the map completion quest or the monster hunting one; so I was happy to see that there was some of that.Overall, I definitely enjoyed it and would recommend it to anyone who is fine playing a happy-go-lucky RPG. If you're looking for some epic story, this is not it. If you're looking for a fun 40+ hours, this is a good choice.

As you may have seen in multiple reviews, this is a problematic port that can crash a lot. It is weird, though, as it uses the same game engine and launches from the same launcher as FF XIII. I would assume the porting process was the same across these two games. I played FF XIII for nearly 60 hours until I beat the game and it never crashed. This one, however, is totally different. This is exactly the reason XIII got a positive review but this one is mixed. This game obviously has some memory management problem, and probably the video RAM management issue, too. I first played this game with an 5th-gen i7 and integrated graphics, the same setting I played FF XIII. It crashed, like, three seconds into the game. Then I tried the 4gb patch, which slightly made it better -- the game lasted for a minute to three minutes, still not able to pass the intro part. So I shelved this game, until recently I got a new laptop with a 1070M graphic card. Believe or not, in its original form downloaded from Steam, it still crashed within three minutes. But this time, after I tried the 4gb patch again, I was able to beat the game. It still crashed twice, both in the "Academia AF 4XX" area, which is arguably the busiest part of the game featuring a downtown area with lots of flying vehicles and NPCs walking around. So when you get there, remember to save frequently, I didn't experience any crash elsewhere.And for the game content itself, it isn't much different from XIII. It is a beautiful game. Of course it is of the last-generation technology, but high definition and great artistic design make it still a visual treat today. The music is great, too. The gameplay, however, is not really fun. Unless you are an old-school J-RPG fan, I strongly recommend cheating to save the grinding time. I beat the game in around 30 hours thanks for that, and I regret I didn't do so when playing XIII. But this is a J-RPG so I knew what I was getting. Nothing to complain about.The biggest problem of this game is, exactly like XIII, its writing. A totally stupid storyline together with stupid conversations. The clothing design of the characters is also ugly and childish despite nicely rendered, an unfortunate tradition since FF X and X-2. Overall it is great visual and music talents wasted by writers and character designers, making the whole product full of the feel of "chunibyo (中二病)" -- extremely childish people trying so hard pretending to be mature and sophisticate both intellectually and emotionally. I gave up trying to understand the story probably halfway into XIII, and this didn't change to the end of XIII-2. This game, however, is more of an asset-recycle of XIII. Probably to save budget, they didn't put too many characters into it and the whole story you have only two people in your team. This makes it a better game than XIII -- less stupid people around, therefore less annoying behaviors and stupid talks. Get it on sale, make sure you have enough graphic memory, use 4gb patch, and cheat for the grinding, you can enjoy a beautiful trip, knowing you are going to beat the final boss but don't bother to understand the details.

This is probably the game that has frustrated me the most  to the point where I couldn't even finish it.--Going a bit more into detail on the different aspects...The start of the game was actually really enjoyable and I started getting into the story without any bigger problems, however, that only lasted for maybe 10-15 or so hours. I do feel like the story had potential but suffered due to poor game design and story progression experience.The amount of times I got lost when trying to progress forwards in the main story isn't even funny to think about. It feels like I spent more time on the internet searching for clear directions on story progression than following the directions the game itself gives the player. This right here is probably my biggest problem with this game.And again, the battles were enjoyable for the first 10-15 or so hours, however, when all you do is walk around aimlessly for hours while trying to understand a story segment, the random encounters become nothing more than a chore.I liked many of the other aspects of the game, such as the Bestiary, team building options, the music and the characters etc. However, if the game design can't make the game experience enjoyable with a smooth story progression and clear directions, none of the other aspects really matter.In short:The game is 80% searching for answers and wandering around aimlessly, trying to find wild artifacts and more.10% enjoying a actual meaningful battle.and 10% enjoying the other aspects of the game (Filling the Bestiary, creating team builds etc.)

When getting started, you'll need to know enough about your PC to make this game run properly and smooth. There are some out of the box issues with it for most people and their PC's. HOWEVER, that shouldn't stop anyone from getting this game and playing it, unless your computers a toaster, you should be just fine to run this game, after some Graphics Card Settings tweeks for this game specifically or looking for some optional Mods to make the gameplay better. <-- Reference this for Graphics Settings that once applied made my game run at better graphics and much smoother than originally on start. With all the "Typical Issues" aside. I recommend this game as a Nostalgic Recap or a way to Permanently add another game to your Final Fantasy Library. I personally like this game and the Time Travel / Puzzles / Combat Styles this game offers, compared to Final Fantasy XIII. It's not really that hard or complicated of a game and you're given a lot of Freedom to Explore and Build Characters in this Version which allows for customizable gameplay styles early on. There are things to do in all the areas you can explore and you're almost never forced to endlessly grind in a single boring area to beat the next boss in this one. You can meet a boss or monster you can't fight, go explore a different path and then come back to it at a later time and try again without feeling like your roadblocked. That is assuming a typical Pace. Compared to XIII where you'd often find yourself in a Tunneled Roadblock Situation if you took no time trying to get through the story. Solid 8.6/10 in my honest opinon.

NOTE: his review covers the whole trilogy, as it is basically one single story spanning over 3 games, with slightly different mechanics from chapter to chapter.TL;DR version: Game is bad. Don’t buy it, don’t rent it and wait for a very deep sale (75%+), but only if you’re a completionist of Final Fantasy games. Also the PC port quality is horrendous for 13 and 13-2. Less so for Lightning Returns.Let’s make it quick and dirty, shall we? I’m a big fan of JRPGs and of the FF series in general, and I have to say that this game is BAD. It pains me to admit it, but after playing the first 2 games and ½ of the third I had to force myself and rush to the ending of Lightning Returns, just for the sake of ticking the damn box and getting over with it. I definitely could not bother with New Game+.The most egregious fault by Square Enix was to try and shoehorn an abomination of hybrid action combat system in place of the traditional ATB-based (or turn-based) system of the previous 12 chapters. With the aggravating factor that you mostly control only 1 character at any time, while the other 2 in the party are controlled by the AI and just follow generic patterns (if they are ever present at all, see below), with frustrating results.The second and absolutely horrendous decision was to dramatically reduce the number of spells and actions that each character could theoretically execute in battle (because console controllers have only four buttons to mash, amirite guyses? Did anyone ever mention these weird things called “scrolling menus”????). Forget the classic ATTACK - MAGIC - ITEM - SUMMON - SKILL - WHATEVER list, you now have either a variation of “Mash A to Auto select skills” or “Press A for Slash, B for Fire, X for Cure, Y for Potion”. That’s it. And trust me, it is even worse in the first two games since you only choose the classes/jobs you characters are, and then the fight basically plays by itself on auto.But hey, at least FF games have epic stories with strong characters, many plot twists and memorable villains? Right? RIGHT? WRONGHere is a summary of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that is this trilogy (SPOILER SAFE):The first chapter of the trilogy is definitely the worst, considering also the overly-long development time. It is a glorified tutorial at best, and the player is forced through long linear corridor map sections with absolutely no clue of what is going on, without being given even a small hint to understand the plot of the game. For hours and hours. Sometimes the player controls 1 character, sometimes a different couple, sometimes 3 completely different guys, with the only task to move from one mob group to the other, from one cutscene to the next. Oh, and there is no character advancement system whatsoever, up to at least mid-game. Because who needs it in an RPG? That's preposterous!The most insulting thing of them all? Once the corridors end and the first true “open area” is reached, when you are finally given the option to rearrange your party and properly equip it, the final mission starts and THE EFFIN’ GAME ENDS. I had to read a walkthrough guide to be sure that I did not skip most of the game by accident by entering the final dungeon prematurely (à la Chrono Trigger). Sadly, I did not make any mistake: the game was really over at that point.Take the convoluted and obscure plot of the 1st chapter, throw time travel paradoxes in, remove all the characters you barely knew from FF13, add the most annoying protagonist teen couple ever in the mix and reduce the max number of party members down to 2. And you still get a better game than FF XIII-2! Seriously, they could have done worse only if Square was so lazy to recycle most of the assets again and again from the 1st game on every map… oh wait… they actually did it! FF XIII-2 is basically just an asset flip of XIII...But hey, you can collect Pokémon in this game! Isn’t it cool?Also, the character advancement system in 13-2 (yes, Square remembered to add one since the beginning this time!) is the worst thing I have experienced in any RPG, ever. You need several external guides just to get a grasp of it, since it is THAT badly documented in-game. It would have been better if Square simply did like in the 1st chapter or forget to implement it at all.I must admit this is the most solid game of the trilogy. Or at least the most solid turd of the 3. On the positive side, this time the plot is explained to the player, somehow. The efforts put in to fix the dumpster fires that were 13 and 13-2 are pretty evident the more you progress (although several core game mechanics are still undocumented and oblivious af, which frustrates the player) but Square Enix in his almighty wisdom decided that it was a brilliant idea after the backlash of 13-2 to reduce the max number of party members even further. That’s right! In this game you can control only 1 playable character during the whole story! But you can dress her up and play Barbie Fashion Wheel! Isn’t it wonderful?And if that wasn’t enough, the whole game is on a death timer: once the 13th in-game day ends, unless you have completed the 5 main plot quests this results in an immediate GAME OVER. Even though you’ll soon learn that the time limit is absurdly lenient (I completed each quest in the game, including optional and secrets, in 7-8 days of in-game time) it is still a very bad design choice, because it puts undue urge on the player and pushes you to skip everything just to get to the objective and save time. Yes, this game basically punishes the player for exploring its own hand-crafted open world!Final note of shame for Square: in the English translation the localisation team completely butchered and removed lots of subtexts and romanticism in the dialogue between the main characters. Because why not? WOULD SOMEBODY PLEASE THINK OF THE CHILDREN!?

Chocolina and Mog.  Possibly the only redeeming qualities of XIII-2.  Okay and maybe the music.  XIII was a full, flagship title game; XIII-2 and LR feel like they were created by a third-party using assets that were not included in the original XIII.  The developers even stated in interviews that they had enough material leftover from XIII to create another game.  Well, guess what, this is what you get; sloppy story written to fit the usable assets rather than build assets for a decent story.  Time travel can be an excellent tool in storytelling but it can also be an excuse for developers to reuse the same environment but give it a different name.  They did try to make this game seem appealing, and it would be, for, say, people who have never played a above average RPG.  While I did not run into many issues other players have reported a number of issues with the port on the community hub page.  Sadly as a whole the experience was not very memorable for me but for someone new to FF - maybe.  And cripes would it have killed them to change or even modify the model of the treasure spheres?? Pros: a) Mog & Chocolinab) You can throw mogc) You get to see all the assets that could have been in XIIId) Cinematic cutscenese) Couple of nice music tracksCons:a) Messy story (if you were expecting romance, sorry to disappoint)b) Barely any Lightningc) Few new monsters (reused the same models/animations from XIII)d) Gimmicks/time sinks in place of good storytelling (coliseum, casino, quizzes, weather changes, 100% map collection)e) Changes as a result of time travel not tied to the main story are superficial, no significance, minimal impact (you don't get to see the results of the change and quite frankly aren't given many opportunities to make change)f)  Spawn rates are far too frequent to let you just enjoy the game; you never become truly immersedg) lazy end game; at one point it literally turns into a platformer with respawn by falling into void space (FML) h) Poor character development

tl;dr: great game that improves and builds upon the first entry plagued by technical issues (which can be manually patched / addressed to an extent)The game has some serious bugs, so I'm not surprised about the mixed review at the time of writing. For example, if you have cloud saves enabled (which is the default) it'll randomly crash sometimes when saving. Seriously!? I actually lost at least an hour or two of progress when this happened to me since autosaves aren't time-based but event-based, and I wasn't actively making manual saves. On top of the bugs there are performance issues just like in the first game. I would STRONGLY recommend looking up the fixes/patches available to apply online and disabling cloud saves (I only re-enabled them once I was completely done with the game so it would upload my completed saves).With that out of the way, moving on to the game content. I loved the game, story, mechanics, soundtrack, art, etc.! This entry is hands down my favorite of the trilogy (I already completed part 3 at the time of writing this review). It addresses many of the weaknesses in the first game (e.g. linearity, upgrade system) while keeping what worked (e.g. combat system). Moreover, I felt it cohesively flowed from the events that happened in the first game, and, in fact, fleshed out details surrounding endgame events from the first game that I had complained felt lacking in the first game. I'll leave it at that since there are interesting twists that I do not want to spoil.

Summary : good game, but sometimes tedious. You should follow a guide to ease your pain.7 years later after my initial review (see below), I decided to give another chance to this game. Since then I have upgraded my PC 2 or 3 times. To my surprise the game WAS now completely playable. Steady 60 fps (even with the original executable file). No icon problem. All the frustration was gone ! So yeah, I finally got to enjoy playing this game. To be on the safe side, I used a modded .exe of the game, one that make the game use 4 GB of RAM, instead of only 2GB, and correct some bugs along the way (and also for throwing away the bad fps frame limiter).Not a single crash during the 80 hours I spent on this game. But from time to time I had a problem when saving. Sometimes the save process was ‘infinite’, I had to kill the game. But each time it happened (maybe 6 or 7 times in total), the save HAD worked, I lost nothing.All in all, the game is good, but not for everyone I think. You have to warp between space and time, and in the order you decide, that’s not the best for telling a story, tough it’s only my opinion. There are also multiple puzzle games on occasions. I especially hate the ones with the numbers like a watch, I had to search for an online solver for the biggest difficulties. And you really need a guide if you want to 100% complete this game. I preferred FFXIII, but I had to play this 2nd entry of the trilogy. Now I’m ready for the 3rd and last of the entry : Lightning returns, and hopefully it’ll be less tedious.[Original review]A shame of a port.* Game is jumping constantly between 20 and 30 fps, despite none of the threads of my CPU, nor my GPU, is even at 50% of its maximum. Not a memory problem either. Unexplainable.* Despite having set the option to have *controller* buttons in the texts on screen, I'm seeing *keyboard* keys.It may be a good game, but I won't know : I can't stand to play it in this frustrating state.

This is the game FF13 should have been. It's almost amazing how well Square Enix managed to improve upon FF13 while maintaining it's core principles and mechanics.Gameplay is an improved version of FF13's paradigm/ATB combat. You still have the same roles (COM, RAV, SAB, SYN, MED, SEN) and the same maximum of 3 members in your party. Except now you have the ability to get rare drops from almost everything you fight (excluding bosses) that allow you to use said monster for your 3rd party member. This really opens up that much needed flexibility, compared to FF13 where all 6 party members were essentially the same apart from their full ATB skill. Also important to note is that there's no longer a long animation for paradigm shifting, which really feels more natural and doesn't make your characters idle for a few seconds, wasting that precious time you could be using to input commands. Characters feel less clunky and slow in their animations and you get the full combat system available very early on into the story. One of the main gripes I had with FF13 was that you were forced into the slow progression into unlocking the full capabilities of the paradigm shifting system. Other than the reasonable improvements, it's still essentially FF13's combat mechanics. You still craft higher tier-weapons with monster materials, although it's less farmy compared to FF13. Accessories take a major backseat due to a limitation being placed on the amount of accessories you can hold on one character, which different accessories having different amounts of capacity they take up. Eidolons/Summons are gone, but it's not really missed since you'd barely use them in FF13 anyway. You also get Fragment Skills, which are unlocked as you go along completing the game. These have a wide range of effects from changing monster encounter rates to opening up different endings by allowing an alternative path.The world itself has been really revamped though. You can now jump (although you're often blocked with invisible walls in most places) and as a result, there's a lot more verticality in the map design. You aren't forced into a corridor driving you forward towards the story. Progression is done by visiting areas of varying sizes, some small, some very large, in different time periods. You'll often have the option of visiting a place multiple times in different time periods, but it's not repetitive due to the slightly altered designs and different npcs. FF13-2 still has that gorgeous visual quality from FF13. The level design really has an emphasis on creating the perfect atmosphere for the situation, It's amazing how well they managed to convey each time period of the same location so uniquely.The story's done much better, with excellent pacing that feels natural and not forced. You unlock new locations (and time periods of that said location) within a level and progress slowly along with the story, although the locations have barely any correlation with each other. The story itself is actually done well. Characters feel natural and likable, and the main antagonist is one of the best Final Fantasy villians in recent memory. Pacing is done well since you control where and when to go and it's fairly open. It feels more like you're just going around places solving time paradoxes and moving onto the next world, which is a really nice change from FF13's forced pacing. There's plenty of optional areas to visit during the story, and the hub (Historia Crux) allows you to visit past areas instantly without having to retrace your steps. Sonically, this is personally one of my favourites from the recent FF games. There's FF13 tracks, remixed FF13 tracks and new music that really helps set the tone of the game. There's beautiful orchestral tracks, well written vocals and context appropriate background music that help drive the atmosphere of each and every situation. Although I felt there were a bit too many vocals and it was definite far more than what's usually present in a FF game. Not that I'm complaining though, some of the vocal tracks are done perfectly. Naoshi Mizuta outdoes herself in Noel's Theme, which features hauntingly sombre vocals, with a simple piano and violin background. The song really encompasses the character Noel and his struggles, and it's used to really emphasise emotional scenes. The main battle theme, Paradigm Shift, is a fast paced track featuring a vibrant violin, a simple but strong drum beat and a bassy synth. It really suits the frantic but orderly nature of battles and it's colourful but subdued enough to help focus on the battle. Eclipse is another standout, with vocals acting as a backing to the sharp violins, frantic pianos and punchy bassline. Honestly, even if my terrible adjectives haven't convinced you, at least listen to the soundtrack. It's really good.As a PC port, it's bad. Not FF13 bad, but still pretty bad. It has graphical options for resolution, anti-aliasing and shadow resolutions but nothing else. And it's not even ingame, but within a window that acts as a launcher of sorts. The EscKey=AltF4 is still here with it's warning box that's STILL a popup box outside of the game. It's 60fps, but poorly optimised so you can expect sudden drops in certain areas. Graphically, it's stunning but with few options to tinker around with. There hasn't been any bugs I've noticed though, compared to FF13 which suffered from random crashes that forced you to save at every available opportunity. As PC ports go, Square Enix still has a long way to go.All in all, it's a good game with great visuals, an interesting time-travel based story with an optimised combat system from FF13 and a very memorable OST. Better than FF13 in every way. Easily get it if you're a fan of jRPGs, it's an excellent choice.

Oh, and I use "Skacik pl" launcher.Btw this game has strange affection by its graphical seetings. Lessen shadows won't improve performance (from 2048 to 512 or even 1). Checked it many times. There seems to be a lot of hate for this game stemming from largely unimportant technical issues versus actual game quality, so let me give my two cents as an avid gamer with a very diverse array of games and technical knowledge.Let me start off by saying that this is a console to pc port.  While this game, as all games are, have been developed on a pc, it was developed, originally, for an entirely different type of hardware, so you can't just take your pc dev source and throw that on a computer and call it a day.  While there are some technical issues, they are largely minor and unnoticeable with a few exceptions.  I'll cover all of that in detail below.Gameplay:This game uses a similar combat system to its predecessor, FFXIII, in that rather than micromanaging every move of your team, they learn from their combat experience and adjust their fighting on their own, you simply tell them what role to fill in the party by changing your party paradigms.  While this means a whole lot less button pushing and decision-making as far as battles go, it makes for a more casual gameplay experience and allows battles to be conducted in real-time.  For those of you that still want the final say in what is done how and where to what, you can select the abilities individually through the combat menus.  I don't suggest doing this on boss fights, as a note.The game is split between exploring maps, battling monsters, and dialogue.  As far as the story goes, they have a lot of interesting bits.  There IS a solid story to be told and you are fed it through a myriad of time-jumps and side quests.  You could, of course, straightline the story and be done with the game in a few hours, but you'd be missing out on a lot of the depth of the story and information.  Take the time to explore the world, do the side quests, and you will be rewarded for the experience with a rich plot that is severely downplayed in reviews.  Once Serah grows a spine and takes up sword and bow for her sister's sake, she's a certifiable badass, and, something new from the previous game, you actually have a say in the stories, deciding what she says or asks at critical points to affect the information and reactions of the npcs.The party mechanics are pretty different now.  Serah and Noel are your only real party members and you can swap between which of them leads freely.  The third party slot is filled by tamed monsters, each which has a specific role and can be evolved along the crystarium at the cost of item drops.  This mechanic is a bit odd, but not unwelcomed.  There's a lot to be said for a Behemoth mowing down your enemies along side the mains.  There are some battles where the characters from the first game assist, such as a battle alongside Snow fairly early on, but I wish there would have been some of that for some of the newer npcs, like Alyssa, who you run into repeatedly and even voices an interest in the party's actions and time travel.Controls:Don't use mouse and keyboard.  Sure, they work, and they will get you through some stuff, but they are a bit awkward and clunky.  The convenience of a controller is that all the controls for the game are easily accessible and don't require reaching across your keyboard and hitting the wrong button during a crucial moment, or simply losing track of where your fingers are on the keyboard.  I am very accustomed to keyboard/mouse controls....get a controller.  It will make your life easier and many games benefit from the ease of access of the buttons you need in your hand.Audio:I applaud Squeenix for this whole-heartedly.  For those of you who like the english voice cast (which they did do an amazing job of casting, I might add), the game offers the usual English release as seen on the consoles.  For those of you who prefer to hear the original voices, you can choose the original voice track from the Japanese version of the game.  If you know Japanese, you'll here some inconsistencies between the dialogue and the subtitles that are curious, but for the most part, both are solid and you won't miss anything one way or the other.The music for this game is very easy to listen to.  Though the battle theme is repetitive and a bit obnoxious at times, especially as frequently as you end up in battles, the rest of the soundtrack during exploration is beautiful and well done.  Rather than simply extending the soundtrack a little from the previous game, there are only a few familiar songs from XIII, and most of the music for XIII-2 is new.  Nice vocals sung in English (for the most part) help add to the story as the songs are actually relevant to the plot in their weirdly Engrish way.  I wish the soundtrack was available for this on Steam as well.Graphics:Here's the bit where things get dicey.  The game is fantastically beautiful and well-worth exploring.  That said, the game's requirements are fairly punishing on most middleweight/moderate systems.  The game runs beautifully on my desktop (3.4ghz AMD Quad-Core, 16gb RAM, Crossfired 6870s), with no measurable issues.  All those people complaining about frame rates dropping to unplayable levels are either experiencing hardware incompatibility issues or other OS-related issues (such as background processes, viruses and malware, or everyone's friend, System Idle Process) ...or are simply first-worlders with no real concept of what unplayable is and are just whining for attention and because things aren't perfect for them.  Nothing is going to be perfect and this title is no exception to that rule.  It IS playable.  My laptop struggles a bit more with the game, on the other hand, but the issues are so minor that I still have no real unplayable moments.  The game engine is built with an internal frame-skipping mechanic that mitigates lower end systems, something I don't think many people have noticed.  While the game may not be running 30frames per second, it does it's best to keep it as close to 23 as it can.  I have no complaints with this.  Even when the count drops below this, the game is still playing smoothly thanks to the frame skipping with only a little bit of lag during the visually stunning spells, like Thundaga and Ruinga.  It's running a 3.2ghz AMD Quad-Core, 8gb RAM, and HD6650 video card.In Conclusion:This game is worth the money.  At $20, its not like Squeenix is trying to milk a new market, plus we get most of the DLC at no additional cost.  The only thing that they could have thrown in to make it a better deal would have been the soundtrack.  Sure, the game may occasionally drop in performance a little bit at times, but it's never bad enough that the game can't be played and the gameplay experience is not bad.  I'm playing Final Fantasy on my computer and I'm very happy for the experience.  As a side note, I do own both games on consoles, so I am aware of how they play there.  I can't pack up my console and take it on a roadtrip like I can do with my laptop, however, and as often as I'm on the road or in a position that I CAN'T play my consoles, this is a nice and welcome option.

Being a truly dedicated fan of Square's franchises, (especially Final Fantasy) I sometimes am biased about my opinions. However, this really deserves a down to earth look at what's wrong here.The game itself isn't bad. In fact it's above average by what I consider a fair standard for JRPG's coming westside recently. This game is simply a port of its console predesessor. And that is what I'm calling it through this review. My PC's specs aren't high end, it's completely running on factory hardware. And I can play games such as Path of Exile and Call of Duty AW without much trouble, if any. And I'm running on 6 GB of RAM with an AMD A8 Quad-Core processor. Final Fantasy XIII ran almost PERFECTLY with very little chugging when the particles started flying. So as a PORT this game fails to meet what I would consider even sub-par standards that we've come to expect from an A-class company.This game needs some serious patching. So if you're intending to buy this game, think hard about your rig's specs. This game may not hold up to your expectations, at least for now.

I admit that I wasn't warm to the concept of XIII-2 the first time around, and it never won me over in the end. Curiosity got the best of me, and here I find myself, playing a game I never expected to like, and never got into when I tried.The Crystarium is improved from XIII by allowing the grind-happy players to grind to their heart's content and fully develop their characters as soon as the option becomes available; no story-locked stat progression. However... It must be said that my least favorite mechanic of any RPG is the concept of random battles. I find them tedious, annoying, repetitive, and grounds to legally assault whoever decided they were worth including in the gameplay mechanic. When you can just be walking along and some random winged and clawed thing sprouts out of the ground like hopped up kudzu right in front of you with no explanation, and this is a common occurance at the rate of less than 30 seconds per incident, something is UNSPEAKABLY WRONG with your game. The only worse gameplay offense I can specifically name is QTEs, and this game has those, too. A less observant onlooker would assume I have Tourette's.The story is marginally less embarrassing than Final Fantasy X-2's, though no less thoughtless. You can talk all you like about VIII being the entry in the series that discovered recreational uses for household cleaners, but this story is the one that should have warranted an intervention. The only reason I'm happy that it didn't is because I did find enjoyment in Lightning Returns, which I will undoubtedly purchase as soon as it appears on the market, with a very small amount of self-loathing. This series is my guilty pleasure, though this game in particular is the one I will look you in the eye and say, "I swear, this isn't mine; I don't know how it got here".If you use the (all but necessary) community fixes, this is far and away a superior version than the console releases, but I can't recommend it to anyone who didn't already like the console releases. And if you did like the console releases... I am so sorry. Please, pick up Lost Odyssey.TL;DR - This is the best release of a hateful game, but only if you use the community fixes. I'd just rather be playing Lightning Returns.

I'd like to share my personal perspective on the quality of the port, given that this is Square Enix Japan's second true port onto PC.Pros:Released at a fair priceAnti-Aliasing up to 16xShadow resolutionsJapanese or English audioComes with DLCPassable resolution optionsNo secondary DRM platformCons:No anti-stropic filteringFrame-rate issuesThis is a great improvement over the last game. I never realized how far shadows had to be cranked to make a game look good though, so make sure to max that out. Anti-stropic has a really small performance impact for a night and day difference, and I would really love to see Square Enix look into that. Keep working on optimization, people will be far less forgiving on a true action game like FFXV.

I played this way back on my Xbox 360, and 100% it too, and I'll say that the game is great. It's better than XIII in every way really. I personally didn't like the first game that much, it was too restrictive and it took forever before you had some freedom but XIII-2 gets to the point very quickly compared to the first game and doesn't bombard you with as many tutorials. I would still recommend playing the first game or watch all the cutscenes on YouTube or something because this is definitely a direct sequel and you'll be very lost in the story if you don't check out the first game. The game does come with a XIII primer to help people who didn't play XIII to catch up so there's that too.I was pretty happy to see this game coming to the PC. Unfortunately, the game has some issues. There are two main issues that IF fixed will help this port immensely. There is a TON of screen tearing and the frame rate is all over the place (the lowest I hit was 20fps). My rig has an i7-3770K, 16GB RAM and a GTX 670 FTW so it's definitely not my PC which can't run the game at a constant 60fps on its highest settings. As for graphics options, don't expect a myriad of options. This is definitely a console port so don't expect advanced options like Tesselation, PCSS, and so on. You have resolution, shadow resolution and MSAA. The game is not ugly by any means though.I will still recommend it. It's definitely the best in the XIII series, but buy with caution. I hope that Squeenix release a patch soon and/or someone releases a mod which fixes these problems.

The worst Character in FF13-1: HopeThe best Character in FF13-2: Hope.Now for the real rewiev:In comparision to FF13-1, they improved the game in some parts, while making it worse in others. One thing they improved is the combat (no more stupid animation, when you switch your paradigms) but at the same time the enemies do not walk around in areas anymore, they will just appear out of nowhere, the problem with that is that random encounters respawn infinitely with some areas having a real high random encounter rate, which makes this change really annoying.The story is still good but a downgrade in comparison to FF13-1. They advertise the game with Lightning but you can´t play her anymore after the Prologue, which makes it really strange. But what makes this game special is the ability to time travel. You see some areas in different time periods and eras, which is kind of cool.This is where it gets complicated. Would I play this game if it would not be a FF-Game? Probably not.Would I play it, if it would be a Standalone FF-Game and not part of the Lightning Trilogy? Maybe, as the Story around Time Traveling is really interesting and well done.I had some fun with this game, while it also had some really annoying and frustrating parts. I would not play it again, but I am not regreting it that I played it in the first place.

This positive review is only because I have personally enjoyed FFXII-2 even though I am not a fan of so many things in this game.Final Fantasy, at least my favorite moments in this game anyway, all come from FF1-X for me.  I have never been a fan of how they keep trying to change more and more to a action based type of strategy game.  Almost like a hybrid nowadays, however, I understand that those descisions come out of demand more than loyalty.  With that in mind, I completely disregard that aspect which I hate most out of this game.The next is the story.  Like FFXIII, it is just a very weak and confusing story.  It is almost as if the writers all got together one summer to come up with the most "amazing plots full of twists, turns and intrigue".  What the casual gamer is left with is yet another very confusing story line which is supposed to be the hallmark of the FF series.  Gone are the days of good vs evil.  The days in which the games arch villian makes themselves known at the very start of the game and the entire story line through the game is a build up of that final showdown.  Just like XIII, it takes a while to even know who the true enemies are in this game.  I am only 2/5th through it and I honestly have no clue who the enemy will be.  Will it be Caius and Yeoul?  Those are the likely choices.  Or could it even be Sereh and Noel who are actually upsetting times paradox?  Or is it Lightning who is stuck in some sort of confusing limbo I have no clue how she would have got there or why.The story of this FF is perhaps the worst I have ever seen.  I am doing everyhting in my power to talk to EVERY NPC, read up on EVERY story line recap and have been following guides without spoilersto try and keep knowledgable about what is going on.Could writing like that actually be described as a masterpiece?  Sure, depends on how you look at it.  May work great for movies, but I am just not a fan of it belonging to a FF game.But I CAN get passed the story.  It has a lot of story so in a way it makes up for the lack of knowing what is happening.  Half the reason I want to keep playing every day is just to unravel what is happening.  Again, sounds like a compliment, but it truley is not.  I want the old more linear FF's of the old days to return.  Not this confusing crap.  GAMEPLAY: Plays just like 13.  So if you liked the combat style or it was good enough, then don't expect any surprises.  I believe they removed summons as well.  They are mentioned from a few NPC's that are not a part of the storyline at least.7/10 MUSIC: Has enoug original music to make this yet again one of the best reasons to ever play FF.  It carries over many songs and parts of songs from 13, but I also hear a few nods to FF1, FF3 and FFX in there (but not the exact songs from them).  Still not the best music I have ever heard in a FF game, but close. 9/10STORYLINE: So confusing.  There where no hints at all at the end of FF13 that any of this would happen.  They really pulled this one out of nowhere.  It takes a few hours for the utter confusion to sink in before you grudgingly admit this is the course the story line will be for pretty much the entire game.  You understand quickly that some alter-universe is happening, but it gets very hard to wrap your head around as to why and how.  In fact, after pouring over guides, walktrhoughs and wiki's as well as 40 hrs in game, I am still not understanding those two questions.  3/10 - Worst FF storyline everGRAPHICS: Seems good for a PC port to me.  980ti and 6780 i7 (top end).  Only complaint is that they need to support ultra-wide.  No FPS or stuttering issues to report.  CONTROLS 9CONTROLLER): The D-Pad for the Steam Controller works horrible with this game.  Just moving the camera around your character takes 3-7 swipes even at full sensativity.  I'd recomend playing this on a PS3 or XBox controller instead.  6/10Overall, it IS  a fun game.  Certainly not the best, bt it's WAY better than FF12.  And TBH, since FF13's story also sucked,  I find myself enjoying this one slightly more than FF13.  Probably because I already know the charcters more.  And the side content is massive in this game.  UPDATEI have finally beaten the game and the ending was very powerful and well written.  This game immediatly goes up a few notches because of that and you finally start piecing together the overall story a lot more even though their are some pretty obvious loopholes on why the game ended like it did given in earlier parts of the game you where lead to believe something else would happen.  So just beware, you really need to push yourself through the first 30 hours of this game before the meat finally starts coming off the bones and you can start seeing the story.  Another thing I forgot to mention was the top level voice acting the game has.  It was flawless and fit every major character perfectly.  Off to Lightning Returns.  God I hope no more time travel!

Alright so first of all: the port isn't great, but the complaints about the crashes in other reviews here are absolutely stupid.it takes about 5 minutes of googling to resolve these for good, some people are blowing stuff way out of proportion. (Note: namely disabling steam cloud save for the game, aswell as adding the d3d9.dll form your Windows/System32 folder to the game directory, done)Anyway, with that off the table: the game ultimately doesn't hold up to what the first one built, the characters feel bland the story makes absolutely no sense on any level. Pretty disappointing.The gameplay, while at first glance improved, is also alot worse than before. There's more stuff to do while outside of combat, most of which doesn't significantly add to the overall experience though. The combat itself got faster, but also alot dumbed down. The saboteur and synergist classes were made entirely pointless, free skill trees were more or less removed entirely and the game has unfair difficulty spikes at certain points, since you can end up in areas you were never intended to, ultimately forcing you to grind for hours to progress at certain points. Tl;dr: Skip this one, play the first and third one and watch/read a recap of this one somewhere online.

Absolutely buries the player in mechanics. Every 3-5 minutes, a new tutorial screen pops up to (badly) explain a new game mechanic. Nearly 6 hours into the game, this is still ongoing. Most of these mechanics have to do with capturing legally-distinct-from Pokemon and the game's awkward Time Travel related progression, to the degree that the game just becomes difficult to comprehend, or even think about, and I find myself shutting it down no sooner than I've booted it up, and moving on to other games.Final Fantasy XIII was a slow start that took time to hit its stride, but had an interesting world and just enough of a spark of wonder to grab me and keep me interested long enough to hit that stride, at which point it became a page turner I couldn't put away until it was done. This game has none of that. Five hours into Final Fantasy XIII, I wanted more, if only to answer some of my questions. Five hours into Final Fantasy XIII-2, I want NOTHING MORE TO DO WITH THIS GAME.The soundtrack is pretty, but that's on Spotify for me to enjoy whenever I like; I don't NEED the game for that. The story is convoluted even by modern Final Fantasy standards, and the new characters are shallow replacements for the original party who I frankly don't care in the slightest about.FFXIII was definitely a divisive game, but there was something special to it that I loved. FFXIII-2 abandons all of that to cater to people who weren't even fans of the saga to begin with, and in the process, it lost THIS FAN who loved XIII for what it was.

I recently gave Final Fantasy XIII a negative review, and was told that this one fixed many of the issues that that game had, and that it would be worth at least giving a try. So I did. Or I tried. What do I mean with "I tried?". Well, I tried to play it, but the port makes it unplayable.I can't make a rundown of the story, the gameplay or anything like that, because I've spent less than an hour with the game. The makers of this game seem to have taken the criticism of FF XIII having a far too long "tutorial" section to heart, and the bits of the game I could see felt a lot less railroaded, which are both things that would have been massive improvements. It did have a really long and uninteresting quick time event section though.Keys are partially re-bindable, but there are keys you can't rebind. Hope you like moving your hand between the numpad and backspace repeatedly, because you need to use the numpad for camera controls, and backspace for certain interactions, plus quick time event commands.Sadly the game does not work. At least not for me. The first issue I had was that the first menu that popped up after I had selected new game, which asked me if I wanted to play the tutorial or not, made the game completely unresponsive. There's a known issue with gamepads causing this issue, and it was also present in FF XIII, but my gamepad was not plugged in. Turned out I had to unplug my bog standard optical mouse, and my cellphone to get the game to respond (yes having a cellphone, a Samsung Galaxy S4 mini, plugged in for charging was enough to make the first menu not work).The second issue is massive stuttering. My computer exceeds the minimum system requirements by a wide margin, yet the game stutters constantly.After finally having got into the game, I noticed that whoever was responsible for the sound mixing had not done their job properly. I could not hear the dialogue due to the music being way to loud. Subtitles helped alleviate this issue, but it's still a rather big issue when you can't hear the character speak.And then the game crashed. Unceremoniously it just dumped me to the desktop with no error message.There might be a good game underneath all these technical issues, but this port is so bad that I'm unable to play the game. It's actually worse than the rather horrible port that FF XIII got.

After the first seven hours of this game I couldn't really begin to tell you what it's about. A generic anime villain ends the world in the future so a generic anime protagonist travels back to just after the events of FF XIII to team up with a school teacher. Something like that. Combat is mostly a copy and paste from FF XIII but with a Pokemon element. Instead of a third human character you can use a monster you've defeated to act in a pre-defined role. The leveling up system is similar to FF XIII as well, but a little confusing and not as satisfying . I always feel under-leveled to the point that I ultimately decided to quit the game because the boss I was fighting was so overpowered compared to me I felt sure it was supposed to be a scripted loss. The game wants you to fight each battle a very certain way, which a lot of FF games do, but it's taken to the extreme here. If you haven't spent the last hour leveling in the exact manner needed for the upcoming boss you're screwed. I could put the game on easy mode but the story isn't interesting enough to warrant that; quitting feels like the better option.

Definitely a step in the right direction from FF13, even might be worth your money, but there is still room for improvement... You're not completely free from corridors, character limitation, or no-think combat, but the game is just too short to make these things unbearable.You can rush through main story in 30 or so hours and it won't be even that difficult to do it, but you can also choose to mess around, do side quests and explore areas and timelines you won't visit in the main line. Yes, timelines, this game has time travel. You visit the same places in different years, to access different sub-locations, complete quests from the present in the past, defeat enemy in the past so he can't kill you in the future, that kind of thing.The story itself is still meh. Humanity goes extinct, so you go back in time to change that. Along the way you're also trying to reunite Serah and Lightning (wasn't that the plot of the first game?) Most of the time you have canonically no idea where to go, so you jump around timelines hoping for the best, and sure enough, eventually you get where you need to go. But you did an oopsie along the way and the whole world is being destroyed. That's the whole story.Since you can jump around time, you can jump back to a previous point in your journey too, and sometimes even make a decision that leads you to a non-canon ending. Cool addition.Combat is pretty much the same as before, but 1) you never get locked into a bad team during the story, because the team is always the same 2 people, and 2) it gets a change up in the form of monster partners. Most common enemies can be tamed and put into your party, each one has some unique abilities, and you can transfer them around to create super-killing machine. It's pretty good, though really grindy to min-max.So on its own, it's a thumbs up. BUTThe game's first moment is telling you that ending of FF13 didn't happen, and from there it spirals into chaos that is only sorted in the third game. On the other hand, if you never start this game, that ending did happen, and everyone walked off into a happy sunrise. So you have a choice. Stop at the first game, or go the distance for all three.

I will talk about game play  This is the first and Olney final fantasy game I have played. The game play has two  major game play  elements   the battles  which you can actually do on an auto battle system .  where your sitting there pushing the  A button on your x box controller or whatever . until a quick time event where you have to  push a  series of buttons in sequence  and some areas have puzzles that you have to solve .       This game  can go on pretty much almost forever,  As you can travel back and forth between   areas  and after you get the main ending There are at least two mini games available to you if not more.   so a lot of content in this game .   However some areas the  battles get repetitive and annoying at times  showing the same  animated graphics sequences over and over again. and   some of the puzzles take a long time to solve this is not a short game .  It has really nice graphics  and good voice acting  I found the easy battle system to be an advantage  as I liked to drink while playing this and eye hand coordination was not an issue with the exception of the quick time events.  .There are also  NPC's that ask you to find various things for them and you have to go back and forth through the time line to  get them. For the most part however these are not mandatory items. For  getting the standard ending with the exception of  gravitational cores. and wild artifacts     Check your  computer system with the spec's on this this page  in the negative reviews there is a lot of people complaining that they can not run the game I had no problem with this .    Should you buy this game  I would wait for a sale though it does have a lot of content It is an older game, From other negative reviews it seems that  It was simply moved from  the old game play system  with very little to adapt it to  pc's   As I said I was lucky and had no problems with Running it..  But the thing that did bother me is there is no function for turning off the background music  In some areas particularly when I was doing puzzles I muted my computer sound system , But given these two  problems I would not pay it at  its current price of 22.49 Canadian . The partial controller support  icon  makes me also  cautious about recommending this title   at full price as well.   Good points    1  a lot of content  with a lot of available hours of game play   2 great voice acting   3 good graphics   4 easy battle system   5 at least two  mini games after  finishing main story line.  Bad points   1 can not turn off  background music   2  battle system although easy repetitive nature of battles can get annoying  3 seems not to operate on all PCs  4 partial controller support with no signs of square ENEX updating system,      Recommendation  Yes  buy it  but  wait to purchase on sale for about 4 or 5 $ ,  The three  big negatives that  made me suggest a reduced price are  1 unable to turn off background  music   2 seems not to have been given vary many technical modifications for pc  3 partial controller support icon .   4 older abandoned game square Enix  Seems not to be interested in this tittle or support for pc users.

The first game of the series was perceived as being too linear, so Squeenix tried to remedy it. Instead of going from one map to another in a linear fashion, you go from one map to another, then back to the first map, but at a different time. The story progress is still set on a strict path, so when you really think about it, the game is linear, but with maps repeating themselves 2-4 times, which is brilliant if you look at it from the development side of things! From the player's perspective, it's not too bad, considering you can leave a map at any time and load another to finish up a sidequest or grind some CP for levels. As for the story, you can hate it or love it, but it's a separate matter if you can understand it. Having played through the game and done all the sidequests, I still don't know if I understood it or not. I didn't bother much with the DLC; it seemed pointless. You either play Texas hold'em as Sazh in a casino or do some 1 vs. 1 grinding with Lightning; the arena is nice if you want a real challenge.I'll briefly mention what I liked about this game: the music.Alright, now that that's out of the way, let's talk about the cons:1) Characters and dialogue - I just can't stand that every other sentence these teenagers blabber out is supposed to sound "deep" and perhaps they can if you're high enough. The topics the main characters dabble in are philosophy, motivational poster quotes, and moral high ground, with your usual anime tropes as filler: something about needing to protect certain individuals and defeat the villain.2) Level design - there are some really weird and archaic design choices made, all with the sole purpose of wasting your time. I'll bring up some very specific examples, like the entirety of Augusta Tower - not fun, not challenging, very annoying.The weather control device in Archylte Steppe, there are 4 weather modes that you can switch between by using 2 levers. You need to set the lever combination (up or down) for specific weather, which then triggers a 6~ second unskippable cutscene, and unless you're a speedrunner, you will not have memorized the combinations, so you try again, hope for the best, and look at the damn cutscene again. Why not simply give me a selection of the 4 weather modes, with the currently active one being a different colour? It doesn't take me out of the game, and most importantly, it doesn't waste my time.The slow giant rock critter ride in Sunleth Waterscape was okay the first couple of times, but after the third time, I despised it.The escalators in Academia 400, the ones that go in the opposite direction, so you either bunny hop through it or interact with a lever for a couple of seconds to switch directions, just why?Last map has the tetris block barges: you stand and wait on a platform ledge for the block to turn towards you, you get on the block and wait for it to turn towards the next platform, you move to that platform, and you do it again, and again, and again. The devs must've really thought the environment visuals were simply too good not to force the player to "enjoy" them. I think on this map you spend more time waiting than doing anything else, and that includes the encounters. And the "best" part about this map is that you get to redo it from the start if you want to gather all the fragments (because of the bestiary collection).3) Character progression - did you know that levelling Commando on a big crystal gives +2 bonus strength and levelling Ravager on a big crystal gives +2 bonus magic? What about the fact that if you level Synergist to an odd level (e.g., from 10 to 11) on a big crystal, you'll get bonus magic? And the best one is of course levelling Saboteur, even level on big crystal gives bonus strength and odd gives bonus magic. The maximum level for each role is 99, so if you waste too many levels of the above roles on small crystals, you'll make your characters much weaker than if you'd meticulously followed the rules, and you cannot reset the Crystarium. I personally didn't notice these rules being mentioned in the game, so you'd need to pay close attention to know this.4) Monster Breeder - The 3rd unit on your side in a battle is a monster that you capture. Not that I mind the fact that you can breed monsters to become better than either of your main characters, but you'd need to do quite a bit of research and experimentation to know how, what, and when to fuse monsters together to get the best passive abilities. Aside from fusing monsters together, the monsters have their own Crystarium, which is a bit different; they use items instead of CP, which means grinding for items. Here's an example of how to get one of the most powerful Ravagers in the game: a Blue Chocobo. First, you need to catch one, and a Blue Chocobo is a rare Pokemon, so getting it to even spawn without the Battlemania Fragment skill can take some time. Next up, you need to get lucky to actually catch it; there's another Fragment skill that can help with that, but RNG is RNG. Because it's a Ravager role, you'll want to boost its magic, which means leveling the Crystarium with mostly mana-type materials (for levels 11-40, I used potent materials, the rest all mana). You'll need to level it to at least 86, which is good because getting mana crystals is a pain, so much so that I stopped levelling the bird after level 95 since it's asking for 10 crystals per level and I can't be bothered anymore. It didn't really matter; I still beat the final boss in 2 minutes instead of the target time of 11 minutes. Got it levelled up to 86+? Great, now all you need to do is just capture 14 other monsters, a few of which are rare, one of which only 3-4 exist on a map, and you'll need two of them, so better save before battle and reload if capture fails, then close the gate and redo some story parts to get the second one. Level up these monsters as well until specific abilities become available, then infuse them in the correct order, and you're done. I understand why some people would enjoy this process, not me, though. Granted, creating the most overpowered critter isn't required to beat the game.5) The good old Japanese grind for 100% - because sometimes it's not the skill that matters, but how much time you're willing to give. Obviously, playing 100% of a game is optional, and I definitely would've hated the game less if I had not decided to go for it, but here we are. It's mostly about Fragments, and you'll actually want quite a lot of them to unlock certain Fragment skills. I'll just mention a few good examples of the grind. Captain Cryptic quiz in Academia 4xx, getting a question wrong will make him disappear and reappear in one of the 12 possible locations, so you'll need to search around this annoying map. Once you get all the questions correct, you'll get a Fragment, and now you get to do it four more times! I think nobody would find this fun, but this is the way of the Japanese grind. The Monster Professor fragment, which requires you to completely fill out the bestiary, will require you to have finished the game and gotten most of the Paradox endings to finally complete it; needless to say, it was the last one I completed. What's so bad about filling the bestiary? For example, did you know that a Cactuar enemy can use an ability to change into a Giant Cactuar during a fight? In fact, that's the only way to encounter a Giant Cactuar. Considering it takes a long time until it uses the ability, you'll have beaten the Cactuar way before it does it. How would you know to wait for Cactuar to morph into Giant Cactuar without looking it up on the internet? I have no clue. How would you know where to find the missing monsters, actually nevermind, how would you even know which monsters you're missing from your list without looking it up on the internet? I have no clue once again. I suppose you'd just go map by map and try to spawn all the monsters until you thought you had them all.

There are many problems already with the port itself discussed in many of the best reviews. To fix them just search up the pcgaming wiki for solutions. Even after applying the mods the game continues to crash. I did not like this game. After spending more than 50 hours and a will to continue to 100% it at sometime in the future, I would not recommend this game to anyone. I'm honestly appalled at those reviews that state that this is one of their favorite Final Fantasy games. To each their own, but I found there to be only one real moment of heart and emotion I felt for the characters and events that unfolded. I don't know if I've matured to some degree or if the Japanese style writing has gone downhill so much. I watch Japanese movies occasionally and they still come off great every now and then. Japanese game writing though, Death Stranding, FFXIII-2, and the Kingdom Hearts series in general have no sense of real human emotion, everyone comes off as an atypical anime action hero. They feel sad when the story insists it upon them to. They are happy just to get the other character happy. Lets tell the viewer why they are sad and when they bond they'll just tell each other they are bonding.FFXIII-2 has only two main characters and they some how develop them less than the 5 of the previous effort. We spend time jumping back and forth through timelines while the narrator discusses the perils of defying fate. The main villain seems to note defying fate is wrong while defying fate itself. While the game is not the hallway that FFXIII is, it still is rather limited. you get to go to different world, meet up with old friend. You never stay in an area long enough to get a connection. You travel time to see who its like in the past and future, but nothing like on the scale of Link to the past or even ocarina. Each era is basically nailed down to as a Mario 64 level. Lets do this objective to get a star, move on to next level. There isn't any moment of urgency. We do what we do to "fix the timeline and find Lightning". We know at the beginning we are not fixing the time cause the narrator tell the audience we are in the wrong. Lightning is a god like being who can see the future, so there is literally nothing that I can empathize with her as well. She tells us what will happen in the story too. Noel sorta has an arc, but thats it caius and Serah don't do much really in evolution. I've been a fan of the Final Fantasy and Squaresoft/Enix RPG's since playing FFX and Kingdom Hearts. My point of entry is important when trying to explain my perspective on this game and the franchise as a whole. I haven't play FFXIII in a decade so bare with me. I enjoyed FFXIII for what it was, an okay story about fighting fate. The consequences of which are thrown upon two of the main characters, who may or not be homosexual. The characters are great. Vanille and Fang at least are. They have layers and different facets of their "personality" emerge depending on who they interact with. The only two wet blankets could be Snow and Lightning, but they serve the archetypal purpose of strong stoic character, and another who is romantically in love. The thematic link between all the MC's are wanting to protect someone who seems fated to die/leave. They all fight the power, oppressors, and it leads to being able to get what they want. Besides Two of the main characters, because they were the cause of much of the suffering. Thesis statement: who defies fate, should they defy fate, what are the consequences? Answer you can, you must, consequences are worse if you hold off presumably. Even then the ending is ambiguous enough to allow the viewer the freedom to decide what was right themselves.Final Fantasy X(favorite) top 5 of ALL TIME, sort of begins like an Isekai anime. You are thrown into the world without any prior knowledge. You learn and feel for the racism of the Al Bhed and Rikku, Yuna as half Al Bhed draws parallels to the half Guado villain Seymour. The main characters abandonment issues are address directly through out the game in his fathers character interactions through flashbacks and indirectly through inner thoughts of Tidus. The religion portrayed throughout the game is shown with reverence and is heavily catholic inspired. It works to help draw the player into believing in the use of the religion for the characters. Then slowly they dish out the relevatory lies. You learn through minor characters and Historians what the world used to be like. While everything in the beginning is explained exposition they still have cutscenes to show ritualistic dances and movements to add more culture to the religion. While 10's characters may not be the most exciting they all have interesting personality quirks and a arc. This with an innovative level up system and great story with scope. This is not even mentioning how every area to me is memorable. Maclania crystal, moon flow, a river on an elephant with shumi bluemen. Farplanes, thunderplanes... This not even mentioning again the fantastic sequel which finishes minor character arcs, MAECHEN!!!! FF7 the supposed classic. I remember hating the story the first time around. I replayed it sometime in 2019 and was surprised at how much the game tries to be the best game ever made. Pushing the playstation to its limit. Expressive character movements portray emotions such as anger and sadness. The music is sweeping and sprawling. I love the way it plays with memory and trauma. Theres nuance, for a story about an evil corporation, which ff 13-2 is lacking altogether. Shinra the company is not all evil AVALANCHE is not all good. Like 10 it has great pace which drops off in the second and third disc. Still great and charming. The cursing is absolutely sublime. The sh!t Cid and Barret says to Sherry and Cloud respectively. FF6 second favorite, drops off right at the end. Amaxing sprite work each character has an arc. WOR is a doozy, but thats another plus.FF 9 is pretty close to 6, but its been awhile. I started to replay in 2019 and was struck by the visuals and fun MC's. It looks like picture book or a stage play. I found it odd the hate for the game. I get not liking 8, but come on FF games are mostly cute. FF8 I like more than 7, but its been so long. It has "realistic" visuals, but it still has the classic humor even if its a bit dryer than FF7. A lot of things stick out visual but the characters are probably the least interesting.Anyway 13-2 is charmless with competent gameplay. It was not short enough. Feel free to disagree! ;D

WARNING, this is a recommendation with a huge list of "BUT"s and things you need to know and is very much not a glowing one. And first thing to know - do NOT play this game with steam cloud on, turn it off before you even start in the game library properties, otherwise the game will crash very often during "now loading" screens and attemtps to switch to offline saves mid-game will result in infinite loading screens for that game, unless switched back to cloud saves. Also, the game port is pretty buggy, you should search for a rain effect fix if you value your eyesight and the game will load like 1/5 times when you launch it, just keep trying.So after this lenghy "the port is horrible" opening let's get to the actual game. What's good about it is that it actually tries to use all those ideas found (and wasted) in Final Fantasy XIII properly and succeedes in many cases. All RPG systems and mechanics are still flawed, but are much more fun to play with, battles are less boring and actually require some thought and the progressions is rather open. The levels are no longer "go from point A to point B in a corridor" and while they're reused constantly with variations via the whole time traveling plot, they're mostly fun and look good. Game has a system similar to oldschool random encounters, which is both good and annoying. There are horrible puzzle sections, although they are ussually tied to optional areas and quests. And there are few super annoying and boring platforming sections, but the game is not too insane with those.What is also good is that the plot is happening. It's weird to put "this storydriven RPG has plot" as a plus, but after FF XIII that has nothing happening for dozens of hours, having things happen, story expand, characters develop all the time is great. The story itself is, like with FF XIII, more interesting in theory than in execution and few twists and turns feel not just silly but completely undermining some of the other stuff, but it has moments. And is surprisingly darker than you might expect. But overall, storytelling and themes are good, waaaay better than hours of nothing from FF XIII, even if a lot of stuff feels stupid or absurd and tone can be off by a lot.It looks good, it sounds very good, if sometimes unexpected (soundtrack switches from usual FF, to Resident Evil/Parasite Eve 2 feel (same composer), to Devil May Cry 3-4 in seconds and always catches you off guard). It has very welcome tweaks to UI and controls. It's a bit too experimental for it's own good. But it's also pretty fun. Not something to go into for a full price, especially with the port quality like this, but a pretty interesting jRPG nonetheless.

Continuing my save part-way through was a struggle, but coming back to the game with fresh eyes really made me appreciate the level design, music, and battle system. If you approach this game as "FF's take on a 3D collectathon platformer," (and if that's something that sounds fun to you), then you're in for a treat. The story involves time travel and was written by Japanese people, so don't overthink it. Also, near the end of the game, I appreciated Serah and Noel "enough." They're nobody's favorite, but they do have some development and become interesting eventually. Here's my original review from like 5-7 years ago:"This is one of the worst FF games of all time. You'll love it if you're a die-hard fan of FF13, though I am not aware of the existence of any such person. The characters, story, environment, mechanics, and absolutely everything just feel soulless and sterile, which is excruciating for games this linear. FF13-3 (Lightning Returns) is great though"I deliberately called it "linear" to insult it. By design, it's a wildly non-linear game, but the timeline/world selection is literally a series of closed-off zones on a few lines... The game has in many ways improved on the FF13 formula, though it has one major addition which made it a lot less enjoyable for me compared to the previous game. In FF13 all mobs you were going to fight were visible on the path in front of you with the exception of some triggered events. In FF13-2 most mobs spawn on you randomly, . It is possible to outrun these and avoid the fights in most cases (unless you are in tight corridors, that is), though this feature still severely detracts from the game in my opinion. Pokemon is a fun game, but if you are like me, and get to a point where you just cringe every time a new random encounter interrupts your progress, when you for instance are searching an area for an item, then FF13-2 will probably irk you the exact same way.It has of course been a key feature in many of the older Final Fantasy games, though is harder to stomach in this modern installment, especially after playing through FF13 first. I suspect this is due to the way enemies were themed to their location in older games. In FF13-2 they can literally spawn in from different timelines, meaning the fights are completely disjointed from the area you are currently in (for the most part, anyway).I played through FF13 twice, and it's a game i love despite it's flaws, though i do not think i will ever finish FF13-2. Besides, compared to the cast of the previous game, Serah and Noel are far less interesting to me (granted, i have only played it for 15 hours, their stories might get fleshed out later on, sadly i will never get there).

After a lengthy development cycle, Square-Enix took the main criticisms of FFXIII and implemented those changes into its direct sequel, FFXIII-2. Maps are no longer corridor shaped, your party is modifiable from the start, and exploration / puzzle solving is at the forefront. Some of the things in this game are done significantly better than its predecessor while others might honestly be worse. Namely, the story's overarching explanation of anything and all things weird is "It's a Paradox, Kupo!". Without given an entire synopsis of the game, you and your party are tasked with restoring the timeline to its former glory and fixing the future by doing so. Overall, some of the mechanics and writing are cheesy but other times they are well played out. The reason I remember this game so fondly is because of the soundtrack. So, even if you don't like the game, I would consider giving the soundtrack a listen by itself. Most of the tracks have lyrics with English lyrics, sung by a variety of artists. The general genre is electronic, but there are a few bits and bobs throughout the OST to make you stick around if that's not your thing.Final statement: Give the game a chance if you like JRPGS, Pokemon style "catching" mechanics, puzzle solving, and time travel.
