Awesome title from Square, even though the port could've been a little bit better, but still, the experience is there...(sidenote: I've beaten both FFXIII and FFXIII-2 first on Xbox and now on PC)Mechanics: IMO Better than FFXIII; Everything feels more responsive while switching paragims and selecting abilities (it was veery restricive in FFXIII, to that extend, that I was thinking about modding it for the sake of beating Long Gui) there are still some balance issues and, if you plan the whole development of your characters beforehand, you will end up with killing everything in one salvo without stagger, srsly, if you want the challenge later on in the game, try mods that increase HP, Strength and Mana of all enemies (google "FFXIII-2 Difficulty Enhancement Mod"). Oh, and the +50% ATB rate weapons are OP, totally OP. Since you get them, there isn't anything else worth looking when it comes to weapons (MAYBE +1 ATB weapons for that 6 ATB segments action lol)Story: Interesting, yet somewhat disappointing and too short for my taste (when this game was coming out, I was hoping for the title that would be like FFX-2 was to FFX). Tbh I liked FFXIII's story better despite its linear feel, but it does not mean FFXIII-2 sucks in that regard. It has some awesome and funny moments, plus you decide what to do next (you can techically get ~140 fragments before beating the main plot, but that would make the final boss battle laughable considering the amount of CP you will acumulate throughout the game). Overall, it's damn dark compared to the first title and, let's be honest, how many FFs are there where the "bad guys" actually win?As for the DLCs, PLAY'EM! the boss battles are a lot better than the main story (read "more difficult").Replayability: The amount of combinations that there is when it comes to Serah/Noel stats is just astonishing. Every player is able to create his/her own, unique character setup with the new CP system, that does not make your characters unstoppable. Each development strategy has its strenghts and weaknesses, and leads to different late game scenario, which is shaped by person's individual needs when progerssing though the game, A BIG PLUS for that.Is this game better than FFXIII? In some ways, yesDo I like it? YESIs it my favorite FF? Nope, that title goes to FFXWould I recomment it? If you've played FFXIII and liked it, ABSOLUTELYScore:chocobo/10

ProsConsFirst, let me tell you one thing:  I bought and went into this game expecting an exeptionally bad piece of software. What I got exceeded my expectations by a long margin. This game is - believe it or not - .But first things first.It is terrible. Just plain awful. Even if you thought the story of the first Final Fantasy XIII was fine and never left any questions unanswered, XIII-2's story will most likely go over your head. I have to admit, it lost me very early on. It  makes sense in the end, but then again...not really. Don't try to wrap your head around it.It's not even the fact that it is about time travel, which in itself has always been one of the most confusing topics in movies and video games, no, it's just that the story writer went and took a rather simple concept and filled it with lots and lots of 'technobabbles' and weird pseudo-scientific assumptions to make it sound more complex than it actually is.Some of the dialogues in this game reminded me of what it feels like to watch an episode of Star Trek.Half the time they don't make any sense. Other times the characters just blurt out seemingly random thoughts and assertions, which we are - apparently - supposed to take for granted. More often than not they just make up the rules as they go along.It starts with lines like : To which to the  answer is:(You'll hear the " paradoxes did it" bit a lot.)Or how about this one from the casino:Just.....go with it. There is only one real way to play this game in my opinion. Turn your brain off, don't think too much about what's happening, take in the atmosphere and relax whilst listening to the phenomenally good soundtrack.Which leads me to the next bullet point.If you compare it directly to Final Fantasy XIII, then this game is undoubtedly much more open. Every map has lots of secret (and sometimes invisible) stuff to discover in every corner. And I personally just love the attention to detail everywhere, like when your character's foot step noise dynamically changes depending on the surface he's walking on, including small puddles on the pavement, or when you use your weird 'Moogle Magic' and every NPC in the vicinity gathers around in curiousity. The world generally feels alive and is really atmospheric.My only gripe is the way they handled invisible level bounderies. It is kind of immersion breaking when your characters can jump up towering trees that are dozens of meters high, but at the same time the knee high rubble in another area proves to be an insurmountable obstacle and you need to "find a way around it".Some of the aforementioned items you can find allow you to unlock more and more areas and side quests. Speaking of side quests though, the area selection hub does - in my opinion - a poor job in distinguishing the main story line from side quests. With how often I traveled back and forth between different time lines and areas I wasn't always quite sure if I was doing a mandatory or an optional quest. And in some cases a quest is even optional in the beginning, up until the game tells you that it is now mandatory for the story progression, and you realize you already did all that 6 hours ago. Oh well.The missions itself feature a good variety of objectives. Nothing  out of the ordinary, but they usually require specific actions in specific locations and times to change something along the time line. It never felt like i was doing boring chores.Now let's get to my favorite part of the game.Aside from walking around and talking to NPCs, the field gameplay features small 'puzzles' every now and then. Most of them are insultingly easy, though. Some of them are plain annoying.Now, the battle system is largely the same as XIII's. However, it has one neat little addition. You can now recruite Pokémon to fight at your site.I have to admit, I'm a sucker for the Shin Megami Tensei series and its demon recruiting and fusion mechanic. And Final Fantasy XIII-2's system is kind of similar to this.Whenever you kill a monster there is a chance to 'capture' it. You now have your very own lvl. 1 version of this monster with basic abilities, which you can either keep leveling up with specific monster materials (random drops, loot; can be bought later) or you decide to infuse it, in order to pass some of its abilities on to a stronger monster. This way you can spend dozens of hours trying to create unique and powerful allies. Unfortunately, as much as you can customize your monsters, the same thing does not apply to your main characters. Their level progression is much more set in stone. Both of them have obvious roles they excell at. Like, Serah is a much better Ravager than Noel, while Noel is the better Synergist and so on, so you obviously want to focus on these first.Additionally, the very high encounter rate lets you accumulate way too many CP (exp) too quickly, leading to overleveled characters, who steamroll every story boss in a matter of seconds (both main characters even stopped learning new abilities about 30% and were completely maxed out a little over halfway through the game).Speaking of encounters in this game, they technically aren't random encounters, as they appear on the map in front of you and you could theoretically avoid them. This is easier said than done, however, as many of the enemies move significantly faster than you and hit you before you can escape.One thing I did like about the encounters, though, was how in some locations there is a rare chance to spawn significantly stronger monsters than usual. Sort of like optional bosses who randomly appear in certain regions.And don't worry, even if you manage to die at any point, you will never lose anything. You have the option to retry any battle at any time and the game generally autosaves left and right.The autosave feature also reminds me of my final bullet point.Lets get this straight. The PC version of Final Fantasy XIII-2 is one of the worse console ports out there. Thus, it can and will randomly crash during loading screens.  it autosaves everytime you enter or exit an area. So, I never lost any progress, personally.Another problem is the awful frame rate. Currently there is no surefire way to fix the frame rate stuttering, everyone has. Forcing V-Sync and triple buffering and disabling the weird 'maximized windowed mode' (yes, the game runs in windowed mode, even if you choose the full screen option in the launcher) made it somewhat bearable for me. Some of the more populated areas will most likely always cause problems, though.If they ever manage to fix these issues, this whole point becomes moot.  But until this happens, the game may or may not give you a headache due to its unstable framerate.

Part Two Of Final Fantasy Thirteen. I tried this game(P2) years ago after beating Part One(P1) but I couldn't play it for a variety of reasons. So, bad stuff first so you can work through it.P2 has to be modded. Don't even try to enjoy it before modding it.1 - P2's volume is all over the place. Even after receiving a mod for the music, I still found not only the song volume was all over the place from song to song, but the battle sounds were still much louder than the voices, so sometimes when characters talk during battle(like when we hear Yeul talking), we can't actually hear them over the noise of battle. If you decide to mod the music, I suggest you set it to 60-80 percent, depending on how tolerant you are of the annoyingly loud songs that are in P2. You could also just make multiple versions of the music, including some over 100 percent volume for those zones where you really want the nice and quiet music to be louder without blowing your ears off with the interface/battle sounds.2 - P2 crashes almost constantly because of the mandatory autosave feature. Workaround for this is to disable steam cloud support for it, sadly.3 - The graphics are not optimized for whatever software/hardware is used. I had to change the 3D settings for P2 according to some very old guide to get it to be smooth and play better.It's trying to give players OCD.4 - The story and side quests blend together so much that the only stuff that really feels like true side questing is their equivalent of 'Gold Saucer' but on the plus side compared to P1, at least it has a Gold Saucer. P1 made me feel like the side quests were part of the main story. Most of P2 has me repeatedly going back to zones for little to no reason and being inconsistent with whether I can complete or undertake a mission, sometimes I could have the mission completed before it's assigned to me, other times I have to wait for I don't even know what to get things to trigger.5 - Vercingetorix, the Doomherald...one of the unnecessarily difficult marks from P1 has got the same move list as and looks like the mark named Yomi in P2. Why don't they bring back a cool mark like Ruby/Emerald Weapon or something from FF8/9? I don't think it's a fun idea to have us do it again in here. Long Gui is back, too. Makes sense though I guess but what about the other turtles/tortoises? Neochu seems to be not here though which is a relief, just the weaker Ochu.6 - Exploration is a burden sometimes. I wish the game had encounter-none available, this would be the best solution to this mess. It has encounter fewer but couldn't get it until the game was nearly already finished which is completely different from my experience in FF8 where encounter-half and encounter-none were both available relatively early if effort was made for it.7 - Even if P2 isn't crashing due to steam cloud autosave glitching, I still find I have to go to the Historia Crux(timeline) before something happens so I can save to another save slot. Going to the timeline will automatically save, so trying to save after something happens to a new slot is impossible. This is a rather annoying flaw, but since the game is meant to be played again and again, I can't go back and catch the story action again any time soon, but eventually instead. Which can be very irritating, especially if I wasn't expecting story action. Thankfully, story action can be paused, but I'm not particularly used to doing this.P2 has made some worth-while improvements over P1. Time for the good stuff.1 - I can change the leader during battle. This allows more control during combat compared to P1.2 - Monsters can be recruited, which is interesting, although it's one of those things that could have a better set of data for the player so they don't feel forced to look at guides for the sake of their third party member(TPM). Although the 2 main characters in P2 have access to job names identical to those from P1, they have some significant limitations which are made up for with the TPM's power/flexibility, which is kept in check by the fact players can only switch between 3 different monsters in a battle(each is a single job character). 3 - Those points above bring life into the combat system which is an important part of any RPG. There's no shortage of enemies that are undefeatable and enemies that are challenging to keep players wondering about the game. This is the plus side to the minus of constantly feeling like I'm going back and forth like a ping pong ball unlike the way a traditional RPG feels.4 - Outfits are pretty interesting. I can use the default outfits for Serah and Mog, as well as her sidekick Noel, or some alternative outfits. However, there are not very many outfits for them(except for Mog). Black/White Mage outfits are the good ones. I like Cat the most for Mog but I would like to assume with so many outfits that many people like some other outfits more. The outfits work very well and-are-present in most cutscenes.5 - P2 has a guest fighter in one of the zones which brings back the nostalgia from many of the previous FF games.I also think it improves in at least one way compared to FFX-2.6 - P2 includes music from P1 although it won't happen in the first zones accessed. I like good music, and some of the best songs from P1 make a return in P2.7 - I dislike that they took away everything from FFX's combat system when making FFX-2. It had a decent combat system in its own right, but for a sequel it felt kind of bad not improving upon the old. However, I don't think FFX's combat system was as bad as FFXIII's. Using any older battle system, even if it was a poor one, and then making it better? Big thump up from me.Will update the review after doing the post game content.

Tldr; Low FPS, Visually Unappealing, Music is Hit or Miss, Story is Final Fantasy, Battle System is Boring. I've always wanted to try this title out. I've been told to avoid the first instalment and start with this one. Of course the PC version is a terrible port, however, there are awesome people who've done their best to patch up this game. Sadly, it doesn't do too much. The game will always run around 20 FPS when in the over-world and battles are below 40. This wouldn't be a problem if it was consistent. Despite having all the additional fixes/mods, the game doesn't look too great. I understand it's from the X360/PS3 era, but man, Grey sure is my favourite colour. Everything looks washed out and bland and for some reason the character models just look ugly (to me at least). Even applying the Xbox Button Prompts patch, the game refuses to show them. If you wish to apply any additional patches, you have to start over and apply *every* patch again in a certain order. Not worth the time or energy to get this game going. Play any other FF game (a part from other FFIII titles).As for the game play, it's automation. You don't do much besides *watch* your characters fight. Your choices don't seem to matter (for the early portion of the game) as the game encourages you to Auto-Battle. The only thing you have to do is Paradigm Shift which isn't thrilling. I wouldn't mind slogging through the mind-numbing battles, but the story is not interesting (again, visually unappealing), the English Voice Direction is god awful and dialogue is sped through with no one having chance to breathe. If you find early 2000s anime dubs to be funny, this will be for you. You're best off watching the cut-scenes on YouTube instead of playing an Auto Battle game.

It's imperative you do research before purchasing this game, unfortunately. Look on the Steam forums for potential hardware issues (AMD CPU/GPU owners especially) and only decide after reading around. Depending on your rig, this game either works fine or with a tonne of issues (if at all). Sadly, I am in the latter group.However, the game itself is really enjoyable. I originally played it on the PlayStation 3 so I have prior and relevent experience with it. It is a relatively easy game as far as Final Fantasy titles go - even moreso if you're a well-seasoned RPGer and spend a lot of time exp grinding / farming. Aside from the main content of the story, there are quite a few additional things you can amuse yourselves with: chocobo racing, completing the monster log, slot machines, additional areas to explore, min-maxing pets and of course, the PC version comes with all of the DLC included.The environments are varied and interesting, full of colour and detail. In addition to the main characters, you're able to capture and train a pet for the third party slot. They will fulfil a specific role (Medic, Saboteur, Ravager etc.) and you can build paradigm sets to suit your play style.FFXIII-2 is designed with casual play in mind, I believe. There's a catch-up cutscene every time you load a previously-saved game, to remind you of your progress in the main story missions. This game also has, in my opinion, one of the best Final Fantasy soundtracks in recent years.Worth a try, certainly.

As much as I didin't like FFXIII, it at least had a satisfactory, conclusive ending. Unfortunately we now have a sequel that basically throws it out of the window, because FFXIII-2s main focus is time travel. Poorly done time travel that creates plot holes the size of Jupiter.Throughout the game, you hop through several time periods to help unravel the overall story line. Unfortunately, this chopped narration left me confused on what the underlying tale was trying to tell. What is left is a jumbled, forced gibberish that some game designers called a story line. It also doesn't help that most of the plot is explained through long and uninteresting monologues, rather than actual cutscenes with dialogues. And when FFXIII-2 finally concludes with now infamous sequel-bait my only thought was "Really?".Also, be prepared to hear the word "paradox" at least five times in each cut-scene. It's a convenient maguffin that drives the plot forward.Combat system taken almost verbatim from FFXIII with all its ups and downs. Since your two protagonists are the only "real" party members, you now have a random chance to recruit monsters, which you can then add to your team. They all have innate paradigm, but you can level them up individually and even fuse them together to create stronger versions. Unfortunately challenge is mostly gone as 95% of battles are easily doable using auto-battle autopilot.FFXIII-2 tries so hard to fix some problems of FFXIII. Long corridors are gone and replaced by (mostly) open areas. There are actual side quests, various challenges, different paradox "endings", post-game content and a new game plus. There are also a handful of minigames located in poor-man's version of Gold Saucer from FFVII. All this makes for an overall better gaming experience. Base game took me 24 hours to complete, but I imagine that if were to 100% it, it would take at least twice as much if not more. Be wary that few pieces of content is locked on PC - nothing that modding can't fix.Port-wise it is a tad better than FFXIII. We now have an option to change screen resolution, shadow resolution and anti-aliasing (MSAA), but why do I have to use third-party programs to unlock framerate, fix minor UI problems and graphical glitches?Final Fantasy XIII-2 is another, after FFX-2, sequel that no one asked for. It left me indifferent but since Steam only allows Yes or No then... can't recommend.

In some ways I find it better than FF13, in some ways I find it worse. The two should have a combat baby.While I appreciated that the monster party member makes for a diverse range of party builds, it also feels tacked on. I would have preferred to have had a third fleshed out character, access to more skills for all characters, and an improved crystarium. I also found it annoying that main characters had limited access to skills from each class.I did not care for the anomaly puzzles. This felt like a waste of my time. While I think the floor falling puzzle and the clock puzzle are interesting, they had no place in this game, and I do not need them tacked on in a nonsensical way to waste my time.After about 40 hours, this game began to crash often upon trying to go to new areas from Historia Crux. Disabling Steam overlay appears to have fixed this. By the time I obtained over 140 fragments and realized I had to kill every enemy in the game, and also fight some very beastly monsters, to finish all 160 fragments, I abandoned the idea of finishing the fragments and just beat the game. A pretty good port of a pretty alright game. XIII-2 doesn't have the same level of polish that the first game has even though the port is much better thsi time around, meaning it has a very inconsistent difficulty level and some rather arbitrary mechanics, but the wide variety of new features, an overall improved battle system, and a still-stellar soundtrack make this a game worth playing for the price. The visuals are also spectacular in moments, particularly near the beginning and end, but a painfully padded middle-game really shows that they did not give nearly as much effort to the aethetics in the core of the experience. If you are able to get through a lot of the padding, you'll find a fun game with some moments on par with the high points in its predecessor, particularly the boss battles. Overall, though, the added visual options are a great touch and if you set your rig to maximize performance, you'll get some really smooth gameplay. While I have not played the entirety of the game on PC, I have completed it on PS3 and this review is based on my initial impressions. I will change them if anything significant lowers my opinion later on in the game.

The Final Fantasy series used to be good, nowadays... not so much. This coming from a guy who played the early FF games on the SNES and on various consoles throughout the years to current gen stuff. I used to enjoy FF games and looked forward to each new installment, nowadays... not so much. FFXV will probably be my last FF game, it looks promising... but sadly thats Square-Enix's MO nowadays... flash over susbstance, game looks stunning but lacks any depth and just feels hollow.FFXIII was a massive let down for many people for many different reasons, all of which have been well documented and beaten to death across all forms of media and review sites. I too found myself asking, What happened? The FF series began to slip with FFX and FFX-2, for me thats where it started to go down hill, save for FFXII which I enjoyed. Actually if you really want to pin point the beginnng of the end, its probably when Squaresoft partnered up with Disney for that horrible Spirits Within movie and the following Kingdom Hearts collaboration.I'll give Square-Enix some credit FFXIII-2 is a lot better than FFXIII, but honestly how could anything have been worse than FFXIII. The battle system is essentially the same as FFXIII except your third party member is made up of one of many different monster you can get throughout the game. The maps are a little less linear but your still hand held as you make your way through. NPCs actually exist now, aswell as some hubs/towns so some effort can actually be seen on Square-Enix's part. Getting a ton of negative backlash tends to make you not rest on your laurels and name recognition and makes you actually have to try, go figure. Adding Mog was a definite plus, how moogles were completely and utterly ignored in FFXIII was a joke. It would be like having a Mario game without Mario.Still FFXIII-2 has a ton of short commings. I logged about 7hrs on this before I finally tapped out, I couldnt force myself to even bother with it anymore. I'm also more than a little annoyed at how liberal Square-Enix is at borrowing and the re-interpretation/perversion of nordic mythos when it comes to things like Odin and Valhalla. I'm sorry but that is just pure ignorance and disrespect for the nordic mythos and if I was Square-Enix I would be wholeheartidly ashamed.I forced myself to complete FFXIII, literally forced/tortured myself because I kept telling myself that the game couldnt be this bad and that it had to get better at some point. I wasnt making this same mistake with FFXIII-2. I'm going to revise this review. I had initially given up on this game due to mysterious bugs that hampered my experience. I can't say what the cause was, but since it stopped, I was able to get through the rest of the game.I'll keep it short. This game is gorgeous. It came out back in 2012, and it holds up great. The OST is fantastic as well, and I'd rank it among the best of the series. Gameplay-wise, it branches off from XIII a bit in terms of how it handles the crystarium and party composition. It's a straightforward upgrade path, but you can choose other roles and perks for the characters as you progress. Catching and outfitting monsters is cool, but not having a party is a bummer. Boss battles are pretty fun in this game. The combat events are a flashy and fun way to end a battle. It's a nice additional touch. They also seem faster than in the previous game. Or perhaps just shorter in general. Switching paradigms also doesn't pause the game like it used to, so combat flows more smoothly. The levels in this game are far more open, which is somewhat refreshing. There are times where you REALLY don't feel like having to run to given locations, though. You do have access to chocobos to make travel a bit faster. Got a nice chuckle out of the red chocobo. You'll know what I mean when you get one.The story is a whole lot of nothing for most of the game, due to 85% of the game being a search for Lightning. Expect a lot of "Wait, what?" moments, as things get confusing at times, especially as you approach the end. The game isn't exceptionally long(if you don't do too much extra work), so it largely doesn't overstay its welcome. Well, sort of. You will spend a significant amount of time (upwards of 2 minutes average) waiting for the game to load when going to a time period. Sometimes entering battle can yield significantly long load times.That can be grating, especially if you're looking for particular things between areas or, god forbid, grinding for materials. Outside of that, it's alright. I got some Hope out of it. You will have to apply a mod or two for this game to be playable. FF13fix(fixes the majority of problems this game has) and Leviathan's Tears(fixes the rain textures). Note that you may still run into a strange bug or two. Game was doing funky things with my controller for quite some time. If it works, it's fine. If not, well, you don't have many other options. I don't think anything can be done about load times, unfortunately.I do like this game. Not more than the first one overall, but it can be a fun time. I like that Square did try to set this one apart from XIII, and it does have some cool ideas. The openness is a nice contrast, even if there are instances where you'd rather just get to the point. Battles flow more smoothly, and boss fights are mostly pretty fun. The monster capture/raising aspects add a bit of variety to party composition, and some of them damn near trivialize the game, so it's rewarding in a sense. There's plenty of optional content to do if you're interested, so you won't get bored anytime soon, provided you were enjoying yourself to begin with.The main problem is just the  port. It's a damn poor job. If you are a patient man, like myself, you can manage to get through this. If you haven't played Final Fantasy XIII-2 before, I would recommend the PS3 version. It runs more smoothly than this. Due to the variable performance, I would not buy this at full price. It's playable, as your computer can probably brute force it at this point, but it would benefit hugely from a fix patch. For 10 bucks, it's fine. It can be fun, albeit kind of directionless. YMMV. I can't strongly recommend it, but if it works, it's worth trying.

Review on Final Fantasy XIII-2   1. Intro.   2. Problems/Why this is Honestly Not Recommended.   3. Advice and Recommended to play.   4. Finale. 1. Intro.  First, If you Have Windows 10, dont buy this. Most problems are held buy people with Windows 10 but not held by others. It isn't properly supported, dont get it.  Next, I've played this game for 200+ hrs,By saying this, most gamers understand the amount of experience I have with this story-based game that can be finished in 40-70 hrs, compared to an angry review after 2-10hrs of blindly butting heads with the terrible *edit* bad, port. This is a review by someone who has played through this game for a significant amount of time.  2. Why this should Honestly Not be Recommended,   a) This review is from a gamer that played this PC version for months I want to say that I Honestly think this is a great game brought from the PS3, but the performance put out by the port isnt very good. Unless your PC runs at some amazing stats, Its hard to play at anything other than the base image settings and the FPS is still pretty bad.   b) One of the Biggest problems happens during Cinematic Cutscenes, your game will try to load a lot of new information and also try to autosave which worked on the console, however the longer you play the game, the more information the game will tryto process. i.e. completed/ongoing quests, certain events that need to be implemented, and the biggest thing are Savestates which will take a significant amount of processinging all occuring in the small amount of time oof moving between the world you are in, and the World Select. Whenever you transition between worlds, which in mid to late game is a significant amout of times, this game will try to load , process and save all at the same time. During the early game this problem isn't very apparent, but at 40+ hrs, the change becomes much more apparent, eventually past 100+ hrs triggering even small cutscenes, which automatically load and autosave at the same time, will often crash the game, causing whatever progress was made to all feel worthless. While the game itself is fun and engaging, with a great story, and  good design, the PC version has its issues.   c) Occasionally, if the amount of data in your Savestate is fairly high, (100+ hrs worth, but possibly less.) Steamcloud, where all default savestates are managed will randomly"move", essentually deleting them. Meaning that they are no longer accessable to you from your Main Menu or found any where in your PC's Files, leaving only the New Game option available. 3. Recommended and advice  a) Steamcloud shouldn't be turned on while playing this game. There is a warning on the Launcher stating that processing may take longer because of Steamclouds synchronisation with the servor. The fact that there is any kind of Warning on the launcher should be a clear indicator that there is a problem.There will be planty of times that SteamCloud will start synchronizing and crash your game. It would be best if you played this while in offline mode, the trophies may be fun to get but if you want to enjoy this game its not worth the risk's.  b)  Make sure you create an independent Save file location that is not managed by Steam. Frequently delete unnecessary savestates, and you can keep the amount of information processed farther on in the game to a more manageable amount.  c)  Keep your settings low, again this port isn't the most capable, during the early game when the amount of data being processed is rather low, it should be fine to raise the settings to whatever your PC can handle, just remember that even if your game runs fairly smoothly later on in the game, cutscenes and loading processing requirements will grow at a steepening curve. Whatever you can do to help your game run smoothly even at the cost of quality is worth it.  d) Look up Crysterium and Monster Guides before you leave the first world. Like others in the FF Series this Game will seem fairly easy at first, but even moreso then prievious games, it will absolutly punish unknowing mistakes, stopping you from even reaching the late game, let alone post game. Leveling the Crysterium (Essentually Levels) is an irreversable process, that if left to a novice will cause any small mistakes in building your character, that might not be so relevent early on, will become devestating to those that want to enjoy the late game.  d.i)  Monsters play a huge role in this game, and just like with Crysterium, are a major part of the game that will eventually be the focus of your team, as in they will be the party member that you recruit, train, and carry you through the game.  d.ii) While its not neccesary to look up guides on these to succeed, it is reccommended, finding the Hidden Monster(s), that can become the Gods to carry you through late game and final bosses. Finding the correct Infusiuon Recipes to build them into said Gods, finding which monsters youll need to grind for in certain conditons. And realising before you kill certain indespensible and unrespawnable monsters that you actually need them and should save in front of them and soft reset if you dont get it until you do.4.  Altogether this is a great game. I would say that this Port has to many problems that havent been corrected, and can only be managed by the user who pays the full price for this, but then has to do the providers job of making it usable in order to actually play this. After playing over 200+ hrs on the PC version of this game I can say that for those who still want to purchase this after reading this review, follow the above recommended advice, and hopefully someday this game will be Patched enough That I can honestly Recommend this to prospecting FF Players.

Upfront, the main reason I wouldn't recommend this to -anyone- is the fact you will almost certainly have to use one of the mod guides to make it so the game doesn't repeatedly crash on you. This port is shambolic.But putting that aside and focusing entirely on the game, here's why I didn't like it.I was going to write a fairly detailed review but once I started it just seemed self indulgent so here's the bullet points;- Combat essentially plays itself, including high end bosses, I might as well just be watching the game, it's just an exercise in time wasting in the end and almost always involves the same strategy with one or two exceptions (Naabat, Yomi)- It made cellotaping down the L1 trigger something I'd even have to consider in order to get the lucky coin fragment in Serendipidy. No game should, under any circumstance, compel you to afk it in order to do something in it.- Characters may look fantastic for the most part, but they're all bland, empty "so the story can happen" types- I don't like (read: I hate) time travel (admittedly you might like it, but you're wrong and should feel bad.)I didn't even bother to drag myself through some of the post-game DLC content because it essentially boils down to time wasting just to watch the game play itself.To be clear it's rare that I don't do the majority of things a game has to offer, but I just can't see why I'd want to sit through yet another instance of debuffing boss, buffing self, push chain guage, heal as necessary, ooOo big attack better Sen/Sen/Sen ok cool blablabla repeat ad infinitum ok finally it died great. Just seems like I could find something better to do.If you're wondering how I did 63 hours only to write this review I'll have you know I'm a masochist.

Final Fantasy XIII was the worst JRPG I had ever played.... Until XIII-2! There are a couple minor improvements here - there's less of a delay when paradigm shifting, and there's no longer an "on rails" experience, with you spending hours pushing through narrow corridors. Also, important plot details and character motivations are no longer squirreled away in a text-based codex. Apart from that.... friggin' yikes. The paradigm battle system and leveling system are still in place, which is deeply unfortunate. Your cast of playable characters is boiled down to two, which makes the scope of the game feel small and the dialogue much less interesting. The plot is slapdash and nonsensical (and not in a fun, crazy JRPG kinda way), and is a major downgrade from XIII (which, at its core, had an intriguing concept of malevolent overseers and protagonists doomed to die). What really brings down FFXIII-2, though, is the fetch questing. You have to scour maps to look for gates, which unlock different areas. You need to unlock those areas to unlock OTHER areas. because inside those OTHER areas are..... invisible artifacts that you have to find and collect. But, oh wait, before you can unlock the FIRST gate or the OTHER gate you have to scour the world for DIFFERENT invisible artifacts (which you need to render un-invisible with your moogle). (Also, moogles talk in this game and it's terrible.)Separate from the fetch questing, the game's levels are massive asset flips. These gates you unlock are to revisit the same 7-8 areas in different time periods...... so essentially the same level with a swapped color palette. It's all tiring and boring and monotonous, and the fact that you only travel via gates means nothing in the game feels interconnected or large. Everything's small and tedious, like your two-player roster. The one major upside is that this game's runtime is under 25 hours. Couldn't have ended quickly enough.

You may be here because you played FF XIII, and you thought like me: "Hey they probably made this game way better because the last one was a single button mashing rail cart of a game devoid of player inclusive story."If you buy this game you will make the same mistake I did, and it is a painful one. Bad Stuff:I'm sure there is a great extra-convoluted fantasy story tucked away somewhere in the numerous Datalogs most wont read. But I didn't witness it outside of that. So much of the game stops you after 30 seconds of walking to subject you to a full dialogue of characters saying things in long form of little to no consequence. Remember old final fantasy games where a nice rounded rectangle would pop up allow you to read quickly the interesting dialogue? That's gone now. Also left on the cutting room floor is any real tactical form of combat, you get to pick battle styles once again in set styles then press one button for the rest of the game. How fun. You can go and see how many household activities you can do one handed with a wireless controller in the other mashing that one button while doing bosses or the random battles that pop up blocking you while you try and work out the inane puzzles you may find in the game.There is an unusual amount of running back and forth to find certain keys or do fetch quests, which somehow dilute the already drivel injected plot. Many of them are frustrating and pointless. It's almost like they had a special team at Square-Enix dedicated to editing out anything that made this game fun.Good Stuff:I enjoyed the voice acting by Liam O'Brien and Laura Bailey, although somewhat wasted.The proper cinematics are always a pleasure to watch. This does seem to be the most futuristic Final Fantasy has gone, its a pity that it was squandered. But the aesthetic in some zones was really cool.It was good seeing chocobo racing back, but it was executed with not quite the amount of necessity. Thankfully the abundant and superfluous dialogues are skippable.This is the worst game I've played in a while. And the for sure the worst Final Fantasy numbered game I've played.3/10

Let me preface this review by stating that I'm a long-time Final Fantasy fan, yet I am not a JRPG fan. That may sound confusing. I am not a fan of FF1-FF6 (I know some games are repeats in there, depending on the Japanese release). I have played FF7-FF13, and I wish I had skipped over this one. Let me explain below.GRAPHICS:The graphical fidelity is no better than FF13. That said, it's not an ugly game by any means. I noticed my laptop (which is not equipped for high end gaming) tended to chug harder and burn hotter than when I played the FF13 PC port...I found this strange, since I noticed draw distance tended to be better on FF13. You'll also note the lack of monsters and their animations on the overworld map. So...why is this game more taxing?PRESENTATION:It's not any uglier than FF13, that's for sure, but the characters are a lot flatter. We didn't get to see much from Serah in FF13, but in FF13-2 the actress seems a lot less interested and passionate. At times the body language is overplayed and at other times there's no body language beyond standing arms akimbo.SETTING:I could ask...what setting? A lot of reviewers have said that you don't need to play FF13 in order to play this game. That's true, but you won't understand anything unless you read through all of the FF13 primers on the main screen. Even if you do, the plot won't make much sense. FF13 was enchanting because it introduced a novel theme that seemed unfamiliar. A great purge of unclean civilians united six heroes who gain magical abilities to unite the citizens of a police-state world to overthrow their god-like leaders. Sounds nice, right? The setting of the sequel, FF13-2, builds off of that. But instead of introducing a unique or innovative story arch it starts from where FF13 left off. Our protagonist, Serah, can't remember what happened (how convenient) and she has been separated from her sister and her lover. A timelord deus ex machina character is introduced in the form of Noel Kreis. Lightning, Serah's sister, summons him from another plane of time and reality to do her bidding. The rest is in the plot development, or lack there of. But seriously...time traveling? My head already hurts.CHARACTERS:Noel is boring. Through the few hours I played he describes that he is from the future. Approximately 300 years from the present plot point. He explains that he has never known what a vegetable tastes like and that he is the last of man's existance. So why does he look so clean and handsome? And what is with his weird weapon? Nothing is explained. Noel's character design is meant to be ambiguous so we don't get too curious. It's lazy and it's flat. Skip over this character.Serah is boring. She acts like a scared little child when we're introduced to combat. Her feminization is peaked by giving her a bow and reducing her physical damage below what Noel is capable of. I'm not promoting or dismissing any sort of female rights, but I will point out that Lightning was an exception to this "feminization of damage" rule in FF13. Lightning was the female protagonist, and she was more than capable of putting out tons of damage as well as taking tons of it in return. She was by far one of the most powerful characters...so why isn't Serah?Kupo: Kupo? Kupo...why did they add a moogle to this plot? You will note that I avoided playing most of the games with a moogle in it. Well...there's a moogle here. He will plague your cutscenes and you will often find yourself hitting "0" and "skip." The moogle only makes Serah's sex more generalized.Any others, I didn't get to. I thought I might have picked up a new character after beating "the hand" in the second chapter but that was not the case. I don't know what other characters exist out there, but you will have to figure that out for yourself. I won't touch this game again.CUTSCENES: As I stated in the GRAPHICS section, the visual presentation is quite the same from FF13. That's a good thing. Most cutscenes look very nice. One thing that upset me was the introduction of Quick Time Events (QTE). This requires you to make a movement or button press based on a notification on the screen. From what I can tell the QTEs don't actually affect anything in the plot. Sometimes you will notice your character painstakingly and stupidly getting squashed by a giant meteor only to roll over and get back up. Sometimes failing these QTEs during a boss battle will result in extra damage. Likewise, succeeding a QTE might result in a status effect boost. This doesn't belong in an RPG. It ruined the balance and flow of the game, and should not have been included.GAMEPLAY:The gameplay is very similar to FF13, but it feels like it behaves faster. Enemies seem to have less health, and encountering enemies is much different. You lack the techniques that you gain early on in FF13 and enemies aren't displayed on the overworld map. Instead enemies spawn randomly, and they seem to spawn based on the number of steps you take. After a certain number of steps enemies spawn and you have the choice of either running away or using the action button to swing your weapon and hit the enemy avatars. If you connect before they do then you gain Haste and surprise the enemy. If you take too long or the enemy runs into your overworld avatars then you initiate combat as usual.I initially thought this was kind of a cool idea. A lot of RPGs have an initiative system. However, I quickly realized this was just a gimmick to reduce on-screen rendering. It also builds an unfair disadvantage for tactics by not showing what enemies you're up against. All in all, this was a failure by the creators.Leveling up has become a nightmare. In order to create a simpler and more uniform character progression system the creators have done away with the traditional Crystarium of FF13 and have created a new "Crystarium" that allows you to choose which class you want to specialize in. This character progression system feels a lot like the FF Tactics games.I get where the creators were coming from. I am betting they received a LOT of feedback from FF13 explaining why the individual Crystarium stat point nodes were trivial. Of course you're going to level up for the least amount of CP, there's no point in trying to use statistics and levels to negate that. However, the solution here was horrible. Basically every "level" in the Crystarium is worth a certain point value--regardless of what you invest it in. Serah and Noel start with level 1 in Commando**, Ravager**, and Sentinel**. After you level up enough you can either gain a deeper specialization of these role trees or you can get an ATB segment or a new role. It is never explained who should specialize in what or how well rounded your party should be. In FF13 each character had specialized roles and some characters synergized with others neatly. I never got this feeling from FF13-2.SUMMARY:I give this game a 4/10. I know it's rough, but it simply did not capture my attention for more than a few hours. It's not a bad game if you like JRPGs that are a bit over the top. The fact that I enjoyed FF13 so much and yet I disliked this game really speaks volumes. You don't have impressive antagonists like Roche or the Fal'Cie. Instead your villain is some emo kid with an ugly looking "sword."**Let me just reiterate that a lot of reviewers state that you don't need to play FF13 in order to play this game. That's where they're wrong. If you didn't play FF13 then you have NO idea what these roles are. The in-game primers are brief, and they don't at all explain how important these roles are. I won't go into deeper specs of these roles, so if you're interested please look up a game guide.

Being that this game has technically been out for over 3 years, I will mostly write about the quality of the port. I have an Nvidia Geforce GTX 980 and an Intel I7 4770k with 16 GB system RAM. The game works just fine for me, however, when I try to play the game at 1080p, I find that the FPS is highly unstable. It goes anywhere from 20-60 FPS, depending on what is going on. Prerendered cutscene: 30 FPS (although the video itself was only rendered at 30 FPS anyway). In-engine cutscene: 60 FPS. Menu: 40-60 FPS. Running around: 20-60 (again, it depends on what is going on).Now, that being said, I have tweaked with the settings and I have found something that works for me:-Resolution: 1600x900-Fullscreen-Shadow Resolution: 2k-AA: 8xWith this setup I was able to play the game at a much more stable 40-60 FPS, depending on the situation. I will also note that I am using a device to measure the amount of wattage that my computer uses and I noticed that it uses almost the same amount of power as it does when I idle on the desktop. This isn't a problem for me, however I will say that it is not pushing my system to it's limits, as is normal for console ports these days.

First, yes, the performance is terrible. You will need to use various patches on several files of the game for it to even start. You will need to modify obscure Windows parameters for the game to not crash right after starting. Even then you will need to disable Steam Cloud for the game to not crash on saving. And even  you will need to find the right monitor for it to not crash randomly - too big monitor and it might crash on scene load, too many monitors and it will crash on fights, etc. And still the game will refuse to launch 1 out of 10 times, still you will have weird audio buzzing, still you will have frame drops in some menus for some reason.But that's not the worst IMHO. I've played my share of retro/emulated games, I don't mind fighting a bit the get the game in shape. I would have expected better from an actual Steam game but still I can handle it. But usually those games at least have the decency of being ok games. This game only rewards you with more crap.Let's see, you picked a JRPG, so maybe you were looking for a deep combat system? Lots of optimisation, management, leading to tense battles that test your wits and preparation? Nah, you get two stats and the whole game is you pressing auto-battle again and again and again.Oh, then maybe you wanted a diverse and interesting group of playable characters with who to travel and discuss? Tough luck, all you get are two characters for the whole game. They're not really interesting but they kinda discuss I guess? And they don't play different from each other due to the dumbed combat mentioned above.Ah but then it's ok you say, there must be tons of NPCs to encounter and chat with? Yeah. Around ten. And only three of them are new, the rest are just the PCs from the previous game.Interesting destinations maybe? Well it's better than the previous game I guess, not linear and you can actually explore this time. Let's see there are the ruins, the snow ruins, the sea ruins, the jungle ruins, the city ruins... Oh and there are inhabited areas this time! But for some reason everybody is living in ruins.And then there is the story. I could have accepted all the issues above, I kinda expected it going in - the previous game had almost the same issues. What convinced me to give it a try was the story - I mean time travel should be cool in at least some ways, right? Time travel means Chrono Trigger, means Radiant Historia, it's the dream.Don't make the same mistake I did. The story is nonsensical, poorly told, and tbh not really interesting. You have a bad guy that says what he wants to do and why from the beginning of the game, then you spend the whole game running around wondering what he wants to do and why. And then you find out that it's what he said at the beginning, wow. And all that time in the middle - and it's long, really long - is just people talking through cryptic sentences ("she calls..." "it happened again..." "it's too late...") and hearing voices and talking a lot to say absolutely nothing. If you can, search for an example of the game's "story so far" summary, it's hilarious.Not only that, but the whole time travel thing is just used to justify making you go through the same maps over and over again. Literally nobody cares. You appear in a village with a big flash of light and they're like "wow where did you came from?" "oh we're time travelers" "cool lol". Or "oh yeah I time traveled too". You meet people from the first game 100 years in the future, and the only explanation they give is "yeah I often get lost haha". Sometimes they don't even give explanations, they just pop 500 years after the first game and everybody acts like that's normal.And then there are all the situations where one of the characters start reacting completely weird to stuff - one of your two characters meet someone from the first game and goes completely ballistic about it, flipping out, saying they hate this kind of people, etc. Before the guy even talked! And it stops as suddenly as it started.Honestly there are so many of those situations that I genuinely wondered if the people making each scene talked to each other. The last part of the game is kinda coherent I guess - as in unlike the rest of the game you get the same characters from one scene to the others, actions make sense etc, but the rest of the game really feels like each chapter was given to a different team with a quick pitch of what was supposed to happen and the result was put as is in the game.Anyway, that's it from me. I usually don't leave reviews of games unless I really want to convince people to play them, but I guess this is the first time I really want to convince people to NOT TOUCH THIS.

I so wish I could say that this is the worst game I have ever played, but in all fairness I've played E.T. the Extraterrestrial.However, Final Fantasy XIII-2 is by far the worst RPG I've ever played in my thirty years of gaming.  I'll highlight the worst parts of it, but first I want to make clear that any of it's many infractions would be sufferable were it not for the horrendousness of the "story."  Most of it simply makes no sense, but from what I can gather, there are time travelling asteroid anomolies from other dimensions.  This might seem strange, but in the game world, everyone is an expert on time anomolies, because you know... this stuff happens every day.  Honestly, my five year old niece could have written a more cogent and engaging story.Combat.  They took everything that was good about FFXIII's system out, and left us with everything we wish they'd improved upon.  Nothing you do matters.  I got through most of the fights in this game by simply setting my controller down, going into the kitchen and making myself a beverage while the NPCs finished the fight for me.  I got all the way to the end area this way, but then the enemies became so much more powerful that I've had to go back and grind these meaningless battles for hours upon hours to build up enough hit points to survive the end boss' attacks.Saving.  You can save anywhere, but evidently the time anomolies have infected the game's save system, because it routinely takes 2-5 minutes to save my game.Pacing.  Everything takes twice as long as it should.  There are load screens to load the load screens for the animations.  This game has more in common with a kaleidoscope than anything else.Characters.  Utterly forgettable.  Whatever their motives are, I don't even care.  I stopped listening hours ago.So in closing, if you enjoyed FFXIII as I did, be content to stop there.  This game does nothing to add to the game's world, story, or legacy.  Instead spend your $20 on some glass shards and salt to roll your eyes around in.  The experience will be similar, but will take up less of your life.

First and foremost: BUY THIS GAME FOR CONSOLE INSTEAD! YOU WILL RECIEVE NOT ONLY BETTER & MORE STABLE FPS, BUT YOU WILL ALSO RECIEVE BETTER VISUAL AND AUDIO QUALITY.Final Fantasy XIII-2 is the sequal to Final Fantasy XIII, but it makes itself a whole different game. While the battle system is the same as before, it spruces it up with the ability to use monsters as companions. This keeps battles fresh and gives you many options for paradigms. I personally like this in combat, but the cost of this is that you won't be gaining a third companion. Also the Crystarium is different. Instead of multiple different trees to grow, there is just one, and what you gain per sphere depends on the role you choose to upgrade. When you reach the end of the path your Crystarium will expand. Then you are given multiple choices to level up including increasing ATB and increasing the amount of accessories you can hold. I like this change as well. The two main characters are Serah, Lightning's sister, and Noel, a mysterious stranger from the future. The premise is that after Cocoon fell from the last game, Lightning vanished. A few years later, Noel appears on a meteor and begins traveling through time with Serah. The story from there is driven by each point in time you travel to. From what I've played so far, the cutscenes are mostly based on feelings instead of character development. This means that most players will find that they don't care about Serah and Noel. The story ends up being weak and unimmersive. To add on, the music is no longer orchestra, but is now electronic J-Popish music. If that's your style, then godspeed but I personally perfered the Orchestral tracks. A few minor  points are that now there are options to pick when you get in dialogue, the side quests are more varied than just helping a L'cie stone out, and there are quicktime events in some cutscenes.  But the main thing I have to complain about it is the quality of the port. It's terrible. No matter what you do, maybe unless you have a REALLY good computer, you will experience frame rates all over the place, but almost never over 30. Also the audio quality ends up being terrible, it sounds like the voice acters are speaking through a cheap headset instead of a studio microphone.So to summarize:Pros:                        -Revamped Battle System (Pets)-Crystarium Revamp-Time Travel makes the game less linear.-More Varied Side Quest Premises-Branching Dialogue and Quick-time events make the game more engaging than it would've been.Cons:-Story and Main Characters are uninteresting and melodramatic.-The PC port is terrible.So the bottom line is if you aren't a fan of FFXIII, look up different & better games. If you are a FFXIII fan, then this game may be worth your while IF YOU BUY IT ON CONSOLE.

Pros:- Battle system is okay and fairly deep for this type of game- Character building allows decent customisation- Fun pet system that ties into the battle system- Nice soundtrack, overall- Cooing Chocobos- Visuals are great, albeit too flashy for my taste sometimes- Voice-acting is mostly decent in English- Outfits for your Moogle (and other characters)Cons:- The story- The amount of story- The cutscenes explaining the story- The NPC dialogues repeating what you just learnt (in a cutscene) about the story- The story is overly convoluted also, not sure I mentioned this- One day they will make a game where controlling your character works well (as in: you don't need to stand in a specific spot to jump a curb), but this day has not yet comeWould recommend in a sale if you don't mind buying a game that contains (literally) 7 hours of cutscenes and cinematics.P.S.: There is so much terrible story, it's as if they hired everyone who ever wrote FF fanfic and said "go nuts guys, we'll put it all into the game", and then they did. You have been warned.

I'm in the unenviable position of having to bash one of my favorite JRPGs in recent memory: Final Fantasy XIII-2.  ... Well, the PC version anyways.  The console versions are still fantastic obviously.I can't believe this.  Original FFXIII actually runs surprisingly well on my PC considering all the port issues, but FFXIII-2 runs like CRAP, even with the lowest possible settings (I freaking played FFXIII the day it launched on Steam and even then it ran WAY better than this).  There's got to be some bigger issues at play here as even people with very high-end graphics cards are reporting problems getting the game to run at a consistent framerate.  This is ridiculous, it's pretty much the same engine as FFXIII, and I remember it running a hair more smoothly than FFXIII on consoles, but it runs a whole heck of a lot worse here.Well, hey, that's nearly 30GB of space I can get back on my PC at least, and I won't have to feel even the slightest temptation to get Lightning Returns when it inevitably comes out.  Glad I kept my PS3 copy.Kind of a shame too, as Square-Enix frequently has PC sales, and the PC version includes most of the console DLC right out the gate (I think the only things not included are a few costumes and weapons and such, nothing major), plus the Japanese language track.I hate to do this, as the game itself is wonderful, but I really can't recommend the PC version at all. Sorry to say, this game is a mess. There are elements at play that are really interesting - the inversion of the player's relationship with Lightning and Serah by making Serah playable and Lightning the non-entity she's chasing after, the same compelling, deceptively-deep combat system as the first game, the base elements of time travel and seeing the same places at numerous points on the timeline - but the rest of the game surrounding those elements is tragic in how bad and bland it is. The level design is the same linear pathway style as XIII, but most of the environments are dull and dingy since so many of them take place in dark, bad futures, plus you need to backtrack a bunch to progress the story so you're hitting these places again and again when they weren't interesting in the first place. The plot is basically the rough outline of a story, bolted together through the time travel mechanic, where it feels like very little happens at any given moment until suddenly the status quo drastically shifts. The roles the original party members serve vary wildly and, aside from Hope, feel completely superfluous, which is particularly egregious when you consider that Snow is literally Serah's fiancé, so you'd think his role would be significant. Ultimately, the game just feels like a huge slog to get through, and as the middle part of the trilogy, it probably serves as a hard gatekeep on Lightning Returns because people will assume you need to play XIII-2 to understand it and nobody wants to play this game so nobody plays Lightning Returns.The most egregious thing, to me, is that Lightning is used to sell this game, is on the box art and all the promotional material, and, for Plot Reasons, literally is barely in the game at all. I just think that's crazy - not anything inflammatory like "false advertising" necessarily, but the entirety of the game's plot hinges around her sudden absence which necessitates her NOT BEING ON SCREEN!! Like, don't use her as the mascot and the center of marketing, put Serah on the box! Sheesh.In short, if you really, really want to see the plot (for whatever reason), just watch it on YouTube and move on to Lightning Returns.tl;dr alyssa was perfectly justified in everything she did, if you know you know, don't play this game though

ff13-2 is definitely not my favorite game in the series. In contrast to 13, 13-2 is very open ended in progression, to the point where it's often detrimental to the game. I used a guide to get through the game, and there were multiple instances where I knew I would have struggled to find out where to go.The gameplay of 13-2 is a minor variation of 13, the largest difference being the use of monsters to fill your third party slot. The idea is cute, and leveling your monsters in fun, but in the end it really felt like one more thing to grind out before I finished the game.13-2 is actually pretty forgiving with players who don't want to spend a lot of time engaging with side stuff. I was able to beat the game on easy with what felt like a pretty underleveled team with relatively minor difficulty.The story wasn't as engaging as 13, and I didn't love the cast as much, but it was an important bridge between 13 and lightning returns and it never really felt like it was overstaying it's wlecome.

Very good game! One of if not my favorite final fantasy games of all time. this game uses the paradigm battle styem but puts a cool spin to it by allowing you to collect monsters that have certain roles on your team. This replaces the 3rd part member and becomes a really fun and cool part of the game where you catch monsters and level em up along with your characters. The game is a little bit shorter than the orginal final fantasy 13 but id say its even better. its not as linear, theres more exploration, a secret ending you can get by geting all the 160 fragments as well as the ability to time travel. Caius the main villain of the game is a really good character and has an even better voice actor as well as my favorite final fantasy character Noel. Id recommend beating the first game before trying out this game. playing the first one will not only help with the story understanding but also helps you master the battle mechanics. There is even a part of the game where you can face off against the villain again and get more clarification on the events during the story. Overall i definateley recommend the game and be sure to download the 4gb pack of the discussions tab and turn off steam cloud. that will fix the crashing and lag issues with the game.

Technically played on the Steam Deck, which was actually a good experience since the latest OS update. A confusing one to gather my thoughts on..by itself, it’s a good game with a unique time travel traversal mechanic and story. The combat is just as fun as the previous game. The puzzles and fragment hunting can get pretty annoying, but guides fix that. I think as a standalone FF game, it would be stronger, but it does feel like an odd filler episode after 13, only because the jump from abandoning the Fal’cie plot/lore and replace it with a time travel story seemingly out of no where felt jarring. Any connection to previous lore/story in 13 was minimal, to the point it felt like this time travel story could have been in any FF game really. It feels like we aren’t even in the same world of Pulse and Cocoon (beyond visually), mostly abandoning all the main characters from the prior game. It’s not a bad game by any means, it’s just a weird one that feels really different from the previous game. It doesn’t feel like a sequel, it feels much more like a spinoff. That being said, the ending cliffhanger has me very intrigued. I haven’t played Lightning Returns yet, so maybe it will fill in these gaps/weirdness. I liked 13 more for the story personally.

If you really need to know how the story continues, you'll be better off watching condensed playthroughs on youtube of XIII-2 and Lightning Returns. XIII-2 isn't bad and probably worth playing if you like puzzles, and there are parts of the storytelling that are done well, but it's just such a disappointment after the high bar set by the first game's writing, world building and character development.

All in all it is a step up from the previous game. It still has the paradigm system and technically less characters, but that you only ever got to use three at a time anyway. Encountering enemies is generally better for getting pre-emptive attacks. I would have preferred that they didn’t just spawn out of nowhere, but the landing the attack to start combat is nice. Also going through different areas at different times an unlocking the respective areas was actually fun.The story is mostly a mess. It starts off confusingly and remains largely detached from the previous game save for it's characters. It also puts in a lot of arbitrary fancy names for things that actually makes the situation worse. The realm inbetween time is the Historia Crux, but this knowledge is passed to you by someone who doesn't really know anything about it. The story had some neat concepts some enjoyable character developments occurred with some touching emotional pieces, but it felt disjointed and separate. A primary example is NOEL KREISS himself, his character is somehow all over the place, mysterious (cause lack of content) and boring all at the same time, yet at some point you can identify with him. With the new characters that were introduced, it really just felt like I played an elaborate filler of the last game. I wouldn't be surprised if someone with a good idea wrote half of the story and then the rest was poorly filled in by the B Team.The game maintains its visual style. Some designs I was not too much of a fan of, but they did allow for costume changes which fixed a lot for me. The environments are what really shine here, especially the Academy. Also NOEL KREISS himself had a very nice move set which kept combat engaging.The sound was a very mixed bag. The voice actors did a good job on their part and kept each character alive, however due to some of the lines, it just stood out as cringe. They put an over-reliance on those proper names and sometimes that just sticks out in the audio and reminding me this is a poorly written story. What goes in concert with that is some of the music choice. Much like my story comment, some of the B team just randomly threw songs at this that just didn’t fit, while using some previous music which was tried and true and some well placed bangers.  It left me feeling confused but mostly cot content with the audio. The default combat music was 100% terrible though.Overall the game was fun to a point, but I could not recommend that someone else plays it unless they REALLY like final fantasy and specifically 13. It'll be entertaining, but if you have other options, your time is better spent there. The time travel both made me really want to like the game, and also nearly pass out from how hard my eyes rolled. Where Final Fantasy 13 had me excited to see where the next part of the series takes me, this one left me just wanting to finish it quickly or skip it entirely given the overall rating of the game.

Right off the bat, I want to say that FFXIII-2 is not the best PC Port, and there were more than a few isssues that i had getting this thing to run properly. From graphical glitches that caused problems with the MSAA to a weird sound bug caused by surround sound that caused that game to have a loud buzzing noise. To call the early impressions of this game a chore, would be an understatement. While all of these issues can be resolved, it is important to talk about them none the less and should be a consideration when making you purchase decision.Now with that out of the way, FFXIII-2 is a fantastic entry in the Final Fantasy franchise. It seem like everything they established in the first game was polished and improved for this entry. The Paradigm system is back and now allows for the Team Leader to be changed upon death, it also allows the player to recruit monsters to act as the third party member ala Pokemon. The crystarium has been simplified, streamlined and it no longer takes ages for the player to upgrade their character. The story has a new cast of characters that fit in nicely with the old cast. The story also features a cool time travel mechanic that allows the player to jump to any point in the time line and see how their actions a have affected the world and characters. This game improved so much from the first entry that it is genuinely one of my favorites of the franchise, i finished the 27 hour campaign over the course of 3 sittings as i found it hard to put down, and while it may not be perfect, i find it hard to pick out anything to really criticize about it. If you love Final Fantasy or have never played the franchise before, This and the original XIII are must plays.

Imagine how great this game was for game that released 12 years ago.For those who has bad experience with crashes, this might help :1) Disable Cloud saving for Steam (very important!). To do this, right-click on FFXIII-2, select Properties, then Updates, then uncheck "Enable Steam Cloud synchronization for Final Fantasy XIII-2".2) Find your Cloud saves. They're stored in <Your Steam directory>\userdata\<Your Steam ID>\292140\remote, and the Steam directory is typically C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\3) Copy these Cloud saves (the .dat files) to C:\Users\<Your user name>\AppData\Local\SquareEnix\FinalFantasyXIII-2\save. If the folder doesn't exist, create it. This fixed my crash problem and i have never experience any crashes after it.Enjoy this MASTERPIECE game series of FF.

Regardless of how I feel about the actual game, I can't recommend this with how much of a mess the PC port is.  Some mix of FF13 fix, music fixes, rain effect fixes, and running in Windows Vista compatibility mode being required.For the actual game it's a mix of things that are neat and interesting and things that are just frustrating. Story: Well I hope you read the novel that released after the game came out that explains how you get to 13-2 from 13, because it's quite a jump. Overall the story is neat but not without dumb moments. Combat and Progression: It's 13's combat again. If you liked that, well here is more of it but with new limitations. Now for your 3rd party member you get to use monsters you tame but only up to 3 of them can be included in a set of Paradigms so that limits what your build options are. Leveling is largely similar with levels split between jobs but instead of the larger crystarium it's a clear "1 level of Commando please" interface. There is a fair bit of room to dig into monster customization but I did not.Gameplay: Why did they add in random encounters? Ok they almost certainly did it for time reasons and to make grinding clearer but it's a nuisance and jarring after 13's system of just running into enemies in the overworld. The jumping and platforming added are largely fine until the end. Overall things are fine difficulty wise until the last boss which is a wildly large jump.Music : The music director for this game did a great job at just picking some wild choices and I'm here for it. The musical choices are just bizarre but other than one really annoying piano track at the end it's good but not at all what you think of when you think of "Final Fantasy music". Overall, FF13-2 definitely had segments that got me real grumpy but overall it's an interesting time if you can manage to get through the myriad of technical issues.

This is the one review I will make: for a good reason.Overall I enjoy the Fabula Nova Crystallis: Final Fantasy trilogy, excluding Type Zero only connected via the world of Nova Chrysalia. The story is good if you the world of Nova Crystallis is enjoyable to you, from the plot points of Snow becoming a L'Cie again, all the way to Hope becoming a director for the Academy, BUT THIS IS WHY I THE REVIEW. The story is good if you enjoy the Nova Crystallis world that Final Fantasy has but the game play is beyond painful: to make a short list- Certain aspects of the Paradigm system are just straight up removed from both playable characters and all monsters you can obtain as the third party member: want to cast haste? WELL NOPE NOT ALLOWED UNLESS YOU FARM FOR ITEMS TO LEVEL YOU MONSTERS SO YOU CAN UNLOCK AUTO-HASTE! It is the same with other spells as well and this process can take hours to just get the materials for a single grid of Crystarium system for a monster to get to level 99 in some cases if you want to Bonus Crystarium Points ability because there is no growth egg item.- Monsters that you obtain as the third party member must be leveled up through items obtained in combat, thing is the datalog is just as confusing to navigate if you find a monster that drops a specific item/items.- Your equipment is locked to a set number points meaning you can only have a set number of points allocated to equipment and each thing of equipment has a base total of at minimum 25 and at max 100, your maximum total of points you can have is 100 after a few levels of your Crystarium system.- The amount of points the Crystarium system requires to level this time around is grows in additive nature meaning you can start with low numbers but after two or three level through you are paying up to 500+ to a single node that does the total back to base even if you are starting on a class such as Commander being level 65 and medic being level 1, you are still paying over 500+ points for a node in medic even if it is level 1.- There are fights that no matter what you do just seem unfair to the point that the rate you can do things to the rate monsters can do things is just insane. Some combats monsters are able to act two or three times before you can act once due to being stagger locked out of being able to use your attacks.Even with the story if you enjoy the entire line of games Final Fantasy 13/Type 0 have to offer but I cannot recommend this because it is just painful to play. If you want to play a Final Fantasy 13 game I recommend the first one because of these issues. I can find most games enjoyable even if something is super flawed, but this is painful on the hands and headache inducing to play.
