There are similar technical hurdles to make all ff 13 games launch and play correctly. But if you get passed those and the game will play, it's fantastic!  This takes the gameplay of the first FF 13 game and makes it non-linear.  You also get to have a beast summon which functions far better than anything in previous FF titles' summons in that it works with the party instead of for it. This game is a must for completionists as well. You will find yourself easily chasing down all of the fragments to get the secret ending. It's less of a find all treasures vibe and more of the story goes until the end vibe. Which was nice. Many games just want you to collect 160 of something and then come back. Not here really.As far as getting the game to launch, FF 13 titles have a series of issues that can be fixed easily with "FF13fix" on GitHub. More or less copy 2 files and it works. Try this first if having issues. There is a second version of "FF13Fix" that involves the file to fix the buzzing sound for anything not stereo. You will know if you have this issue at launch. I sure did lol.With all of the issues regarding getting the game to launch, I hope they update this one day. I mean the red and blue "Crazy Chocobo" is a good enough reason on it's own to buy and play this game.It's an angry, agro, moshing and headbanging choco that eats all of your greens while nu/death metal chocobo theme music plays and you ride around. It also runs from you when you want to get back on. lolAll things considered, it's a wonderful game in hindsight. Also, most of the team(s) that brought this game to PC were contracted. The reason these errors persist in running FF 13 1/2/3 and FF 12 was because they were contracted to make the game work on PC and it was completed right before massive changes to how graphics cards work. As such, no one was around to rework a patch or redo chunks of the game. Shockingly, a workaround can be found on GitHub that is like 2 files. But, it explains why we do not have updates as simple as this as they are no longer working on that project. This speaks more about Square Enix's contract based working practices and how they do things than i does the dev team that brought this to PC.I hope this review will resolve a lot of the long standing questions involved with this series and the community.  Have a nice day!

Unfortunately, this game deserves a negative review even after just 5 minutes into the game. The normal fights just don't feel worth, yet you still need to do them if you want to become stronger. Also, why is there so few ways to obtain Mana Crystals? Going for magic late game just feels like you're handicapping yourself, better to just use physical.The soundtracks.. what the hell even happened there? It's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Most tracks don't feel like they match the moments and none of them are memorable. I spent over 30 hours on this game and I cannot remember any of the musics in it, beside that terrible boss music with the screams. I went back to FFXIII a few weeks ago to finish the achievements I hadn't done and I was vibing with the music. I just can't here.With all of that said, I still enjoyed the game to an extent. For me, it was as simple as downloading the "4gb_patch" which patches the executable to run with 4gb of ram rather than 2gb, and now over 7 hours in I have had zero crashes. i am surprised to say i really like this game. it felt like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ cashgrab at the beggining, ngl. but honestly, what surprised me the most is just how much better this game is than ff13. like in the following ways:- literally all open world, non linear. i skipped a bunch of the story in episode 3, had to go back and do it lol.- the battle system is still amazing and fun. the monster collecting aspect is pretty fun too, plus there is a whole lot more options for party customization here.- the crystal level up system is now actually pretty cool. it has multiple pathways for each character, i can make every character a fighter, black mage, white mage, buff, debuff, tank, literally whatever i want. and then choose a monster with it's own role. it has layers of interesting combinations and new stuff to try out.- tons of sidequests and exploration. exploring the timeline is really fun, seeing how places evolve, or how they were in the past, really adds a lot to the story and mood of the game.- you don't need to read the datalog (aka giant wall of text in the menus) to understand what's going on, for the most part (lol)- the music is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ goat, all battle themes are great and feel unique to this game. i even like the metal chocobo song, i get it's cheesy as hell but come on, it's just a bit of cheese.- the story progresses naturally, ♥♥♥♥'s easy to follow, understandable.- the art direction is still ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ great. some amazing environments here, and time traveling through weird, surreal scenarios really shows what the FF artists can do.of course, not everything is great. the plot is still horribly cheesy, and the dialogue still sucks hard. look, it's not much worse than ffx or ffx-2, but there's still some gems like this one at the beggining of the game:"Become an arrow through time and speed your way to Serah."- Lightning (wtf?? why is the wording here so odd??)lightning probably has the worst lines of all, literally all of her dialogue feels either out of character or just plain stupid. thankfully she doesn't appear much in the game lmao."That time was lost; yet time continued onward. Divine Etro. Go peacefully to your rest. I will stand guard over your legacy."- Lightning (completely out of character lol)there's also all this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ about a goddess of time, which was introduced completely out of nowhere. not to mention how they retconned XIIIs ending to squeeze a bunch of sequels, sleazy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.the story usually makes sense as well, thank god. starting this out i honestly thought this was gonna be a mess, like giving a complicated time travel storyline to the ff13 writers, who literally had to put exposition dumps in the game menu to make up for the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ pacing and explain core plot concepts. surprise: nobody wants to read a wall of text after every boss fight lmao.but this game, honestly it just works here. literally never had to read the datalog, this played like a normal rpg. you and your party do stuff, and the story advances there. ♥♥♥♥ just works.also, the PC port is by far the worst console port i've ever played. if the game sucked, i might as well have been scammed. i experienced everything here: awful fps dips, constant slowdowns, graphical bugs, hours of messing with the graphics driver and fanmade fixes to actually get this game to work. it's just a mess man. definetly skip the pc version, go for ps3 or xbox 360, unless you have a fairly beefy pc (i have a 4th gen i5 and a gtx 1050, decent setup, and still had massive slowdowns, even if the game did run at 60 fps most of the time).but, even with all the story woes and the AWFUL port, this game is still pretty good. just a fun experience, like an ffx or ffx-2, not mindblowing, but a good final fantasy game and a great jrpg for sure.

This is a game I enjoy for the game, not so much the story. The writing is pretty forgettable other than Caius being kind of a narmy villain. There's plenty of sidequests and interesting way of exploring the same area across timelines so it's familiar-but-different. Time mechanics could've made for more interesting puzzles (and the time rifts get tedious) but they're still fun.Musically it's mostly FF13, just with a few new tracks.Gameplay take the FF13 gameplay loop, tighten & fix it so that it's more intuitive and faster, make the crystarium make more sense, and you end up with a decent battle system.And then there's monster recruitment and infusion. And that's when the rabbit hole REALLY shows. You can recruit *every* non-boss non-twisted-human monster in the game, each fitting one of the 6 classes with some permanent passives/abilities...and slots to have up to 10 total. And ability to learn and inherit skills by the same way you fill passives - infusing other monsters. The net result is you could make a LOT monsters in the game work in your team if you so desire and it ends up being fun figuring out how to build and optimize the party for late and post-game challenges.Also Chocobo Racing is back and much deeper than it was in FF7 which automatically makes this recommended.

This game is good time.  XIII-2 as well as the rest in the XIII trilogy get a lot of hate and most of this is understandable.  However, XIII-2 does a great job of just being a fun experience despite its narrative shortcomings.  As the second game in the trilogy, Square basically took everything that was good about XIII-1 and fixed a lot of problems that people had with the first game.  There is no unnecessary padding when it comes to combat being fun.  Monster collecting is also rewarding and offers a lot of customization to combat setups.  Side quests are almost immediately present and exploration is encouraged.  The game is short but sweet (unlike XIII-1) with lots of side content available if you want to seek it out.  Music takes great tracks from XIII-1 and adds in some new bangers.  Environments range from beautiful to a bit unnerving with creepy time space distortion sections.  My main criticisms are the general plot of the game and the characters.  The plot is a time travel plot that throws almost all of XIII-1's story out the window in a comical way.  Time travel plots are okay at best and absolute incoherent messes at worse.  XIII-2 is in the okay-ish range with some questionable moments thrown in for no reason.  Still more enjoyable than XIII-1's plot.  The main characters Noel, Serah, and Caius are interesting characters that unfortunately don't get completely fleshed out by the end of the main story.  It feels like we are just getting to know them before their screen time is up.  I do like them but feel as the 3 were a bit of a missed opportunity.  Overall, very good game would prefer this game to XIII-1 any day.  Maybe one day I'll try Lightning Returns but we shall see.  Also only real chads appreciate the metal Chocobo song.8/10

Final Fantasy XIII-2 is definitely an improvement over the first game, but knowing how Square Enix is, it's still riddled with technical issues mostly resulting from a bad port of the game. As usual, the game runs poorly - capping in at 30FPS no matter what the Store Page says about 60FPS possibilities - low bitrate audio, crisp FMVs due to compression for some reason, and the game only using 2GB of RAM like the first game. And, of course, the same author who compiled a bunch of fixes for the first game has also written a Steam Guide on how to enhance FFXIII-2 so go check it out. As usual, it contains performance fixes, crash fixes, and the "modernization" of the game although this time, the HD textures are a lot more subtle than the first game. There's also a mod that restores past DLCs that Square Enix removed due to licensing issues which is pretty nice.The improvements come from the overall gameplay; from redesigned drop tables and how the game calculates monster drops, to tiny optimizations in the battle system. The crystarium is also not as linear as it was in the first game, but they went a bit overboard as it's almost impossible to understand how the thing works without looking up a guide, and advancing through the crystarium willy-nilly will result with you having a weaker party and may make the game quite more difficult than it should be in the late game.Traversing the game world isn't as linear as the first game as well. Unlike FFXIII where you just follow a predetermined path up until the third to the last chapter (which goes back again to being linear a couple of chapters later), FFXIII-2 offers players the freedom to explore any place they want at any time (emphasis on ) which makes for a very modular, non-linear way of playing the game. Of course, some places have higher-levelled enemies than the others which would indirectly guide you back to where the game wants you to be, but it isn't as spoon-fed as the first game and, if you persevere enough, even places blocked by the sheer level of enemies are still doable.The biggest change, in my opinion, is the introduction of . It's basically like Pokemon where you capture a monster that you fight and have it battle for you. In FFXIII-2, instead of a 3rd human party member, you will be utilizing the powers of monsters - each monster specializing in their own role, and one role only. Unlike in FFXIII where you can pretty much choose from any role at any time, FFXIII-2 limits that by making your third party member be of limited roles. You can only have up to three third roles that you can switch between.Gil is not a notable issue anymore in the game. You still need a hefty amount of it when you're building your monsters, but unlike the first game, you can easily amass Gil as you play through the story. In my experience, I had amassed over 150 thousand Gil just from clearing 3 chapters, and no items are ridiculously expensive in the shop which is really nice as well. No more 2 Million Gil material that you will only use once and you have to get another one way or another.CP, just like in the previous game, can be acquired as you play the game and you almost don't need to grind for it. Or at least, don't directly grind - because capturing monsters isn't as simple as it seems and you will probably need to fight a lot of enemies to find really good monsters to add to your party which, in turn, will make you amass a lot of CP before you even realize it. You can easily be underlevelled in this game, but it's as easy to be overlevelled as well. That's because the Crystarium stages aren't locked behind story progression so if you have so much free time in your life and perseverance, you can upgrade both characters' Crystarium to the latest stage even during the early game. Another thing that I liked about this game: Square removed the tedious way of levelling and upgrading weapons and accessories. You can now just buy weapons to replace your current ones, and the shop will even offer you the upgraded version of the weapons in exchange for Gil and materials that are relatively easy to acquire (compared to Traps and Dark Matter; which means pretty cheap too) and most of them come from enemies that are relatively easy to kill (compared to toises and long guis). Of course, there's still materials that can only be acquired from rare-spawning enemies and the material itself is a rare drop from said enemies, but the game introduces a new feature called  to help you with the grind.One of the key objectives in the game is to collect "Fragments". I won't be diving into what these are, but if you collect enough of these, you can talk to an NPC that will give you  depending on how far you are in the game and how many Fragments you have collected so far. These Fragment Skills range from little adjustments like being able to move the camera during cutscenes, to insane game-altering effects like making rare enemies to spawn more often, or increase the amount of enemies that you can encounter. Each of this Fragment Skill has their own use and you can tweak them any time you want. Beating the game will also give you a Fragment Skill to see other endings that you normally couldn't get, which adds more to the non-linearity of the game.I think this is what really separates FFXIII-2 from its predecessor. FFXIII practically has no post-game content; once you beat the game, it's pretty much the end. Of course you can fill out all the characters' crystarium to their maximum level after beating the game, but there's not much to it. The Ci'eth Stone missions that you have to do after beating the game is only that way because you are virtually limited by your characters' stats that are locked behind the Stage 10 Crystarium that can only be unlocked after beating the game. But technically speaking, you can do all Ci'eth Stone missions even before the final boss, thus technically making post-game content non-existent. I really feel that FFXIII had a DLC that never came to be since all post-game content is all about making your characters even stronger, but that's a topic for another day.In FFXIII-2, you get the alternate endings called  after you beat the game, and there are a handful of them to go through. The game also has actual DLCs to play through after beating the game which I think FFXIII is really lacking (like I mentioned earlier), and it will take you hours to finish all of them. The DLC even includes literally a Coliseum where you can fight a bunch of enemies to test your skills and the monsters that you have built throughout the game. Unlike FFXIII where the only post-game you can do are the Ci'eth Stone missions that you can actually do before beating the game, FFXIII-2 actually offers content that you can only do after beating it.Like I said, I grinded for materials and monsters in the game so you can pretty much shave of 5 to 7 hours off of the recorded playtime in this review. I am also writing this review before doing post-game so expect the playtime hours to jump to, I don't know, I guess maybe 8 to 10 hours more. I am still not finished building my monsters and I have yet to begin viewing the Paradox Endings, let alone the DLCs and stuffs. However, as much as I like this game, and being the cheapskate that I am, I still recommend buying this game on sale. It's a pretty old game (especially if you count the years from its initial release on the PS3) and spending almost 10 bucks to play it with technical issues that Square could have easily fixed, but didn't, isn't really worth it. But I really recommend playing this game especially if you liked the first game.

This is the direct sequel of Final Fantasy XIII. Every single aspect of gameplay is improved compared to the previous game. The story is not as good as Final Fantasy XIII, but it is still enjoyable. + Paradigm Shifts now takes no time and it is instantaneous;+ Upgrading Weapons are now very simple and you can do it pretty early on the game;+ Monsters drop Gil and now you get a feeling of older Final Fantasy titles with a decent drop system;+ Historia Crux system lets you replay previous chapters of the game;+ Graphics are very gorgeous;+ The modding community made several improvements in regards to graphics, crashes and fixes;+ Most DLCs from the console version are included in the game.- Very inconsistent 60 FPS;- Another terrible port by Square. I had nothing game breaking, but many people do;- There's no Japanese background music. If you select Japanese voice-overs, you still get the North American background music, even if you bought the Asian version of the game; - The Crystarium system in this game is a headache, make sure you follow a guide to get the right boosts;- Doesn't have Haste as a skill, but you can still get this buff for a short time with a Pre-Emptive Strike;- The ATB feels a little bit slower, there is no option to speed it up in the settings;- Camera Sensitivity in battles is reduced and can't be changed in the settings;- 4 Outfits and 5 Weapons DLCs are not available due to licensing reasons, you can still easily mod them back in though, since the files are still present within the game;- Square was lazy enough not to give the game a decent artwork cover on Steam Library.

There really won't be too much that I can say on this one; for the most part I enjoyed it, the gameplay was improved in every way over its predecessor and the story was actually not half bad (and I say this as someone who really doesn't like "time travel" plots.).To be more specific about the gameplay XIII-2 does a lot of things better, The game kicks off running and doesn't lock you behind limited paradigm decks, crystariums, or anything else; essentially XIII-2 starts off at the point XIII took 20 hours to reach. The game also removes the horrible first paradigm switch's long animation vastly improving the flow of combat. The change to have sentinel be a passive damage reduction adds a lot to the gamplay when combined with fast paradigm switching as well. They also finally added high level ass-saving spells like ultima and meteor through class bonus's.One issue I had with the gameplay though a minor one given as the game isn't as difficult as XIII is that getting a preemptive strike no longer gives 99% stagger making it more or less pointless.The soundtrack is also probably my favourite in the franchise, There are songs from other Final Fantasy titles that I like more than anything in XIII-2 but the level of quality it showcases is incredible and is even better than XIII, I love that they included drastically more vocals in the music in general.Now the story I just thought was good, nothing special here, again I do not like time travel plots so the fact that I'm not hating on the games story speaks volumes; The problem however is that this title has the worst ending in the entire franchise as far as i'm concerned. The entire thing happens just so they can set up XIII-3 so it's just a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ show all-round. I do not think it's appropriate for the game to end without wrapping things up like it does as all Final Fantasy games are and should always be their own complete packages, regardless of "-2" status; This was a complete ♥♥♥♥ up. So yeah I recommend the game, It's a decent Final Fantasy title with a good story and pretty damn good gameplay all things considered, Just expect the ending to not "end" anything . Case in point make sure you buy XIII-2 and XIII-3 together.the switch to somewhat non-linear levels was done fantastically and I also think this game doesn't overstay its welcome at all like XIII did. whereas I got deathly bored by the end of XIII I was doing perfectly fine by the end of XIII-2.Oh and it is completely unacceptable how poor performance is in this game, I just sucked it up and got used to 30fps on average and that's WITH several mods installed to fix the game; and with settings changed in nvidia control panel to increase performance.

Surprisingly enjoyable - nothing like the first FF13 game. I'd actually recommend giving this game a try if you enjoy Final Fantasy, Doctor Who, and/or Chrono Trigger. Feels more like a real Final Fantasy game, since there are enjoyable side quests, NPCs to interact with, choices to make, areas worth exploring and revisiting, and an interesting story that is actually fun to learn about as you progress. Also offers a fair bit more customization of character development than a lot of Final Fantasy games - Crystarium allows you to focus completely on the job classes you want in this game (unlike in FF13 which locked the crystarium progression until linear story milestones, forcing you to spread your CP to jobs you don't use just to boost stats to survive the tedious battles). Speaking of battles, FF13-2 actually has enjoyable battles - you still have stagger system, but it doesn't take 3 hour to stagger a random enemy in this game - most battles can be won in a reasonable amount of time even in the end game section. Easy mode was a bit too easy, so feel confident in going with Normal mode on your first play if you're used to other Final Fantasy games. This isn't FF13. This is fun.

It took me about 40hrs to finish the game, and a further 30hrs to 100% it. All I can say is getting 100 consecutive pre-emtive strikes, filling out the entire beastiary, and stupid slot machine and chocobo racing mini-games are the worst achievements. Let's preface this by saying my game kept crashing until I added about 4 small mods to make it work. After that I had no problem. While it's dumb SquareEnix can't fix their own game, the fact that easy fixes exist will let me overlook that fact.Overall it's a good game. Some minor changes from FF13 include cutting out the time-wasting paradigm shift cinematic, monsters pop up randomly as you run around like older FF titles instead of being a feature of the landscape, the entire shop / weapons progression system is effectively removed, and levels are not linear but instead being very back-and-forthy. Big changes include the whole time-travel mechanic for the story and the pokemon-like monster system for your 3rd party member. I generally dislike time-travel stories because no matter how consistent a story tries to be with the rules inevitably there is some plot hole or paradox that I just can't accept. Square Enix seems to have found an ingenious solution to that problem by just having the entire system not really make any sense to begin with so my "that-makes-no-sense-o-meter" just breaks and somehow I end up just accepting everything. Sure, you can totally just 'shout so loudly that somebody in the past hears you and changes the future.' It actually wasn't that hard to just go with it and have a good story of it as long as you didn't try to think too much about it. I still definitely think FF13's story was better, but it was nice meeting Serah and Noel and seeing how the world progresses over about 700 years. There's actually quite a lot of interesting lore to learn about the universe so I liked that. But the monster-collecting thing? I hated that. I hated it in FF10-2 and I hate it here. And the entire weapons progression thing from FF13 is replaced by collecting components to upgrade monsters then feeding monsters to other monsters so they can learn their abilities. You can get some pretty OP combos if you're willing to grind, but thankfully you can play the whole game without really bothering with it and I was so happy when I could do the DLC content and have Lightning in my party again (she was actually stronger than my max-level characters). Let's talk about characters. In FF13 I loved the group and having the story split them up and seeing their interactions with other members, etc. Here you only have Serah and Noel. With only two characters you can have less of a dynamic. Some don't like Serah because she doesn't really have much character, but I liked her enough. I was surprised by how much I liked Noel, though. He was much better, from a character motivation point of view. As for the main villain, some seem to really like him and see where he is coming from. I disagree, I think his entire motivation is stupid. I much preferred the Fal'cie from FF13. TL;DR - Its a good, fun game, but nothing to write home about. I loved FF13 and it doesn't 'ruin' that for me like I feared it would. I'm excited to play Lightning Returns next.My Final Fantasy rankings, from favourite to least favourite: FF10, FF13, FF12, FF13-2, FF10-2

Bad port of a pretty/very good JRPG depending on your tastes and what you find appealing. You'll probably at least get console level performance at higher and arbitrary resolutions if you cap to 30, uncapped you'll likely get severe fps drops when loading new areas of maps, and might experience generally lower fps in crowded parts of the game too. You will really want to use the FF13Fix mod as well as the 4GB or Large Address Aware patches -- check PCGW. Despite all this I more or less 100%'d the game. Nowhere was ever unplayably bad, and my CPU isn't too great compared to stuff from the last year or so that I hear gets a fair improvement in performance. I will say on the whole performance is substantially worse than XIII though.With regard to the game itself, it's a zany time travelling adventure with a veritable bevy of side content in the form of minigames, collectibles, extra unlockable abilities and game modifiers (more money, encounters, alternative hidden endings etc.), a really cool villain with a big sword and some great DLC boss fights, albeit gated effectively behind near 100% completion due to how difficult some of them are. Graphics: Very nice for a console title from early 2010s. Character models look great, environmental art is stunning at times, as it was in the original 13, with some locations being visually striking and extremely imaginative. Some lower res textures here and there. There are a handful of graphical mods also available. Monster designs are frequently reused from 13 and continue to look great.Music and sound: Just great all around. Very large diversity in genres, some really top-tier JRPG boss themes. Voice acting is solid, in both English and Japanese, but the voice volume is a little low in some cutscenes. There are mods that address this. Gameplay: The core battle system is basically refined from the original 13. You have two party members you can swap control of freely, versus the original 1 at a time, while the third party member you can assign from a pool of monsters you can recruit -- Monster recruitment is its own sub system, including leveling paths, learning skills and transferring skills to new monsters to make super powerful party members. The ATB system works basically the same as in 13, except the usage feels snappier and more fluid, with much less of a delay on Paradigm changes. The combat system is really exceptional, and makes me sad that it will probably never return in future FF entries. I'd recommend checking out at overview of the system, but at its strongest it can feel exceptionally dynamic and reactive, with you having to constantly learn enemy attack patterns and how to respond on the fly given what monsters you have, how much damage you need to deal in a fixed time, etc. Really good stuff.The other big facet of gameplay is exploration, which is far less linear than 13 almost to a fault. It can often feel overwhelming with how many possible areas you can explore at any given time, leading to hidden enemies, bosses, sidequests. All these things also reward you with additional story scenes, some more context into what life is like after the end of 13, and datalog entries which really flesh out characters and lore more. Exploration will also reveal minigames (including races, poker, slot machines etc.), (included) DLC secret episodes, superbosses. It feels like the game is more side content than main game, so if that is something you really like in your JRPG you'll probably dig it here.Story and Characters: The story is needlessly convoluted and retcons the ending to a game which ending more or less conclusively. Shortly after 13's ending, everyone becomes convinced that Lightning disappeared, and then time travel shenanigans start to happen and Lightning's sister Serah and a time traveler called Noel team up to solve these problems. The balance is probably the opposite to 13, which had arguably dislikable characters situated in a world and mythos that were extremely interesting. In 13-2, the story is held up by character interactions and a villain who is really compelling despite a story that sort of starts and ends in the same place.Overall probably a 6/10 story mixed in with 8/10 characters, 8/10 exploration, 9/10 battle system, 9/10 music, 8/10 visual design. A really nice experience for fans of 13. Just be aware of the port issues and how to mitigate them.

This game is good.Gameplaywise, FFXIII-2, the sequel to the first game, is excellent. There are more places, areas to explore than before. A more free form exploration than the first game. The combat is faster. Although there are some omitted parts which are kinda a downside.Unlike the first game, the party consists of the monsters you collected while adventuring. Kinda like a pokemon kinda way. These monster will act as the third person of your two main-character party. It's kinda tacked on, not giving any reason lorewise why we can't just have other characters as third ones instead. The other downside for me is the story. This is maybe due to the somewhat mediocre voice direction, but I don't really pay attention to that. The story is about Serah, one of the core characters from the first game, wanting to find her sister after she was erased from time due to a paradox invasion. Then she joins a time traveller, Noell, in a quest to save the timeline from being destroyed.A story about time travel can be easily be a miss for some people, and can get very convoluted very easily. This is a miss for maybe due to not having enough investment and information on this fantasy world. Because most of the story goes on to travelling each places from the first game adn solving a paradox happening there. It got better in the end when some character moments starts to shine like Noell and the antagonist. After the story ended, it lead to more questions than answers, which I was kinda dissatisfied. Although again, this is maybe due to the lack execution in its world building.The soundtrack, world, and character designs are gorgeous. But overall, the gameplay really balances out the bad. Making it a very mid game. 3/5Edit1: I forgot to mention that this is a VERY BAD PORT. Straight up unplayable. Mods are needed in order to play it. Although I recommend it, that does not mean I encourage this practise at all. FIX IT.

FF13 players begin this game in New Bodhum 003AF and can can't help but immediately notice that the game developers have fixed one critical problem in the original, by making the game open world from the start. Characters are not just enemies who should be killed, but real people with real dialogue. You're likely to feel genuine empathy with the scientists, Guardian corps. soldiers, other NPCs in the game. The way the music changes with enemy encounters, the way the NPCs react whenever the protagonists sit atop a Chocobo or find a hidden treasure, gives a feel of liveliness in the game, something lacking in FF13. The dialogues in FF13 seemed mostly cringe to me, while those of FF13-2 seem extremely realistic. One of my favourite things in the game is the realistic way it portrays scientists. No need of dealing gameplay progress in order to farm monster materials at a specific location, like in FF13. You can now easily 'teleport' to other areas of the game via the Historia Crux.One more good thing with the Steam port is that the graphics are in 1080p. You can clearly see Serah's abs in the beach outfit. Even Lightning (as a DLC secondary party character) looks like the actual lightning as can only be seen in the pre-rendered cut scenes of FF13.CONS:Ridiculous monster spawn rate in August Tower 200AF. Some locations such as Oerba 400AF have too many puzzle to solve, which becomes extremely monotonous. You'll most probably need to watch video guides on locating every Wild Artefact, which sometimes are at ridiculously hard to find locations. Post game content requires a good level of grinding for monster materials.Overall I'm glad that I played this game. Better than FF13.

Story is dumb and confusing af, but the gameplay is honestly top notch. This is still one of my top games of all time because of the gameplay. The battle system is fun af. Don't focus on the fact that it says "auto-battle" - it's only like that because the battles are so fast-paced. The XIII battle system needs you to focus on the strategic aspects of what roles you need in the moment, and you have to shift your paradigms according to that. XIII-2 perfects this by speeding up the ATB Gauge a bit, lets you switch between party leaders, and lets you catch monsters to pick your 3rd party member. I won't go into more detail, but just don't discount this game just because people say "it plays itself with auto-battle". The world is actually quite nice. It's nowhere near the FInal Hallway 13 that the first game has a reputation for. Each timeline you visit is basically a self contained world, which all vary in their openness. Some are like mini open-world game sections, and some can be a bit more linear. There's still a lot to explore. There is a lot of content here. Overall, great game, just don't take the story too seriously, actually take the time to learn how to play the battle system, and you'll be in for a great time!

It's definitely a fairly unstable game with a number of issues that cause graphical lag and random crashes some of which even cause Steam to freeze and crash as well.  The community patches help a little bit (installed after 3-4 hours of dealing with many crashes), but is far from a proper fix.It's unfortunately not just an issue of people not having good enough PC's either.  I played the game at 1440p with 4k shadow resolution and 8x dlss.  With a window open monitoring resource usage, I found that GPU usage and memory both usually sat around 33% usage and bouncing around a bit of course, with CPU never going above 35%, memory around 4G.  I actually found that switching to 16x dlss actually caused more issues, while GPU usage topped at around 60% the game significantly dropped to a laggy frame rate and I also had issues with audio falling out of sync and clipping out as well interestingly enough.  Anyways, enough of that and to the actual game.So we get hit away with the same combat system as FF 13 which is perfectly fine given that it is a sequel and whatnot.  The keyboard controls weren't exactly conveniently mapped, so using a controller is much more pleasant.  However, I did find that this game suffered from the same "issue" that FF 13 also had.  Which is that I can more or less beat every battle minus a handful of boss battles by just defaulting to Relentless Assault (COM + 2x RAV), occassionally switching to Diversity (COM + RAV + MED) for harder fights.  In all the older FF games I can't really think of any where this really happens and to me it just takes out a piece of fun of the game.  Even FF X-2 which had a similar combat system didn't really seem this obscenely easy.  I honestly found myself just spam clicking A on the controller while browsing my phone in the midst of most of the battles I got into, just zero attention required and still found myself getting 5 star ratings most of the time.  I almost wonder if the game would be better off without auto-battle just to promote more interactivity.  Another minor annoyance I found at higher levels is your spell list is a two column list that can't fit all the spells for a class at once on it (mainly for RAV).  I wish they expanded that to be a 3 column+ or expand more on the screen just so I could see everything I had available at once since it's an active combat system.  In turn based combat of older FF games that wasn't really required since you had all the time in the world to decide what to do.  I also found myself annoyed with the insane reuse and retexturing of all assets.  I absolutely expected it to some extent of course, but jeez it feels like a bit much.  One map was used 4x over with different lighting, and a few others used 3x over, the Steppe at least was managable for it's credit and I did love Academia for the most part.  But I really expected at least a few models for weapons, at the very least for the Chaos weapons, but no. Just another recolor on top of the base model, not even an interesting texture applied to it.Also I'll note I haven't played FF 13-3 (Lightning Returns) yet either. Overall, I wanted to enjoy the game, but between the: bugs, inconsistencies, cliches, over-reuse, and the blandness of battle I just honestly spent a fair bit of the time playing wishing I was onto the next piece of the story already so I could finish it.

TL;DR : Its a decent game, but not for most folks.The Maps are repetitive in some kind, because you re-visit the same area over and over, just in different times. So basically, you travel to sort-of-the-same-area, but in different eras (like 05 years after 13, Bresha Ruins, then also Bresha 100 after Fall, Bresha 300 after Fall) Which can be annoying. Long:If you have played and ejoyed FF-13 it is a decent follow up. However, the Paradigm-System can be sort of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ up, because you only have 2 Characters + 1 Monster, so the Monsters need to be leveled through Materials instead of CP. The System does not explain it too good, so here is a short: Monsters are sorted in 3 categories, which are Early Peaker (Gains Stats early on, but does go up too high) Well Grown (Gains Stats decently and peaks in middle level (about 45) and Late Bloomer (Does not get Stats early on at all and is useless below certain "treshholds" however, later on gets huge stats boosts and also upgrades further, which makes them the best choice for Lategame) In early stages, you should focus on "Early Peaker" Monster or Well Grown ones, too get a good value without too much effort. IF you can get into this, the Story is pretty good imho. The time-travel stuff can be sort of annoying, but I liked the game overall. Also, I am a huge fan of FF-13, so maybe its just my thoughts.Overall: If I had to give it a rating from 1-100, I suppose this game is somewhere around 84. Some things are not well designed and feel stupid at first, but if you get behind the scenes it is absolutely worth it!

A sequel to a game most people didn't like, and to no ones surprise, most people didn't like it.The gameplay changes that XIII-2 introduce include restricting the cast to only two characters and a monster slot, leading to what you would think would be a more streamlined leveling system right? Wrong, instead of allowing the characters to level their jobs based on said jobs individual grid ala the previous game, you now follow a pre set leveling path with big and small orbs that dictate the level of stat bonus your character gets depending on which job levels on which size of node. The difference between a horrible choice of levels versus an "optimal" damage build set is minimal once you factor in proper team setups and gear, but that begs the question of why is it even in the game at all if it doesn't matter? Because it's a half baked idea just like monster leveling is. Monster leveling also follows this idea of allowing a monster to get stats based on the orb it picks, but it also depends on the kind of random material you use as a catalyst for the monster to earn a level, along with what job that monster is. Oh, and monsters all have arbitrary level caps that mean that starting monsters are effectively just trash you're going to throw away when you find something just a bit later in the game, instead of allowing you to use any monster in the entire game that you're actually allowed to capture and use.The ability to travel through time is horribly pointless as even though it opens up the idea of abusing time paradox's to travel to timelines that otherwise shouldn't exist or have become nonexistent due to said paradox's, it only ever boils down to "Kill a boss" or "put an item here" sidequest feeling objectives that serve as story progression based roadblocks that could've served a better purpose should the developers bothered to have thought out a real purpose for letting us jump back and forth through time that wasn't to push this awful narrative that winds up being pointless due to the way it is destined to end from the start.Giant wall of text later, XIII-2 is both a slightly better, and significantly worse experience than XIII, and I would never recommend anyone play it for anything other than a couple background songs.Big wall of text later, to no ones surprise,

As a huge fan of the first game, I was expecting a similar experience with the second one. To have the best experience however, I learned  that you have to tweak your game and steam settings to minimize crashes and performance hits that plague the reviews of this game (trust me the game itself is not bad compared to the first). I found and followed the steam community guide by Surihix and have not had any crashes or major performance issues (some minor temporary slow load-ups is about it) so far.Regarding the actual game, it definitely a different direction from the original. There are additional mechanics and much more additional quests, making it much more complicated and varied than the first. I considered myself a master of the paradigm system in the original (few deaths overall), but after dying quite a number of times in the beginning it feels like the developers want to make you question your ability. The story is not as focused as the first, which is something I missed. If you are interested a broad story with many details then it might work you. Overall I'm enjoying the game and can't wait to see how my characters develop over time. Not as addicting like the first but enjoyable nonetheless. I would rate it 7-9/10 depending on what's going on and what I'm doing. Solid game but please be sure to follow the fix guide for the best experience. Oh, did I forget to mention the music is just as awesome as the first?

Much like my review in Final Fantasy XIII, I didn't enjoy the story, music and characters in this game very much either. As you only had the two characters, you collected monsters that took the place of your third character, and you leveled and improved them through a sill tree. The true beauty was the DLC additions that allowed you to get several characters from the previous game as a monster, but this happens later in the game than I would have hoped. Unlike the previous game, it is way too easy to overlevel in this game.All in all the game was interesting to play, but while some aspects of the game were an improvement, others changes felt worse than the previous game. Alright, this is... quite something. I enjoyed 13-2 immensely, sunk in about 200 hours total on the Xbox 360 version, and fully completed the game on there. That being said... the port is REALLY poorly done. In order to even get the game to a playable FPS, you have to install a fix compatible with both XIII and XIII-2 from github and turn off your Steam Cloud initially. But, once you get past the first chapter or so... it'll be a lot smoother from there on out. That being said, I'd still recommend the game.One part I enjoyed a lot about this game was the diversity of Paradigm Packs over that of XIII. There are so many monsters to collect that can make your life a lot easier if you put a lot of time in getting materials for them to level up and such, especially the DLC characters, which can only go up to Level 13 as opposed to 90 for many other monsters, but hit way harder at a cost of being really ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hard to get.The story itself could be considered mediocre for a Final Fantasy game, but it does have a lot more to do than XIII, with a lot of endgame bosses to farm and beat, which I do recommend doing for the sake of earning achievements and getting materials for the endgame weapons.Controls feel a tad bit wonky, but it doesn't feel so bad. I'd recommend the use of a controller though just to make it a bit easier and smoother.Graphically, the XIII trilogy always looked good, and still does, even if it isn't on the level of Final Fantasy XV or the newer games, and the movie scenes - they still look great to this day.Character wise... I do like it a lot. Serah can feel a tad bit bland at times, but she does develop as the story goes on, and Noel is a great addition who adds a good bit of depth; Caius is an interesting antagonist, albeit not a favorite of mine from the series, and it's also nice to see that Lightning has developed quite a lot since XIII, and feels a lot more personable and as such, likable.Soundtrack is overall good, but a few songs(such as Limit Break! and Crazy Chocobo) are just flat out memes. Other ones (such as Caius's Theme and Threat Level Omega) are honestly really good to hear and audibly pleasing.Overall, I'd give this game about an 8/10. The fan fix from github makes it a lot more bearable to play and a lot more fun.

This is a review that I want to separate between "The Entire game" and "The last Episode". It took me years to finally sit down and playing Final Fantasy 13-2, mainly due to the fact that the PC port is terrible. But with patches and mods the game is more than playable now and was a very pleasant experience. I had gotten this far into my life without ever knowing the ending or story to this game so I went in blind. All I knew was that Snow wasn't in it (I was wrong but its not like he plays a big role anyway) so that was already a mark against it.  The positives are the story is, at the least, engaging, and all the major set pieces do a good job at conveying the story and a message to the player. Unfortunately the story itself is pretty terrible, but time travel stories usually are. The combat is a slightly more polished FF13 with a pokemon monster battle system included. Honestly, the game is short, I beat it in about 20 hours. I don't have much to say about it. The ending was very good though, and that alone bumps it up for me a lot. I'll say this though, I'll probably never play this game again, but I feel like I got my money's worth.Onto my review of "The Last Episode" Up until the final two boss battles, this episode is, without question, the worst experience that I have had in a JRPG. The final dungeon is a waste of time, boring to look at, the music is also incredibly bland, the puzzle suck, and the dungeon mobs themselves are f'in annoying, to the point where a random mob is more powerful than any of the previous boss battles that I fought leading up to this point. I hated it. I hated the last two hours of this game so much that it was the final nail in the coffin as to whether or not I'd ever replay it. The game is saved by the last two bosses and the ending (I know there are multiple endings, but I'm  assuming the one I got was the real one) My overall rating is a 6.5/10. I'm, at the very least, happy to have played through the game, but honestly all the hate that FF13 gets is unjustified, but if it were directed at 13-2 specifically, I would probably jump on that hate bandwagon too.

TL;DR:  "No" recommendation due to technical aspects of the port wrapper, but "Yes" if you're willing to troubleshoot.  High probability of crashing as purchased.The content and artistry of the game itself is a thumbs up.  Unfortunately, it's wrapped in a technical package that is prone to crashing without taking measures on your end to attempt to stabilize the game while it runs.  For my part, I'm using a so-called "4GB patch"--for those who don't know, it's not that the patch is 4 Gigabytes in size, it's to allow the game to use more than the original 2GB memory limit imposed by hardware constraints when this game was originally developed... the patch itself is a few kilobytes.  I also had to disable cloud save due to crashing/hanging related to saving the game--in my case, the game would crash at points where it would normally save, and the save process completed because I could reload the game and it would resume right where it crashed, so I think it's some kind of interaction between the game and steam around save data that's causing the problem.I can't in good faith recommend this game, as it doesn't work as expected out-of-the-box so to speak.  I want to recommend this game, because I just replayed through FFXIII--on steam, no less, without having to do anything special--and just the opening sequence of this game reveals that the team who worked on the content side of FFXIII-2 took a lot of lessons from the first game and tried to evolve with this work.I DO recommend this game to those who are willing to do some troubleshooting to enjoy an otherwise worthwhile game.

This game is some sort of weird mixture of Pokemon, Final Fantasy, Doctor Who and an old school collectathon. Your third party members are three of a pretty large array of enemies you "capture" randomly throughout the game. The gameplay is a lot like FFXIII and the battle system will feel very familiar to you if you've played it. This time around instead of having a separate crystarium for each job class, there's just a single crystarium for all 6 roles which gives you a chance to (slightly) customize your characters if you're into max/min character development.The real depth comes from the monsters you collect. They each have their own crystariums, traits and skills they can learn. The monster crystarium is more similar to the sphere grid from FFX where you can use a part to level the monster up and choose which stat you want to raise.To make it more fun, you can also infuse your monster with other monsters that will allow it to gain spells and traits from the monster that's consumed. All in all, there's a lot of depth there if you want to dig deep, but it's not necessary if you just want to play through the game.The story is...there. It's time travel nonsense and it gets in it's own way more often than not. Noel is difficult to like and Serah is just missing something (these are your only two party members) to make the characters engaging. You get plenty of cameos if you're into that sort of thing, but overall I couldn't really tell you too much of what happened because time travel is annoying.Outside of your standard FF affair there's 160 fragments to collect throughout the game. This is Banjo-Kazooie style. Each area has X amount of fragments that you may or may not get a clue to find. It was a cool idea to see implemented in an RPG but it lacks the charm of what makes those old N64 collectathons fun to do and you'll be a little sick of it once you get in the 140s.There's also 9 "paradox endings" that you can unlock using some late game items that are somewhat interesting.This game is pretty easy to get 100% achievements on. I only had issue with slot machines and it took several hours of rubber banding my controller to unlock that one. There's also a super annoying quiz section that refuses to die in one area that you need to get through. Otherwise, it's not too hard to 100%Finally, this is a lazy port. You'll more than likely need to check the community guides to patch the game to make it work somewhat decent. Even then you get a lot of flickering and framerate issues but nothing game breaking and nothing that ruined my enjoyment of the game. The game crashed once, and in a very inopportune sport but that was the only real issue I had with this port.Also, there's an area where people just fall over for no reason, it was really captivating.

You can capture, level up, and fight with basically any monster you encounter in the game. I feel the music is just as good as FFXIII. I can't see much of a change, but the first game did have a banger battle music. The art direction continues from the first one, awesome monsters and character designs. My first hour with the game went like this:Oh God, this game has quick time events.  Oh, the game has crashed and locked Steam.  Disable cloud saves.  Restart the game, have to redo the intro since now have no save.  Control Serah.  Why do Serah and Noel start with the exact same known roles? Get to paradigm tutorial. Oh, the game has crashed and hard locked the PC. Download external fix.exe to get through tutorial.  Previously on Final Fantasy XIII-2 read to me by a Moogle.What a terrible introduction to a game, and indicative of Square-Enix's total lack of respect for PC consumers that this port was deemed acceptable to launch.Combat is essentially the same as FFXIII, except now your third party member is a monster. Monsters are captured in the form of crystals that drop (maybe) after you defeat that monster. Encounters are now random, as enemies will spawn out of the ether as you explore the world. You then have the time shown on your Moogle's 'mogclock' to attack the enemy and get a pre-emptive strike, run away from the encounter (unless the enemy is a meanie and chases you) or if the time runs out, get dragged into battle. You make your monsters stronger by feeding them materials of various tier levels (orbs, engines and other loots drops) to advance their 'crystarium', while you grow Serah and Noel via 'crystarium points' earned after battle.Filling the chain gauge and staggering enemies is perhaps less important in this game than its prequel. It's still the best way to deal big damage but I felt that Commandos could actually do a decent amount of damage outside of stagger, as opposed to just being there to keep the chain gauge from falling.The difficulty of bosses in this game comes from their endless, and I mean endless, use of de-buffs on your party and the absolutely awful wounding damage mechanic. Wound damage lowers max health, is completely worthless when used against enemies, and results in your companion monsters constantly dying and needing raised. You spend entire fights removing de-buffs so you can have 5 seconds of switching to an attacking paradigm. At this point the boss will probably use some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to remove all your buffs at once and hit you with 3-4 de-buffs again, and maybe spawn some extra mini-boss. Your own buffs last what seems like about 30 seconds, or as long as it takes to completely wear off before you get to make use of it, and the attack and magic boosting buffs (bravery and faith) can't be learned by Serah and Noel, necessitating bringing in a monster synergist.The music in this game is absolutely awful.  Normally you can rely on Final Fantasy games to have a decent OST.  XIII's wasn't stellar by any means but it wasn't completely offensive to the ears like this garbage.  Those responsible for the screamo-Chocobo song should be tried for crimes against humanity. What on Earth were they thinking, and who were the target audience for this tosh?What did they do to the rain? It looks atrocious. I needed to download a mod to make it look bearable - it hurts the eyes to look at.Why do the children fall over so often? They must all have inner ear infections.The clock-face anomaly puzzles - oh boy.  I can't think of a worse puzzle shoehorned into a game. I'm sorry Squenix, but I can't visualise a 12 step pattern in my head with a time limit and a random starting pattern. I doubt many people that aren't chess masters can. Use of an online puzzle solver is mandatory to complete these sections.The story is naturally terrible.4/10

The paradigm shift battle system is a pain, I'd much rather have a classic ATB system or a turn based one, where you're not forced to juggle with roles like a madman.2. The sudden difficulty spikes at certain points of the game make it really difficult to complete it quickly if you're only interested in the main story.3. Horrible Steam Cloud support occasionally makes the game crash while saving, which makes you loose all the progress you've made since the last succesful save (it can be especially punishing after defeating a difficult and/or tedious boss or beating countless enemies while farming Crystogen Points, if you've forgotten to save frequently). If you're not playing this game on multiple devices, I STRONGLY SUGGEST TURNING OFF STEAM CLOUD SAVING.

This is a fun, quirky time travelling adventure. I've seen a lot of people complain that FFXIII is too linear. FFXIII-2 allows the player to jump between locations at will. It also features a tonne of side quests  (some more engaging than others) and optional content. The PC version comes with the DLC from the Playstation version except for a few outfits which they couldn't port over for copyright versions.One main downside: this game was obviously designed to be lower budget. Maps are reused from FFXIII and even most of the new maps designed for FFXIII-2 are recycled at least once (you go to the same map in different time zones). This can lead to the world feeling small at times. Overall, I enjoyed FFXIII but felt this was the better game.

EDITED TO ADD: I see that by far the most common complaint other reviewers have is instability or other issues with the port. All I can say is that I never experienced any of these problems. (And usually if there's technical issues that some people have and others don't, I get them really bad. I had an absolute nightmare with Divinity: Original Sin 2, for example.) The only technical issue I had with this game was occasional slowdowns that were fixed easily by turning off cloud saves. I can't promise you won't have those problems, but I can tell you they're not happening to everyone by any stretch of the imagination.ORIGINAL REVIEW: It's the same basic engine as FFXIII, but the gameplay experience is everything that game wasn't - exploration-oriented and radically non-linear, and fairly lighthearted despite the sometimes apocalyptic plot. This makes for a much more enjoyable gameplay experience than the dour, linear, and overly hand-holding FFXIII. I'd go so far as to call it the only direct sequel to a Final Fantasy game that is actually better than the game it's a sequel to. It's a bit simplified from its predecessor, though this is compensated somewhat by giving you access to almost all of the gameplay mechanics right from the beginning. The original Final Fantasy XIII eventually gave you a bit more to work with, but it took two thirds of the bloody game to get there, thus the common complaint that most of the game feels like a tutorial. The previous game's weapon upgrades are particularly missed, although working out which monsters to use in your third slot is at least as interesting.The characters are a bit flat, and while the plot sometimes uses its time-travel aspects in interesting ways, I suggest not trying too hard to work out how time-travel works here because ultimately it's pretty incoherent. My biggest complaint, though, is that the challenge level is very low even by Final Fantasy standards; slower advancement through the crystarium and giving out some abilities at much higher levels would have helped the pacing. Some may view this as a positive, as it does make the game very newcomer-friendly.Naturally it's gorgeous with a great soundtrack, it is a relatively modern Final Fantasy after all, and that alone would make it more enjoyable than not. If I can't give an unqualified recommendation, there's nevertheless a lot more to like here than not.

This game is a massive improvement over FF 13. The battle system feels much tighter, you receive freedom of movement much sooner and the characters are far more likeable.  There are a fair amount of cameos from the old cast of 13, but it doesn't get too overbearing.As the game revolves around two core characters, in order to not break the battle system they introduced a monster system to replace a third tagalong character, where you need to feed upgrade items to improve them vs using the Crystarium system.  The monster system is interesting, but you won't have the money (or rather, gil) to really explore it until later on in the game unless you'd like to do a lot of farming.The story is a time travel romp, and the Non Canon Paradox Endings explore some of the more interesting aspects of what could be done with it.  Not everything is sunshine and daisies unfortunately:- The DLC (outside of outfits) is only accessible after beating the main story.- The Golden Saucer Equivalent, Serendipity, is not great.  Chocobo racing is ok, but Slots is painful, random, and you *need* to play and win a certain amount of money (which took my playthrough something like 6 hours) in order to unlock the True Ending. - There are some questionable design choices that just seem to be there to lengthen the game (some monsters, for example, only show up once a level - to get them to come back, you need to reset and play to where they spawn in the level again)While it isn't without flaws, if you're a fan of JRPGs, I imagine you'll enjoy it.

Is the game fun?  Yes, and worth getting.However, it is a very big step down from FF13 in almost every way.*Very* few pre-rendered cutscenesOnly two playable chars in the entire gameRaising a point in one class makes all the others more expensive seems silly.Accessories feel... useless because of the point cap.  Want to use a ribbon?  Then you can have no other accessories.One thing it has going for it:The world feels like you're exploring, and they use interesting reasons for recycling assets.Having said that, there's very few actual maps to explore, most are either tiny or vast empty spaces or "hallway simulator".13 had very few loading screens and they lasted seconds.13-2 has frequent (and gets even more frequent post-game) that are long... and **OMG** is the loading screen obnoxious.  To the point of inducing physical pain.  This is the only serious flaw I can say about the game.**NOTE** the game crashes frequently as is.  I used some file that I found that fixes the problem.  "Converts to us more ram" or something like that.

Before you start playing, it is strongly recommended you visit the game's forums and find the link to download the "4GB Patch" (it's not that big) from the pinned Troubleshooting topic. Otherwise if you're playing on a relatively new/powerful PC you will have a lot of issues with random crashing, various framerate fluctuations, audio cutting out, etc.As a rare sequel in the FF franchise (only 4 & 10/X had similar), it's much like FF13 with a few gameplay & character tweaks, including being able to change outfits as you please (hello, Serah fanservice right away!). As far as the story goes, you'll get much more out of it if you've finished 13 but it's not required.The big thing here is your PC really determines the game's quality-if your PC meets the minimum requirements but doesn't have a good processor and some VRAM the game is playable but the framerate will be poor and will stutter a lot. More powerful PCs make it look fantastic in HD but due to limitations of the port you may have a lot of issues although the aforementioned patch does help out.I would try and play all the way through 13 before checking this one out although it's not required. Good for the price (especially the awesome soundtrack) but I'd hold out for a sale. For now I only give it a slight thumbs-up due to the various technical issues. Again, get the 4GB Patch and apply it first. You will have a much better experience if you do.

I personally really liked the game. You only get two characters (+ a monster for team compositions), which might seem a bit silly for an RPG, but the characters are quite likeable so it didn't feel bad to have only the two of them. Story-wise, it felt a little small to be honest, but I didn't try to complete most side-quests, so I think that adds a lot of hours to the game. I enjoyed the fact you can sort-of choose your own "story timeline" near the middle. I enjoyed the combat style - it feels fast action-y but also with strategic elements since different team formations lend to different add-on effects.My only grief with the game (and with most Final Fantasies tbh), is that you can be over-leveled for every stage... except the last! So you need to sit in the very last stage and grind monsters just so you can beat the last of the Final Bosses. I actually beat the 4 Final Bosses with relative ease and then the very last one is just so stupidly hard. Honestly I'll probably just watch the ending online, I don't feel like sitting to grind to beat that one boss.Edit: With about 4-5 more hours spent on a couple side-quests, I went back and beat the final boss. I still wish I didn't have to spend more hours on the game, as the side-quests didn't really add anything story-wise.

Crashes when exceeding 2GB of RAM; Honestly, I have to think what SE's dev team were thinking when they planned to release this, because this kind of behaviour from any graphics/cinematic game is expected and has been for over a decade.Yet, there is still no official patch to convert it to 64-bit/increase the memory use.It suffers the classical problems with ports and mouse controls, too sensitive, or not sensitive enough, there doesn't seem to be a nice balance in the settings, which is awkward when your character movement also effects the characters walking angle, which has the turning circle of a moon.Additionally, syncing cloud saves isn't recommended, because again, more crashes, more problems.Occasionally having Steam-overlay on can also cause issues.That loud as ~ background music, why?Bottom line:It's another dodgy port, it's fine-tune patching for fundamental problems in the software, has been ignored since the day it was released on Steam.If you want to play it, I highly recommend visiting the Community Hub to self-administer some much needed patching/modding to stabilize, fix some of the missing graphical content and stabilize the horrific scaling of the audio.It's not the best FF story (IMO), but this is best played on a console if you want hassel free gameplay and to forgo any negative impacts of neglect on this PC version.

Such mixed feelings with this game. In short: a sizable amount of people really hated XIII so they ran in the opposite direction in almost every regard. Personally, I thought XIII was kinda of OK, I really liked the battle system in that game for some reason, but it is undeniably an exercise in frustration in A LOT of ways. So they made XIII-2 and reused a lot of the assets to make something that could perhaps be a bit more compelling. A lot of open locations that you can walk around and interact with people, get quests, do some stuff and fight some monsters. And I like it. I like it a lot. I really enjoy the "jumping around from time to time while trying to make a better future" structure of the game. It makes locations worth revisiting and it's interesting to see the changes. I even enjoy the crystal fragment collecathon thing they have going on. I like the extra bosses and the completely optional locales that do nothing but flesh out the world and the characters. There is a lot of interesting things that are actively hidden in this game. Having said all that, it's bizarre to think about how 20 years ago Chrono Trigger did this way better, but XIII-2 is still really enjoyable in its own right.My main problem with XIII-2 is pretty much the same as it was with XIII: The story is complete garbage. It's just complete garbage in a different way. XIII suffered from an incomprehensible plot obscured by terms that weren't explained until 3/4 of the game, and a party that had no idea what it actually wanted to do until the last hour of gameplay. Meanwhile, XIII-2 suffers from having an atrocious plot that is explained excessively at every corner, no one misses a chance to spout exposition, but they mostly just say words that make no sense in context or otherwise. The game is loaded with some of the biggest plot holes this side David Cage. People just say stuff and it's true but there is no context for more than half of it. Noel is a potentially interesting character but he is very badly realized in the context of the game. Everyone else ranges from mediocre to terrible. Playing it on the PC, after having already done so in the PS3, I am sure I made the correct decision: Skipping every single main story cutscene made this immensely more enjoyable. The only redeemable feature of this game's story is, ironic as that may be, its ending. Because even though it is nothing but a hook for Lightning Returns in the most blatant "to be continued" way possible (and I mean it literally says "to be continued" in the ending), it is still the one and only time in the entire game where the writers set up a major plot point and followed through with it, and it works really well.XIII-2 is very similar to X-2 in a lot of ways, now that I think about it, and I enjoy it for largely the same reasons: an interesting world and game mechanics, varied quests, nice battle system that scales nicely and presents good challenge. I have been a long time fan of the Final Fantasy series. As such, I've had some standards that I look for in all Final Fantasy games. FFX was my favorite, with a great storyline that didn't make me feel trapped in a linear path. FFXII was great for giving us open battle and a great story as well. FFXIII for having a fantastic story line. FFXV for having a great story with all around brand new mechanics to breath life into the series. I enjoyed FFXIII for the story as well and the less complecated level system compared to FFX. This game, however, has taken found some way to not incorporate any of the above things, which is amazing. Combat is...again...random with load screens for each battle. Escaping is difficult and getting premeptive strikes impossible on a decent number of enemies. Like FFXIII, it's auto-battle until they die unless you need healing. The story line seems like it was built to give clarity as you go on, but it just seems like one big convulted mess.One thing I always loved was mini-games, as they provided a quick distraction. Now, those mini-games are mandatory and timed, so the fun is replaced by forced challenge. At least in previous games you had they opprotunity to study as you went, letting everyone enjoy at their own pace. Not to mention sidequests, which only indicate the original quest giver on the map, not the target. This would be fine in a game that offered decent options to reduce or remove random encounters, or had encounters you could see coming, like it's predecessor. Instead, in most cases, you're wandering around blindly, coming across fight after fight that you're over-levelled enough for the load time to not even be worth it.If you're like me and NEED the story to be completed across all games, wait for a sale, but dont anticipate enjoying this game. I've put it down many times over the last few weeks just to play ANYTHING else. It feels like a chore to play sometimes, which is a shame for a series I love so much. If you don't need to play more of the story, do a solid pass and move on to another game. Not worth it for those who dont feel a compulsion to play. And not truly worth it to those who do.

Final Fantasy XIII-2 is the direct sequel to the hot garbage known as Final Fantasy XIII. I would have never guessed that I would have had so much fun with FFXIII-2 after my soul-draining experience with FFXIII. It is no exaggeration that Square Enix took fan feedback from the first game close to their hearts and did a thorough a 180° with this game. In fact, Square Enix made such drastic measures that they retconned the ending of FFXIII and pretty much wrote away most of the L’Cie, Fal’Cie and focus jargon. This is one of the few games I’ve played where the sequel is so much better than its’ predecessor that you could just pretend that the first game never existed (another game series that comes to mind is Mass Effect and Mass Effect 2).The story takes place directly after FFXIII and changes the ending. Instead of Lightning reuniting with her sister Serah, Lightning is literally erased from history and everyone believes that she sacrificed herself along with Vanille and Fang to save the inhabitants of Cocoon. The only person that seems to remember what truly happened is Serah. The cause of all this is Caius, a man in a purple jumpsuit and wields a cool looking sword eye weapon who has manipulated time itself for some nefarious purpose. It is up to Serah and Noel, a mysterious time traveler from the future to fix the time paradoxes and confront Caius. As a time travel story, the game completely misses the mark and tries to explain mysterious things because of “time magic”. Fortunately at least what FFXIII-2’s story has going for it is that it is at least mildly comprehensible with no need to consult the Datalog. There are also nice episodic recaps everytime you load your save. In the first hour of gameplay you can tell Square Enix immediately did right with this game. Characters no longer spout non sequiturs at each other. There are multiple branching paths to explore. You can actually talk and have conversations with NPCs! And finally you can access most of the gameplay immediately with the rest unlocking within the first three hours. The Paradigm system from FFXIII also got a revamp. Serah and Noel will always be in your party, with a rotating slot used for monsters. That’s right, FFXIII-2 is also a Pokėmon-esk monster collecting game! Each monster represents a specific Crystarium role and it becomes a quest in itself to find and raise the best Commandos, Ravagers, Medics, etc. That said if you didn’t enjoy the Paradigm system in the first game, this game will not be changing your mind.I was not a fan of some of the other changes that Square Enix has made. For some reason they learned that that QTEs are pretty popular with the kids these days and included them throughout the game. The QTEs show up in cutscenes and during battle. Hitting every QTE will deal bonus damage or reward you with a special prize. Fortunately failing the QTEs isn’t an automatic fail.Another feature included is branching dialog sequences. While branching dialog is much appreciated as it helps flesh out Serah and Noel, it usually only rewards an item if you pick the one correct/serious choice..There are also severe pacing issues with FFXIII-2.The first 4 episodes are fairly easy and straightforward to follow. The 5th episode is gated off until Serah and Noel collect 5 specific fragments located in various timelines.The game give you hints in which timelines and areas to find these fragments, but the problem is, the game does not tell you how. In order to reach these specific timelines, you need to have enough Wild Artefacts, the keys to opening these timelines. The game never keeps track of which locations have Wild Artefacts are in them and it becomes painfully annoying to scour through each and every timeline for them. The problem is also exacerbated when these Wild Artefacts are impossible to access without pursuing some relatively long quest lines. Unless if by dumb luck you opened the right timelines and did the right quests, I strongly recommend resorting to a guide if you get stuck at this point.FFXIII-2 suffers from a low production value and most of the content is recycled from the original game. The new music is eclectic and random and doesn’t quite feel like a Final Fantasy soundtrack.There are some catchy tracks like the Red Chocobo song, but also random ones like this heavy metal song they put in some boss fights. Most of the character models and monsters are recycled from the original. Voice acting with the exception of the main cast is shotty with Mog being the most annoying to listen to. Lip syncing is poorly done and you can notice characters moving their lips but not matching what they’re saying.The poor production values also creep their way onto the PC port of the game. On Windows 10, the game will crash within the first few minutes of gameplay due to a memory issue. The framerate advertised to run up to 60 FPS, regularly dips down to 30 FPS even on powerful rigs. I experienced no issues playing FFXIII on PC so it’s strange how all of these bugs happen with the sequel. Luckily there is a great FF fan community that has provided most of the fixes to these issues (see: . It is a shame that Square Enix did not patch their game even though it has been released almost 4 years ago and counting.Final Fantasy XIII-2 feels like a game that took major risks and paid off. Rather than living in the shadow of the first game and playing it safe, Square Enix decided to take the series into a whole new direction with this sequel. The game oozes with new ideas, some brilliant and some awful. This is a game that is so different from its’ predecessor that saying it is the sequel to Final Fantasy XIII is an insult. Yes, it is using the same main characters and battle system, but it does so much more than the original. Despite my complaints, I enjoyed my time playing Final Fantasy XIII-2 look forward to playing the end of the trilogy: Lightning Returns.
