Final Fantasy XIII-2 carries on where the previous title left off, with Serah searching for her sister. This title overall is far less difficult than its predecessor, less linear and also a little more open-ended.If you played FFXIII, you'll be familiar with the paradigm combat system. In this title you create up to three sets, or packs, of paradigms for use in different situations. However, instead of 3 humans, your party will consist of Serah, Noel and a tamed beast which fulfills a fixed role. You capture these beasts by defeating them in battle; each has a set capture chance. Sound vaguely familiar? Yes, this is somewhat like Pokemon.Once captured, each of your monsters will have a crystarium of their own. Instead of using traditional CP as you're used to and will do for Serah and Noel, for the monsters, you'll spend resources you acquire as drops through battles to level them up. You can also infuse them with skills and passive attributes from other monsters you've captured to make them even stronger. Your creativity is the limit in what types of paradigm packs you create.The way in which the story is managed, through the Historia Crux, is unique. This central hub allows you to traverse time as you so chose, providing quick access to all the gates you have opened to specific locations. From here you can also close a gate and roll back the story to where you were before you arrived at the gate you just closed. You can then replay everything up to this point all over again, while still maintaining your stats and cast of monsters. If at any point you want to revert to your original forward progress, return to the Historia Crux and just open the closed gate. All will be restored, again with no impact on your team. It's a really cool system in my opinion.There are still various weapons and accessories for your characters to employ, but the demands on grinding out gil or special resources (read: trapezohedrons) to get the best gear are gone. The best weapons are acquired through more reasonable methods. Also, it's worth reiterating this game is much more forgiving in combat than FFXIII as there are no hard caps on stats based on your degree of progress in the story.If there is a minor drawback, it's the graphics. The pre-recorded cinematics are not at all up to the level of FFXIII, which was like watching a film at times, but for the era this game was released in, the visuals are still good. Framerates can be a little shaky, especially while moving around towns or other areas, but combat is pretty fluid. Overall, considering the rest of the package, this issue is not too difficult to overlook.I've played this title off and on since 2011 and still find it enjoyable. More friendly to franchise newcomers than FFXIII.9/10

FFXIII-2 continues the story of FFXIII seconds after it ended. The timeline is changed by some tiny details, but the consequences are huge. This time around, you don't run from scene to scene in one long story hose, but you can travel through time and space from some sort of hub world. Every place in this game has at least one extra time you can travel to. Say, you're in year 10 of some place, but a rock blocks your path, so you travel to year 2 and prevent the rock from being there in the first place. You also don't have to do everything in a specific order and you can progress several threads of the story at the same time.The combat system is quite unusual, although upon further inspection, it really is an amalgam of the usual FF "ATB" (Active Time Battle, a half real time, half turn based system) and FFX-2's role system, mixed with some FFXII style AI "what to do when". The system expanded a bit since FF13, you can now pick your team leader. Since there are only two playable characters, you'll have to catch, level and breed monsters as a third player. Monsters can have only one role, but you can have three monsters in the third slot to toggle through at the same time. If your main is killed, the game switches to the other character automatically, so this time around, a healing role as non-main actually makes sense. The roles can be fine tuned this time. The level system has also been changed, it looks simpler, but you actually got more choice than in FFXIII.They also added some sort of QTE system in film sequences. You're presented with a choice of buttons and different effects (use magic or use melee). You can then decide what to do or do nothing. Those choices usually have minor consequences, but they always change something.As usual for an FF game, the game itself isn't very hard, but there is a grind-intensive endgame, if you really want to do everything.The PC port of this not without problems, most of them are the same as in FFXIII:- Aggressive VSync goes down to 30, if 60 cannot be held for a very short time. This produced an annoying fps lag on my machine, I had to limit the FPS to 30 with an external tool.- Framerates other than 30-60 will do weird things to the engine.- The general performance is wonky at best. I think it's still better than the PS3 version, because here you have a chance at playing the game in a high resolution with some AA at 30+ FPS, while the PS3 version struggled to maintain its 30 FPS at the 720p internal resolution.- The game constantly polls USB HID devices for controllers. If you have no controller connected, you'll probably get a nasty stuttering effect. There are workarounds, but a controller is suggested.- The game plays well with two or six sound channels. Anything but 2.0 or 5.1 is likely to warp your audio channels around.- Cloud saving crashes the game for some people. I recommend turning it off, because there is no actual map of which points break the game.- There is a slim chance of a game breaking bug in the first five minutes of the game. Without spoiling too much, you'll see your character leave the battle screen, but the game won't end the battle. In this case, restart the game and skip the scenes. Once you've seen the first "score card", you'll know you're fine.
While you can make due with this port, but turning off cloud saves and then hoping it doesn't randomly crash otherwise. It's just too much effort to get a game to work.

Actually the best entry of the trilogy. They improved upon the FF13-1 battle gameplay with changes such as faster class switching and your main character dying not meaning an instant game over (I cannot tell you how many times I almost threw my controller on the floor over this in 13-1). Furthermore, the music in this installment is probably some of the best I've ever heard in any Final Fantasy. Two songs stand out the most (listing their names not their appearances due to spoilers): Invisible Depths and Limit Break.The plot is... urgh. FF13-1's was waaaay overcomplicated, with many of the finer plot details left to datalog entries and so many unexplained crazy naming conventions. Add time travel on top of that and you have, well, pretty much a clusterf***. However, all is not lost here, for the main cast is easily the driving force of this game. Serah and Noel are decent characters, but the main antagonist, Caius Ballad, easily takes the cake. I mean, I totally empathized with the guy, to the point where though I understood where Serah and Noel were coming from, I really wished Caius would have won, because his feelings and motivations were so genuine. And if I had the powers he had and the same backstory, I would have done the same. Because, really, the world matters little if you are fated to see the one you love die over, over, over and over again until the end of time.I would call FF13-2 a rough diamond. Definitely better in terms of gameplay than either 13 or Lightning Returns, but it suffers from some plot-related issues, some stemming from the convoluted 13 and some stemming from the time-travel motif. Still, by far and large the best game of the Final Fantasy 13 trilogy,

XIII-2 and the original XIII are NOT the same game, nor is it a faithful continuation of the story, really.While the basic battle systems remains identical (same roles, paradigms, etc), the Crystarium in 2 is all kinds of weird by compare and nowhere near as intuitive.  They've also added these weird "Cinematic Action" sequences where you have to press random buttons on the keyboard in order to complete a cinematic sequence without penalty...  it completely breaks immersion and is a horrible addition to the game.As for the story: you control Serah and RandomGuy.  RandomGuy is completely uninteresting, Serah is clueless, and apparently Lightning is known as the Warrior Goddess?  While what they came up with is unique, it's also extremely off-the-wall.  To be clear: this is not a worthy successor to FFXIII.Despite enjoying XIII a great deal, there's not a single thing about XIII-2 that I like.

I finally decided even if it is lag crazy I really really wanted to know the plot and how this story/trilogy was going to be played out so I bought it and played it.It lagged and crashed horribly. The first couple of episodes it felt like I was swimming through thick goo. But whatever. I was ready for that and kept on playing. Then my ancient graphics card overheated and died. (Not due to playing this game, although it happened while I was playing it. A poorly placed cord near the graphics card moved at some point and blocked the graphics card fan from spinning.) Somehow though I acquired a fairly new 2016 graphics card for free through a co-worker and installed it onto my, I have no clue how long I've had this thing, computer and it worked great. No more lags, no more crashes. So as long as you're not playing on a laptop or trying to record yourself for YouTube, and have a fairly new, decent graphics card, playing this game should be no big deal. (Just for reference, I have Windows 10, and my processor is a duo-core or something like that, not even a quad, and at least 8 years old or more.)As for the game itself, I enjoyed the game better than the original. I don't have to grind to get through it and I can just enjoy playing it. I don't care about getting the rare whatever or the best thingamajig. I like that you play the same characters from beginning to end unlike the original where you keep jumping around (that made it hard for me to get into the game since I didn't feel attached to anyone.)Not really sure what people mean by bad port. The game seems perfectly fine to me (but it's been awhile since I've owned a console of any sort). But I'm one of those people that can't tell the audio difference between a MP3 and a WAV format so if you're into PS4 like graphics then maybe this game will be disappointing? Anyways, I enjoyed it and can't wait to see the ending (I'm almost there).

Just to first note, yes this game is buggy for the PC, but this is one of the best FF games. You can get around a lot of issues limiting your cores to real cores if you have a Intel CPU, if you're running AMD you should be fine. Then setting the game to window not fullscreen and use "Borderless Gaming" to achive fullscreen.  I've had the game crash very little since doing that. There are various fixes through the community you can look into. I'm running an Intel i7 4790k with a R9 390, my FPS is normally 60 but this game does drop frames even if you do the fixes. I'm not holding my breath for Sqaure to come back and patch this game, there isn't much of a point now considering the game's age. Now to the actual game. Overall I've really enjoyed this FF a lot, the improvements they made to the gameplay aspect really improved it. I like the fact that there are puzzles and almost a "treasure hunt" throughout the game. The characters are really likeable, which is something I think the XIII series get's looked over for. The story is actually really good, it's not confusing if you have half a brain, I saw some reviews critiquing that. You can easily get about 30 hours on this game, right now I have 29-ish and I haven't even completed the story. You're rewarded for exploring (much like XIII) and taking your time in this game, so do so.Game can kinda be a press "x" simulator at points like it's predecessor, but the leveling up system in this one provided more a challenge as well as your Paradigm Shift and ATB playing more of a factor in this one. I also like the addition of having monsters that fight with you.All in all this game isn't perfect for the PC, but it still get's a 5/5 for me for the actual game.And finally it's got Mog. :3

Not just because it is essentially "milking it" but also because we have lived in an original world and now we are distorting that original.2. I did not like the cliffhanger at the end. Particularly that it leads to the disaster that the Lightning Returns was.3. The markers of map are confusing. Sometimes a lot.OK, what do I like about it:1. I like the transitioning of characters. They are quite real. You can accept that character turning to this. They match their world and they feel, even more than the first episode, like the older games of the series.2. It is a bit of a difficult game but not too much. They have successfully managed to create a world in which you would be rewarded by doing more side quests.3. Without going into spoiling stuff, the physics of the game and everything about it which has changed has not really broken your link to the original. It is well enough that after a year of playing them you may not exactly remember what fight was in which game unless you try to remember the story sequence leading to it.And to address an old argument: The original is often called a tunnel simulator. It is often criticized for being linear. Well I don't care personally, but yes, this one is less linear. But not even close to an open world.Overall? If you liked the first one, give it a try. To me, it's unfortunate that the string of Final Fantasy games that were released with the main number of XIII are written off as lousy games. Yes, they all have flaws, but that doesn't mean you can't enjoy playing them. FF XIII-2 is a prime example of such a game.When you release a sequel, the game will inevitably be compared to the source material and I'll do such a thing here as well. While I personally enjoyed XIII, it has received its fair share of critizism. The complaints were mainly aimed at the long tutorial sequence, the linear gameplay and the convoluted story. It also had some other issues, such as a long transition time between the first paradigm shift (the battle system in these games) and the sometimes uninteresting or downright annoying characters.Square seemed to have done something about most complaints with the sequel. For starters, the opening level (playing as Lightning, the protagonist of the first game) is pretty interesting and while the tutorial sequence with Serah (Lightning's little sister) is a bit tedious again, it doesn't drag on for hours to come. Besides that, there are many ways to explore and revisit different regions and they give the player more options to choose from and more routes to follow. This is probably the biggest change compared to its predecessor and it really helps the game.I myself embrace most of the changes they made compared to the first game. Like I said, I enjoyed XIII, but most annoyances I had with the first game are removed. For instance, it took me about 60 hours to finish XIII and a few sidequests but it took me ANOTHER 65 hours to wrap up every achievement in the game, including having to grind the toughest enemy of the game in the hope of getting an item I needed for every weapon available. It's way less tedious to complete everything in XIII-2, with the chocobo rider and slot machine achievements being the exceptions. Most battles are now avoidable, which is also a step up from XIII. They also improved and simplified the leveling system, sped up the first paradigm shift and gave us the opportunity to use monsters as part of the team.Another feature they added in this game is the possibility of alternate endings. While some can be found and viewed during your regular playthrough, most can only be seen after beating the final boss. That also brings us to the post-game content. There are many fragments in each world that serve as a sorts of collectibles. Some serve a purpose, for instance opening a portal to a new and unexplored world or timezone. Some are easier to find than others. The alternative endings you view also net you a fragment for that region. With the time map you use to explore the worlds, it's easy to see if you have found every fragment in that world and time zone. What's even more interesting is that you have the power to "rewind" a certain section of the game, meaning you can go back and play that part of the story as if you had never set foot on the world before. This serves as a fun way to kill time and make sure you have explored every nook and cranny of the game.The biggest drawback of XIII is the story. While XIII's story was convoluted and complicated if you didn't take the time to read TONS of story-related content in your menu, XIII-2's story is just too simple. Every problem in the world has to do with time paradoxes and time-travel (which is a key part of the gameplay as well) and they can all be resolved by fixing said paradoxes. That's as straightforward as it can get. The game has a really interesting enemy in the form of Caius Ballad, though he's mainly made interesting by some stellar voice acting by Liam O'Brien. The fights with him are especially very epic and the first battle with Caius proves a hefty challenge if you don't level up some more. It's too bad he didn't get as much screen time he deserved.That being said, the game is still very much enjoyable. If you can look past the obvious plotholes, or timeholes if you will (badun tss), XIII-2 will give you a fun time exploring the wonderful world of Pulse in an abundance of time zones. The music, the graphics and especially the gameplay make for a game I wouldn't mind completing over and over. I hope you'll give it a chance - and enjoy it as much as I did!

FF XIII-2 is surprisingly good and enjoyable game. I didn’t expect much after XIII which was mediocore after all and maybe I am too kind. I liked XIII-2 from the beginning on the contrary of its predecessor.Characters and story are not the strongest ones in franchise but it worked just fine. Time travelling to various locations and even to parallel times is fresh idea (Chrono Trigger was first and better,yea I know.) and really fun to explore all the areas. Also several endings which were unxepectedly brutal and sad reminded me Chrono Trigger again. Story and time paradoxes are sometimes a bit confusing but nothing too awkward.Battles are pretty much the same as in XIII. Team includes 2 main chars and one tamed monster (I sticked with healing Cait Sith nearly whole game and then I got healing slime…epic team). Taming monsters in new feature, along with live triggers (wannabe dialogue options), quick-time events (lovely on the keyboard), time rifts with logical puzzles and moogle skills such as throwing him to find treasures and revealing invisible things.PC port is ok – game looks great. FPS rarely drops but nothing serious. Controls are worse case, I recommend controller because of quick-time events and for scoring pre-empive strikes. Music is questionable – I like Nobuo-san music in older games so much more and I really don’t remember more than 3 tracks from this game. Main theme is fine, Ending Japanese romantic pop song is also good, weird rap song from Bresha ruins and awful nu-metal remake of chocobo theme are not my favorites. Dual subs works here, so I played with Japanese audio/English subtitles and had nothing to complain.Long story short – you have to be brave and complete FF XIII to enjoy this much better game. I think it is the biggest minus.*I wish they made remake of Chrono Trigger in bad-ass graphic…

A good game, but a very, very bad PC port.  If you're interested in this game and have a PS3 or 360, i'd recommend playing it on one of those systems.Storyline;An incredibly tragic time-travel based storyline.  It does it very well (in my opinion) and is the strongest game, story-wise, in the Lightning Saga.Gameplay;It has a streamlined, simplified version of FF13's ATB battle system.  Serah and Noel are your two static characters, with your third character being a tamed monster of a fixed role.  You can have up to 3 differnet monsters in your "Party Pack" that you can use to make paradigms.  Still a good system, but I prefer FF13's.Difficulty;This is a pretty big one for me.  There's almost no difficulty at all here. The superbosses, as you might expect them to be, aren't a challenge at all.  I came across both of them while doing sidequests with no preperation at all and was able to defeat them with ease.  I didn't even know they were supposed to be "superbosses." The only difficulty in this game comes from fighting the poor frame rate and the DLC Colosseum.Music;It has a mix of original songs and songs from FF13.  There are some songs made for 13-2 that are nice, but the majority of them are quite bad.

Final Fantasy XIII wasn't a bad game, just a disappointing one. However, it had a good conclusion, and a sequel wasn't needed or wanted. But Final Fantasy XIII-2 truly feels like a Final Fantasy game, and in almost every way is how XIII should have been in the first place. If you enjoyed XIII, you'll love XIII-2. If you didn't, you'll probably enjoy XIII-2. Knowing the story of XIII helps, but isn't very important. So, what's improved? The combat is mostly the same when it finally got good in XIII. But here, you have it in full force in around 2 hours. The paradigm shift animations were removed, making the combat more fluid. There's only 2 permanent party members, so the third needed to be filled. And that's where the monster capture mechanic comes in, using defeated monsters in battle with you, where you can level them up and combine them. And it's actually fun, but the infusion mechanics are a bit complicated. You can change you party members in battle and are forced to in you're leader is KO'ed, but unfortunately you cannot control the monsters. That would be cool. Now the maps are more open, and you can revisit almost all areas at almost any time. There's more side quests, but most of them are just collecting stuff. It definitely isn't linear as XIII. As a bonus, you can also play in slot machines or participate in chocobo races. Random encounters are back, and for the most part you can avoid them if you want. Leveling weapons and accessories is more traditional, using some monster drops to upgrade them one time at best. The graphics are a bit improved, but i prefered the original animations and locations. The music is a bit worse, but still pretty good. They even added some great songs from XIII, and it doesn't feel like cheap, but as an addition. The story is shorter and weaker, but the characters are more interesting, some of them. My favourite was definitely the new main villain, Caius Ballad. What i didn't like was the sequel baiting ending. The PC version also includes most of the consoles DLC, including another Lightning vs. Caius battle, poker and an original card game, and my favourite: additional boss battles, including two very hard superbosses (one of them is Gilgamesh). In the end, XIII-2 has a XIII feel, but returns with many of the things that make the Final Fantasy series great, at least in the gameplay.BUT...The PC port is horrible. XIII wasn't good either, but XIII-2 is really bad on PC, mainly because it has worst performance, lots of low FPS and FPS drops, and crashes randomly including when you save with the Steam Cloud active. You can use the cloud to backup your save, but i don't recommend you to use it as a regular save feature. And sadly the game most likely won't be fixed. And it's a shame. A much better sequel with a much worst port. If your PC can handle it and if you're ready to play a bad PC port, i can recommend it.

As the middle chapter of the Final Fantasy 13 trilogy, I considered this game a must play after finishing FF 13. Final Fantasy 13-2 is the story of Serah, Noel, and the Time Rangers. Time is broken and it's up to them to solve history. As Time Travel stories go, I've seen worse and more confusing ones. 13-2 gets going right out of the gate in stark contrast of FF 13 which took about 10 hours before it opened up.  In this game, you can explore right from the the start. The combat system is the same paradigm system from the first game with the added touch of monster taming. Tamed monsters fight with you in battle as part of your paradigms and, most monsters in the game can be tamed;each coming with their own active and passive benefits. Taming  monsters became my thing as I sought out and farmed specific monsters to add to my party.The combat system never got boring, the story kept me interested until the end, and the monster farming added a fun side thing to do. Sure this is a Jrpg ass jrpg and got anime AF at times. But that's pretty much what I was expecting from a Final Fantasy game.  Some people on here were griping about the frame rate, but, I never experienced any FPS issues.  Worth the purchase. This game also has a primer that tells the story of Final Fantasy 13 very well so you can skip the first game and not feel that you missed out on anything. Played on a Toshiba Satellite i5-3337u740m 2GB12GB RamPlayed on medium/high settings with no noticable frame rate issues.

### FIVE KEY POINTS ###Truth is, FF XIII-2 it's a great game if you're looking for a RPG about distant worlds. The ensemble, characters, story, graphics, music & (re)playability are awesome and beautiful (kawaiii !!).The game is just beautiful (aka Kawaii), the illumination blends very well acrosss every environment from cities to the  wildlands. It's not a flat grey land, or a scenery full of glow, The FF XIII-2 design is just great from the start to the end.Well, the soundtrack mixes good tracks of  modern guitar rock, instrumental (classical/baroque) and piano... along the game you'll hear some tracks full of voice and lyrics. The blend between the play and music is as you can expect.. awesome.Personally, I like The Last Hunter, Knight of The Goddess, Eclipse, New Bodum, Plains of Eternity, Run ...Enjoyable, It can be played using the keyboard. The turn-based strategy was crafted to enjoy the combat... the paradigm switch is faster (than in XIII) and you can wander around every map looking for combats or just going to the mission objectives. Some interactions are needed in cinematic time, great!. You can tame almost every monster to fight in your team, i like this idea. A really big dog fights in my team ...lol.The story is not dependant on FF XIII, the game can be enjoyed as a standalone game. The story involves time travel, fighting for what is worth, frienship and trust, all in all the storyline is clear (not crystal clear but clear) and the characters are well defined...You can choose to play the role of the boy or the girl... in any case you can use magic, and close combat but you must choose carefully what abiities you develops first.The replayability is guaranteed, to get extra items, to explore the maps, to accomplish secondary missions, and so on. The bosses in this FF are diverse, you'll fight a giant gelatinoid, an old spirit, and some gods beyond time-space.I've not found any glitch in the game, not a single crash, however sometimes it's dificult to switch to another window (I played in windowed mode), ... but ...  somehow switch to the "task manager window" is "mandatory" for the operating system. So, no problem at all.*** This game is not optimized for PC, if you have a low end PC it is certain that you will not enjoy this game. I have played in an AMD A8-Radeon R5 machine 15 fps (average).The game don't have graphics options to disable, the game always run at full antialias, shadows, illumination fx, etc. However, you can adjust some options in your Driver Settings... you will gain 5fps or so...Personally, I've enjoyed this game a lot .. so ..

A worthy successor to XIII. XIII-2 boasts improved gameplay mechanics with the introduction of monster taming and quick-time events (called 'live triggers'). XIII-2 also has a more open-ended plot, allowing the player to choose where they will go next and what they will do. XIII-2 has multiple endings and a great deal of post-game content such as an arena, a casino and the ability to replay entire chapters.The only problem with this PC port is that it crashes unless its graphics settings are tweaked just right. I was forced to tweak the game in these ways so that it wouldn't crash all the time:- Run the game with the lowest "Shadows" resolution in rainy areas.- As an AMD graphics card user, I had to run this game in the lowest window resolution possible.- I had to disable Steam Cloud save- I had to turn of Skype and all other background processesCheck Google or the Steam forums if this game keeps crashing. On the plus side of this problem, I ran the game using the 16x anisotropic filter with no issues. It's a super pretty game!

Bought this back on the PS3 when it first came out but couldn't get into it. Tried it again a few years later, pushed past the slightly dull opening few hours and now can't put it down. Sure, it still has that slght repetitiveness that FFXIII had, but this time the world at least feels more open and not so much a 'walk down this corridor and fight lots of enemies ad infinitum' feel that its predecessor had.I know there are meant to be issues with the port, and my FPS fluctuates wildly between 20-60 all the time, but I can't say I've actually noticed any difference when it does (i.e. lagging or screen-tearing), so can't comment on the actual issues themselves.All in all, this is a more interesting game than FFXIII (minus some of its most interesting characters in Lightning and Fang, for me) and I'm looking forward to completing it so I can finally play 'Lightning Returns'. Even if you got bored of XIII, I'd recommend giving this a go, especially for the sale price.

I outgrew liking JRPGs years ago now; they're too tedious and filled with too much nonsense...and yet I keep subjecting myself to them out of some oddly stubborn nostalgia and a kind of academic curiosity.While I didn't particularly like how FFXIII (the original) played and found the story filled with far too much gobbledygook to be compelling, I at least found things to like in some of the characters and the spectacle of it all (impressive cutscenes, settings, etc).FFXIII-2 is a game that I think fans of the genre would identify as better playing due to the more immediate access to its various systems.  However, it's still an absolute grind fest if you want to exploit the upper limit of what the game has to offer (extra hard optional bosses and such) - and if you don't, then the game is still more or less on autopilot just like FFXIII.As the gameplay doesn't appeal to me, what I've got left is the characters, story, and aesthetics - all of which I found lacking.  Noel and Sarah are little bland; the villain is much better, but they're all entangled in a story built of such nonsense that it's hard to empathize with any of them.  The settings and presentation don't compare to a proper full FF game either.On top of all that, there are few rather despicable elements to this game that seem to actively hate its players.  In particular, there's a casino in the game which has a slot machine - with odds of winning that seem barely better than real life.  Getting the game's bonus "true" ending is reliant (in part) on winning a big payout from this slot machine - something which is entirely random and no in any way influenced by player skill.  This is completely ridiculous.  It's the worst kind of creatively bankrupt time sink and completely disrespectful to players.  Even if I don't care about the bonus ending because I'll just watch a video of it, the mere presence of something as insulting as completion being tied to a random number generator casts a shadow over the whole game.  Finally, as noted by many other reviews, the performance is unacceptable to the extent that it does impact enjoyment of the game.  The game is internally locked to running either 30fps or 60fps because the gameplay engine is tightly coupled to the renderer and they hacked in 60fps support simply by halving the gameplay simulation speed and then only allowing the game to run at these two framerates instead of more sensibly decoupling the renderer from gameplay simulation.That still wouldn't be too be to bad if the game could maintain 60fps all the time, but even on hardware that should be more than sufficient to run the game at a solid 60fps (4790K and GTX 970), it will constantly jump between 30fps and 60fps depending how much is on screen.  The frequent changes in framerate are jarring and arguably worse than if the game was simply locked to 30fps.I'm going to suffer through it and see it to the end because I'm stubborn and compulsive about finishing games I start, but it's going to be a struggle for sure.

While I personally felt largely positive towards Final Fantasy XIII, this installment in the XIII series has left me feeling mostly frustrated and disappointed. Lightning was the focal point and poster girl of XIII but this time around you instead play as her sister Serah. Normally I’d have no problem with the idea of a spin off focusing on a different character however Serah was probably one of the least interesting characters in the original game and I was never really thinking “Hey, I sure would like to play as her”. Unfortunately the supporting cast is pretty lacking and the second member of your party “Noel” is nothing to write home about either. This also leads me to my next problem with XIII-2 which is that you only have two members in your party (the third slot being allocated to a monster of your choice). The plot is one of the most convoluted and dull time travel stories I’ve yet to see in a long while and at no point did this installment really ever feel warranted to me. The gameplay and progression is changed up a bit this time. The much criticized linearity of XIII has been somewhat remedied by adding branching levels which gives the player more options as to how they’d like to progress. The levels mostly feel pretty empty and dull with some nice scenery here or there. Lifeless npc’s inhabit most of them providing lackluster side quests to keep you from progressing too quickly. My biggest grievance however is that this port does not feel like it was given very much love or care. Your mileage may vary but even after installing an unofficial patch I suffered a lot of frame drops and low fps in the open world segments (however menus and battles mostly remained smooth). This doesn’t seem excusable when my PC is capable of running games like GTAV and The Witcher 3 on reasonably high settings at consistent frame rates. I was fortunately able to tough it out through most of the slower segments of the game. I should probably mention what I actually did like about the game. You get a lot of the same quality scenery and pretty cutscenes that you should be familiar with from XIII. It’s got the same easy and action based combat that I enjoyed from the last installment. The music is varied from the usual pretty tunes you expect from Final Fantasy to some perplexingly strange songs (Wild Chocobo theme, anyone?). The game doesn’t seem to always take itself too seriously which is fine by me. Be ready for some goofy anime nonsense. I could only really recommend this game on very particular circumstance. While this review is mostly negative I did however enjoy a good portion of my time with it and for the price I felt satisfied. It’s a pretty bad port and I’d imagine most wouldn’t have the patience to complete the game because of this. If the performance was improved I’d easily recommend it on the basis of an impulse buy during a sale however you may just be better off skipping this installment. There’s a lot of better Final Fantasy games on Steam.

**Warning: Contains minor spoilers**Final Fantasy XIII-2 is one of those games where you spend hours doing stuff, but you usually don't really know what you're doing, or why you're doing it. Later, you find out, and the game gets more interesting.This game has some differences from the first part of trilogy, and it's got a nice pace. However, playing FF13-2 felt like I was playing a game that is completely unrelated to FF13.I can't put my finger on it, but something was bothering throughout the game. Don't get me wrong - I liked it, I liked it a lot. It's different than many FF titles in more than one way, but at the same time - it felt as if it's not really a Final Fantasy game. More like a game that borrows characters and some things from Final Fantasy, but is an individual game.The plot is weird, we all know that. Everything is in some kind of time-chaos, which leaves us to fix everything through lots of action, FMV sequences and dialogues. That's what we love about Final Fantasy, right? I liked the plot and the character progression. What I hated was the fact that I had very little chance to play with FF13 characters, since everything was revolving around the newcomer and Light's sister. Another thing I didn't like about the game was the limited focus on Alyssa's character, so her development seems a bit forced.The Battle system is very similar to FF13's, so everyhing is great until you come to the "Cinematic Action" parts of the game. It's frustrating and annoying, and should've stayed a feature in one of those old Spider-Man games. It has no place in a Final Fantasy title IMHO. Action is cool, and the battle-animations are great. Again, I would love to have seen more of the original FF13 cast, but Noel and Serah did a fine job too.Now that Lightning Returns has come to steam too, I will finally be able to finish this trilogy, and this makes me very happy. Playing through Final Fantasy XIII-2 left me with mixed feelings. Final Fantasy 13 is a game that I will surely play again some day, but I'm not sure I want to play 13-2 ever again. I'll be honest and say that I finished this game just for the story, and was not too interested in many of the side-quests (although I did some).Final Fantasy XIII-2 is a nice filler between FF13 and Lightning Returns, but playing this game I couldn't get rid of the "sequel syndrome". It's good, but not as good as FF13. I recommend the game to any Final Fantasy fan, and I think that players who are new to FF will like it as well.Don't play it if you love Counter Strike, Black Ops and Fallout. It's not that type of game, and you probably won't like it at all.My score: 8.2/10

I much preferred FFXIII to the sequel: many moaned that the original was far too linear, which is true, but it had a guiding plot and complex characters with interesting interactions. The sequel suffers from Time Gates (you don't know where/when you're going... means you can have no reason to 'GO' somewhere, you only ever get reasons to 'LEAVE') and only having 2 main characters plus a gimmicky Mog.Quick rundown of the characters:Serah: gets no character development from her supporting role in FFXIIINoel: cross between a cliche of a heartbroken teenager and a cliche of a boy with a fallen hero; neither is developed well. He's protecting Serah because he lost someone and wants to fight Caius because of anger... that's basically everything you get.Mog: "oh isn't he cute..." there, desired reaction achieved. Lightning: watch the trailer on the store page, look at the screenshots... that's about 50% of her presence in the entire game. I'd call her role a cameo but then I'd have nothing to say about Snow, Sazh, Vanille, Fang or the Nora gang...Hope: hey look, one of the original main characters made it intot he game in a meaningful way... too bad they took the most irritating of the characters and took him from an angry/lost kid to the ultimate boy genious. I'm assuming I wasn't the only one to miss the groundwork to suggest he wasn't just average intelligence... probably because it isn't there. He doesn't even get any noticeable character development: assume he's just a cliche child genious and you won't go far wrong.In fact Hope's role in this game is simply a lazy plot device... same goes for almost every solution to every part of every section of the game: do random things and the answer to your problem drops straight in your path. If they'd called this "FFXIII-Deus Ex Machina" I could have understood that, but as it is I just found it robbed any sort of unifying force to the story.

Some have complained about in-game lag, and yes, it lags a good amount when too much is happening (especiialy ruinga spell), however for any FF fans this is no where enough of a reason to play this game. They have managed to create a sequel with a completely new feel to it. Though it is technicaly in the same world as FFXIII everything feels different, in a nice and refreshing way. The combat system is similar, though seeing how we had the same combat system for over 9 main FF titles, and this one is only shared with FFXIII, we cant complain at all. "XIII-2" just barely crosses my "Recommend" threshold.It is, indeed, a "Final Fantasy" game. It has the requisite production values, large scope, interesting battle system, monster variety, and pretty much everything else you'd expect. Square Enix did well in taking a very different direction than the game's predecessor. The ultra-restricted linearity is gone, replaced with far more explorable environments - and, at a macro level, the ability to time hop. It doesn't get much more nonlinear than that.But the overall result is disappointing.When it all comes down to it, one of the central game mechanics becomes "find and do as much as you can." This kind of approach can be entirely functional and fun. It works wonderfully for the "Mass Effects," "Elder Scrolls," and "Fallouts" of the world. The problem is that "XIII-2" chooses to go the route of the 3D pixel hunt. That is, hints and direction are quite sparse, when they're around at all, and certain things (especially the Archylte Steppe) come down to a process of walking around every inch of an area you've already seen, hoping to run across something new. Which character offers quests? Who knows! What actually has an effect on this part of the gameworld? Who knows!The mixture is both boring AND frustrating, which is not a recipe for a happy player.Now, this kind of thing has been found in the "Final Fantasy" series before. It's just that it's very, very optional. Completing the game is usually about the core mechanics of character development and party management, with some very powerful goodies thrown in for the person who pokes their nose into everything. In "XIII-2," poking your nose into everything is much more central to finishing the storyline - and that can make it rather maddening. The game suffers from a case of "Guide Dang It" (where you would never logically figure out an element from gameplay alone) more than any other "Final Fantasy" I've played."XIII-2," like its predecessor, also has a case of a suddenly steep difficulty curve. You'll find a combat groove, and it will work all the way to the end of the game...and then the final battle occurs, and...looks like we need to go hunting around for more things in places we never thought to look! Let's try talking to everybody again. Again! While getting attacked by monsters the whole way! Again! Some more!Sigh.And then, you finally get to the ending, and it lacks any real payoff at all. (I can't say too much without spoiling things, but my reaction pretty much sums up as, "They can't actually be serious about this, can they?")As a final note, I have to say that I just dislike the whole "time travel and alternate universes" thing. It really worked for "Dr. Who," but I find it thoroughly stale and disinteresting when used anywhere else. It seems to always turn into a case of "we just want to throw a bunch of random stuff together, and so we'll explain it with TIME GATES!" The game doesn't quite go that far - it is decently written - but my not being a fan of the central premise as a storytelling strategy doesn't make me want to award points to the title.In summary, "XIII-2 " really does improve on "XIII" in certain areas, but it's still more obtuse than it ought to be. Also, it REALLY hits some sour notes with how it wraps itself up. It was good enough to play through, but if "Final Fantasy" were a band, this would be one of the weakest albums in the catalog.

Overall Review: 8.5Graphics: 9Sound: 8Story: 8Fun: 9Difficulty: 9.5Controls: 8Here is my review and opinions on this game. Overall I really enjoyed playing this game, and am still building up the monster's for fun! If you like RPG's you will probably like this game. It might help to know the previous story in 13 but honestly I had to re read most of it again since it's so complicated at times so really you can jump in at this game I think. You'll find the graphics are nice and the animations are good, its overall a very nice game to listen to and play but its not a very good FF game. Meaning that because its has FF in the front of its title its supposed to blow the doors off of the ride. Its just not that good. So if you like rpg's you'll find the game to be a mix of chrono trigger with time travel and tomb raider with exploration and finding VERY hard to find fragements that are shaded dark and transparent so have fun with that without a guide!The rest of the difficulty is just navigating the huge world where i feel it can slow the pacing. Old final fantasy games would frustrate me with the amount of battles and lack of story progress where as here the sheer size of the worlds to travel can take up time. there are chocobo's to speed things up but still... some maps are needlessly big. A common square enix complaint of mine. To much world not much interaction.The music is good but for its ups it has downs, i wouldn't play the ost front to back but playlist about half of it. Nice though overall.The battle system is where its at. This time you have only two character's,  aa bold rpg move, but you have a rotating monster to fill the third spot, this is fun but they are usually kinda weak untill late game so its helpful but sort of lacking as a real team member.The story is cool but why is time travel just now making an appearance in FF13 series? I don't think this is really all bad but it makes the world seem contrived and its just an odd feeling of the series being not a very well defined and formed rpg.They just make these ff games ont the fly these days without much real originality. Its a very manufactured rpg for your enjoyment but that's like a person who tries hard to be your friend and makes thier life choices around you. I would rather know they had a personality that was original and that I liked them... anyways i respect that they made improvements based on what we didn't like in 13... but why did they need to? Shouldn't they just make a good FF game that we are used to? Since 10 (the last true FF in many's opinion) its been all over the place and honestly just play this game as an RPG and put up with the Final Fantasy in the title as just a title not the gameplay hint.Sad but true, its still a good RPG and i reccoment it. Its very fun but very hard and the story is different but interesting albeit with very few actual characters. Most places have people in the towns but its not like they really are that interesting in my opinion. I feel like this is a very KOTOR Final Fantasy actually but that could just be me.If you like RPG's and action turn based combat get this one, its fun overall! If you like FF6 religiously try to take it in stride!

First thing first: I would highly advise not playing this if you havent completed XIII already as while XIII is a game with serious flaws, the story of it will directly be spoiled in like the first half hour of this game.On the whole, I enjoyed the game. There are some underlying flaws but it left me with a positive experience playing through to the end. The plot is very hard to follow, in that sometimes it just doesn't make sense. It's a time travel plot but where usually with this type of plot, you change the past and the future changes, here everything changes including the past, as well as having a location and character in the opening sequence that falls out of 'time' and you arent really sure whats going on. The good? It look's pretty, even if things don't make sense .The battle system is probably the best disguise for a bad system I've seen in a long while. 'Auto Battle' command is back, which lets the CPU choose the best actions round by round. Personally I like to issue commands manually, only the thing is, to do so will put you at a huge disadvantage - manually issuing commands takes a couple seconds more while enemies still attack and prepare moves, and the commands are very generic (Attack, Magic attack, and four elements) for the most part. There are some battles with 6 enemies where I couldn't even tell what was going on, I found most battles I was glued to the HUD without looking at the graphics etc.You control one character while the AI controls the other, as well as a tamed monster you can have. I disliked this system too - it had potential but did a bad job of explaining what monster stats were, what benefit using monster A over monster B was, or even the fact it doesnt flag 'rare' monsters you encounter in the field up so you can easily pass them by.Character progression felt flat. You can level according to what you prefer, class wise, but by the end of the game you realise that in the end you will end up the same as every other player. As well, the points you put into the system to level up, dont seem to actually 'do' much. Partially realted to being glued to the HUD, you don't notice your characters scoring that massive crit thanks to their new stats/gear, because well, the numbers arent that impressive. Additionally the game seems to reward grinding and raw stats over strategy leaving many battles feeling unrewarding.The game is not linear, one of the main complaints many had with XIII. Did they take it a bit too far here? Maybe. I would say no, overall, however the tools you use to unlock extra stages or unlock special skills, or heck to even advance, were very difficult to locate in levels without the assistance of a guide. I didn't have too much issue finding my way to the end of the game, but then going back and trying to unlock extra stages or locate and capture decent monsters is impossible to acheive in any sort of decent time without a guide.Performance wise, it is a bad port, but with a few tweaks it is bearable, even fine if you have a good specced PC (I run it on an i7, GTX 770, and aside from a few frame rate drops it has been fine after tweaking using nvidia's own graphics settings.) There are no meaningful graphics settings in the games menu, so first thing you will want/need to do is google up some reccomended settings and then change these directly in your GFX cards manufacturers tool.Expect to get around 30 hours from the main story, and exploring side branches of the story reasonably well. Post game, FF fans may expect an uber boss, there are a few in this however as mentioned before, to even set about finding them, or preparing for them, you need a guide. If I'm using a guide to do everything I don't see the point in doing it, so I will likely complete some of the DLC and retire from the game. Overall the 30 hours have been enjoyable and I felt I have definately got my moneys worth,

I had high hopes for this game and I did have fun but when carying the FF name you get held to a higher standard. Here are my pros and cons.Pros:Fun high paced style very different from previous FF games.Great animations and environments.Lots of freedom to explore and extra challenges to face.Good voice acting and excelent music.Cons:QTE finishers on boss monsters. I hate QTE sequences I'm sure some people love them just not for me.No limit breaks. Your monsters get limit breaks which can be mildly powerful but your characters don't get them they get these ♥♥♥♥♥♥ super spells that can only be used once a fight and do only slightly more damage than normal moves.Auto attacking is more effective than trying to cue up abilities manually. The fighting is too fast to navigate the menus and select the ideal combos (especially if you are hasted in a boss fight) and auto select does a decent job so why even bother?Only having two people is novel but I didn't like it. Requires grinding areas for rare monster crystals which could take tens of hours if you're unlucky.Story is hard to follow even for a time travel game.Limited customization in character leveling. (again only two characters and they can be maxed out pretty quick)No crafting or ultimate weapons.Capacity limit or status ailments makes good gear worse (better to stack delicate low level items for synergy bonus).Repetitive zones. It's cool you can go to the same place at different ages but it's the exact same map you play though 3 sometimes 4 times.No new monsters or bosses. Same exact monsters and abilities and differet time periods have the same mobs just a different color pallet.No fun mini games. The casino is dull the poker can only be played after the game is beaten and even then the opponents are predictable and no fun to play against. Slot machines are worthless.Ending sucks. No spoilers just know that the ending along with pretty much all the Pardox Endings are sh*tty.Final verdict.It was fun and I did throw a bunch of hours into the game collecting almost all the fragments and getting the various endings but the poor story, poor character development, and lame ending are all major turn offs. Get it if you are a major FF fan (though you would probably already have played it by now) or it's on a significant sale.

This game is a pretty good sequel to FF13 and is a pretty solid FF game overall with a couple caveats.The story itself is pretty solid, albeit not quite as memorable as that of FF13. Overall, I'd probably rate it like a 7 or 8 or so for story. The story feels like it can stand on its own for the most part, but a lot of stuff builds off of FF13 so it probably would be extremely confusing for a lot of the character's backstories/motivations/etc. if you haven't played FF13.The gameplay itself feels really solid. The combat feels a bit more refined than FF13 with the pet/monster system and the combat job system is a bit smoother and more streamlined than that of FF13. Your characters can fill pretty much any role you want without being gimped or it being impossible to upgrade them past a certain point for a given job, unlike in FF13. The way battles are initiated or avoided is also pretty cool and makes it a lot easier to avoid annoying enemies and a lot easier to plan against harder enemies. It feels like they took most of FF13's flaws and fixed them without making it boring.The game feels a bit too reliant on strategy guides for side quests though. FF13 was usually pretty easy to figure out or would at least have some clues as to what to do, but a good number of the side quests in FF13-2 feel like they need a strategy guide or just plain luck to find. I eventually reached the point I didn't care at all about the side quests after beating the main story. The main story is pretty easy to complete without referencing anything though.

Remember that like any modern Final Fantasy game, you may just hate it at first glance and I respect that decision.TL;DR below.Story-  This story is full of plot-holes and makes no sense.  Final Fantasy XIII's story is a Godsend in comparison to this.  Imagine Final Fantasy XIII's story but with time travel that goes against all of the modern time travel conventions.  It is really only there to get the characters together for a new adventure.  You should not be playing this game for the story.Exploration-  While still somewhat linear, there are hidden chests placed throughout the world that you can find.  You are also able to accept quests in the field.  Completion of these quests will cut down on grind time because they give you EXP (Crystarium Points).  You can travel between the different areas of the game in the Historia Crux, a menu showing all of the points of time you can travel to.  This menu allows you to reset areas, battling bosses again and gathering treasures you might have missed.  Enemies show up at random on the field, but you are given a short period of time to run away from them or get an early attack on them.Combat-  In combat, you have a bar that is split into several segments that fills over time.  Battle commands can be attached to the segments of the gauge.  You can choose to use the entirety of your gauge at once, or use moves as the bar fills up.  Serah and Noel can be assigned classes and switch between these classes in combat.  This is where the meat of the battle strategy comes from.  You are able to have a Pokemon-esque monster accompany you in battle.  This monster also has a class which will help balance out your team.  The way the class system works still goes over my head, but I think that combat is enjoyable nonetheless.Optimization- This game will run like garbage on YOUR PC.  I DON'T CARE IF YOU HAVE A TITAN X, THE GAME IS JUST BROKEN.  EXPECT 30 FPS AT ALL TIMES.TL;DR, like most modern Final Fantasy games you will endure it or you will hate it.  The story is meaningless, but the gameplay is enjoyable.5/10 mediocre, would bluescreen while playing again.

One of my favorite FFs so far, which was totally unexpected since the reviews seemed mixed and I didn't like XIII that much.Good:- Attention to detail with the plot, which makes a lot of efforts to appear coherent and is a lot more memorable than the one from XIII (). Of course, it's a time paradox based story so you'll find as many plot holes as you want to, but I'd say the writers watched a lot of Doctor Who and it looks decent enough to be enjoyed.- The main paradox in the story is just great, with a Doctor Who style resolution. Awesome.- Real choices with corresponding alternate endings which make sense. - The two main characters are annoying and mean good but don't really know what they are doing. Clever. Lightning on the other hand is the best character from the XIII series by far, and they found a nice way to keep her busy while making her look good.- Good combat system, slightly improved from XIII.- The way the side content is blended with the main story (you have to do side missions at some points in the story, explore timelines a bit randomly, etc).- Lots of side timelines and additional missions.- Lots of content.Bad:- Could use a few more locations and one or two major paradox plots in the main story.- Some important side content is gratuitously hard to find without guides (wild artefacts locations ...).- Too grindy to complete the endgame content.- Confusing character advancement (read guides).- The third character in the party are monsters which can be swapped. Nice, but again too grindy and impossible to use correctly without reading wikis and guides. Although they tried to find something original and it's a decent attempt, a regular character would have been better.- Graphics and textures are a big downgrade from XIII. Less budget (but far better game).- Some technical details.

Final Fantasy XIII-2 (FFXIII-2) adalah lanjutan cerita dari FFXIII. Bertema tentang time traveler, Serah bersama Noel berpetualang mengatasi paradox untuk menyelamatkan dunia & menemukan Lightning yang menghilang.Cerita (7/10)Lightning menghilang tepat setelah bertemu Serah, terjebak dalam dunia yang disebut Valhalla. Ingatan tentang Lightning terhapus & semua orang menganggap Lightning tersegel dalam Cocoon bersama Fang & Vanille. 3 tahun kemudian, Serah bertemu Noel dan menceritakan bahwa Lighting ada di Valhalla akibat paradox.Meskipun lanjutan FFXIII, cerita FFXIII-2 benar2 baru, villain baru dan masalah baru.  FFXIII-2 menggunakan konsep yang sebenarnya cukup menarik, time traveler, paradox & paralel universe. Permasalahan cerita di FFXIII-2 benar2 bisa dikatakan lepas dari FFXIII tentang Barthandelus & fal'cie lain.Berbeda dengan FFXIII yang endingnya sudah bisa dikatakan "selesai", ending FFXIII-2 benar2 cliffhanger yang membuat saya pribadi mengerutkan dahi sambil berkata dalam hati, "Kok gini?" dan tertawa.Sangat terlihat kalau Square Enix benar2 merencanakan FFXIII menjadi trilogy di sekuel kedua ini setelah mendapat banyak kritik pada FFXIII sebelumnya (yang sebenarnya sudah tamat ceritanya).Gameplay (7/10)Sistem battle FFXIII-2 nyaris sama dengan FFXIII, masih memakai konsep crystarium & CP, perbedaannya kini party yang ada cuma 2 karakter (Serah & Noel) ditambah monster yang telah dijinakkan & tidak ada lagi eidolon.Gameplay FFXIII-2 bisa dikatakan lebih bercabang. Tidak seperti FFXIII yang isinya cuma maju terus, kita bebas menentukan dungeon mana yang kita jelajahi dulu. Ada kota seperti layaknya FF sebelumnya, kita tidak lagi beli barang2  di save point tapi kini pada "mbak2 cosplayer". :DEnding FFXIII-2 juga bercabang, ending FFXIII-2 ada 10. 1 true ending, 8 paradox ending, & 1 secret ending.Grafis (7/10)Tak ada perbedaan yang cukup signifikan dari segi grafis karena pada dasarnya sama seperti FFXIII, FFXIII-2  ini tidak lebih dari sekedar port game PS3/XBox360.

Part 2 of the Final Fantasy XIII trilogy starts off fast and gets right into things. The story is nicely carried over from the first XIII title and is generally presented pretty well. We return to familiar faces, along with some new ones.The story starts off quite confusing and you are given tons of info pretty quickly. It may seem messy at first due to alot of unexplained events and the time travel aspect can mix things up a little further. However time travel in XIII-2 is mostly used as a way to get the game world to be opened up a bit and to move away from the linear direction that was FFXIII, from this point of view its done well and doesnt really pose any issues. As the story goes on it gets really intense, i found myself at the edge of my seat a few times.The graphics for the most part seem to be slightly improved over the first game and are really enjoyable. The battle system is fantastic. Its simular to XIII with a bit of a twist with things like the mog clock, allowing you to start off a battle with haste if timed well. There is also the addition of pets and they act as the third member in your party. The Crystarium System is more streamlined and works really well.The performance for some reason isnt as good as XIII and i find myself getting very varied frame rates, this should not happen on a 4000 dollar PC that was purchased in 2015. Overall its not too much of a problem, however it certainly doesnt go unnoticed and its worth mentioning. Hopefully they improve on this for Lightning Returns.Boss fights feel very rewarding and fun. Encounter mechanics are fresh and interesting, this game has one of the most memorable final boss fights ive experienced in ages. There is a fair amount of grinding needed to be done to down the final boss but nothing too crazy, the progression feels right, they really nailed it here. There is a great addition of skins in XIII-2 that are taken to the next level in Lightning Returns, something that i rate very highly as i love customization in any game.There is a lack of CG cutscenes in XIII-2 i would have liked a little more than the 2 or 3 they did for the game.Overall i found FFXIII-2 to be a fantastic sequel that is a must play for anyone that enjoyed Final Fantasy XIII, you get the chance to delve further into Lightning and Serah's story, I cant wait to jump into Lightning Returns, this might be one of the best game trilogies ive played, infact this game was the reason i will continue to invest my time and money into the franchise and purchase a PS4 to contine the legacy that is Final Fantasy.Would thank Square Enix again and again and again for porting this to PC.9/10

I've always been a big fan of Final Fantasy games, even their most recent games. I've purchased VII, VIII, and XIII on Steam. the XIII games have had problems being ported so far, but the problems for XIII have been addressed for the most part, and it runs excellently! XIII-2 on the other hand, runs like a dead raccoon. There appear to be some CPU performance issues due to the game being a port from the PS3 version, with the abnormal CPU they put in that console. The game runs fine out in the world, the minimap instantly reduces fps from 60 to 30, disabling it boosts back to 60 right away. Upon opening the menu to equip items, change Paradigms, etc, the fps drops to a solid 20. I know that fps don't seem too important but with the amount of monsters to scroll through the low fps becomes a pain. Getting to the worst thing, in battle, I don't see fps higher than 15. Upon entering the battle, I have a solid 60 fps, but as soon as the battle menu HUD comes up, it drops and sits at 15, not going lower or higher than that. FFXIII menu also has an effect on fps, but not one this great. At 15fps most battles are not enjoyable, sounds seem lagged at that point and effects take a while to finish, I have attempted multiple fixes but have been unable to correct this problem. According to their specs, I should be able to run this game no problem, but that isn't the case.Don't get me wrong, I love Final Fantasy games, no matter how different each installation may be, but this port in its current state is not worth your money. Save the 20$ until they either fix it, or you buy a thousand dollar intel processor to run it. Here's hoping they correct this problem so I can finish the game myself!My specs:AMD FX-8370NVIDIA GTX 98016GB memory G-SKILL 1600Gigabyte 99XA-UD310,000RPM velociraptor HDD

I've completed most of the main Final Fantasy titles: III, IV, V, VI, VII, VIII, IX, X, X-2, XII, XIII and now I'm playing this.Ok, there are my FF player credits. Now I am going to "rant" more about this game in-detail. STORY/ART STYLEI wasn't a big fan of the thirteenth instalment in the series. That said, in retrospective, I think I actually like it story-wise more than XIII-2. Why? Because of the time travel element! The wisdom I once heard: "Usually, when a time travel plot element is involved, it tells that the story writers were desperate." That seems to be the case in some parts of the story. While the story seems much clearer so far in the game, initially, when you first start, the concept of time traveling seems to do nothing but confuse with all the feeling-based concusions about the future and the past. You are given a simple goal: get from point A to point B, and the "road" to there is all tangled up. Sort of.Remember FFX-2? It was supposed (?) to be a direct sequel, sure. However, it was a whole different game! There's sort of a stigma associated with direct sequels to Final Fantasy games and it sure made my expectations lower for this "direct sequel", too. The plot? with all the "kupo! look-at-me-i'm-so-cute" and some painfully slow and outright boring parts aside, I have so far enjoyed the idea of finding Lightning and untangling the tangles. I think I will finish the game (once). I'm not very fond of the violin-piano-la-la-la-remember-my heart-la-la-female vocalist faintly singing type of a thing, as it seems very "girly" or overly romanticized and overused in the universe of FFXIII. I do, however, like few of the battle themes and how the track intensifies when monsters appear on the field.The characters? We see three kind of character behaviour in this game:1) Characters state the obvious. and do it again.2) Characters don't know a thing3) Characters (Serah infamously so) become quantum scientists; they pull wild, speculated theories out of the thin air that turn out to be truth.Usually in the following pattern:  1 - 1 - 1 - 1 - 2 - 3 - 2 - 3 -1 - 1 -1 -1GAMEPLAYWithout a doubt, combat and leveling up are my salt and butter in this game. Just like in FFXIII, I find it satisfactory to level up the crystarium and watching the stats go higher. I like the paradigm system as it makes it possible to "stagger" the otherwise ridiculously strong opponents and beat them up with the right set of paradigms.I am not entirely satisfied with few things:Mog throwing? ugh. A nice idea, but the implementation is not quite there.Mog clock? In few places of the game, the enemies "chase" you and the mog clock turns red. The problem here is, the enemies are no where to be seen! This means, you are forced into combat with no retry option. How convenient. The gameplay really drags the story in some parts. Some dungeon hallways are so narrow that you are practically forced to fight battles every few meters. The same things with fast and aggressive enemies in some dungeons. Luckily, the dungeons seem short, which seems to balance this out a little.Performance issues: the game seems to lag here and there and the gameplay seems capped at 30fps for the most of it. I am running the game on a decent "gaming" rig:i5 3570k @ 4ghzgtx 970 4gb12 gb ddr3 ramThe performance definitely could be better. At 1080P 8x AA, The graphics card barely gets a challenge. Seems like this game is more CPU intensive.And by no means my cpu is a slouch.Long story short: I'm glad I bought it on sale! I SAY DO IT!+ If you're a final fantasy fan (not hardcore level) like me and out of curiosity want to play through the game at least once+ you liked FFXIII+ If you are a hardcore ff fanI SAY NO WAY IN H***- If you are new to the series- if you haven't completed FFXIII prior to playing this7/10 story so far8.5/10 battle system

A great sequel to FFXIII, that improves and expands on FFXIII in some terrific ways. Pros:• Better Plot: I found the story in FFXIII-2 to be easier to follow than FFXIII's plot. • Less Serious Tone: More lighthearted moments throughout the story. Moogle had quite a few funny moments.  • Less Linear: There are multiple pathways in most levels with hidden loot. • Less Grinding: The harder encounters are usually optional, so you don’t need to grind as much. • More Freedom: Can choose where you want to travel to and what content you want to do. • Dialogue Choices: A great addition, that was nonexistent in FFXIII. • Great QTE Events: I usually hate QTEs but FFXIII-2 does a good job of making the QTEs feel appropriate, without overdoing it. • Interesting DLC: Lightning and Sazh’s side stories were particularly engaging to play through. Cons:	• Dull Side Quests: Quest design is not that interesting, and usually involves a lot of backtracking. • Limited Characters: There are only 2 characters and 1 monster in your party. This is definitely a step back from FFXIII’s cast of 6 characters.
